* The layered organic material AI3 has been studied since the 1980s and has recently attracted renewed interest due to its low-energy massless Dirac fermions under hydrostatic pressure.

column2: * The material has a unique set of properties, including a tilt of the Dirac cones and anisotropy in the Fermi surface.

column1: * AI3 has a lower Fermi velocity than graphene, which indicates the relevance of electronic correlations.

column2: * The effective coupling constant for Coulomb-type electron-electron interactions is expected to be ten times larger in AI3 than in graphene.

column1: * The material has additional massive carriers in the vicinity of the Fermi level, as recently pointed out in ab-initio band-structure calculations.

column2: * The interplay between massless Dirac fermions and massive carriers has not yet been proven experimentally.

column1: * The researchers present magneto-transport measurements of AI3 crystals under hydrostatic pressure, showing the existence of high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes.

column2: * The interplay between both carrier types at low energy is the main result of the study.

column1: * The measured mobilities for the two carrier types hint at scattering mechanisms due to strongly screened interaction potentials or other short-range scatterers.

column2: * The analysis of the experimental results is based on the study of the magneto-conductivity and is similar to the one presented in ref. for multi-carrier semiconductor systems.

column1: * The researchers extract the mobilities, zero-field conductivities, and carrier densities of each carrier type from the magneto-conductivity curves.

column2: * The strong temperature dependence of the carrier density is a signature that temperature is higher than the Fermi temperature for both carrier types.

column1: * The carrier density can be calculated from the Fermi-Dirac distribution and the density of states for massive and Dirac carriers.

column2: * The results are consistent with ab-initio calculations of the band structure of AI3 under pressure.

column1: * The researchers perform thermopower measurements under pressure on a second sample, showing a sign change for the Seebeck coefficient around 5K.

column2: * The sign change indicates that the relevant carriers at low temperature have a different charge than those at high temperature, requiring a two-carrier scenario.

column1: * The results support the idea that massless and massive particles coexist in a broad pressure range.

column2: * The absence of a third 'plateau' in the magneto-conductivity data allows the researchers to consider that Dirac electrons and holes have roughly the same mobilities.",0

column1: 114,"Here is the summary of the text in 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
• Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) is a method of secure communication that uses quantum mechanics to encode and decode messages.

column2: • QKD is considered unconditionally secure, meaning that it is theoretically impossible to intercept the message without being detected.

column1: • QKD systems are typically based on the BB84 protocol, which uses four non-orthogonal quantum states to encode the message.

column2: • The security of QKD relies on the no-cloning theorem, which states that it is impossible to create a perfect copy of an arbitrary quantum state.

column1: • In practice, QKD systems are vulnerable to side-channel attacks, which can compromise their security.

column2: • Side-channel attacks exploit weaknesses in the implementation of the QKD system, rather than the underlying quantum mechanics.

column1: • Measurement-Device-Independent QKD (MDI-QKD) is a variant of QKD that eliminates the need for trusted measurement devices.

column2: • MDI-QKD uses a third party, called the measurement unit, to perform the measurement on the quantum states.

column1: • MDI-QKD is more secure than traditional QKD because it eliminates the possibility of side-channel attacks on the measurement device.

column2: • MDI-QKD is also more practical than traditional QKD because it does not require the users to trust the measurement device.

column1: • The security of MDI-QKD relies on the assumption that the measurement unit is honest and does not collude with an eavesdropper.

column2: • If the measurement unit is compromised, the security of the system is compromised.

column1: • The authors propose two new MDI-QKD protocols that use phase encoding instead of polarization encoding.

column2: • The new protocols are more practical than previous MDI-QKD protocols because they do not require the users to share a reference frame for the polarization mode.

column1: • The authors also provide a security proof for the new protocols, which shows that they are secure against any attack allowed by quantum mechanics.

column1: 118,"Here is the summary of the text in 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The first evidence of time reversal symmetry violation was found in the kaon system, but no other signal has been found to date.

column2: * Despite this, studying time reversal symmetry has become a cornerstone of the search for physics beyond the Standard Model.

column1: * Some alternatives or extensions of the Standard Model, such as dynamical symmetry breaking, multi-Higgs models, and supersymmetric theories, imply specific ways of time reversal symmetry violation.

column2: * These theories are formulated in terms of quarks and leptons, whereas nuclear low-energy tests of time reversal symmetry involve hadronic degrees of freedom.

column1: * To extract hadronic degrees of freedom from observables, effective one-nucleon nucleon potentials or mesonic exchange potentials can be introduced.

column2: * These potentials have been proven useful in treating the nuclear structure part involved and extracting effective hadronic coupling constants.

column1: * The purpose of the paper is to give estimates on hadronic matrix elements that arise when relating quark operators to effective hadronic parameterizations of the time reversal symmetry violating interaction.

column2: * The authors focus on the charged vector type exchange and axial vector type exchange nucleon-nucleon interaction.

column1: * The authors use the constituent quark model to relate quark operators to effective hadronic operators and evaluate the matrix elements of the quark operators.

column2: * The resulting relation between quark and hadronic time reversal symmetry violating coupling strengths is given for both types of exchange.

column1: * The authors conclude that the factors arising from the quark structure reflect the nucleon structure effects, which are due to the spin, isospin structure, and different mass scales.

column2: * The origin of the structure factors is essential in deriving the relative strength of the strong coupling constants.

119,"<summary>
• Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are used as standard candles to measure distances to remote galaxies due to their uniform light curves and high brightness.

column2: • They are thought to result from the explosion of a white dwarf in a binary system that has accreted material from a companion star until it reaches the Chandrasekhar mass limit.
• The accreting white dwarf model predicts two main evolutionary paths leading to SNe Ia: the super soft X-ray source (SSS) channel and the symbiotic channel.
• The companion star is expected to remain in the vicinity of the explosion site, but its identification has not been confirmed by observations.

column1: • A direct method to identify the companion star is proposed, which involves observing the absorption lines in the spectrum of a star located inside the ejecta of a SN Ia.

column2: • The absorption lines are expected to have a broad wing on the blue side due to the absorption of photons by the ejecta moving towards us.
• The method is applied to the Tycho Brahe supernova remnant, and the expected absorption feature is calculated.
• The identification of the companion star would provide strong evidence for the accreting white dwarf model of SNe Ia.",0

column1: 120,"<summary>
• Quantum Entanglement in a Cascaded Qubit System

column2: • The system consists of two high-finesse optical cavities, each containing a single atom, with unidirectional coupling from cavity 1 to cavity 2.
• The atoms are assumed to have five relevant electronic levels, representing an effective two-state system or qubit.

• The system is open, with the output from cavity 2 recorded by a detector, and the inter-cavity coupling is imperfect, with a fraction of the output photon flux from cavity 1 lost to the environment.

column1: • Quantum Trajectory Theory

column2: • The system is described by a pure state conditioned on the counting histories of the detectors.
• The evolution of the system is described by a non-hermitian effective Hamiltonian, interrupted by quantum jumps.
• The jumps occur with probability proportional to the norm of the state, and the system state is renormalized after each jump.

column1: • Entanglement Dynamics

column2: • The system exhibits a bimodal behavior, with the possibility of an entangled-state cycle.
• The cycle involves the system switching between two orthogonal bell states while emitting a continual stream of photons.
• The entangled-state cycle is a result of the competition between the periods of evolution between quantum jumps and the jumps themselves.

column1: • Imperfect Intercavity Coupling

column2: • The system settles into one of two distinct cycles, involving either the symmetric or antisymmetric bell states.
• The decision of which cycle to settle into is random, depending on the number of photon counts at detector 1.
• The ensemble average state of the system is mixed, described by a density operator.</summary>",1

column1: 122,"<summary>
• The paper discusses the security of Continuous Variable Quantum Key Distribution (CVQKD) systems, which are vulnerable to attacks on the local oscillator (LO) intensity.

column2: • The LO intensity fluctuation can compromise the secret key rate if Bob does not scale his measurements with the instantaneous LO intensity values.

column1: • The traditional security analysis of CVQKD assumes a constant LO intensity, but in practice, the LO intensity can fluctuate, allowing Eve to launch a LO intensity attack (LOIA).

column2: • Eve can reduce the LO intensity to hide her attack and steal the secret key without being detected.

column1: • The paper analyzes the effect of LO intensity fluctuation on the secret key rate estimation for reverse and direct reconciliation protocols.

column2: • The results show that even a small fluctuation of LO intensity can compromise the secret key rate severely if Bob does not monitor the LO intensity.

column1: • The paper proposes a method to monitor the LO intensity and scale the measurements with the instantaneous intensity values to ensure the security of the CVQKD system.

column2: • This method can prevent Eve from launching a successful LOIA and ensure the secrecy of the key distribution.

column1: • The paper also discusses the challenges of accurately monitoring the LO intensity, especially in long-distance communication.

column2: • The imperfections of the balanced homodyne detector (BHD) can make the LO intensity fluctuation have a more severe impact on the secret key rate estimation.

column1: • The paper concludes that monitoring the LO intensity is crucial for the security of CVQKD systems and that the traditional method of scaling the measurements with the initial LO intensity value is not sufficient.

column2: • The proposed method can provide a more secure way to estimate the secret key rate and prevent LOIA.

• The code has options to output the eigenfunctions and displacement eigenfunctions, which can be used to study the properties of the modes.

column1: 127,"<summary>
• Inferring macroscopic properties from microscopic descriptions is a challenging task in physics, especially in systems with phase transitions and symmetry breaking.

column2: • Phase transitions can be identified by an order parameter, which is zero in the disordered phase and non-zero in the ordered phase.
• However, in some systems, the order parameter can only be defined in a complicated non-local way, making it difficult to identify.
• Machine learning techniques, such as unsupervised learning algorithms, can be used to identify phase transitions and order parameters.

column1: • The Ising model is a well-studied model in physics, and its phase transition can be identified using machine learning algorithms.

column2: • The variational autoencoder is a powerful unsupervised learning algorithm that can learn the latent representation of the Ising model and identify the phase transition.
• The reconstruction loss of the variational autoencoder can be used as a universal indicator for phase transitions.

column1: • The variational autoencoder can also be applied to more complex models, such as the XY model, which has continuous symmetries.

column2: • The variational autoencoder can learn the latent representation of the XY model and identify the phase transition.
• The latent parameters of the variational autoencoder can be used to construct an order parameter that captures the symmetry breaking of the XY model.

column1: • The use of machine learning algorithms in physics has the potential to uncover new phases and order parameters, and to develop new methods for identifying phase transitions.

column2: • The connection between deep neural networks and the renormalization group may also be explored further.
• The application of machine learning algorithms to physics can lead to new insights and discoveries in the field.",0

column1: 136,"<summary>
* The paper proposes a qubit controlled by a symmetry breaking effect in a triangular triple quantum dot (tqd) system.

column2: * The qubit is encoded in the doublet subspace and controlled by applied gate potentials that break the triangular symmetry.
* The qubit states can be manipulated by quick impulses of the electric field, allowing for Pauli X and Z gate operations.

column1: * The paper introduces a new method for read-out of the qubit state using the electric transport through tqd and the doublet blockade effect.

column2: * The doublet blockade effect is related to an asymmetry of tunnel rates between the doublet states and the electrodes.
* The method is compatible with pure electrical manipulations and spin-to-charge conversion is not necessary.

column1: * The paper also considers the time-dependent electron transport in the doublet blockade regime, including dynamics of the qubit, coherent oscillations, and relaxation processes due to the presence of the electrodes.

column2: * The role of leakage processes from the doublet to two-electron states is studied, and the driven case with a time-dependent mixing parameter is also investigated.
* The paper also examines the mixing of doublet subspaces with different spin orientations caused by spin-flip processes in the electrodes.",1

column1: 137,"<summary>
• The symbiotic system Z Andromedae (Z And) consists of a cool giant star and a hot compact component.

column1: • The 1984-1986 outburst was studied using spectral observations and modeling.

column2: • The modeling revealed that the outburst was caused by the collision of the white dwarf wind with two ejected shells from the red giant.
• The collision led to the formation of shock fronts and the emission of radiation.

column1: • The spectral observations showed that the ionization parameter and shock velocity varied during the outburst.

column2: • The variations were caused by the changing distance between the white dwarf and the downstream nebula.
• The distance increased suddenly due to the ejection of a new shell from the red giant.

column1: • The modeling also revealed the presence of silicate grains in the nebula.

column2: • The grains were formed after the collision of the white dwarf wind with the first shell.
• The grains were not present at the epochs corresponding to the collision with the second shell.

column1: • The continuum spectral energy distribution (SED) was calculated using the models.

column2: • The SED showed that the emission from the nebula appears in a small frequency range between the optical and near-UV.
• The SED was compared to observed data and showed good agreement.

column1: • The distance of the nebula from the center of the system was calculated using the adjusting factor.

column2: • The distance varied during the outburst, with a sudden increase between November and December 1985.
• The increase was caused by the ejection of a new shell from the red giant.

column1: • The 1984-1986 outburst of Z And was unique compared to other outbursts.

column2: • The outburst did not attain its maximum luminosity due to the distortion of the wind network by the oncoming shell.

column1: 138,"<summary>
• Networks of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) are emerging as novel materials for various applications, particularly as electronic materials.

column2: • SWCNT networks can be viewed as a 2D network of conducting 1D rods.
• The rods are either metallic or semiconducting with large dimension ratio (length/diameter).
• The nanotube-nanotube junction resistance is much larger than the nanotube resistance itself.

column1: • The frequency-dependent and electric-field-dependent conductivity have been investigated for individual SWCNTs and some types of SWCNT networks.

column2: • Burke and co-workers measured the microwave conductivity of individual SWCNTs and investigated their operation as a transistor at 2.6 GHz.
• For SWCNT networks with 30 nm thickness, the ac conductivity is frequency-independent up to an onset frequency of about 10 GHz.
• The conductivities at dc and 10 GHz are almost the same for thicker films with thickness in the range of tens of micrometers.

column1: • There is a lack of frequency and electric field dependent conductivity investigation for systematic variation of network densities.

column2: • There is no correlation study between the onset frequency and the length scale determined from nonlinear transport.
• The frequency- and electric-field-dependent conductivity investigation of different network densities is important for the sake of applications.
• Knowledge of their frequency-dependent electric transport properties is required for using SWCNT networks as high-speed transistors or transparent shielding materials.

column1: • In this paper, the frequency- and electric-field-dependent conductivity for SWCNT networks with systematically varying densities were investigated.

column2: • The onset frequency extracted from the frequency dependence measurement increases with the film thickness.
• The length scale extracted from the electric field dependent measurement decreases at the same time.
• An empirical relation between the two transport measurement methods was developed.

column1: • The SWCNT networks were prepared by the spraying method on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate.

column2: • The network density was controlled by the solution concentration and the spraying time.
• The thicknesses of the films range from submonolayer to 200 nm.
• The sheet conductance ranges from 10^(-3) to 10^3 S/square.

column1: • The frequency-dependent conductance of ultra-thin sub-monolayer nanotube networks was also measured.

column2: • The conductance of these films was measured by a 4284A precision LCR meter.
• The onset frequency versus their dc sheet conductance was plotted",0

column1: 140,"Here is the summary of the text in 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The many-body effects on XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) spectra were studied in the 1970s.

column2: * The effects include singularities near edges in absorption and emission spectra.
* The conduction-band electrons can have many different effects on the XPS peak from the core level.

column1: * The excitation process is not adiabatic, resulting in shake-up effects in the form of single-particle and collective excitations.

column2: * The electrons contributing to the shake-up effects are the electrons in the valence and conduction bands.

column1: * The core-hole potential is approximated with a pure Coulomb potential.

column2: * The Hamiltonian for the system is used to derive the XPS line shape.

column1: * The dynamical structure factor is related to the dielectric function and is nonzero in two regions: electron-hole pairs and plasmon dispersion curve.

column2: * The bosons are assumed to be independent.

column1: * The adiabatic approximation is used to diagonalize the Hamiltonian, resulting in a constant energy term.

column2: * The transformation of the Hamiltonian has the effect of changing the interaction term into a constant energy term.

column1: * The sudden approximation is used to derive the Green's function.

column2: * The Green's function is used to calculate the XPS spectrum.

column1: * The XPS spectrum reflects the density of states of the core electron and becomes a convolution of the density of states and the satellite generator.

column2: * The satellite generator is a function of the boson propagator and the dynamical structure factor.",0

column1: 141,"<summary>
• The article analyzes a two-genotype system with asymmetric mutation probabilities and nonlinear fitness functions in finite populations.

column2: • The authors derive the Fokker-Planck equation to describe the dynamics of the system and quantify the quality of the approach for an example, showing that the difference between simulation data and theoretical solution becomes almost undetectable for population sizes larger than 10^4.

column1: • The study identifies the individual effects of selection, mean mutation rate, and mutation difference, as well as genetic drift, and derives the stationary probability distribution.

column2: • The authors find that asymmetries in mutation probabilities can induce the shifting of existing stable points to new positions and lead to the emergence of new stable points.

column1: • The article concludes that frequency-dependent fitness together with asymmetric mutation rates induces complex evolutionary dynamics, particularly with nonlinear fitness functions, and that theoretically, there is no limit to the number of stable points that the dynamics can exhibit.

column1: 142,"<summary>
* The phase-field method is a popular approach for simulating microstructure formation during solidification.

column2: * It is widely used due to its algorithmic simplicity and ability to describe complex microstructures.

column1: * The method's popularity stems from its ability to avoid tracking moving solid-liquid interfaces or grain boundaries.

column2: * Instead, it describes the geometry in terms of one or several phase fields that obey simple partial differential equations.

column1: * The foundations of the phase-field method and its application to solidification have been reviewed in several recent articles.

column2: * However, some fundamental questions remain open, and the method's limitations need to be addressed.

column1: * One limitation is the thin-interface limit of two-sided phase-field models, which cannot eliminate all effects linked to the finite interface thickness.

column2: * This limitation can lead to errors in simulations, especially when the interface thickness is increased to make simulations feasible.

column1: * Another limitation is the inclusion of microscopic fluctuations in the phase-field equations.

column2: * The standard approach to include fluctuations as Langevin terms in the field equations has limitations and needs to be re-examined.

column1: * The phase-field method has been used to model polycrystalline solidification, but the evolution equation for the orientation field is not consistent with the coherent crystalline structure of matter.

column2: * A consistent equation of motion for the orientation field needs to take into account the connectivity of matter and the resulting geometrical conservation laws.

column1: * The method has been used to investigate the interplay between positional and orientational degrees of freedom during solidification.

column2: * However, the quantitative importance of the committed errors needs to be confirmed for each case at hand.

column1: * The role of fluctuations has been investigated in connection with the formation of sidebranches in free dendritic growth.

column2: * The standard approach to include fluctuations needs to be re-examined and improved.

column1: * The phase-field method has been used to model the solidification of pure substances and alloys, but its limitations need to be addressed to achieve quantitative simulations.

column2: * The method's limitations need to be overcome to achieve robust and accurate simulations of microstructure formation during solidification.",1

column1: 145,"<summary>
* The paper discusses the local moment approach (LMA) to the periodic Anderson model (PAM) for heavy fermion (HF) metals.

column2: * The LMA is a non-perturbative method that can handle strong interactions and is capable of capturing the crossover from the low-energy coherent Fermi liquid state to the high-energy incoherent regime.
* The approach is based on a two-self-energy description, which leads to a natural separation of the local moment and itinerant electron degrees of freedom.
* The paper focuses on the strongly correlated HF regime, where the low-energy scale is exponentially small in strong coupling.

column3: * The LMA results for single-particle dynamics at finite temperature are presented, showing universal scaling in terms of the low-energy scale.
* The scaling spectra depend only on the conduction band filling and the f-level asymmetry, and are independent of the interaction strength and hybridization matrix element.
* The crossover to incoherent effective single-impurity physics is observed at high energies.

column2: * The paper also discusses the application of the LMA to transport and optical properties, including the calculation of the dynamical conductivity and the Drude weight.

column3: * The LMA results for the Drude weight are exact and show that it is exponentially diminished in the HF regime.
* The paper also discusses the difference between the Bethe lattice and the hypercubic lattice, and how the LMA can capture the vanishing DC conductivity in the kondo insulating state.

column1: 146,"<summary>
* The kinetics of polymer loop formation has been studied for several decades and has recently attracted renewed attention due to its importance in biology.

* Et al. showed that in Gal repressor and DNA-bending protein Hu-mediated looping, mechanical constraints such as tension and torsion play a pivotal role.

column1: * Theoretically, Yan et al. developed a transfer matrix method to calculate semiflexible polymer end-to-end distance distribution function and loop formation probability.

* They also studied effects of tension on the loop formation probability, which is related to the free energy barrier for loop formation.

* They also find that the looping time is greatly reduced in the presence of a fluctuating tension.

column1: 149,"<summary>
• The glassy wormlike chain (GWC) model is extended to include inelastic behavior:

column2: • The model accounts for the breaking and reforming of bonds between polymers in a network.
• The bond fraction, which determines the material properties, is dynamic and dependent on the strain and stress history.
• The model exhibits viscoelastic behavior at small deformations and inelastic behavior at large deformations.
• The inelastic behavior is characterized by a yield force and a fluidization of the network.

column1: • The model is used to study the response to deformation pulses:

column2: • The force-displacement curve shows a stiffening regime followed by a softening regime.
• The bond fraction decreases sharply at the yield force, leading to a fluidization of the network.
• The rate dependence of the yield force is estimated and compared to numerical results.
• The minimum bond fraction reached during the pulse depends non-monotonically on the rate.

column1: • The model exhibits passive remodeling and fluidization:

column2: • The deformation pulse leads to a decrease in the storage modulus and an increase in the loss angle.
• The system properties recover after cessation of the external perturbations.
• The fluidization resembles a plastic process on short time scales, but is more similar to pseudo- and superelasticity on long time scales.
• The model demonstrates cyclic softening and viscoelastic shake-down effects.",1

column1: 150,"<summary>
* Topological insulators have been extensively studied in two and three dimensions due to their potential applications.

column2: * They are characterized by non-trivial topological invariants and robust surface metallic states.
* The topological phases are typically realized in systems with strong spin-orbit interaction.

column1: * The topological Mott insulator (TMI) is a type of topological insulator that emerges from a spontaneous symmetry breaking.

column2: * It is driven by the Coulomb interaction and has an unconventional quantum criticality.
* The TMI has been proposed in various solids and cold atoms loaded in optical lattices.

column1: * The stability of the TMI is hampered by competing symmetry breakings, such as charge density waves (CDWs).

column2: * The CDW instability must be considered on equal footing with the TMI transition.

column1: * The authors use a variational Monte Carlo method to study the extended Hubbard model on a honeycomb lattice.

column2: * They examine the ground states of the model by tuning the on-site and second-neighbor Coulomb repulsions.

column2: * However, by modulating the fermi velocity, the TMI becomes stable.

column1: * The authors discuss the realization of the TMI in real materials, such as twisted bilayer graphene.

column2: * They propose that the TMI can be stabilized by suppressing the fermi velocity and controlling the Coulomb repulsions.

column1: * The authors estimate the single-particle excitation gap induced by the TMI and find it to be substantial.

column2: * They conclude that topological insulators with large excitation gaps can be obtained using abundant carbon atoms.

column1: * The authors acknowledge the need for further analysis and _ab initio_ estimates of the stability of the TMI in bilayer graphenes.

column1: 153,"<summary>
* The light flavor scalar mesons are an exception to the naive quark model and their structures have not been unambiguously determined yet.

column1: * The QCD sum rules are used to study the nonet scalar mesons, and the results are compatible with experimental data and theoretical estimations.

column1: 154,"<summary>
* Time-domain simulation is important for power system dynamic analysis, but it can be computationally expensive due to the large number of differential and algebraic equations involved.

column2: * The long-term stability model includes different components with different time scales, making simulation challenging.
* The quasi-steady-state (QSS) model is an approximation, but it can suffer from numerical difficulties and provide inconsistent results.

column1: * The pseudo-transient continuation (PTC) method is a numerical method that can accelerate simulation speed and overcome numerical difficulties.

column2: * PTC can be applied directly to the long-term stability model or the QSS model.
* It has a better stability property than conventional integration methods.

column1: * The PTC method is based on the idea of increasing the time step size to filter out fast dynamics and sacrificing temporal accuracy to gain rapid convergence to steady state.

column2: * It can avoid converging to nonphysical solutions or stagnating when the Jacobian matrix is singular.
* It has been proven to converge for smooth and nonsmooth systems.

column1: * The PTC method has been applied to power system models, including the long-term stability model and the QSS model.

column2: * It has been shown to provide correct approximations and overcome numerical difficulties in the QSS model.
* It can capture instabilities in the long-term stability model.

column1: * The paper presents three numerical examples to demonstrate the feasibility of the PTC method.

column2: * The examples show that the PTC method can provide correct stability assessment and overcome numerical difficulties.
* The method can be used as an alternative to traditional integration methods.

column1: * The PTC method has been implemented in the PSAT-2.1.6 software package.

column2: * The software package is used for power system analysis and simulation.
* The PTC method can be used in conjunction with other methods in the software package.

column1: * The paper concludes that the PTC method is a useful tool for power system long-term stability analysis.

column2: * It can provide fast simulation speed and accurate results.
* It can be used in conjunction with other methods to provide a comprehensive analysis of power system stability.",1

column1: 155,"<summary>
* The problem of anisotropic quantum scattering in 2D attracts increasing interest due to its potential applications in creating exotic and highly correlated quantum systems with dipolar gases.

column2: * The recent experimental production of ultracold polar molecules in optical traps has opened up ways to realize these phenomena.

column2: * The paper discusses the succinct encoding of permutations, which is a fundamental problem in computer science.
* The goal is to encode a permutation of n elements using fewer than n bits.
* The authors present several encoding schemes that achieve this goal.
* The schemes are based on the concept of runs, which are maximal sequences of consecutive elements in the permutation.

* The authors present encoding schemes for permutations with strict runs and shuffled upsequences.

column1: • Kauffman networks are disordered dynamical systems proposed by Kauffman in 1969 as a model for genetic regulatory systems.

column1: • The dynamical phase transition in Kauffman networks was found and studied in the framework of mean field theory.

column1: • The relevant elements in the network are those that influence the long-time behavior of the system.

column2: • They are the only ones that can influence the asymptotic dynamics.
• The number of relevant elements scales as √N on the critical line.

column1: 165,"<summary>
• White dwarf (WD) stars are the end points of stellar evolution for low-mass stars, and more than 97% of stars in the galaxy will become WDs.

column2: • WDs are divided into spectral classes, with DA WDs being the most common, making up about 80% of all WDs.

column1: • DA WDs cool to a temperature that fosters a hydrogen partial ionization zone, leading to global pulsations, making them ZZ Ceti stars.

column2: • These pulsations can be used to determine the WD's fundamental parameters through asteroseismology.

column1: • The ZZ Ceti instability strip is a region of temperature and surface gravity where WDs pulsate, and it is believed that all DA WDs will pass through this strip.

column2: • The strip has been mapped observationally, with a dependence on surface gravity, and WDs with lower surface gravity pulsate at lower effective temperatures.

column1: • The blue edge of the instability strip has been successfully estimated through convective period arguments and full non-adiabatic calculations.

column2: • However, estimating the temperature at which pulsations shut down remains a challenge, with a discrepancy between theoretical and empirical red edges.

column1: • The discovery of pulsating extremely low-mass (ELM) WDs provides an opportunity to explore the physics of WD pulsations at cooler temperatures and lower masses.

column2: • ELM WDs are likely the product of binary evolution, with helium cores, and their pulsations can be used to constrain their interior composition and evolution models.

column1: • The authors have discovered pulsations in two new ELM WDs, SDSS J161431.28+191219.4 and SDSS J222859.93+362359.6, which are the coolest pulsating WDs ever found.

column2: • These discoveries bring the total number of pulsating ELM WDs to five, establishing them as a new class of pulsating WDs.

column1: • The ELM WD instability strip may not be pure, as they may not all evolve through the strip in the same way, and theoretical models predict multiple unstable hydrogen-burning episodes.

column2: • Empirically discovering ELM WDs that do or do not pulsate can be used to constrain binary and stellar evolution models for low-mass WDs.</summary>",0

170,"<summary>
• The analysis of modern accelerator-based neutrino oscillation experiments requires good control over the intermediate-energy neutrino-nucleus scattering cross section.

column2: • This control is crucial for understanding the importance of multi-nucleon events in charge-changing quasielastic cross sections.

column1: • The contribution of two-particle-two-hole (2p-2h) excitations is essential for a proper description of data.

column2: • The 2p-2h models are being implemented in Monte Carlo event generators used by neutrino collaborations.

column1: • The frozen nucleon approximation is a fast and efficient method to calculate the inclusive 2p-2h responses in the relativistic Fermi gas model.

column2: • This approach neglects the momentum dependence of the two holes in the ground state and requires the use of an effective propagator for the Δ resonance conveniently averaged over the Fermi sphere.

column1: • The validity of the frozen nucleon approximation relies on the fact that the integrand inside the 2p-2h response is a function that depends slowly on the momenta of the two initial nucleons inside the Fermi sea.

column2: • The mean-value theorem applied to the resolution of the integrals provides very precise results.

column1: • The frozen approximation has been validated by comparing the approximate 2p-2h response functions with the exact results in the relativistic Fermi gas model.

column2: • The results show a good agreement between the two approaches, especially for the transverse responses that dominate the cross section.

column1: • The physical interpretation of the frozen approximation is that the detailed information about the momenta carried out by the two nucleons is lost in the inclusive responses for two-particle emission.

column2: • This is because the energy and momentum transfer are shared by the two nucleons in multiple ways.

column1: • The frozen approximation can be used instead of the full 7-dimensional integral, obtaining very satisfactory results, and can be of great interest when implementing 2p-2h models in Monte Carlo event generators.

column2: • This approach enables one to make 2p-2h calculations very efficiently and rapidly, allowing the parameters of the models to be modified inside the codes if desired.

column1: * The anomalies can be classified into two types: external and internal symmetries.

column2: * The breakdown of an external symmetry is not dangerous for the consistency of the theory.
* The breakdown of an internal symmetry, such as gauge symmetry, leads to an inconsistency.
* The anomalies can be calculated using various methods, including perturbation theory, heat kernel method, and Fujikawa's path integral approach.

column1: 176,"<summary>

* The STE-QUEST mission aims to study the cornerstones of Einstein's Equivalence Principle (EEP) by pushing the limits of measurement accuracy by several orders of magnitude compared to current ground-based experiments.

column2: * The mission will perform four primary science objectives, including measuring the gravitational red-shift experienced by highly accurate clocks in the gravitational fields of Earth and Sun, and testing the universality of free fall.

column3: * The atomic clock will be used to measure the gravitational red-shift, while the atom interferometer will be used to test the universality of free fall.

column1: * The spacecraft will follow a highly elliptical orbit, with a perigee altitude of 700 km and an apogee altitude of 50,000 km, which will maximize the gravity gradients between apogee and perigee.

column2: * The orbit will allow for measurements of the gravitational red-shift of both Earth and Sun, as well as tests of the universality of free fall.

177,"<summary>
* The paper presents a numerical study of the propagation of a high-frequency electromagnetic wave into the ionosphere and its interactions with the ionospheric plasma.

column2: * The study uses a one-dimensional model that neglects the electromagnetic field falloff and the influence of field-aligned irregularities in the ionosphere.
* The simulation uses a linearly polarized EM pulse with a carrier frequency of 5 MHz and a maximum amplitude of 10 V/m.

column1: * The EM pulse propagates without changing shape through the neutral atmosphere until it reaches the ionospheric layer.

column2: * At this point, the pulse undergoes Faraday rotation due to the different dispersion properties of the L-O and R-X modes in the magnetized plasma.

column1: * The L-O and R-X mode pulses are excited, with the turning point of the L-O mode being at a higher altitude than that of the R-X mode.

column2: * The maximum amplitude of the R-X mode is 20 V/m, while that of the L-O mode is 30 V/m.

column1: * The electric field components of the L-O mode are primarily directed along the geomagnetic field lines, and hence only the Ex and Ey components are excited.

column2: * The magnetic field components of the L-O mode are very small.

column1: * At later times, the EM wave starts turning back towards lower altitudes, and the L-O mode oscillations radiate EM waves with significant magnetic field components.

column2: * The leading part of the pulse is primarily R-X mode polarized, while its trailing part is L-O mode polarized.

column1: * The simulation also shows the production of electrostatic waves with a wavelength of approximately 33 m and a frequency of 5 MHz.

column2: * These waves are produced by mode conversion of the L-O mode and are on the same dispersion surface as the Langmuir waves and the upper hybrid waves/slow Z-mode waves.

column1: * The frequency spectrum of the electric field component shows the large-amplitude pump wave at 5 MHz and the relatively weak second harmonics of the pump wave at 10 MHz.

column2: * The spectrum also shows low-frequency oscillations due to the nonlinear down-shifting/mixing of the high-frequency wave field.

column1: * The study demonstrates the importance of numerical simulations in understanding the complex behavior of plasma turbulence and secondary radiation in the ionosphere.

column2: * The results of the simulation are in agreement with experimental observations and can be used to interpret and predict the behavior of ionospheric heating experiments.",0

column1: 178,"<summary>
* The paper discusses the Mott-Hubbard model of interacting bosons on a lattice, which has been used to describe superfluid-Mott insulator transitions in various systems.

column2: * The model is studied using a combination of mean-field theory and perturbation theory to include short-range correlations.

column1: * The authors calculate corrections to local observables, such as particle number fluctuations, and find good agreement with exact diagonalization results in 1D lattices.

column2: * The corrections to the correlation function and expansion patterns are also studied, and show distinct modifications compared to mean-field results.

column1: * The inclusion of short-range correlations leads to broad peaks in the expansion patterns, even at small values of the hopping parameter.

column2: * The peaks are suppressed in the superfluid region, and broadened in the Mott insulator region.

column1: * The authors also study the effects of a harmonic confinement potential, which leads to coexisting superfluid and Mott insulator regions.

column2: * The perturbative corrections to the expansion patterns become more complex in this case, with modifications of up to 20% of the peak maximum.

column1: * The paper concludes that the inclusion of short-range correlations is essential for a accurate description of the Mott-Hubbard model, especially in the vicinity of the superfluid-Mott insulator transition.

column2: * The results are relevant for the study of ultracold atoms in optical lattices, where the Mott-Hubbard model is used to describe the behavior of the atoms.

column1: * The appendix provides details on the perturbation theory calculations, including diagrams illustrating the corrections to the density matrix.

column2: * The perturbation theory is used to calculate corrections to the mean-field results, including the first-order and second-order corrections to the density matrix.",1

column1: 179,"<summary>
* Cosmological models with scalar fields have been studied in the context of inflation and late-time acceleration.

column2: * The type of scalar field potential obtained from compactifications is restrictive, making it difficult to get accelerating cosmologies.
* However, compactification on a compact hyperbolic manifold with a time-dependent volume modulus can lead to a flat, expanding universe with transient acceleration.
* The transient acceleration is easily understood in terms of the positive scalar field potential produced in hyperbolic and flux compactifications.
* The generic nature of transient acceleration is clear in this perspective.

column1: * The paper aims to generalize the analysis to the multi-scalar case and determine what can be said about cosmologies with more general scalar potentials.

column2: * The authors review the equations of motion for multi-scalar cosmologies and derive a useful alternative criterion for acceleration.

* They consider possible fixed points, concluding that these occur only for exponential potentials, and determine the nature of these fixed points for arbitrary spacetime dimension and sign of the potential.
* The authors develop an alternative method of visualizing cosmological solutions that applies to any potential, and illustrate it by an application to exponential potentials.

column1: * The paper discusses the phase-plane trajectories and presents exact solutions for flat cosmologies.

column2: * The authors develop an interpretation of multi-scalar cosmologies as geodesic motion in an augmented target space.
* They introduce the notion of the acceleration cone and show how cosmologies arising in exponential-potential models fit into the new framework.
* Other potentials of current interest are also considered.

column1: * The authors summarize the results and discuss their implications.

column2: * They note that the fixed points of the multi-scalar model are the same as those of the one-scalar model.
* The authors discuss the behavior of trajectories in the one-scalar model and how it is modified in the multi-scalar case.
* They conclude that transient acceleration is less generic in multi-scalar models than in the single-scalar model.

column1: * The paper provides a new framework for understanding cosmological solutions in multi-scalar models.

column2: * The authors show that cosmological trajectories can be viewed as geodesics in an augmented target space.
* This framework allows for a more general understanding of the behavior of cosmological solutions.
* The authors hope that this framework will be useful for studying more general scalar potentials and cosmological models.",0

column1: 180,"<summary>

column1: 181,"<summary>
• The paper presents a supersymmetric Mass-Varying Neutrinos (MaVaN) model that includes the effects of supersymmetry breaking mediated by gravity.

• The supersymmetry breaking effect is transmitted to the dark sector through gravity, resulting in soft parameters of the order of TeV scale.
• The model is consistent with cosmological observations and avoids the instability of the speed of sound in the neutrino-acceleron fluid.

column1: • The paper considers two types of models: one with vanishing mixing between the left-handed and sterile neutrino, and another with finite mixing.

column2: • In the vanishing mixing case, only the mass of the sterile neutrino varies on cosmological time scale, and the speed of sound squared is positive, making the fluid a viable dark energy candidate.

• In the finite mixing case, the mass of the left-handed neutrino also varies, but the variation is extremely small, and the effect of the mixing does not affect the evolution of the sterile neutrino mass and the equation of state.

182,"<summary>
* The quark-gluon plasma (QGP) is a phase of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) where quarks and gluons are deconfined.

column2: * It is a state of matter that exists at extremely high temperatures and densities.
* The QGP is thought to have existed in the early universe and may exist in the cores of neutron stars.

column1: * The QGP can be created in heavy-ion collisions, and its properties can be studied using lattice QCD and perturbative QCD.

column2: * Lattice QCD is a numerical approach that uses a discretized spacetime lattice to calculate the properties of QCD.

column1: * The Landau Fermi liquid theory is a theoretical framework that describes the behavior of relativistic fermions, such as quarks, at high densities.

column1: 183,"Here is the summary of the text in 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

* The conformally symmetric model for strong interactions at low energies was proposed, based on the observation that the dynamical equations of gauge theories retain their flat-space-time form when subject to a conformally-flat metrical field.

column2: * The model describes quarks and gluons confined to an anti-de Sitter (ADS) universe with a finite radius in flat space-time.
* The model introduces two scalar fields that spontaneously break the conformal symmetry down to SU(2) and SU(3) symmetry, respectively.
* The model also defines a symmetric second-order tensor field that serves as the metric for flat space-time, coupling to electromagnetism.

column1: * The fields in the model comprise one real scalar field and one complex scalar field, whose dynamical equations were solved for the case that the respective vacuum expectation values satisfy a certain relation.

column2: * A solution for one of the vacuum expectation values leads to ADS confinement, via the associated conformally flat metric.
* The only quadratic term in the Lagrangian is proportional to a certain expression.
* Under a certain condition, one obtains a light scalar field associated with confinement and a very heavy complex scalar field associated with electromagnetism.

column1: * The model does not easily allow for interactions between hadrons, as each hadron is described by a closed universe.

column2: * To compare the properties of the model with measured cross sections and branching ratios, the model has been further simplified.
* The ADS spectrum is coupled to the channels of two or more hadronic decay products for which scattering amplitudes can be measured.
* The ADS spectrum reveals itself through the structures observed in hadronic mass distributions.

column1: * Experimental evidence for the possible existence of a quantum with a mass of about 38 MeV is presented.

* The signal seems to be visible on the slope of a certain resonance, though with little more than 2σ relevance.

column1: * The light scalar glueball discussed in the text seems to correspond to the lowest-order empty-universe solution for strong interactions.

column2: * It has similar properties as the electroweak Higgs, but now for strong interactions.

column1: 184,"<summary>
• The concept of stochastic resonance is introduced and its presence in different fields of applications is reviewed.

column2: • The phenomenon is explained as the improvement of signal transmission by adding noise to a periodic input signal.
• The problem is formulated as estimating a signal transmitted through a channel with a threshold, and the optimal level of noise is defined as the one that maximizes the Fisher information quantity.

column1: • The paper studies the problem of estimation and hypotheses testing for a model with a threshold and a subthreshold constant signal, perturbed by a noise that is a trajectory of a diffusion process.

column2: • Two schemes of observations are proposed: observing the proportion of time spent by the perturbed signal over the threshold, and measuring the energy of the signal when it is above the threshold.
• Asymptotic properties of estimators are established, and an example of stochastic resonance is given.

column1: • The paper also studies the problem of testing two simple hypotheses for the model, using the maximum a posteriori probability criterion, and shows that the overall probability of error is non-monotonically dependent on the noise level, exhibiting the effect of stochastic resonance.

column2: • The decision rules for the model are similar to those proposed by Chapeau-Blondeau in the i.i.d. setting.
• The use of ergodic diffusions as noise in the problem of stochastic resonance is discussed, and potential future research directions are outlined.",0

column1: 186,"<summary>

column1: 187,"<summary>

• Anomaly Mediated Supersymmetry Breaking (AMSB) models have attractive properties, such as calculable soft SUSY breaking terms, real and flavor invariant soft terms, and renormalization group invariant soft terms.

• The soft terms are real and flavor invariant, solving the SUSY flavor and CP problems.
• The soft terms are renormalization group invariant, and can be calculated at any convenient scale choice.

column1: • Hypercharged Anomaly Mediation (HCAMS) is a string-motivated scenario that uses a similar setup as AMSB.

column2: • SUSY breaking is localized at the bottom of a strongly warped hidden region, geometrically separated from the visible region where the MSSM resides.
• The warping suppresses contributions due to tree-level gravity mediation, and anomaly mediation can become the dominant source of SUSY breaking in the visible sector.
• Possible exceptions to this sequestering mechanism are gaugino masses of U(1) gauge symmetries.

column1: • The HCAMS model has a different mass ordering compared to AMSB, with a wino-like neutralino and higgsino-like charginos.

• The model has a different phenomenology compared to AMSB, with a larger reach for sparticle production at the LHC.
• The model can be distinguished from AMSB by the presence of long-lived charginos and different decay patterns.

• The model predicts a different mass ordering and decay patterns compared to AMSB, which can be used",0

column1: 188,"<summary>
• The zero-range potential (ZRP) approach is a method for solving scattering problems, which allows for exact solutions.

column2: • It is based on the idea of representing the potential as a boundary condition on the wavefunction at a certain point.

column1: • The ZRP approach has been developed to widen the limits of traditional treatments, such as those by Demkov and Ostrovsky, and Albeverio et al.

column2: • It has the advantage of providing an exact solution to the scattering problem.

column1: • The Darboux transformation (DT) is a technique that allows for the construction of exactly solvable potentials.

column2: • This allows for the study of scattering problems in complex systems, such as polyatomic molecules.

column1: • The ZRP approach has been used to study electron scattering by various structures, including those with multiple centers.

column2: • The results of these studies have been compared to experimental data and other numerical calculations.

column1: • The DT has been used to dress the ZRP model, which allows for the inclusion of long-range forces and the correction of the model at low energies.

column2: • This has been shown to improve the agreement between the model and experimental data.

column1: • The ZRP approach has been applied to various systems, including those with spherical and non-spherical potentials.

column2: • The results of these studies have been published in various papers and have contributed to the development of the field.

• The convection-diffusion model is a semi-linear parabolic partial differential equation that has various applications in science and engineering.

• The differential quadrature method (DQM) is an approximation to derivatives of a function, which is the weighted sum of the functional values at certain nodes.

column1: 194,"<summary>
• The paper presents phase-resolved spectroscopy of LMCX-2, a low-mass X-ray binary (LMXB) in the Large Magellanic Cloud.

column2: • The observations were made using the FORS2 spectrograph on the VLT, with a total of 77 spectra obtained over two nights.
• The spectra show a strong He II emission line, as well as weaker emission lines from the Bowen region.

column1: • The radial velocity curve of the He II line shows a periodic variability, which is interpreted as the orbital period of the system.

column2: • The orbital period is determined to be 0.32 days, similar to the photometric period detected by Callanan et al. (1990).
• The semi-amplitude of the radial velocity curve is small, suggesting that the system may have a low inclination.

column1: • The Doppler maps of the He II line show a ring-like structure, with some changes between the two nights of observation.

column2: • The Bowen region Doppler map shows a bright spot, which is interpreted as arising from the irradiated surface of the donor star.
• The velocity of the bright spot is higher than the disk velocities in the He II Doppler map.

column1: • The system parameters of LMCX-2 are constrained using the observed velocities and the assumption that the narrow emission lines arise from the donor star.

column2: • The mass function of the system is determined to be > 0.86 M⊙, with a lower limit on the center-of-mass velocity of the secondary.
• The mass ratio of the system is constrained to be < 0.38.

column1: • The paper suggests that LMCX-2 may have a precessing, warped accretion disk, similar to other X-ray binaries.

column2: • The long-term variability observed in the system may be related to the precession period.

195,"<summary>
* The axial anomaly is a fundamental issue in quantum field theory, and its interpretation is still a subject of debate.

column2: * The anomaly can be derived using the renormalization procedure, but this approach does not provide a clear physical understanding of its origin.

column3: * The dispersive approach, on the other hand, shows that the anomaly is related to the chiral limit and can be interpreted as an infrared effect.

column1: * The axial anomaly can be related to physical processes, such as radiative decays, where a fermion changes helicity by emitting a photon.

column2: * The anomaly is connected to the non-conservation of helicity in the massless limit, which is a consequence of the chiral symmetry breaking.

column3: * This non-conservation of helicity is a manifestation of the anomaly in the divergence of the axial current.

column1: * The mass singularities cancellation mechanism in radiative decays is different for polarized and unpolarized processes.

column2: * In the unpolarized case, the cancellation occurs through the usual mechanism, involving soft and virtual photon contributions.

column3: * In the polarized case, the cancellation is more subtle and involves the interplay between angular momentum conservation and helicity flip in the photon-lepton vertex.",0

column1: 196,"<summary>
* Salient object detection is a challenging task in computer vision that involves identifying the most attention-grabbing object in an image.

column2: * The task is challenging due to the complexity of natural scenes, variability in object appearances, and the subjective nature of human attention.
* Current models are limited by their reliance on simple datasets and their inability to generalize to complex scenes.

column1: * The paper proposes a new dataset, Judd-A, which contains 900 images with annotated objects and fixation data from 15 observers.

column2: * The dataset is designed to be more challenging than existing datasets, with more complex scenes and a greater variety of objects.
* The dataset is also more diverse, with a greater range of object sizes, shapes, and locations.

column1: * The paper also proposes a simple baseline model for salient object detection, which involves computing a saliency map and an over-segmented region map.

column2: * The model uses a fixation prediction model to identify regions of interest and then segments the object using a superpixel algorithm.
* The model is designed to be simple and efficient, and can be used as a baseline for evaluating more complex models.",0

column1: 197,"<summary>
• The paper discusses the combinatorial description of the ranks of maps induced by two-handle additions in a decorated topological quantum field theory (TQFT) called Heegaard Floer theory.

column2: • The authors show that the maps induced by two-handle additions can be represented by nice triple Heegaard diagrams, which are a special type of multi-pointed triple Heegaard diagram.
• The nice diagrams are defined as those where every unpunctured elementary domain is a bigon, triangle, or rectangle.
• The authors prove that the holomorphic triangle counts for nice diagrams can be computed combinatorially.

column1: • The paper also discusses the properties of nice diagrams, including the fact that they are weakly admissible and that the holomorphic curves in them can be decomposed into embedded triangles that overlap in a specific way.

column2: • The authors show that the index of a holomorphic curve in a nice diagram is zero if and only if it is an embedding.
• They also prove that the domains of generic holomorphic curves of index zero can be combinatorially described.
• The paper concludes by stating that the results can be used to give an algorithmic procedure for computing the ranks of maps induced by two-handle additions.
• The authors also mention that their results can be used to detect exotic smooth structures on 4-manifolds.",0

column1: 198,"<summary>

* The paper extends classical results on deformation theory of associative algebras to a deformation theory for arbitrary pasting diagrams of linear categories, linear functors, and natural transformations.

column2: * It generalizes the results of Gerstenhaber and Voronov on the infinitesimal deformation theory of associative algebras and poset-indexed diagrams of associative algebras.

column1: * The paper establishes that obstructions to deformation are cocycles, and provides a detailed and rigorous exposition of a method developed by Shrestha to prove this result.

column2: * The method involves using polygons with edges labeled by arrow-valued operations to encode cocycle conditions, formulas for obstructions, and cobounding conditions.

column1: * The paper also provides explicit examples of deformation complexes associated with various shapes of commutative pasting diagrams, including ""pillows"" with triangular and square cross-sections, and pasting diagrams involving 1-dimensional compositions.

column2: * These examples illustrate the application of the method to specific cases and demonstrate the complexity of the deformation theory of pasting diagrams.",1

column1: 199,"<summary>
• The aim of physics is not only to calculate observables but to understand the physical picture responsible for the phenomenon.

column2: • This is often difficult due to the complexity of the theory at the relevant scale.
• A main task is to select the essential degrees of freedom.

column1: • In crystals, the fundamental degrees of freedom are ions, electrons, and the electromagnetic field.

column2: • However, to understand electric conductivity, heat capacity, etc., we work with ""heavy electrons"" with dynamical mass, phonons, and their interactions.

column1: • In QCD, one hopes to solve the full non-quenched QCD on the lattice and get the correct nucleon and pion mass.

column2: • However, QCD at the scale of 1 GeV becomes too complicated, and it is difficult to say what kind of physics is relevant to the nucleon mass and its low-energy properties.

column1: • The spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry is the most important QCD phenomenon in this case.

column2: • Beyond the scale of spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry, light and strange baryons can be viewed as systems of three constituent quarks interacting by the exchange of Goldstone bosons.

column1: • The coupling of constituent quarks and Goldstone bosons has a specific form, which gives rise to the spin-spin, tensor, and central interactions between quarks.

column2: • The sum rule indicates that the volume integral of the Goldstone boson exchange interaction should vanish.

column1: • The vector-meson exchange interaction produces a short-range spin-flavor force, which is crucial for baryons.

column2: • The spin-orbit component associated with the vector-meson exchange interaction is big and empirically very important in the NN system.

column1: • In a simple model, the chiral interaction provides different ordering of the lowest positive and negative parity excited states in the spectra of the nucleon and the Λ-hyperon.

column2: • This is a direct consequence of the symmetry properties of the boson-exchange interaction.

column1: • The semirelativistic chiral constituent quark model provides a unified description of both nonstrange and strange baryon spectra in good agreement with phenomenology.

column2: • The model involves a total of 4 free parameters, which are determined from the fit to all 35 confirmed low-lying states.",0

column1: 200,"<summary>
• The invention relates to novel calcium phosphate-coated implantable medical devices and processes of making same.

column2: • The coated devices minimize immune response to the implant and can store and release one or more medicinally active agents into the body in a controlled manner.

column1: • The calcium phosphate coatings are biocompatible and bioresorbable, and can be deposited on implantable medical devices using various methods, including sol-gel, electro-phoretic deposition, and electrochemical deposition.

column2: • The coatings can be designed to have controlled porosity and crystallinity, and can be used to deliver drugs to the body.

column1: • The invention also relates to a process of coating an implantable medical device with a calcium phosphate coating, comprising hydrolyzing a phosphor precursor, adding a calcium salt precursor, depositing the gel on the device, and calcining the coating at a suitable temperature.

column2: • The process can be used to produce coatings with desired crystallinity, bonding, and porosity characteristics.

column1: • The calcium phosphate coatings can be deposited discontinuously on the device, forming ""islands"" or ""patches"" that retain high resistance against substrate deformation.

column2: • The coatings can be combined with a continuous bio-compatible and non-thrombogenic polymer to avoid adverse tissue reaction.

column1: • The invention has broad application to virtually any type of body implantable device, including coronary stents.

column2: • The coatings can be designed to release drugs at a controlled rate, and can be used to prevent restenosis and other negative effects associated with implantable medical devices.

column1: • The sol-gel process provides superior chemical and physical homogeneity of the final ceramic product, and allows for the synthesis of the desired ceramic phase at lower temperatures than other routes.

column2: • The process widens green-shaping capability and is a convenient method for deposition of thin ceramic coatings.",1

column1: 201,"Here is the summary of the text in 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
• The present invention relates to nerve regeneration, particularly to nerve conduits for the regeneration of peripheral nerves.

column2: • The invention provides a fabricated implantable NGC with an inner spiral structured porous sheet decorated with surface channels and electrospun fibers.

column1: • The NGC has integrated spiral structured porous sheets with proximal and distal reserved chambers, which provide an optimal initial environment for nerve ingrowth.

column2: • The chambers prevent stress from accruing when the nerve tissue is sutured with the conduit in an end-to-end fashion.

column1: • The NGC has a dense outer fibrous tube that improves the mechanical properties of the entire structure and provides stable structural support during nerve regeneration.

column2: • The outer fibrous tube can be made from polymers that are different from those of the spiral sheet or the aligned fibers.

column1: • The NGC is tunable, and its size can be varied in a controlled fashion depending on how it is to be used.

column2: • The length and the outer diameter of the NGC are dependent on the size of the spiral-wound sheet.

column1: • The NGC has a high surface area available for cell migration and attachment, which reduces the length of time needed for nerve regeneration.

column2: • The NGC has a highly aligned orientation of electrospun nanofibers that ensures all areas of the regenerating axon come into contact with aligned fibers.

column1: • The NGC has been tested in a 10 mm Sprague Dawley (SD) rat sciatic nerve defect and showed significant improvement in sciatic functional index (SFI) and compound muscle action potentials (CMAP) compared to control groups.

column2: • The NGC also showed significant differences in nerve conduction velocity (NCV) compared to control groups.

column1: </summary>",0
202,"<summary>

* The invention relates to seat base support assemblies, particularly sinuous band seat spring assemblies, and provides a new and improved rail connector that addresses the need for more upward resilience in seat bases with thicker cushions.

column2: * The connector embodies the features of conventional helical spring connectors while retaining none of the undesirable features.

column1: * The invention provides two forms of rail connectors: a first form using pre-stressed, close-wound coil springs with attachment arms, and a second form using a pre-stressed, cantilever spring configuration.

column2: * The first form can be wound on an axis transverse or longitudinal to the axis of spring expansion and contraction, and may have a leverage-amplified torsioning capability.

column1: * The connectors provide four essential seat-force generators: torsioning, dynamic uplift, expansion-contraction, and leverage-amplification, which produce four desired seat-performance characteristics: initial-drop, deep-drop, softness, and resilient uplift.

column2: * The connectors can be used with various seat base support means, including wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, and flat steel bands.

column1: * The invention provides a solution to the problem of thicker cushions requiring more upward resilience in seat bases, and offers varying degrees of dynamic uplift resilience through alternative spring action modes.

column2: * The connectors can be modified to provide different levels of torsioning, dynamic uplift, and leverage amplification, depending on the specific requirements of the seat base design.",0

column1: 203,"<summary>
• The anvil assembly includes an anvil head assembly, an anvil shaft, and a stabilizing collet.

column2: • The collet is formed of a substantially rigid material and is received within a longitudinal bore defined by the flexible legs of the anvil shaft.

column1: • The anvil shaft includes a plurality of flexible legs that flex outwardly in response to insertion of a trocar of a surgical stapling device into the anvil shaft.

column2: • The flexible legs define a longitudinal bore that is dimensioned to receive the trocar of the stapling device.

column1: • The collet is positioned within the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft to support the flexible legs and minimize the likelihood of damage to the anvil shaft.

column2: • The collet is positioned in a location not to interfere with flexing of the legs during coupling of the anvil shaft to the trocar of the stapling device.

column1: • The anvil assembly is used in a surgical stapling device for performing endoscopic surgical procedures.

column2: • The anvil assembly is grasped with a grasper and positioned within a body orifice or lumen to perform a surgical procedure.

column1: • The collet is secured within the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft using protrusions that engage holes formed in the anvil shaft.

column2: • The collet is formed from a medical grade material having a stiffness to perform the functions described herein.",1

column1: 204,"<summary>
• The present invention relates to a container of a blender, particularly to a set of high-speed blades mounted inside the lower portion of the container.

column2: • The container is made of reinforced plastic, which is light weight, cost efficient, durable, and rigid.
• However, the inner wall of the container is impacted or collided intermittently by the stirred objects, resulting in nicks.
• Debris of the scraped acrylic resin may mix into the liquid, leading to poor hygiene conditions.

column1: • The inventors of the present invention provide a metal lining to shield the inner wall of the receptacle, which is known by their patent document 1.

column2: • The metal lining is formed as a shield inside the cup, with a number of teeth projected from the inner wall of the lining for grinding the fibers of vegetable and fruit.

• The lining can be shaped as a half-mask or whole mask.

column1: • The conventional blender has a cup and a set of blades installed within the base of the cup.

column2: • When the blades are rotated in high speed, the vegetable and fruit will be grated until they become liquid, forming a whirlpool.
• The whirlpool brings the rough and long fibers to the outer circle in contact with the inner wall by centrifugal force.
• The rough and long fibers are not swirled into the center of the whirlpool but whirl around the outer circle thereof.

column1: • The present invention aims to provide a container of the blender that reduces the stirring time for promptly providing juice.

column2: • The rigid lining shields the inner wall of the receptacle from collision of rigid material.
• The fibers remained in the teeth on the inner wall of the lining can be ground and cut into pieces.
• The duration of grating fruit and vegetable can be reduced, and the related ""oxidization"" activity of the juice exposed in air will also be decreased.

column1: • The lining can be combined to the cup by injection molding or mounted inside the cup.

column2: • The lining has a number of teeth projected from the inner wall of the lining for grinding the fibers of vegetable and fruit.
• The teeth can be arranged in parallel with one another or arrayed in alignment with each other.
• The lining can be made of metal, glass, alloy, or non-alloy material.

column1: • The cup has a handle and a spout, and several vertical ribs are protruded",0

* Garnish pick design

column2: * The garnish pick has one or more appendages emerging from a main shaft, angled toward a sharp end of the main shaft.

* The pick can be made of various materials, such as wood, plastic, metal, or ceramic.

column1: * Advantages of the garnish pick

column1: 206,"<summary>
• The present invention relates to a cardiac assist system that combines a cardiomyostimulator and a cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator.

column2: • The system provides cardiac assistance during a cardiac arrhythmia and permits rapid detection of a cardiac arrhythmia.

column1: • The system features a sensor to monitor cardiac electrical activity and cardiac demand in a skeletal muscle-powered cardiac assist system.

column2: • The system includes a pulse generator that delivers stimulation to a skeletal muscle graft and senses depolarizations of a patient's heart.

column1: • The pulse generator includes a R-wave detection circuitry that sets a threshold corresponding to a predetermined percentage of the amplitude of a sensed R-wave.

column2: • The threshold level is not adjusted in response to paced R-waves, but instead continues to approach the minimum threshold level following paced R-waves.

column1: • The system operates in various states, including normal sinus rhythm, VT counting mode, VF counting mode, deliver VT therapy, deliver VF therapy, and VT/VF termination detection.

column2: • The system temporarily stops or inhibits skeletal muscle stimulation once the onset of an arrhythmia is sensed.

column1: • The system provides skeletal muscle stimulation while charging for defibrillation, which helps maintain cardiac perfusion and limits the increase in defibrillation threshold.

column2: • This feature allows the device to deliver a defibrillation pulse with a lower energy level.",1

column1: 207,"<summary>
• The invention relates to an accommodating intraocular lens (IOL) device

column2: • The IOL device has a lens chamber and a base lens

column1: • The base lens is coupled to the lens chamber via a lens periphery

column2: • The base lens is more rigid than the lens chamber

column1: • The lens periphery has a circumferential edge that engages the capsular bag of the eye

column2: • The lens periphery has a radial portion and a circumferential hinge
• The hinge permits the lens periphery to pivot radially inwardly towards the lens chamber
• The radial portion transmits the radial compressive force onto the lens chamber

column1: • The IOL device may have a hollow space or circumferential channel to reduce the delivery profile

column2: • The IOL device may have a plurality of apertures or through-holes to facilitate fluid flow
• The IOL device may have raised bumps or troughs to facilitate fluid flow
• The IOL device may have a circumferential channel and radial arms to facilitate fluid flow

• The fluid or gel may be a polyphenyl ether or a fluorinated polyphenyl ether
