438,<summary>

column1: * 18F and USDS are two organizations that aim to improve the federal government's IT services.

column2: * 18F provides development and consulting services to agencies, while USDS recruits and places digital service experts in strategic roles at agencies.

column1: * 18F has five business units: Custom Partner Solutions, Products and Platforms, Transformation Services, Acquisition Services, and Learn.

column2: * These units provide services such as custom software solutions, cloud computing services, and agile software development.

column1: * USDS provides consulting services to agencies, including quality assurance, problem identification, and software engineering.

column2: * USDS also develops guidance for agencies, such as the Digital Services Playbook and the TechFAR Handbook.

column1: * Both 18F and USDS have developed goals and performance measures to assess their progress.

column2: * However, not all of their goals and performance measures are outcome-oriented, and they have not fully implemented important program management practices.

column1: * The majority of agencies that have worked with 18F and USDS are satisfied with the services they received.

column2: * However, some agencies have expressed dissatisfaction with certain aspects of the services, such as poor customer service and higher-than-expected costs.",1

column1: 439,"<summary>
* The baby boom generation is aging, and this will lead to significant changes in the ratio of working-age population to retirees.

column2: * By 2030, there will be fewer than three persons of traditional working age for every person age 65 or over.
* The aged dependency ratio will rise from 21% in 2000 to 35% by 2030.

column1: * The labor force growth rate is slowing, and the number of older workers will grow substantially over the next two decades.

column2: * The number of older workers will grow rapidly over the next two decades, from 18.4 million in 2000 to 31.8 million in 2015.
* The percentage of older persons who participate in the labor force has been growing, especially among females age 55-64.

column1: * Older workers hold jobs in a wide range of occupations, with a shift towards white-collar and service occupations.

column2: * Nearly the same percentage of workers in different age groups are employed in white-collar occupations.
* The shift towards white-collar occupations is partially explained by differences in educational attainment among the baby boom generation.

column1: * Older workers are less likely to lose their jobs, but those who do are less likely to return to work.

column2: * Older workers who lose their jobs are more likely to retire following the job loss.
* The desire to return to work among fully retired older persons who have lost a job varies according to education and race.

column1: * Employers are using flexible employment arrangements to retain and extend the careers of older workers.

column2: * These arrangements include part-time work, seasonal or part-year work, consulting or contracting, and reduction of job responsibilities.
* Few employers have implemented these programs, and they are often limited to skilled workers with expertise.

column1: * Public sector employers have been more active in initiating broad programs to provide incentives for older workers to stay on the job.

column2: * These programs include Deferred Retirement Option Plan (DROP) features that allow pension participants to have pension benefits start while continuing to work.
* State and local government employers have implemented programs to encourage older employees to remain on the job, driven by teacher shortages.

column1: * Internal Revenue Code requirements may discourage private employers from adopting DROP plans and other programs.

column2: * Pension regulations prohibiting in-service distributions of defined benefit pension benefits can discourage the formation of DROP programs.
* Federal regulations governing nondiscrimination in pension benefits or contributions can restrict employers from offering phased retirement programs.

column1: * A variety of factors contribute to discouraging the continued labor force participation of workers after a",0
440,"<summary>
* The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) allows nationals from participating countries to travel to the US for business or pleasure without a visa for 90 days or less.

column2: * The program was established in 1986 and has expanded to 36 countries.
* The program's purpose is to facilitate legitimate travel while maintaining national security.

column1: * The Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) was implemented in 2008 to enhance security and facilitate travel.

column2: * ESTA requires travelers to provide biographical information and answer eligibility questions before traveling to the US.
* ESTA has reduced the burden on travelers by reducing the need for manual forms and allowing for faster processing at ports of entry.

column1: * The 9/11 Act requires VWP countries to enter into information-sharing agreements with the US, including agreements on lost and stolen passports and terrorist watchlists.

column2: * As of 2011, 19 VWP countries had signed HSPD-6 agreements, and 18 had signed PCSC agreements.
* The agreements have improved information sharing, but some countries have been slow to implement them due to legal and technical issues.

column1: * DHS conducts biennial reviews of VWP countries to evaluate their continued participation in the program.

column2: * The reviews examine counterterrorism and law enforcement capabilities, border control, and security procedures.
* However, DHS has not completed half of the mandated biennial reports in a timely manner, with some reports being over 4 years overdue.

column1: * The VWP has facilitated travel for millions of people, but DHS still needs to complete its review of cases of passengers traveling without verified ESTA approval.

column2: * The review will help determine the extent to which ESTA has mitigated VWP risks.
* DHS oversight of noncompliant travelers may reduce the risk of security breaches.",1

column1: 441,"<summary>

• State child welfare systems are complex networks of policies and programs designed to protect children, but growing caseloads have strained their ability to keep pace with the needs of troubled children and their families.

column2: • The federal government plays a crucial role in financing foster care and establishing minimum procedural requirements for the placement process.
• The Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 requires states to make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes.

column1: • States have implemented various initiatives to expedite and improve the permanency process, including:

column2: • Reuniting children with their families more quickly
• Expediting the termination of parental rights when reunification is not feasible
• Reducing the number of different foster care placements in which children live

column1: • Some states have implemented concurrent planning, which involves working towards reuniting a family while developing an alternate plan for permanently removing the child if reunification efforts fail.

column2: • This approach has shown promising results, such as in Colorado, where 87% of children achieved permanent placement within 1 year of initial placement.
• Concurrent planning requires coordination and resources, and its success depends on various factors, including leadership involvement and stakeholder buy-in.

column1: • Evaluations of these initiatives are often lacking, making it difficult to assess their overall impact and identify unintended consequences.

column2: • The lack of evaluation data hinders the ability of program officials and policymakers to fully understand the initiatives' effectiveness.
• Systematic evaluations are necessary to determine the success of these initiatives and identify areas for improvement.

column1: • States have identified critical factors required to meet the challenges of improving the permanency planning process, including:

column2: • Long-term involvement of officials in leadership positions
• Involvement of key stakeholders in developing consensus and obtaining buy-in
• Availability of resources to plan, implement, and sustain the project

column1: • The expected rise in foster care caseloads will place increasing pressure on states to develop initiatives to move children into permanent homes more quickly.

column2: • These initiatives will need to address the difficult issues of deciding under what circumstances to pursue reunification and what time period is appropriate before seeking the termination of parental rights.
• Developing and successfully implementing these innovative approaches takes time and often challenges long-standing beliefs.</summary>",0

column1: 442,"<summary>
* The DATA Act aims to improve federal spending transparency by requiring agencies to report their expenditures and link them to federal program activities.

column2: * The act requires agencies to report financial and award information, including budgetary resources, obligations, and outlays, as well as award-level data, such as award IDs and descriptions.
* The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Department of the Treasury are responsible for implementing the act, including developing guidance and systems for agencies to report their data.

column1: * Agencies face challenges in implementing the DATA Act, including:

column2: * Data quality issues, such as inaccurate or incomplete data, and difficulties in linking financial and award data.
* System integration challenges, including integrating financial and award systems, and ensuring that data is accurately reported and validated.

column1: * OMB and Treasury have taken steps to address these challenges, including:

column2: * Developing guidance and technical assistance for agencies, such as the DATA Act Implementation Playbook and the DATA Act Broker.
* Establishing a data governance framework to ensure data quality and consistency across agencies.",1

column1: 443,"<summary>
• The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) contracted with MPRI for an organizational assessment, but the contracting process was flawed.

column2: • The sole-source justification was inadequate, and the contracting officer did not properly evaluate the price reasonableness.
• The Deputy Special Counsel and other OSC officials performed duties that should have been performed by the contracting officer.

column1: • The OSC's use of an intermittent consultant, Alan J. Hicks, was appropriate and consistent with OPM regulations.

column2: • Hicks' tasks were related to addressing OSC's backlog and were consistent with OPM regulations.
• Hicks' work was valued by OSC officials, who believed he added value to the agency.",0

column1: 444,"<summary>
• VA's IT infrastructure is critical to its mission, but faces challenges in several areas:

column2: • The department operates approximately 240 information systems, manages 314,000 desktop computers and 30,000 laptops, and administers nearly 460,000 network user accounts.
• Many of VA's systems are old, with two systems over 50 years old, including the Personnel and Accounting Integrated Data system and the Benefits Delivery Network.
• The department has a plan to modernize or replace legacy systems, including the Human Resources Information System Shared Service Center and the Veterans Benefits Management System.
• VA has requested appropriations to improve IT systems, including enhancing health care-related systems, modernizing systems supporting benefits delivery, and improving internal IT systems.

column1: • VA's IT challenges affect its ability to provide health care and benefits to veterans:

column2: • The department's failed attempts to modernize its outpatient appointment scheduling system have led to delays and errors.
• VA's inability to electronically share data across facilities has led to difficulties in tracking medical devices and tissue products.
• The department's lack of electronic health record systems that permit efficient exchange of patient health information with DOD has hindered interoperability.
• VA's plans to modernize its electronic health record system, VistA, are ongoing, but the department has not identified outcome-oriented goals and metrics to measure progress.

column1: • VA's IT management is undergoing transformation:

column2: • The department's CIO has initiated an effort to transform the focus and functions of the Office of Information and Technology.
• The CIO's transformation strategy includes stabilizing and streamlining processes, mitigating weaknesses, and improving outcomes.
• The department is establishing five new functions within OI&T, including an enterprise program management office, an account management function, and a data management organization.
• The transformation strategy is expected to be completed by the first quarter of fiscal year 2017.

column1: • GAO has made several recommendations to VA to improve its IT management:

column2: • The department should identify and plan to modernize or replace legacy systems, including establishing time frames, activities, and functions to be replaced or enhanced.
• VA should develop a plan with a time frame and a reliable cost estimate for completing the Veterans Benefits Management System.
• The department should establish goals for system response time, minimize system defects, and assess user satisfaction.
• VA should develop a sound written plan for modernizing its claims processing system, including a detailed schedule, estimated costs, and performance goals.",1

column1: 445,"Here is the summary of the text in 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* HCFA's size and authority make it unique among health care payers

* Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) introduces new health plan options and payment reforms
* BBA provides for a dramatic expansion of health plan choices and reforms payment methods

column1: * HCFA's traditional approach of hiring generalist staff is no longer suitable

column2: * Managers need staff with specialized technical expertise
* Need for specialists in contracting, facilities management, and telecommunications
* Many senior and midlevel managers and experienced technical staff have retired or are eligible to retire soon

column1: 446,"<summary>
* FAA Funding Structure

column2: * The current funding structure is primarily supported by the Trust Fund (82%) and General Fund revenues (18%).
* The Trust Fund receives revenues from excise taxes paid by users of the National Airspace System (NAS).
* The excise taxes are associated with purchases of airline tickets, aviation fuel, and cargo shipments.
* The Trust Fund provides funding for FAA's capital accounts, including the Airport Improvement Program (AIP) and Facilities and Equipment (F&E) account.

column1: * Proposed Changes to Funding Structure

column2: * The administration's reauthorization proposal would change the funding structure to one based on cost-based charges.
* Funding for the Air Traffic Organization (ATO) would come primarily from user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation aircraft.

* Funding for AIP, Essential Air Service (EAS), and part of the Research, Engineering, and Development (RE&D) account would come from an equal fuel tax on both general and commercial aviation and a tax on arriving and departing international passengers.
* Funding for Safety and Operations would include some fees, but mostly General Fund contributions.

column1: * Concerns with Current Funding Structure

column2: * FAA has expressed concerns about the long-term revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency of the current funding structure.
* Revenues from the current funding structure depend heavily on factors not connected to FAA's workload and costs.
* Increases in FAA's workload may not be accompanied by revenue increases because users are not directly charged for the costs they impose on the NAS.
* The current funding structure does not provide a direct link between revenues and costs.

column1: * Cost Allocation Study

column2: * FAA's cost allocation study assigns costs to users based on aircraft type and usage.
* The study divides users into two groups: high-performance aircraft and piston aircraft.
* The study has raised concerns about the methodology used to allocate costs.
* Further analysis and discussion may be needed to reach a consensus on the cost allocation methodology.

column1: * Equity Issues

column2: * The administration's proposal to fund AIP through a fuel tax on commercial and general aviation operators raises equity issues.
* Commercial aviation users would pay a large share of the benefits that come from capital spending at general aviation airports.
* An alternative approach would be to use General Fund revenues to fund part of AIP.
* This approach would be consistent with a policy choice to charge general aviation users less than the cost of the benefits they receive from AIP grants.

447,<summary>

* GSA's Networx program faces significant challenges in finalizing its program strategy to ensure that Networx is appropriately defined, structured, and managed to deliver telecommunications services and solutions that will enable federal agencies to most efficiently and effectively meet their mission needs.

column2: * Ensuring that adequate inventory information is available to planners to provide an informed understanding of governmentwide requirements, establishing measures of success to aid acquisition decision-making and enable effective program management, structuring and scheduling the Networx contracts to ensure that federal agencies have available to them the competitively priced telecommunications services they need to support their mission objectives, and initiating the implementation planning actions needed to ensure a smooth transition from current contracts to Networx.

column1: * GSA must overcome significant challenges and demonstrate solid leadership to accomplish the goals of the Networx program, including resolving issues related to inventory management, measures of success, contract structuring, and transition planning.

column2: * Stakeholder commitment is critical, and actions taken and decisions reached in the coming months to more fully define the Networx program and finalize an appropriate acquisition strategy will significantly influence the telecommunications choices federal agencies will have for the next several years.",1

column1: 448,"<summary>
• FSA manages and administers student financial assistance programs authorized under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965.

column2: • FSA provides more than $50 billion in student aid to approximately 8 million students and their families annually.
• The student financial aid environment is large and complex, involving about 5,300 schools, 4,100 lenders, and 36 guaranty agencies.
• FSA oversees or directly manages approximately $200 billion in outstanding loans representing about 100 million borrowers.

column1: • FSA was established as a PBO in 1998 to improve service, reduce costs, and increase accountability.

column2: • PBOs are discrete management units remaining in their current department under the policy guidance of the department secretary.
• PBOs are to commit to clear management objectives and specific targets for improved performance.
• FSA has taken several steps toward developing and implementing a strategic direction.

column1: • FSA's performance plan discusses its three strategic goals: increase customer and employee satisfaction while decreasing unit cost.

column2: • The plan includes measures for gauging FSA progress in meeting each of these strategic goals.
• FSA uses the American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI) and the Gallup Q12 to measure customer and employee satisfaction, respectively.
• FSA's scores on both the ACSI and Gallup Q12 increased from fiscal year 1999 through fiscal year 2001.

column1: • FSA's unit cost measure has some limitations, including not including all program obligations and changing its calculation method.

column2: • The Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board (FASAB) recommends that agencies provide information on the full costs of programs and their outputs.
• FSA's unit cost measure may not fully reflect progress made or lack of progress with regard to systems integration.
• FSA's customer satisfaction measure may not capture technological progress in integrating its systems.

column1: • FSA has developed strategies to ensure program integrity, including providing technical assistance to schools and working to prevent defaults.

column2: • FSA's draft fiscal year 2002 performance plan includes goals for default management, but lacks details on strategies to achieve these goals.
• FSA has not yet implemented a performance management system to fully develop and assess its employees.
• FSA's human capital senior manager has not been an active participant in setting FSA's strategic direction.

column1: • FSA has taken steps to better organize its services and manage its employees, but gaps exist in its human capital strategy.

column2: • FSA has reorganized its operations",0

column1: 449,"<summary>
* NIH made over 21,500 grant awards using Recovery Act funds, with grants varying in size, geographic distribution, award duration, and research methods.

column2: * The grants were made to three categories, and recipients were required to report on the number of jobs supported by the Recovery Act on a quarterly basis.

column1: * NIH officials reported that Recovery Act funds could eventually support a total of approximately 54,000 FTEs, with the number of FTEs supported by NIH Recovery Act funding generally increasing from December 2009 to June 2011.

column2: * The Star Metrics program is expected to provide additional information about the number and types of jobs funded by the Recovery Act.

column1: * Principal investigators reported using Recovery Act funding to purchase supplies and equipment, contract for specialized services, and provide scientific training to health care professionals, with many reporting preliminary results from their research projects that could contribute to future scientific developments.

column2: * Examples of preliminary results include the prevention of diseases, early detection of diseases, improvements in medical therapies, and improved research capabilities.",1

column1: 450,"<summary>
* Transit-oriented development (TOD) is a type of development that is compact, mixed-use, and walkable, located near transit stations.

column2: * TOD can increase access to employment, educational, cultural, and other opportunities by promoting transportation options.
* It can also reduce road congestion and promote more efficient use of land.
* Local governments can support TOD through policies such as zoning regulations, station area planning, and targeted infrastructure investments.

column1: * Factors that support TOD include market demand for real estate, available land for development, supportive local residents, and efficient access to job and activity centers.

column2: * Construction costs can be higher for TOD due to the cost of mixed-use buildings and parking garages.
* Lenders may be reluctant to finance TOD projects due to perceived risk.
* Local approval processes can add requirements or delays to TOD projects.

column1: * Local governments can use various policies to encourage TOD, such as zoning regulations, station area planning, and tax incentives.

column2: * These policies can help resolve contentious issues and provide guidance for development.
* They can also help mitigate environmental challenges to TOD.
* Examples of successful TOD policies include transit-oriented development districts and area plans.

column1: * FTA assesses several factors that can support TOD when reviewing transit projects for funding, including mobility improvements, environmental benefits, congestion relief, economic development, and land use.

column2: * These factors make up one-third of the summary project justification rating and one-sixth of the project's overall rating.
* FTA evaluates many of the same factors that stakeholders identified as supportive of TOD.
* However, there are limitations to the extent to which some factors can be fully evaluated.

column1: * The amount of TOD realized and the factors that support or hinder it are generally consistent with FTA's pre-construction evaluation and rating of factors related to TOD.

column2: * Ridership performance of transit lines can vary, with some projects exceeding ridership expectations and others falling short.
* Development patterns and acceptance of dense, urban living can be influenced by cultural factors.
* FTA's evaluations are based on a snapshot of a specific moment in time that may not necessarily be predictive of future economic or political cycles.

column1: * The report highlights the multiple challenges faced by local governments in guiding development around transit.

column2: * FTA has a long-standing commitment to encouraging local land use actions near major transit capital investment.
* Authorizing statutes have increased the prominence of land use and economic development for FTA's Capital Investment Grant evaluation process.
* FTA believes that transit",0

column1: 451,"<summary>
* The Social Security Administration (SSA) introduced the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement (PEBES) in 1988 to provide workers with their earnings records and benefit estimates.

column2: * The PEBES is mailed to eligible workers who have not requested a statement according to a schedule.
* The goal of the PEBES is to inform the public about benefits available under SSA's programs and to assist workers in planning for their financial future.
* The PEBES also helps ensure that Social Security earnings records are complete and accurate.

column1: * The PEBES is a significant initiative for SSA, with a projected cost of $80 million in fiscal year 2000.

column2: * The cost includes $56 million for production costs and $24 million for personnel costs.
* SSA estimates that 608 staff-years will be required to handle the PEBES workload in fiscal year 2000.
* The PEBES benefit estimates are intended to help workers plan for their financial future.

column1: * The PEBES benefit estimates are based on certain assumptions about an individual's future employment and earnings.

column2: * SSA assumes that individuals will continue to work until they retire and that their future earnings will remain about the same as their most recent earnings.
* Experts agree that SSA's approach to estimating future retirement benefits is reasonable.
* However, the PEBES estimates may not take into consideration certain special circumstances that could affect a worker's actual retirement benefit.

column1: * The PEBES has undergone several revisions based on feedback from the public and SSA employees.

column2: * The statement has been revised to include an estimate for retirement at age 62.
* SSA has applied a computerized readability formula to the statement to ensure it can be understood by those who read at a seventh-grade level.
* However, the statement still provides too much information and is too complex.

column1: * The public's reaction to receiving an unsolicited PEBES has been consistently favorable.

column2: * In a nationally representative survey, the majority of respondents indicated they were glad to receive their statements.
* Respondents also indicated that the information provided was helpful to their families.
* Older individuals reacted more favorably to receiving a PEBES than did younger individuals.

column1: * SSA has not collected detailed information from its front-line workers on the public's response to the PEBES.

column2: * Research suggests that people find forms, notices, and statements difficult to use and understand.
* A design expert suggested that the PEBES should include an obvious purpose",0

column1: 452,"<summary>
• SSA administers two programs: Disability Insurance (DI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI), with different purposes and requirements, but sharing a common definition of disability.

column2: • DI is an insurance program that replaces lost earnings due to disability, requiring a specified number of work credits.
• SSI provides a minimum income level for individuals with disabilities, aged, or blind, with no work history requirement.
• Both programs have work incentive provisions to encourage beneficiaries to return to work.

column1: • Concurrent beneficiaries receive benefits from both DI and SSI programs, comprising about 14% of SSA's disability population.

column2: • They are more likely to have mental impairments and be female, with an average age of 45.
• About 11% of concurrent beneficiaries work, with median earnings of $250 per month.
• They often do not take advantage of work incentives available to them.

column1: • SSA's guidance for administering DI and SSI programs can make it difficult for staff to serve concurrent beneficiaries.

column2: • The guidance is voluminous and lacks integrated instructions for processing work information.
• Specialists in one program may not be familiar with the other program's rules.
• This can lead to incomplete or incorrect information being collected and shared.

column1: • SSA's procedures for determining DI benefit amounts when concurrent beneficiaries work can lead to overpayments.

column2: • Field offices may not receive cases back from program service centers in a timely manner.
• Tasks related to adjusting benefits may be given lower priority than other workloads.
• This can result in overpayments of about $350 million in 2001.

column1: • SSA has taken steps to improve service to concurrent beneficiaries, including creating an employment support representative position.

column2: • This position concentrates on the needs of disability beneficiaries who work.
• The representative receives extensive training in both DI and SSI work incentive provisions.
• It is unclear whether this position will be made permanent.

column1: • SSA is developing a new computer system to collect information on DI beneficiaries' earnings.

column2: • The system will allow for systematic monitoring of actions needed to adjust benefits.
• It is scheduled for release at the end of 2002.
• The system's effectiveness is yet to be determined.

column1: • Concurrent beneficiaries need to understand the complex interaction of the two programs to make informed decisions about work.

column2: • SSA's public information materials do not provide an integrated explanation of the effects of work on both benefits.
• Beneficiaries may make decisions that are not in their best interest due to lack of understanding.

453,<summary>
* The federal government provided $88 billion in funding for hurricane relief and recovery efforts through four emergency supplemental appropriations acts.

column2: * The funding was allocated to 23 federal agencies, with FEMA receiving the largest share of $42.6 billion.
* The funding was intended to support disaster relief and recovery efforts, including search and rescue missions, debris removal, and individual and household assistance.

column1: * FEMA's reporting on the use of funds was limited and did not provide a complete picture of government-wide spending.

column2: * FEMA's reports only included information on obligations and expenditures made directly by the agency, and did not account for funds obligated or expended by other agencies performing mission assignments on behalf of FEMA.
* This limited reporting made it difficult for decision-makers to track the overall progress of the relief and recovery efforts.

column1: * The mission assignment process used by FEMA to task other agencies with disaster relief work created timing differences between FEMA's and the performing agencies' records.

column2: * Performing agencies recognized expenditures when they paid costs, while FEMA did not recognize the reimbursement as an expenditure until it had reviewed and approved the supporting documentation.
* This process resulted in FEMA's reported expenditures being understated, and did not reflect the actual amount of funds spent by performing agencies.

column1: * The lack of a government-wide framework for reporting on hurricane relief and recovery funding made it difficult to track the overall progress of the efforts.

column2: * There was no central collection point for reporting on the use of funds, and each agency was responsible for tracking its own funding and reporting internally.
* This made it difficult to determine how much funding had been spent, what it had been spent on, and how much was still available.

column1: * The reporting requirements included in the emergency supplemental appropriations acts were inconsistent and did not provide a complete picture of government-wide spending.

column2: * Some agencies were required to report quarterly, while others had no reporting requirements at all.
* The reporting requirements did not cover funding authority received through FEMA's mission assignment process.

column1: * The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) was responsible for collecting and consolidating information on the use of hurricane relief and recovery funding.

column2: * OMB was required to report to the Appropriations Committees on a periodic basis, but did not have a framework in place for government-wide reporting.
* OMB's reporting did not provide a complete picture of government-wide spending, and did not account for funds obligated or expended by performing agencies.

column1: * The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommended that FEMA take four actions to improve the information on the status",0
454,"<summary>
• FAA has authority to authorize all UAS operations in the national airspace, including military, public, and civil operations, and has developed a comprehensive plan and roadmap for UAS integration.

column2: • The plan includes three phases: accommodation, integration, and evolution, with the goal of seamlessly integrating UAS flight into the national airspace.

column1: • FAA has taken steps to facilitate UAS integration, including issuing a notice of proposed rulemaking for small UAS operations, selecting six UAS test sites, and working with industry stakeholders to develop an implementation plan.

column2: • The agency has also worked to address challenges to UAS integration, including the need for public education and awareness, and the development of technologies to support UAS operations in the national airspace.",1

column1: 455,"Here is the summary of the text in 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* CERP efforts in Afghanistan focus on development and construction, whereas in Iraq, the focus is on reconstruction of neglected or damaged infrastructure.

column2: * The program has evolved over time in terms of cost and complexity of projects.
* The number of projects costing more than $500,000 has increased from 9 in FY 2004 to 129 in FY 2008.

column1: * Management and execution of CERP is the responsibility of officials at CJTF-101 headquarters, brigades, and PRTs.

column2: * CJTF-101 personnel include the CERP manager, staff attorney, and resource manager.
* The command engineering section reviews construction projects over $200,000.

column1: * DOD faces significant challenges in providing adequate management and oversight of CERP due to an insufficient number of trained personnel.

column2: * Personnel at all levels expressed a need for more personnel to perform CERP program management and oversight functions.
* Key duties such as performing headquarters staff assistance visits and site visits to monitor project status and contractor performance were not performed or not consistently performed.

column1: * DOD has not conducted a workforce assessment of CERP to identify how many military personnel are needed to effectively and efficiently execute and oversee the program.

column2: * Commanders determine how many personnel will manage and execute CERP, which can lead to inconsistencies.
* The lack of personnel has resulted in delays and inefficiencies in the program.

column1: * Training for CERP personnel is inadequate, with many receiving little or no training on their duties and responsibilities.

column2: * Personnel believed they needed more quality training to perform their missions effectively.
* Inadequate training has led to common mistakes in CERP contracts and project files.

column1: * Coordination mechanisms are in place to facilitate coordination among U.S. agencies executing development projects in Afghanistan.

column2: * Teams have been formed to integrate U.S. government civilians and military personnel to enhance coordination.
* A USAID representative is located at the CJTF-101 headquarters to help coordinate projects costing $200,000 or more.

column1: * Despite coordination mechanisms, military and USAID officials lack a common database to track development projects in Afghanistan.

column2: * Development projects are tracked in separate databases, making it difficult to identify previous and ongoing projects.
* A unified database is being developed to capture reliable and verified data for all development projects in Afghanistan.

column1: * The expected surge in troops and funding for Afghanistan heightens the need for an adequate number of trained personnel to execute",0
456,"<summary>
* The report identifies 65 federal initiatives that support solar energy technologies, with a focus on research and development and commercialization.

column2: * These initiatives are implemented by six federal agencies: DOD, DOE, EPA, NASA, NSF, and USDA.
* The initiatives support various types of solar energy technologies, including photovoltaics, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water.

column1: * The initiatives support different technology advancement activities, including basic research, applied research, demonstration, and commercialization.

column2: * The majority of initiatives (69%) support more than one type of technology advancement activity.
* The initiatives provide funding to various types of recipients, including universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal laboratories and researchers.

column1: * The initiatives have different funding mechanisms, including grants, contracts, cooperative agreements, and loans.

column2: * The majority of initiatives (55%) use grants and contracts as their primary funding mechanisms.
* DOE's initiatives account for the majority of funding obligations, with over $2.3 billion in obligations in fiscal years 2010 and 2011.

column1: * The report finds that the initiatives are fragmented across the six agencies, with some overlap in their goals and activities.

column2: * However, the report does not find clear evidence of duplication of efforts among the initiatives.
* Agency officials reported engaging in various coordination activities to avoid duplication and leverage resources.

column1: * The report identifies several key practices that can help enhance and sustain federal agency coordination, including establishing joint strategies, developing mechanisms to evaluate and report on progress, leveraging resources, and defining common outcomes.

column2: * Agency officials reported engaging in these practices, including participating in interagency working groups and coordinating through program and project management and review processes.
* The report suggests that enhanced coordination among agencies and initiatives could help to minimize duplication and maximize the impact of federal investments in solar energy technologies.",0

column1: 457,"<summary>
* The Department of Defense (DOD) has determined that servicemembers must be protected to survive and conduct effective military operations in a chemically and biologically contaminated environment.

column2: * DOD supplies servicemembers with a protective ensemble consisting of a suit, mask with breathing filter, rubber boots, butyl gloves, and hoods as required, but the current equipment has limitations and is not fully interoperable across the services.

column1: * DOD's risk assessment process is flawed and unreliable, and the Department has inaccurately assessed the risk to military operations as low.

column2: * The risk is actually higher than reported by DOD, and inadequate inventory management has contributed to increased risk, including miscalculating suit requirements, failing to count parts of the suit inventory, and counting suits as part of the inventory long before they are actually delivered from manufacturers.",1

column1: 458,"<summary>
* Program evaluations are systematic studies that use research methods to address specific questions about program performance.

column2: * They assess the achievement of a program's objectives and other aspects of performance in the context in which the program operates.
* They can provide a valuable supplement to ongoing performance reporting by measuring results that are too difficult or expensive to assess annually.

column1: * Evaluations can be key in program planning, management, and oversight by providing feedback on both program design and execution.

column2: * They can help identify areas where additional evaluations or analyses are needed.
* They can facilitate sharing what works with others.

column1: * The Government Performance and Results Act (GPRA) Modernization Act of 2010 established an expectation that evidence would have a greater role in agency decision making.

column2: * It changed agency performance management roles, planning and review processes, and reporting to ensure that agencies use performance information in decision making.
* It required agencies to establish agency priority goals and government-wide cross-agency priority goals.

column1: * The Performance Improvement Council, which includes Performance Improvement Officers (PIOs) from all 24 CFO Act agencies, facilitates agencies' exchange of successful practices and development of tips and tools to strengthen agency performance management.

column2: * OMB's guidance implementing GPRA also directed agencies to conduct strategic reviews of annual progress toward each strategic objective in their strategic plans.
* These reviews aim to inform agency strategic decision making, budget formulation, and preparation of annual performance plans and reports.

column1: * Federal managers reported that evaluations contributed to a great or very great extent to improving program management or performance and assessing program effectiveness.

column2: * They also reported that evaluations contributed to developing or revising performance goals, sharing what works or other lessons learned with others, and designing or supporting program reforms.
* Evaluations were less likely to contribute to allocating program resources or informing the public.

column1: * Managers who reported having evaluations identified lack of resources to implement evaluation findings as the most common barrier to evaluation use.

column2: * They also reported that lack of staff knowledgeable about interpreting or analyzing program evaluation results and lack of ongoing top executive commitment or support for using program evaluation were barriers to evaluation use.
* Difficulty distinguishing between results produced by the program and results caused by other factors was also a barrier.

column1: * Factors that facilitate evaluation use include agency leadership support for evaluation, staff involvement, and evaluation relevance to decision makers.

column2: * Other facilitating factors include clear implications of results for improving program design or management, agency policies and procedures to ensure evaluation quality, and consultation with stakeholders on the agency's evaluation agenda.

column1: 459,"<summary>
• The federal government has taken steps to improve the hiring and retention of individuals with disabilities, but more work is needed to achieve the goals of the executive order.

column2: • OPM has developed a model strategy for agencies to increase the hiring of individuals with disabilities, but many agency plans do not meet the criteria identified by OPM.

• The executive order requires OPM to implement a system for reporting regularly to the president, heads of agencies, and the public on agencies' progress in implementing the objectives of the executive order.

column1: • To ensure that the federal government becomes a model employer of individuals with disabilities, OPM should take three actions:

column2: • Incorporate information about plan deficiencies into its regular reporting to the president on agencies' progress in implementing their plans.
• Expedite the development of the mandatory training programs for hiring managers and human resource personnel on the employment of individuals with disabilities.
• Assess the extent to which the SF-256 accurately measures progress toward the executive order's goal and explore options for improving the accuracy of SF-256 reporting, if needed.",0

column1: 460,"<summary>
• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is developing the Automated Land and Mineral Record System (ALMRS) to manage public lands and resources.

column2: • The system will provide a common information technology platform, integrating multiple databases, and automating land and mineral records and case processing activities.
• It will also increase public access to BLM records through the Internet and provide information to support land and resource management activities.

column1: • The ALMRS project has a total life-cycle cost estimate of $403 million and is expected to be completed by the end of fiscal year 1996.

column2: • The project has been meeting most of its schedule milestones, but there is little time available to deal with unexpected problems, and slippages could occur.
• BLM has taken actions to closely monitor the project status and schedule to avoid slippages.

column1: • The system will be deployed at approximately 200 BLM sites around the country and will be implemented on a common information technology platform.

column2: • The platform will consist of servers, terminals, workstations, and networks interconnected via local, state, and national-level networks.
• The system will provide connections to the Internet and will be protected by firewall systems for security purposes.

461,"<summary>

• The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has strengthened its safeguards to detect and prevent the diversion of nuclear material for military purposes, but faces challenges in implementing these measures effectively.

column2: • The IAEA's strengthened safeguards include the Additional Protocol, which allows for more intrusive inspections and monitoring, but its implementation is limited by the lack of cooperation from some countries, including India, Israel, and Pakistan.
• The IAEA also faces a human capital crisis, with many senior inspectors and managers retiring in the next few years, which could compromise the quality of analysis of countries' nuclear programs.

column1: • The Nuclear Suppliers Group, a multilateral export control regime, has helped to stop, slow, or raise the costs of nuclear proliferation, but its effectiveness is limited by the lack of consensus among its members and the lack of enforcement mechanisms.

column2: • The Group's guidelines have helped to establish common standards for the export of nuclear materials and equipment, but its members do not always share information about approved exports, which can create loopholes for proliferators.
• The Group's decision-making process is also slow and often blocked by individual members, which can hinder its ability to respond to new proliferation challenges.",1

column1: 462,"<summary>
* The Year 2000 computing crisis poses a high risk to critical services provided by the government and private sector.

column2: * Financial transactions could be delayed, flights grounded, power lost, and national defense affected.
* The crisis could also have a significant impact on key economic sectors, including information and telecommunications, banking and finance, and healthcare.

column1: * The information and telecommunications sector is particularly vulnerable, as it is critical to the operations of nearly every public and private organization.

column2: * The sector's failure could have a ripple effect throughout the economy, disrupting the delivery of essential services.
* The government and private sector must work together to address the crisis and ensure the continuity of critical operations.

column1: * The global nature of the problem adds an additional layer of complexity, as many countries are not adequately prepared to address the crisis.

column2: * A survey of 127 countries found that only 18 had a national Year 2000 program in place, while 65 countries had not reported any progress.
* The lack of international coordination and cooperation could exacerbate the problem and make it more difficult to resolve.

column1: * The federal government's progress in addressing the crisis has been slow, with only 40% of mission-critical systems reported as Year 2000 compliant.

column2: * Many agencies have not adequately assessed their systems, and there is a lack of clear priorities and contingency plans.
* The government must take immediate action to address the crisis and ensure the continuity of critical operations.

column1: * State and local governments also face significant risks, as they rely heavily on computer systems to provide essential services.

column2: * A survey of state governments found that only one-third had completed assessments of their critical systems, and many were not on track to meet the deadline.
* State and local governments must work together with the federal government and private sector to address the crisis and ensure the continuity of critical operations.

column1: * Data exchanges between government agencies and the private sector are also at risk, as many systems are not Year 2000 compliant.

column2: * The failure of these exchanges could have a significant impact on the delivery of essential services, such as social security benefits and tax refunds.
* The government and private sector must work together to ensure the continuity of data exchanges and prevent disruptions to critical operations.

column1: * The crisis requires strong leadership and partnerships between the government and private sector to address the problem and prevent disruptions to critical operations.

column2: * The government must take immediate action to address the crisis, including setting clear priorities and contingency plans.
* The private sector must also take steps",0

column1: 463,"<summary>
* IQA consists of two major elements: developing guidelines for ensuring the quality of information and establishing a mechanism for correcting errors.

column2: * The first element requires federal agencies to develop guidelines for ensuring the quality of information they disseminate.
* The guidelines are to apply to a wide variety of government information dissemination activities.
* The guidelines define four key concepts related to the dissemination of information: quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity.

column1: * OIRA developed governmentwide IQA guidelines and helped agencies develop their own guidelines.

column2: * OIRA's guidelines explained what agencies were to do to help ensure the development and public dissemination of quality information.
* The guidelines encouraged agencies to incorporate the standards and procedures into their existing administrative practices.
* OIRA reviewed agency guidelines and provided assistance to agencies in developing their guidelines.

column1: * Agencies were required to establish an administrative mechanism for correcting errors in the information they disseminate.

column2: * The mechanism allows affected parties to request correction of information that they believe is incorrect.
* The mechanism includes an appeals process, which allows petitioners to request reconsideration of an agency's initial decision.
* Agencies were required to post their IQA guidelines and correction mechanisms on their websites.

column1: * The implementation of IQA has been uneven, with some agencies not having IQA guidelines in place.

column2: * Many independent agencies did not have IQA guidelines or correction mechanisms in place.
* Some agencies did not post their IQA information on their websites, making it difficult for the public to access.
* OMB did not provide sufficient guidance to agencies on implementing IQA.

column1: * OMB and agencies do not track the resources and costs associated with implementing IQA.

column2: * Agencies do not capture specific workload or cost data related to establishing IQA guidelines or responding to IQA requests.
* OMB does not have mechanisms in place to track the effects of implementing IQA.
* The lack of data makes it difficult to assess the impact of IQA on agency operations.",0

column1: 464,"<summary>
* Mutual funds and banks are financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and channel them back to the economy.

column2: * They invest in securities, primarily bonds and stocks.
* The funds flow either directly or indirectly to the issuers of these securities.

column1: * The relative importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining since the 1960s.

column2: * Large businesses have been replacing bank loans with short-term securities called commercial paper.
* Corporations have also been tapping the securities markets for their financial needs.

column1: * The household sector has become less dependent on bank loans for financing.

column2: * Banks and thrifts have been selling mortgage portfolios to financial intermediaries, who use them as collateral for marketable securities.
* Consumers' credit card debt and automobile loans have also been financed by securities instead of bank credit.

column1: * The term securitization describes the process of securities issuance supplanting bank credit as a source of finance.

column2: * Banks and thrifts provide the initial financing, but once the loans are sold, the securities market is the ultimate source of financing.
* Nonbank financial intermediaries, including securities firms, insurance companies, and finance companies, have also been providing direct loans.

column1: * The impact of mutual funds on deposits has been significant, with a sizable amount of money flowing from deposits to mutual funds.

column2: * The total net flows into mutual funds from all sources during 1990-1994 were $1,067 billion.
* The impact on deposits had to be less than this amount because there were also flows into mutual funds from nondeposit sources.

column1: * The movement of money from bank deposits to mutual funds has little effect on the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy.

column2: * Both mutual funds and banks generally invest a substantial portion of the funds they receive.
* The funds' purchases of securities add liquidity to the securities markets, making it easier for borrowers to tap the markets.

column1: * The availability of finance for different sectors (residential, consumer, and business) could be disproportionately affected by the movement of funds out of bank deposits and into mutual funds.

column2: * Residential finance has been extensively securitized, with banks and thrifts investing in mortgage-backed securities.
* Consumer credit is still largely provided by commercial banks, but securitization of automobile loans and credit card receivables has increased.

column1: * The supply of finance to the corporate sector has increased, with corporations raising new funds on the securities markets.

column1: 465,"<summary>
• The Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002 requires specific activities related to bioterrorism preparedness and response.

column2: • The act calls for steps to improve the nation's preparedness for bioterrorism and other public health emergencies.
• It also requires the establishment of an integrated system of public health alert communications and surveillance networks.

column1: • CDC's PHIN initiative is a national initiative to implement a multiorganizational business and technical architecture for public health information systems.

column2: • PHIN has substantial size and scope, and is intended to serve as a comprehensive architecture, information exchange network, and set of services.

• It is intended to improve public health systems and networks and provide a means for exchanging data with other federal agencies, state and local government agencies, and the private health care sector.

column1: • DHS is also pursuing major public health IT initiatives, including the National Biosurveillance Integration System and the Biological Warning and Incident Characterization System (BWICS).

column2: • These initiatives are primarily focused on signal interpretation and biosurveillance.
• One of the associated programs, BioWatch, is operational, but has interoperability and other limitations.

column1: • Despite federal, state, and local government efforts to strengthen the public health infrastructure, important challenges continue to constrain progress.

column2: • These challenges include the need to coordinate among federal, state, and local public health agencies, and the need to address specific weaknesses in IT planning and management.

• The national health care IT strategy and federal health architecture are still being developed, and CDC and DHS face challenges in integrating their public health IT initiatives into these ongoing efforts.",1

column1: 466,"<summary>
* Large sponsors of DB pension plans have made changes to their benefit offerings over the past 10 years, including:

column2: * Modifying benefit formulas, converting to hybrid plans, and freezing plans
* 81% of respondents modified benefit formulas, 52% converted to hybrid plans, and 62% froze plans
* These changes were driven by factors such as unpredictability of funding requirements and global competitive pressures

column2: * 46% of respondents no longer offering retiree health benefits to new hires
* 54% of respondents decreasing or eliminating their share of health benefit costs for future retirees

467,"<summary>
* The refugee resettlement process in the United States is complex and involves multiple stakeholders, including federal agencies, national voluntary agencies, and local service providers.

column2: * The process is guided by the Refugee Act of 1980, which aims to provide a systematic and permanent procedure for admitting and resettling refugees in the United States.

column1: * The federal government provides funding and guidance to support refugee resettlement, but the actual resettlement process is carried out by national voluntary agencies and local service providers.

column2: * These agencies and providers are responsible for providing essential services to refugees, including housing, food, clothing, and medical care, as well as longer-term services such as employment training and language classes.

column1: * Despite the efforts of these stakeholders, the refugee resettlement process faces several challenges, including limited resources, inadequate communication and coordination, and varying levels of capacity and preparedness among local service providers.

column2: * These challenges can lead to difficulties in providing adequate services to refugees, particularly in areas with high concentrations of refugees or limited resources.",1

column1: 468,"Here is the summary of the text in 9 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) was established in 1968 to provide flood insurance to homeowners and businesses, reducing the federal government's costs for repairing flood damage.

column2: * NFIP is managed by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) within the Department of Homeland Security.

column1: * The program has been strengthened by several pieces of legislation, including the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973 and the National Flood Insurance Reform Act of 1994.

column2: * These laws made flood insurance mandatory for properties in vulnerable areas with mortgages from federally regulated lenders.

column1: * NFIP has mapped flood risks across the country, assigning flood zone designations based on risk levels, which determine premium rates.

column2: * The program offers two types of flood insurance premiums: subsidized and full risk.

column1: * Subsidized premium rates, which represent about 40-45% of the cost of covering the full risk of flood damage, apply to about 22% of all NFIP policies.

column2: * These rates do not reflect the actual risk of loss, making the program less likely to pay claims in years with catastrophic losses.

column1: * To reduce or eliminate subsidized and grandfathered rates, premium rates could be increased to reflect the full risk of loss.

column2: * This would decrease costs for taxpayers by reducing borrowing to pay claims and encourage private market participation.

column1: * Mitigation efforts, such as elevation, relocation, and demolition, can reduce flood damage to properties and communities.

column2: * FEMA has taken steps to help homeowners and communities mitigate properties, but the number of repetitive loss properties has increased.

column1: * Increasing participation in NFIP would help ensure that losses from flood damage do not become the responsibility of taxpayers.

column2: * Expanding participation would require careful implementation to avoid increasing the concentration of high-risk properties in the program.

column1: * Encouraging private market participation could transfer some or all of the federal government's risk exposure to the private markets.

column2: * This could be achieved through strategies such as requiring private market coverage for all property owners or providing options to private insurers to help lower the cost of coverage.

column2: * The program is authorized by Section 287(g) of the Immigration and Nationality Act.
* The program is managed by ICE's Office of State and Local Coordination (OSLC).
* The program has grown rapidly, with 67 participating agencies as of October 2008.

column1: * The program lacks several management controls, including documented objectives, clear guidance on the use of 287(g) authority, and defined supervision activities.

column2: * ICE has not documented the program's objectives in program-related materials.
* ICE has not consistently communicated to participating agencies how and under what circumstances 287(g) authority is to be used.
* ICE has not defined the responsibilities required of ICE agents directing and supervising local officers.

column2: * ICE's limited detention resources may be burdened by participating agencies seeking assistance for aliens detained for minor crimes.
* ICE may not have the information it needs to ensure participating agencies are adhering to program objectives.
* ICE's ability to ensure management directives are being carried out appropriately may be hampered.

column1: * ICE is working to develop performance measures for the program.

column2: * ICE has not established a plan, including a time frame, for the development of performance measures.
* ICE has initiated compliance inspections for the 287(g) program.

column1: 470,"<summary>
* SEC oversees mutual funds through the Office of Compliance Inspections and Examinations (OCIE), Division of Investment Management, and Division of Enforcement.

column2: * OCIE examines mutual funds to evaluate compliance with federal securities laws and assess the effectiveness of their compliance control systems.
* The Division of Investment Management administers the securities laws affecting funds and advisers.

column1: * The Division of Enforcement investigates and prosecutes violations of securities laws related to mutual funds.

column2: * SEC regulates mutual funds under the Investment Company Act of 1940, the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, the Securities Act of 1933, and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
* The Investment Company Act requires mutual funds to register with SEC and imposes requirements on their operation and structure.

column1: * SEC has made significant changes to its traditional examination approach, focusing on targeted examinations and continuous monitoring of large funds.

column2: * The agency has reallocated staff to conduct targeted examinations focusing on specific risks and monitoring larger funds on a continuous basis.
* This approach offers the potential for SEC to more quickly identify emerging risks and better understand the operations of large and complex funds.

column1: * SEC has established the Office of Risk Assessment (ORA) to analyze risk across divisional boundaries.

column2: * ORA will enable SEC to identify and analyze evidence of potential risks and make better, more informed decisions on regulation.
* ORA will work with other SEC offices to identify new technologies, such as data mining systems, to help detect and track risks.

column1: * SEC's revised examination priorities involve tradeoffs that raise regulatory challenges.

column2: * The agency may limit its capacity to examine the operations of lower-risk funds within a reasonable period.
* SEC's inability to conduct examinations of all mutual funds within a reasonable period may limit its capacity to accurately distinguish higher-risk funds from lower-risk funds.

column1: * SEC has integrated quality controls into its routine examinations, but could benefit from additional controls.

column2: * The agency could improve its quality control measures in three areas: supervisory review of risk scorecards, preparation of written examination plans, and review of completed examinations and work papers.
* Federal bank and other regulators have quality control measures that provide assurances above and beyond those used by SEC.

column1: * SEC's risk scorecards are critical work papers, but the agency does not require supervisors to document their review of the scorecards.

column2: * Without documenting the review of scorecards, SEC does not know if deficiencies resulted from a lack of or inadequate supervisory review.
* The systematic supervisory review of work papers",0

472,"<summary>
* First City Bancorporation's financial difficulties

column2: * In the late 1970s, First City had a high concentration of loans to the energy industry in the Southwest US
* The energy industry's financial difficulties in the early 1980s affected First City's financial health
* By 1986, First City was reporting operating losses

column1: * FDIC's open bank assistance in 1988

column2: * FDIC provided $970 million in capital infusion to First City
* The agreement required First City to reduce its subsidiary banks from 60 to 20
* The agreement also created a ""collecting bank"" to dispose of troubled assets

column1: * First City's recapitalization and growth

column2: * First City's assets grew from $10.9 billion to $13.9 billion between 1988 and 1990
* The bank's loan portfolios included high-risk loans, such as leveraged transactions and international loans
* First City reported profits of $183 million and paid $122 million in cash dividends

column1: * Regulatory concerns and intervention

column2: * OCC and FDIC closely monitored First City's financial condition and identified concerns with loan quality and management practices
* OCC and FDIC considered various resolution alternatives, including acquisition and liquidation
* First City proposed several self-rescue plans, but they were rejected by regulators

column1: * Closure and resolution of First City banks

column2: * OCC declared First City-Houston insolvent and appointed FDIC as receiver in October 1992
* FDIC placed the failed banks into interim bridge banks and estimated the cost of resolution to be $500 million
* The sale of the bridge banks in January 1993 resulted in a surplus of $60 million

column1: * Lessons learned from the First City resolution

column2: * The need for realistic economic assumptions and consultation among regulators
* The importance of including safeguards in financial assistance agreements
* The need for clear and complete documentation of regulatory decisions and actions",1

column1: 473,"<summary>
• The Single Audit Act was passed in 1984 to improve oversight and accountability of federal funds provided to state and local governments, and nonprofit organizations.

column2: • The act requires recipients of federal funds to undergo a single audit, which includes an audit of their financial statements, internal control, and compliance with laws and regulations.
• The audit is performed by an independent auditor and is intended to provide a comprehensive picture of the recipient's use of federal funds.

column1: • The quality of single audits has been a concern since the 1980s, with reports of deficiencies in audit planning, internal control testing, and compliance testing.

column2: • A 2002 study by the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency (PCIE) found that 51% of single audits had significant deficiencies, including lack of documentation and inadequate testing.
• The study recommended improvements to single audit standards, training for auditors, and enhanced oversight and disciplinary processes to address unacceptable audits.",0

column1: 474,"<summary>
• Medicare is a federal health insurance program that assists elderly and disabled beneficiaries, with two main parts: hospital insurance (Part A) and supplemental medical insurance (Part B).

column2: • Part A covers inpatient hospital, skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and certain home health services.
• Part B covers physician and outpatient hospital services, laboratory and other services.

column1: • Claims are processed by a network of 49 claims administration contractors called intermediaries and carriers.

column2: • Intermediaries process Part A claims from hospitals and other institutional providers.
• Carriers process Part B claims.

column1: • Medicare contracting differs from most federal programs, with no full and open competition for contracts.

column2: • Intermediaries are selected through a nomination process by provider associations.
• Carriers are chosen by the Secretary of Health and Human Services from a small pool of health insurers.

column1: • Medicare could benefit from contracting reforms, including competitive contracting and performance-based payment.

column2: • This could lead to efficiency and performance improvements, as well as address concerns about the dwindling number of insurers.
• It could also allow for specialization in specific functions and termination of contracts more efficiently.

column1: • The program has used health insurers to process and pay claims since its implementation in 1966.

column2: • The number of contractors has declined, and the need to broaden the pool of entities has increased.
• The explosion in information technology has increased the potential for using new types of business entities to administer claims processing.

column1: • Allowing Medicare to have separate contractors for specific claims administration activities could improve program management.

column2: • This could enable the agency to select contractors that are more skilled at certain tasks and allow them to concentrate on those tasks.
• It could also lead to better program service and uniformity in efforts to educate and respond to providers and beneficiaries.

column1: • Offering financial incentives to contractors for high-quality performance could also have benefits.

column2: • This could lead to improved program operations and potentially lower administrative costs.
• However, implementing performance-based contracting will not be without significant challenges.

column1: • Allowing Medicare to terminate contractors more efficiently may also promote better program management.

column2: • The Social Security Act limits the agency's ability to terminate intermediaries and carriers.
• CMS has requested statutory authority to eliminate the public hearing requirement and the ability of contractors to unilaterally initiate contract termination.

column1: • Implementing changes to Medicare's contracting authorities will require time and care to avoid disrupting program services.

column2: • CMS would need to develop clear statements of work and contractor selection criteria, integrate new contractors into claims processing",0

column1: 475,"<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) aims to increase modernization investments without increasing overall defense budgets by reducing support operations and infrastructure costs.

column2: • DOD recognizes that portions of its support structure are inefficient and absorb a large share of the defense budget.
• The Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD) requested the Defense Science Board (DSB) to identify DOD activities that the private sector could do more efficiently.
• The DSB issued two reports in 1996 addressing outsourcing and other opportunities for reducing infrastructure costs.

column1: • The first DSB report focused on outsourcing and privatization, concluding that DOD could realize savings of 30-40% of logistics costs by outsourcing support services.

column2: • The report cited evidence from the Center for Naval Analyses (CNA) public-private competition studies.
• The DSB task force stated that an aggressive DOD outsourcing initiative could generate savings ranging from $7 billion to $12 billion annually by fiscal year 2002.
• The report recommended that DOD only provide warfighting, direct battlefield support, policy- and decision-making, and oversight activities.

column1: • The second DSB report provided a new vision for DOD, where the private sector would perform all activities except warfighting, direct battlefield support, policy- and decision-making, and oversight.

column2: • The report estimated that DOD would need to make an investment of about $6 billion but would ultimately save about $30 billion annually by 2002.

• The estimated savings included $6 billion from CONUS logistics infrastructure activities, with $4.2 billion from outsourcing and $1.8 billion from improvements in inventory management practices and equipment reliability.
• The report recommended that DOD make an investment in contractor logistics support and prime vendors to achieve economies and significant savings.

column1: • The Program Analysis and Evaluation (PA&E) directorate assessed the DSB's savings estimates and concluded that the estimate was overstated by about $1 billion and that another $3 billion in projected savings would be difficult to achieve or unlikely to be achieved.

column2: • PA&E officials believed that about $2 billion of the savings was achievable or already identified in DOD's future year defense program.
• The remaining $2 billion of the DSB's savings estimate was unlikely to be saved primarily because of timing and DOD's culture.
• PA&E's assessment concluded that the DSB's savings estimate was not well supported and was unlikely to be as large as estimated.

column1: • The Office of Housing consolidated routine, location-neutral activities into fewer offices, such as the Denver Homeownership Center, to reduce processing times and improve customer service.

column2: • The office also implemented paperless processing of mortgage record changes, default reporting, and other record changes.
• Office of Housing officials believed employees generally had the appropriate skills and experience to maintain performance during downsizing.

column1: • The Office of Housing reported that the creation of new methods to deal with its workload, such as the single family homeownership centers and work sharing, had allowed it to maintain, and in some cases, improve performance.

column2: • Trend data for one goal, to close sales on 95 percent of each year's single family inventory, were available and showed closed sales were 95 percent of inventory in fiscal year 1994, 109 percent in fiscal year 1995, and 194 percent in fiscal year 1996.
• Office of Housing officials believed customers were satisfied with their performance, citing feedback from lending institutions and a decreased number of complaints.

column1: • The Department of the Interior (DOI) reduced its workforce by almost 10,200 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996.

column2: • The Bureau of Reclamation (BOR) shifted its mission emphasis from water project construction to water resources management, including water conservation, environmental restoration, and solutions to the water problems of Native Americans and urban water suppliers.

• BOR reengineered its Denver facilities into the Reclamation Service Center to provide administrative, research, scientific, and technical services to BOR, other DOI organizational components, water districts, and others.

column1: • BOR officials believed BOR employees had the appropriate skills and experience to maintain performance amid downsizing, although they also believed additional younger people needed to be hired.

column2: • To develop a cadre of people to be future supervisors and managers, BOR was rotating people among functions and retraining them.
• Employees we spoke with generally agreed that BOR had the necessary skills, but they were concerned about the future.
