509,"<summary>
* USCIS processes millions of immigration benefit applications each year, detecting and referring suspicious information for fraud investigation.

column2: * In fiscal year 2005, USCIS received about 6.3 million applications and adjudicated about 7.5 million applications.
* USCIS has a staff of about 3,000 permanent adjudicators located in 4 service centers and 33 district offices.

column1: * USCIS has established the Fraud Detection and National Security (FDNS) office to combat fraud and foster a positive control environment.

column2: * FDNS has developed a strategy for detecting immigration benefit fraud, including identifying vulnerabilities in policies and procedures.
* FDNS has established Fraud Detection Units (FDU) in each service center to help identify potential fraud and process adjudicator referrals.

column1: * USCIS has taken steps to detect fraud, including conducting fraud assessments and developing an automated capability to screen incoming applications against known fraud indicators.

column2: * FDNS has completed fraud assessments for religious worker and replacement of permanent resident card applications.
* FDNS plans to initiate additional assessments in the future.

column1: * However, USCIS lacks a comprehensive approach to managing risk, including a plan for assessing the majority of benefits it administers.

column2: * USCIS has not fully incorporated threat and consequence information into its fraud assessments.
* USCIS has not applied a risk-based approach to evaluating alternatives for mitigating identified vulnerabilities.

column1: * USCIS does not have a mechanism to ensure routine feedback to FDNS about vulnerabilities identified during normal operations.

column2: * USCIS does not have a clear communication strategy for balancing multiple agency objectives.
* USCIS lacks performance goals related to fraud prevention.

column1: * USCIS has not established a strategy and methodology for prioritizing future fraud assessments.

column2: * USCIS has not extended fraud assessments to additional benefit types, including temporary work authorization.
* USCIS has not incorporated a comprehensive threat assessment into its fraud assessments.

column1: * USCIS has not verified any eligibility evidence for any benefit, despite its potential to help mitigate vulnerability to fraud.

column2: * USCIS adjudicators do not have access to commercial databases that provide identification and credential verification.
* USCIS does not have a policy of verifying key information or interviewing applicants in all cases.

column1: * USCIS's policy of granting interim employment authorization documents can be exploited by aliens seeking to gain work authorization under false pretenses.

column2: * USCIS's policy may serve to reduce the negative effects of delay on applicants and their families.
* USCIS is evaluating alternative strategies to balance fraud control with other agency objectives.

column1: 510,"<summary>
• IRS' performance during the 1994 filing season

column2: • Processed income tax returns and refunds accurately and efficiently
• Provided taxpayers access to forms, information, and electronic filing methods
• Achieved many of its goals for processing tax returns and assisting taxpayers
• However, there were some problems, including refund fraud and difficulties in reaching IRS by telephone

column1: • Refund fraud

column2: • The number of detected fraudulent refund claims increased significantly in 1994
• Almost all of the fraudulent returns identified by IRS involved the Earned Income Tax Credit (EIC)
• IRS has taken steps to reduce fraud, including adding up-front computer checks and increasing staff for fraud detection
• However, it is unclear how much fraud might be going undetected

column1: • Electronic filing

column2: • The number of individual income tax returns filed electronically increased in 1994
• IRS offers three types of filing alternatives to traditional paper returns: electronic, TeleFile, and 1040PC
• Electronic and TeleFile use increased in 1994, while 1040PC use declined slightly
• IRS plans to expand TeleFile to all or parts of three more states in 1995

column1: • Refund timeliness and accuracy

column2: • IRS met its goals for refund timeliness and accuracy in 1994
• The average issuance time for refunds was 36 days, and the accuracy rate was 98.6%
• IRS measures refund accuracy by reviewing samples of nonelectronically filed returns
• Refund accuracy is an important indicator of IRS' performance

column1: • Lockboxes

column2: • IRS tested the use of lockboxes to improve check processing and deposit tax receipts more timely
• Lockboxes were used for estimated tax payments since 1989
• IRS conducted three lockbox tests during the 1994 filing season
• IRS plans to continue testing lockboxes and implement a nationwide lockbox collection process in 1996

column1: • Taxpayer service

column2: • Taxpayers had difficulty reaching IRS by telephone in 1994
• The accessibility rate for toll-free telephone assistance was 21%
• Taxpayers also had problems ordering forms and publications by telephone
• IRS plans to increase the number of telephone lines for TeleFile in 1995

column1: • Earned Income Tax Credit (EIC)

column2: • The EIC continues to be a source of errors by taxpayers and tax practitioners
• IRS changed its procedures in 199",0

column1: 511,"<summary>
* Medicaid was established in 1965 as a jointly funded federal-state program providing medical assistance to qualified low-income persons.

column2: * Each state designs and administers its own Medicaid program, subject to federal requirements for eligibility, services covered, and provider payments.
* The federal government pays a portion of whatever qualifying expenditures a state Medicaid program incurs.

column1: * Tennessee's demonstration project, TennCare, was designed to use a capitated managed care system to expand coverage to the uninsured population and to control total program and state costs.

column2: * TennCare was implemented on January 1, 1994, and was the first statewide demonstration project to move its Medicaid program enrollees to a capitated managed care system.
* The program was designed to expand health coverage by allowing non-Medicaid eligible persons to enroll and by extending the period of coverage for Medicaid-eligible persons.

column1: * TennCare contracts with health maintenance organizations (HMOs) and preferred provider organizations (PPOs) to operate as managed care organizations (MCOs).

column2: * The state requires HMOs to be licensed as such, and the primary contractual distinctions between HMOs and PPOs are administrative fees and operating profits.
* Most enrollees have a choice of four MCOs, and enrollees in metropolitan areas have a choice of as many as seven.

column1: * The federal spending limits apply to the total TennCare program expenditures, including Medicaid expenditures for services not covered under capitated payments, such as long-term care.

column2: * The federal government will provide no more than $12.165 billion for the 5-year TennCare waiver period.
* For every $1 in TennCare expenditures, the federal government pays approximately $.67 and the state pays approximately $.33.

column1: * The state benefits from federal funding provided to state mental hospitals for expanded TennCare coverage, some of which is not covered under Medicaid rules.

column2: * The state also benefits from federal cost sharing for expenditures for services to enrollees in state mental hospitals that are not normally covered by Medicaid.
* The state obtains revenue from state taxes on capitation payments made to MCOs.

column1: * HCFA permitted new requirements to address enrollee access to care and systems to evaluate the quality of care provided to substitute for the usual Medicaid quality assurance requirements and systems.

column2: * HCFA requires the TennCare Bureau to ensure adequate enrollee access to providers and quality of care.
* HCFA further requires the state to submit quarterly progress reports on quality of care, access",0

column1: 512,"<summary>
• The federal government's response to the crack epidemic in the 1980s was limited by inadequate drug detection mechanisms and a lack of coordination among agencies.

column2: • The National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) was aware of the spread of crack use through its drug detection mechanisms, but the national prevalence of crack use was not measured until the late 1980s.

column1: • Since the 1980s, changes have been made to improve drug detection mechanisms, including the expansion of the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse and the creation of new mechanisms such as the Arrestee Drug Abuse Monitoring program.

column2: • The Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) has also been established to coordinate the federal drug control effort and develop a national drug control strategy, and the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) has been created to focus on service delivery and prevention and treatment services.",1

column1: 513,"<summary>
• The worker-profiling initiative aims to identify unemployment claimants who are most likely to exhaust benefits and provide them with reemployment services to accelerate their return to work.

column2: • States use statistical models or characteristic screens to identify claimants, but many have not updated their models in years, which may affect their predictive accuracy.
• Labor recommends that states use statistical models, which are more efficient and precise, but some states use characteristic screens, which are less effective.

column1: • The reemployment services provided by states do not conform to Labor's original vision of in-depth services, including individualized needs assessments and service plans.

column2: • Instead, states provide orientation sessions and some job search assistance, but the services are not tailored to individual needs.
• States cite lack of funding and resources as a major challenge in providing effective reemployment services.

column1: • The effectiveness of the worker-profiling initiative is unclear due to limited and unreliable data, and Labor has not conducted a national study on the program's impact since the 1990s.

column2: • Research studies from the 1990s found that the program had positive effects, such as reducing UI duration and increasing employment earnings, but the results are outdated and may not reflect current practices.
• Labor's data collection and reporting requirements may need to be reevaluated to ensure that the data are useful for evaluating the program's effectiveness.",1

column1: 514,"<summary>

* The Medicare subvention demonstration was a pilot program that allowed military retirees to enroll in a Medicare-managed care plan, with the Department of Defense (DOD) providing care and Medicare paying a capitated rate.

column2: * The demonstration was designed to improve access to care for military retirees and reduce costs for both DOD and Medicare.

column1: * The demonstration resulted in higher utilization of services by enrollees, which increased DOD's costs, but did not result in a payment from Medicare to DOD due to the demonstration's payment rules.

column2: * The payment rules required DOD to meet a ""level of effort"" threshold, which was based on DOD's historical spending on care for military retirees, and any payment from Medicare was capped at a certain amount.",1

column1: 515,"<summary>

* NTSB has made significant progress in implementing leading management practices in eight areas, including communication, strategic planning, IT, knowledge management, organizational structure, human capital management, training, and financial management.

column2: * Three management recommendations have been fully implemented, including facilitating communication from staff to management, aligning organizational structure to implement a strategic plan, and correcting an Antideficiency Act violation.

* Eight management recommendations have made further progress, including reporting to Congress on the status of recommendations, linking all five mission areas in goals and objectives, and seeking external stakeholder comments.

column1: * NTSB has made progress in investigating accidents, including developing transparent policies for selecting which accidents to investigate and tracking the status of recommendations.

column2: * The agency has developed policies for selecting accidents to investigate in highway, marine, aviation, rail, pipeline, and hazardous materials modes.
* NTSB has also increased its use of safety studies, which are multiyear efforts that result in recommendations to improve transportation safety.

column1: * NTSB has improved its use of the Training Center, including increasing the use of classroom space and reducing the center's operating deficit.

column2: * The agency has subleased classroom space to other agencies, increasing revenues and reducing the deficit.
* NTSB has also increased the number of NTSB-related courses taught at the Training Center.

column1: * The agency has proposed changes to its authorizing legislation, including the authority to investigate incidents in addition to accidents and reducing requirements for investigating rail and maritime accidents.

column2: * The proposed changes would give NTSB more discretion in determining which investigations to conduct and would allow the agency to focus on investigations with the greatest potential to improve safety.
* The changes would also clarify the roles and responsibilities of NTSB and the U.S. Coast Guard in maritime accident investigations.

column1: * NTSB still faces challenges, including improving diversity in its workforce and management, and fully implementing its cost accounting system.

column2: * The agency's current workforce demographics present an opportunity to increase diversity, with over 50% of supervisors and managers eligible to retire in the next three years.
* NTSB has initiated actions to increase diversity, including establishing a Management Candidate Program and an Executive Development Program.",1

column1: 516,"<summary>
* GPRA is intended to shift the focus of government decisionmaking, management, and accountability from activities and processes to the results and outcomes achieved by federal programs.

column2: * New and valuable information on the plans, goals, and strategies of federal agencies has been provided since federal agencies began implementing GPRA.
* Annual performance plans are to clearly inform the Congress and the public of the annual performance goals for agencies’ major programs and activities.

* The measures that will be used to gauge performance, the strategies and resources required to achieve the performance goals, and the procedures that will be used to verify and validate performance information.
* Annual performance reports are to subsequently report on the degree to which performance goals were met.

column1: * EPA reported making progress toward achieving its long-term goal of safe and healthy air in communities.

column2: * The agency reported achieving its goals of improving air quality in areas that do not meet the National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) established by EPA under the Clean Air Act.
* The performance report acknowledges that there are some data limitations with the Aerometric Information Retrieval System for reporting NAAQS progress.
* EPA’s reported progress for its annual performance goal related to toxic air pollutant emissions relies on calculations and estimates.

column1: * EPA reported that it is making strides in achieving its goal of safe and clean drinking water.

column2: * The agency reported that it achieved its goal of having 91 percent of the population, served by community drinking water systems, receiving drinking water that meets all health-based standards that were in effect as of 1994.
* The agency further reported that it achieved its goal of reducing exposure to contaminated recreational waters by increasing information available to the public and decisionmakers.
* Concluding that both of these goals have been achieved, however, relies on information from sources with data limitations acknowledged by EPA.

column1: * EPA reported that it made progress in cleaning up hazardous waste sites and that most long-term commitments for the Superfund program were on track or ahead of schedule.

column2: * The agency reported that it exceeded its fiscal year 2000 goal of completing construction cleanup at 85 Superfund sites by having 87 sites with construction cleanup complete.
* While reaching this point may take many years, more time may be needed before all cleanup standards are achieved and some remaining long-term threats are addressed at the site.
* EPA works in partnership with state and tribal governments to clean up Superfund sites and ensure that parties responsible for the site contamination pay a fair share of the cleanup costs.

column1: * EPA",0
517,"<summary>
* The Corporate Information Management (CIM) initiative was launched in 1989 to improve business practices and eliminate duplicative information systems across seven administrative areas.

column2: * The initiative aimed to standardize and improve business processes through techniques such as business process reengineering and continuous process improvements.
* The CIM scope has broadened to include all DOD functional areas, including procurement, logistics, finance, and command and control.

column1: * The Joint Logistics Systems Center (JLSC) was established to achieve CIM goals for materiel management and depot maintenance business areas.

column2: * JLSC's charter is to work with the services and DLA to identify business process improvements and the appropriate application of information systems.
* JLSC expects that improvements to DOD's logistics functions will provide most of the CIM-related cost savings.

column1: * JLSC identified 20 near-term initiatives, including the Cataloging Tools On-Line system and the Depot Maintenance—Hazardous Material Management System.

column2: * These initiatives were designed to make current business processes more efficient and effective.
* The initiatives were expected to save the services more than $2 billion over time periods ranging from 5 to 20 years.

column1: * In 1992, the DOD Comptroller questioned the viability of the near-term strategy and recommended selecting and implementing standard information systems.

column2: * This led to a shift in JLSC's focus from implementing near-term initiatives to selecting migration systems for materiel management and depot maintenance.
* The selection of migration systems is expected to provide a foundation for significant improvements to current logistics practices.

column1: * Industry experts have advised DOD to focus on reengineering its business processes before improving automated information systems.

column2: * DOD's migration strategy has been criticized for prioritizing technology over process improvement.
* This approach may result in locking DOD into inefficient ways of doing business and not achieving the cost savings needed in the current environment of shrinking budgets.",0

column1: 518,"<summary>
• Undercover investigation

column2: • Produced counterfeit NRC documents and a bill of lading using commercial software
• Purchased a small amount of radioactive sources and a container from a commercial source over the phone

column1: • Border crossing 1 (northern border)

column2: • Investigators drove to an official port of entry with radioactive sources and counterfeit documents
• CBP inspector did not question the validity of the documents and allowed them to enter the US

column1: • Border crossing 2 (southern border)

column2: • Investigators drove to an official port of entry with radioactive sources and counterfeit documents
• CBP inspector used a RIID to scan the vehicle and asked to see the specialized equipment
• Investigators provided the counterfeit documents, and the CBP inspector did not question their validity

column1: • Results of the investigation

column2: • Demonstrated that radioactive sources could be transported into the US with counterfeit documents
• Showed that CBP inspectors did not verify the authenticity of the documents
• Highlighted the potential risk of a dirty bomb being created with the transported radioactive sources

column1: • Corrective action briefings

column2: • Briefed CBP officials on December 21, 2005, and they agreed to work with NRC to verify document authenticity
• Briefed NRC officials on January 12 and 24, 2006, and they disagreed with the amount of radioactive material needed for a dirty bomb

column1: • Conclusion

column2: • The investigation highlighted the vulnerability of the US border to the transportation of radioactive sources
• NRC officials are aware of the potential problems of counterfeiting documents and are working to resolve them
• The amount of radioactive sources transported during the operation could be used to produce two dirty bombs",0

column1: 519,"<summary>

• The Department of Defense (DOD) relies on research laboratories and test facilities, as well as industry and academia, to develop new technologies and systems to improve military operations and maintain technological superiority.

column2: • DOD has experienced problems in bringing technologies out of the lab environment and into real use, including inadequate demonstration of potential, lack of funding, and development of technologies in-house rather than relying on external sources.
• The Advanced Concept Technology Demonstration (ACTD) program, Foreign Comparative Testing (FCT) Program, and other initiatives have been established to address these issues.

column1: • The Technology Transition Initiative (TTI), Defense Acquisition Challenge Program (DACP), and Quick Reaction Fund are three new transition programs aimed at quickly moving promising technologies from the laboratory and commercial environment into actual use.

column2: • These programs have different focuses, such as saving time or money, or broadening the industrial base, and have been allocated increasing funding.
• The programs have reported benefits, including improvements to performance, affordability, and operational capability, but it is too early to determine their long-term impact.

column1: • The programs have limited performance measures to gauge project success and return on investment, making it difficult to assess their effectiveness.

column2: • Developing metrics to measure return on investment is challenging due to the wide range of projects and environments, but starting points may exist within DOD, such as the FCT program's metrics.
• The Naval Post Graduate School is studying metrics for the ACTD program, which could also be useful for the transition programs.

column1: • The ability to spur and leverage technological advances is vital to sustaining DOD's superiority, and the three new transition programs are targeted at solving the critical problem of quickly moving promising technologies into actual use.

column2: • The programs' management approaches and criteria can be used to help solve transition problems affecting the approximately $69 billion spent annually on advanced stages of technology development.
• The programs' flexibility and ability to experiment with different approaches are important, but they need to be balanced with the need for good performance measurement and management controls.

column1: • The Secretary of Defense should take actions to strengthen selection and management capabilities, including developing data and measures to support assessments of performance and return on investment.

column2: • The Secretary should also implement formal feedback mechanisms, formal agreements, and confirmation of technology readiness levels, as appropriate, for each program.
• The Secretary should assess how the Technology Transition Council can be better used to address broader technology transition problems.

column1: • DOD provided written comments on the report, partially concurring with four of the",0
520,"<summary>
• The Master Address File (MAF) is a data file containing a list of all known living quarters in the US and Puerto Rico, used to support the decennial census and other demographic surveys.

column2: • The MAF contains address information, census geographic location codes, and source and history data.
• It is updated through a complete address canvassing, which verifies virtually every existing MAF address and adds new ones.

column1: • The Bureau of the Census is researching the feasibility of conducting targeted address canvassing to reduce costs.

column2: • This approach would verify addresses in select areas that are more likely to require updates to the address list.
• The Bureau plans to increase its reliance on other sources of updates, including US Postal Service files, commercial database files, and input from state and local governments.

column1: • The Bureau's 2020 Research and Testing and GSS-I schedules exhibit some characteristics of a reliable schedule, but have important weaknesses.

column2: • The schedules substantially meet one of the four characteristics of a reliable schedule (controlled), but minimally or partially meet the other three (comprehensive, well constructed, and credible).
• The schedules lack detail, have incomplete logic, and include unnecessary constraints.

column1: • The Bureau's schedules do not provide a reliable means of gauging progress or identifying potential problems.

column2: • The schedules do not include information on resource needs and availability, and do not provide a true critical path.
• The Bureau's ability to focus on critical activities and manage risks is undermined by the schedules' shortcomings.

column1: • The Bureau has implemented some leading practices for collaboration, including establishing joint strategies and reinforcing individual accountability.

column2: • The Bureau has documented its goals and strategies for building a more cost-effective MAF, and has established coordination groups and memorandums of understanding.
• However, the Bureau has not fully incorporated collaboration into its schedules.

column1: • The Bureau's workforce planning process for scheduling staff is inadequate.

column2: • The Bureau has not identified the skills and training needed to ensure that staff can construct and maintain reliable schedules.
• The Bureau's reliance on contractors with certifications in scheduling software and project management methods is not sufficient.

column1: • The report recommends that the Bureau improve its scheduling practices, including ensuring comprehensiveness, constructing schedules with complete logic, and conducting quantitative risk assessments.

column2: • The report also recommends that the Bureau initiate a robust workforce planning process for scheduling staff.
• The Bureau concurred with the findings and recommendations.

column1: </summary>",0
521,"<summary>
• The Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 established a comprehensive federal law to regulate air pollution from stationary and mobile sources.

column2: • The act set national ambient air quality standards for pollutants, required states to develop implementation plans, and established a program to reduce acid deposition.

column1: • Title I of the act established a detailed program for attaining and maintaining national ambient air quality standards.

column2: • EPA was required to review and revise standards every 5 years and set boundaries for areas that did not meet standards.

column1: • Title III established a program to reduce emissions of hazardous air pollutants.

column2: • EPA was required to set technology-based standards for 189 air toxics and review and revise standards every 8 years.

column1: • Title IV established the acid deposition control program.

column2: • The program used a market-based trading program to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions from electric utilities.

column1: • EPA identified 452 actions required to meet the objectives of Titles I, III, and IV.

column2: • As of April 2005, EPA had completed 409 of the actions, with 256 of them being completed late.

column1: • The report found that EPA faced challenges in implementing the requirements, including the need to prioritize actions, develop policy frameworks, and engage in stakeholder participation.

column2: • EPA officials cited factors such as litigation, competing demands, and the need to review a large quantity of scientific information as contributing to delays.",1

column1: 522,"<summary>
* OJJDP established the Girls Study Group in 2004 to develop research on preventing and reducing girls' delinquency

column2: * The group's objectives included identifying effective programs, developing program models, and disseminating findings
* The group reviewed over 1,000 documents and identified 61 programs that targeted girls' delinquency
* The group assessed the methodological quality of the programs using DOJ's What Works criteria
* The group's efforts were consistent with social science research practices and standards

column1: * The Study Group found that few girls' delinquency programs had been studied and lacked conclusive evidence of effectiveness

column2: * 44 of the 61 programs had not been studied, and none of the 17 studied programs provided conclusive evidence of effectiveness
* The group reported a need for additional evaluations, training, and funding for girls' delinquency programs
* OJJDP plans to provide technical assistance and funding to support evaluations of promising programs

column1: * OJJDP's efforts to address girls' delinquency goals were inconsistent with internal control standards

column2: * OJJDP did not develop a plan that was documented, shared with stakeholders, and included specific funding requirements and time frames
* OJJDP officials stated that they are in transition and developing a plan for juvenile justice programs
* GAO recommended that OJJDP develop and document a plan to meet its girls' delinquency goals

column1: * OJJDP plans to take steps to address its girls' delinquency goals

column2: * OJJDP will provide technical assistance to help programs prepare for evaluations
* OJJDP will issue a solicitation for funding to support evaluations of girls' delinquency programs
* OJJDP will publish a juvenile justice program plan in the Federal Register to solicit public feedback

column1: * GAO's report and recommendation

column2: * GAO recommended that OJJDP develop and document a plan to meet its girls' delinquency goals
* OJP agreed with the recommendation and outlined efforts to address the findings
* GAO's report was based on a review of OJJDP's efforts to address girls' delinquency
* The report included recommendations for OJJDP to improve its efforts to address girls' delinquency",0

column1: 523,"<summary>
* DOD's finance and accounting operations

column2: * Before 1991, military services had separate finance and accounting operations that were duplicative and inefficient
* DFAS was created to standardize DOD finance and accounting policies, procedures, and systems
* Military services and defense agencies use operations and maintenance appropriations to pay for DFAS services
* DFAS sets prices and bills customers to cover full cost of operations

column1: * DFAS and military services' finance and accounting responsibilities

column2: * DFAS is responsible for performing most finance and accounting operations
* Military services retained certain functions, such as managerial accounting and customer service
* DFAS and military services share responsibility for travel payment, computation, and disbursement
* DFAS has 5 centers and 21 operating locations, while military services have finance offices at most installations

column1: * DOD's finance and accounting systems

column2: * DFAS has reduced the number of finance and accounting systems from 324 to 217
* Military services operate hundreds of feeder systems that are not included in DFAS' inventory
* DFAS is responsible for standardizing finance and accounting systems throughout DOD
* DFAS' migration strategy involves selecting one system from each service and implementing it servicewide

column1: * DOD's finance and accounting budget

column2: * DOD's total budget for finance and accounting activities exceeds $2 billion
* DFAS' budget is $1.64 billion, while military services estimate their personnel costs at $598 million
* DFAS' budget is expected to decrease by 10% by 2000
* Military services' finance and accounting activities are funded through operations and maintenance appropriations",1

column1: 524,"<summary>

• The Federal Reserve Act established the Federal Reserve as an independent agency with a decentralized structure to ensure that monetary policy decisions are based on a broad economic perspective from all regions of the country.

column2: • The Federal Reserve operates in a unique public and private structure, with the Board of Governors, 12 Reserve Banks, and the FOMC working together to promote maximum employment, stable prices, and moderate long-term interest rates.
• The Reserve Banks are not operated for profit, and their income is used to pay operational expenses, dividends to member banks, and to fund their capital surplus accounts.

column1: • The dividend rate on Reserve Bank stock was established at 6 percent to compensate member banks for the opportunity costs of providing capital and reserves to the Reserve Banks and to attract state-chartered banks to Federal Reserve membership.

column2: • The dividend rate has been modified over time, with the FAST Act reducing the rate for large member banks to the lesser of 6 percent or the 10-year Treasury rate.

• The modification has had no immediate effect on Federal Reserve membership, but has raised concerns about the independence of the Federal Reserve and the potential for future transfers of funds from the Reserve Banks to Treasury.",0

column1: 525,"<summary>
* The 1992 Act aimed to prevent motor vehicle theft by establishing a national motor vehicle title information system and a national stolen passenger motor vehicle information system.

column2: * The national motor vehicle title information system would enable states and law enforcement officials to instantly and reliably determine the validity of title documents and whether a vehicle has been junked or salvaged.
* The system would also provide a way to identify stolen vehicles and parts, and to prevent the sale of stolen vehicles and parts.

* The national stolen passenger motor vehicle information system would contain identification numbers of stolen passenger motor vehicles and parts, and would be maintained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).

column3: * The system would be used by law enforcement officials to investigate stolen vehicle cases and to recover stolen vehicles and parts.
* The system would also be used by insurance companies and other entities to verify the ownership and history of vehicles and parts.

column1: * The 1992 Act also established a task force to study problems related to motor vehicle titling, registration, and salvage, and to recommend ways to address these problems.

column2: * The task force recommended the establishment of uniform definitions for salvage and rebuilt vehicles, and the implementation of a national uniform antitheft inspection program for rebuilt salvage vehicles.

* The task force also recommended the establishment of a national uniform safety inspection program for rebuilt salvage vehicles, and the implementation of a system to track the exportation of vehicles.

column3: * The task force recommended that the system be funded through a combination of federal appropriations, state revenues, and user fees.

* The task force also recommended that the system be enforced through a combination of federal and state laws, and that penalties be imposed on individuals and entities that fail to comply with the system.

column1: * The 1992 Act also required the Attorney General to establish an advisory committee to develop and implement the national stolen passenger motor vehicle information system.

column2: * The advisory committee recommended that the system be operated by the National Insurance Crime Bureau (NICB), and that it be funded through a combination of federal appropriations and user fees.

* The advisory committee also recommended that the system be designed to provide automatic notification to law enforcement agencies of stolen vehicle and part hits, and that it be secured to prevent unauthorized access.

column3: * The advisory committee recommended that the system be designed to provide a user-friendly interface for law enforcement officials and other users.
* The advisory committee also recommended that the system be designed to provide regular reports and updates to law enforcement officials and other users.",0

column1: 526,"<summary>
* PSAOs provide various services to independent pharmacies, including:

column2: * Contract negotiation with third-party payers or their PBMs, communication, and help-desk services to assist with claims and reimbursement issues.

column1: * PSAOs vary in their requirements for member pharmacies, with some requiring participation in all contracts and others allowing pharmacies to choose from a portfolio of contracts.

* PSAOs are owned by various entities, including wholesalers, independent pharmacy cooperatives, and group purchasing organizations, and may offer PSAO services as a value-added service to their members or customers.
</summary>",0
527,"<summary>
• Enterprise architecture is a blueprint that describes an organization's current and desired state, as well as a plan for transitioning between the two states.

column2: • It is a recognized tenet of organizational transformation and IT management in public and private organizations.

column1: • The concept of enterprise architectures originated in the mid-1980s, and various frameworks have been published by government agencies and OMB.

column2: • These frameworks provide a common construct for developing and documenting architecture descriptions.

column1: • An enterprise architecture management maturity framework was developed to provide federal agencies with a common benchmarking tool for planning and measuring their efforts to improve enterprise architecture management.

column2: • The framework arranges 31 core elements into a matrix of five hierarchical maturity stages and four critical success attributes.

column1: • Most federal agencies have not fully satisfied all the core elements associated with stage 2 of the maturity framework.

column2: • However, many have satisfied a number of core elements at stages 3, 4, and 5.

column1: • The framework's core elements can be grouped into four categories: architecture governance, content, use, and measurement.

column2: • Most agencies have fully satisfied a large percentage of the governance-related elements, but fewer have satisfied the content, use, and measurement elements.

column1: • The state of federal agencies' architecture efforts varies widely, with some having developed robust programs and others still facing significant challenges.

column2: • Examples of successful programs include Commerce, which has satisfied 87% of the core elements, and SSA, which has satisfied 87% of the core elements.

column1: • The challenges facing agencies in developing and using enterprise architectures are formidable, including organizational parochialism, inadequate funding, and lack of skilled staff.

column2: • Sustained top management leadership is key to overcoming these challenges.

column1: • Many agencies have already accrued benefits from their architecture programs, including improved alignment between business operations and IT, improved information sharing, and increased productivity.

column2: • However, many benefits remain unrealized, and effective management of architecture programs is key to realizing this potential.

column1: </summary>",0
528,"<summary>
* The U.S.-Oman Free Trade Agreement (FTA) was signed on January 19, 2006, and aims to promote economic growth and trade between the two countries.

column2: * The agreement eliminates tariffs on goods and services, provides market access, and protects intellectual property, labor, and environmental standards.

column1: * The FTA has been supported by the business community, but has faced criticism from labor groups who argue that it does not do enough to protect workers' rights in Oman.

column2: * The agreement has also raised concerns about sweatshop conditions in Jordan and the potential for similar conditions in Oman.

column1: </summary>",1
529,"<summary>
• Concerns about hate crimes have become increasingly prominent among policymakers at all levels of government in recent years.

column2: • Hate crimes are defined as criminal offenses motivated by bias against a person's race, religion, disability, ethnic/national origin, or sexual orientation.

column1: • Congress has recognized the special concerns and effects of hate crimes by enacting several laws, including the Civil Rights Act of 1968, the Hate Crimes Statistics Act of 1990, and the Hate Crimes Sentencing Enhancement Act of 1994.

column2: • The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009 expanded the scope of hate crime victims to include gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability.

column1: • The commerce clause, section 5 of the 14th Amendment, and section 2 of the 13th and 15th Amendments are the grants of power most often mentioned when discussing Congress's authority to proscribe hate crimes.

column2: • The commerce clause authorizes Congress to regulate commerce with foreign nations and among the several states, but its scope is limited by the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Morrison.

column1: • The legislative clauses of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments give Congress the power to enforce the Amendments by appropriate legislation.

column2: • Section 2 of the 13th Amendment may be a more viable option for broadening hate crime legislation, as it proscribes slavery and involuntary servitude without reference to federal, state, or private action.

column1: • The Supreme Court has considered constitutional challenges to state hate crime statutes under the 1st and 6th Amendments.

column2: • The 1st Amendment requires that hate crime legislation distinguish between conduct and speech, and that it not punish speech, thought, or expression.

column1: • The 6th Amendment provides defendants a right to a jury trial, and limits the ability of judges to increase sentences based on findings of hate crimes.

column2: • The Supreme Court has struck down hate crime laws that allow judges to increase sentences without a jury trial, citing the 6th Amendment and due process clauses of the 5th and 14th Amendments.

column1: • There are other constitutional limits on hate crime legislation, including the requirement that it not be overbroad or content-based, and that it not shift the burden of proof to the defendant.

column2: • The Supreme Court has considered these limits in cases such as R.A.V. v. City of St. Paul, Wisconsin v. Mitchell, and Virginia v. Black.",0

column1: 530,"<summary>
* Exchange rate policies of East Asian nations, particularly China, Japan, and South Korea, have been a source of tension with the US.

column2: * These countries have been accused of intentionally keeping their currencies undervalued to gain a competitive advantage in global markets.
* This is seen as a violation of Article IV, Section 1(iii) of the IMF's Articles of Agreement.

column1: * The US Treasury is required to submit biannual reports to Congress on the exchange rate policies of foreign countries.

column2: * The reports analyze whether countries manipulate their currencies to prevent effective balance of payments adjustments or gain an unfair competitive advantage.
* The latest report, released in April 2017, placed six countries, including China, Japan, and South Korea, on a ""Monitoring List"".

column1: * East Asian governments have chosen exchange rate policies between the two extremes of a ""fixed"" or ""pegged"" exchange rate and a ""free float"".

column2: * A ""managed float"" policy allows the value of the currency to fluctuate in international markets until certain economic indicators reach critical levels.
* This policy is seen as a way to balance the need for exchange rate stability with the need for autonomy in monetary policy.

column1: * The IMF categorizes exchange rate policies into three categories: floating, fixed, and managed.

column2: * According to the IMF, only Japan allows its currency to float freely on international markets.
* Five countries, including South Korea, allow their currencies to float but reserve the right to intervene in markets to maintain stability.

column1: * China's exchange rate policy has been a subject of controversy, with some accusing it of manipulating its currency to gain a competitive advantage.

column2: * China officially maintained a ""crawling peg"" policy prior to the global financial crisis, but has since allowed its currency to appreciate gradually.
* The value of the renminbi has fluctuated significantly over the past 10 years, leading to accusations of currency manipulation.

column1: * Japan's yen has also undergone significant fluctuations in value over the past 10 years.

column2: * The value of the yen has been influenced by market confidence in Japan's economy and monetary policy.
* Some have accused Japan of intervening in foreign exchange markets to lower the value of the yen.

column1: * Some analysts have suggested that Southeast Asian countries, particularly those with close economic ties to China, have formed a ""renminbi bloc"".

column2: * These countries have been accused of adjusting their exchange rates to maintain competitiveness with China.
* The existence of a ""renminbi bloc"" is not universally",0

column1: 531,"<summary>
* The Role of the Chief of Mission (COM)

column2: * The COM is the principal officer in charge of a U.S. diplomatic mission to a foreign country, foreign territory, or international organization.
* The COM serves as the President's personal representative, leading diplomatic efforts and overseeing nearly all U.S. government activities in their country of assignment.

* The COM is responsible for coordinating and supervising all U.S. government executive branch employees in their country of assignment, except for those under the command of a U.S. Geographic Combatant Commander (GCC).
* The COM's authority is derived from the President's constitutional powers and is codified in the Foreign Service Act of 1980 and other legislation.

column1: * COM Authority and Responsibilities

column2: * The COM has full responsibility for the direction, coordination, and supervision of all U.S. government executive branch employees in their country of assignment.
* The COM is responsible for keeping fully and currently informed with respect to all activities and operations of U.S. government employees in their country of assignment.
* The COM has the authority to approve or disapprove the size, composition, and mandate of the staff at a diplomatic post.
* The COM is responsible for the security of all U.S. government personnel on official duty abroad and their accompanying dependents.

column1: * Effectiveness of COM Authority

column2: * The effectiveness of COM authority can be impacted by the COM's leadership and management skills, as well as the support they receive from the State Department and other agencies.
* The State Department's 2010 Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review (QDDR) emphasized the need for capable COMs to act as CEOs of U.S. embassies.
* The QDDR also highlighted the importance of improving COM training and education, as well as enhancing interagency coordination and cooperation.

* Some analysts have raised concerns about the ability of COMs to effectively exercise their authority in practice, citing weaknesses in leadership and management, as well as a lack of support from the State Department and other agencies.",1

column1: 532,"<summary>
• China's economy is heavily dependent on global trade and investment flows, with exports and FDI contributing significantly to its GDP growth.

column2: • Exports of goods and services as a share of GDP rose from 9.1% in 1985 to 37.8% in 2008.
• China's foreign trade sector employs over 80 million people, with 28 million working in foreign-invested enterprises.

column1: • The global economic slowdown has had a significant impact on China's export sector and industries that depend on FDI flows, with GDP growth slowing sharply in 2008 and early 2009.

column2: • Annual economic growth of less than 8% could lead to social unrest in China, given the large number of people seeking jobs every year.

column1: • China's exposure to the global financial crisis is unclear, with restrictions on capital flows limiting its exposure to sub-prime U.S. mortgages, but its government entities may have been more exposed.

column2: • China's holdings of U.S. securities totaled $1,205 billion as of June 2008, making it the second-largest foreign holder of such securities.

column1: • China has taken steps to respond to the global financial crisis, including cutting interest rates, boosting bank lending, and implementing a stimulus package worth $586 billion.

column2: • The stimulus package includes infrastructure projects, subsidies to industries, and support for rural areas, and is expected to promote long-term competitiveness and rebalance the economy.",0

column1: 533,"<summary>
• Leasing and Permitting of Federal Lands

column2: • The Mineral Lands Leasing Act (MLLA) authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to lease oil and gas deposits on federal lands, with the federal government retaining title to the lands.
• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) manages most federal mineral development and is responsible for implementing the national mining and minerals policy.
• The Forest Service also manages lands under multiple use and sustained yield policies.

column1: • Payment Terms and Lease Conditions

column2: • Leases are conditioned upon payment of a royalty of at least 12.5% in amount or value of oil or gas production that is removed or sold from the leased land.

• The Secretary of the Interior has the power to reduce the royalty on a noncompetitive lease if he deems it equitable to do so or if circumstances could cause undue hardship or premature termination of production.
• Rental payments are due annually, with the rate increasing over time.

column1: • Energy Policy Act of 2005

column2: • The Act requires the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to enter into a memorandum of understanding regarding issues such as the establishment of procedures to ensure timely processing of oil and gas lease applications.
• The Act also requires the Secretary of the Interior to ensure expeditious compliance with NEPA provisions and to establish a Federal Permit Streamlining Pilot Project.

• The Act includes provisions related to the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, including the requirement that the Secretary of the Interior conduct a study regarding oil and gas leasing in the Refuge.",1

column1: 534,"<summary>
• Itemized deductions are claimed by 30% of tax filers, with higher-income individuals more likely to itemize

column2: • 56.2% of itemizers have incomes less than $100,000, and 86.8% have incomes less than $200,000
• Higher-income tax filers claim a larger average total of itemized deductions

column1: • Specific deductions benefit different types of itemizers based on their income

column2: • Tax filers in higher-income ranges claim deductions for charitable gifts, state and local income taxes, and real estate property taxes at higher rates
• Fewer tax filers in the highest income group claim the home mortgage interest deduction, possibly due to a greater ability to pay for home purchases with cash

column1: • The distribution of itemized deductions varies across income classes

column2: • The home mortgage interest deduction comprises the largest share of total itemized deductions for itemizers with an AGI between $20,000 and $200,000
• The deduction for state and local income taxes comprises the largest share of total itemized deductions for itemizers with an AGI greater than $200,000

column1: • Itemized deduction claims are high when measured as a share of income for lower-income itemizers

column2: • Total itemized deduction claims as a share of income decline as income increases
• Across all itemizers, deductions claims amounted to 18.9% of AGI

column1: • Some itemized deductions are classified as tax expenditures, or losses in federal tax revenue

column2: • The deduction for state and local income or sales taxes is estimated to be the itemized deduction with the largest tax expenditure estimate in FY2018
• The four itemized deductions that are projected to contribute most to tax expenditures in FY2018 are estimated to account for 17.8% of all individual tax expenditures

column1: • Congress might consider policies further limiting itemized deductions to increase federal revenue, increase the progressive structure of the federal income tax code, simplify the tax code, or reduce economic distortions in the tax code

column2: • Efforts to target limits on itemized tax deductions toward higher-income tax filers are restricted in the amount of revenue that can be raised
• The form of a limit on itemized deductions might affect which deductions a tax filer might claim",0

column1: 535,"<summary>

* The Pacific Islands region is strategically important for the United States, with the country having a significant presence in the region through its territories, including Guam and American Samoa, and its relationships with Pacific Island nations.

column2: * The region is critical for U.S. national security, with the U.S. military maintaining a presence in the region to protect its interests and maintain stability.

column1: * The United States provides significant economic and development assistance to the region, with a focus on promoting sustainable development, addressing climate change, and improving health and education outcomes.

column2: * The U.S. also provides military assistance and training to Pacific Island nations, and works with regional organizations such as the Pacific Islands Forum to promote regional cooperation and stability.",1

column1: 536,"<summary>
* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides for the listing and protection of species that are endangered or threatened with extinction.

column2: * Listing a species results in limitations on activities that could affect that species and in penalties for the taking of individuals of a listed species.

column1: * Federal agencies are required to consult with either the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to determine whether an agency project might jeopardize the continued existence of listed species or destroy or adversely modify a species' critical habitat.

column2: * This process is known as consultation, and it concludes with the appropriate Service issuing a biological opinion (BiOp) as to the harm the project poses.

column1: * If a project could jeopardize a species, a jeopardy opinion is released along with any reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPAs) to the agency action that would avoid jeopardy.

column2: * To excuse any incidental taking of listed species, the Services issue an incidental take statement that includes reasonable and prudent measures (RPMs) to minimize the effects of the project.

column1: * When a federal action cannot be conducted without jeopardizing species, and the federal agency believes that the RPAs would thwart the project, the federal agency, the governor of the state where the project would occur, or the licensees or permittees involved in the project may seek an exemption.

column2: * The exemption process offers the opportunity to consider extraordinary economic circumstances in the list of factors used in evaluating federal actions, and provides an opportunity for economic factors to override jeopardy to the species.

column1: * The exemption process is also available for circumstances in which the Service(s) may find that jeopardy would occur and that there is no RPA that would avoid jeopardy.

column2: * In more than four decades since the ESA was enacted, there have been only six instances in which an exemption was sought, and only two in which it was granted.

column1: * The Endangered Species Committee (ESC) reviews applications for exemptions, and is responsible for the ultimate decision.

column2: * The ESC is composed of the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Agriculture, the Secretary of the Army, the Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and one individual from each affected state.

column1: * An exemption application must describe the consultation process already carried out between the federal agency and the Secretary, and must include a statement explaining why the action cannot be altered or modified to conform to the requirements of the statute.

column1: 537,"<summary>
* The taxation of capital gains income has been a perennial topic of debate in Congress since 1913.

column2: * The current system allows for a $3,000 annual limit on the amount of capital losses that can be deducted against ordinary income.
* This limit was established to prevent taxpayers from selectively realizing losses to minimize income taxes.
* The limit has been increased over time, but the asymmetry between the tax treatment of capital gains and losses remains.

column1: * The tax treatment of capital gains and losses has changed repeatedly over the years.

column2: * The Revenue Act of 1921 introduced a flat rate of 12.5% for long-term gains.
* The Revenue Act of 1938 introduced a 50% limitation on the deductibility of net long-term losses.
* The Tax Reform Act of 1969 removed the dichotomy in the tax treatment of long-term gains and losses.

column1: * The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 lowered the maximum tax rate on long-term capital gains income to 20%.

column2: * The Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 reduced the tax rate to 15%.
* The Tax Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act of 2005 extended the reduced rates through 2010.
* The current system still has an asymmetry between the tax treatment of capital gains and losses.

column1: * The empirical evidence suggests that capital gains are concentrated at the higher end of the income range.

column2: * The top 3% of taxpayers with over $200,000 in adjusted gross income earned 91% of schedule D capital gains.
* The top 1% who earned over $200,000 from 1979-1988 received 57% of gains.
* The top 2% of the income distribution receive about two-thirds of gains.

column1: * The distortion relating to gains works in the opposite direction in the case of losses.

column2: * The top 3% accounted for about 30% of losses.
* There are significant losses in very low income classes that are almost certainly people whose incomes are normally high.
* A better calculation is the permanent capital gains share.

column1: * Lower and middle-income taxpayers are unlikely to be much affected by the expansion of capital losses.

column2: * Relatively few low and middle-income families directly hold stock.
* Many of their assets are held in tax-favored forms.
* Assets held in these accounts are not affected by loss restrictions.

column1: * The primary objective of recent economic proposals is to stimulate the economy.

,0
538,<summary>
* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining through representatives of their own choosing.

column2: * The Act aims to mitigate and eliminate labor-related obstructions to the free flow of commerce.
* Congressional interest in the NLRA remains significant, with over 30 bills introduced in the 112th Congress to amend the Act.

column1: * The NLRA does not apply to all individuals employed by an employer, but only to ""employees"", excluding supervisors.

column2: * A supervisor is defined as an individual with the authority to perform certain functions, such as hiring, transferring, or disciplining employees, and exercising independent judgment.
* The NLRB and courts have sought to provide meaning to the term ""independent judgment"" through various decisions.

column1: * The NLRB has clarified the terms ""assign"", ""responsibly to direct"", and ""independent judgment"" in the context of section 2(11) of the NLRA.

column2: * The term ""assign"" refers to the act of designating an employee to a place, appointing an employee to a time, or giving significant overall duties or tasks to an employee.
* The term ""responsibly to direct"" applies to individuals who oversee the work being performed and are held responsible if the work is done poorly or not at all.

column1: * The NLRA prohibits certain misconduct by both employers and unions that interferes with the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining.

column2: * Section 8(a)(1) of the Act prohibits employers from interfering with, restraining, or coercing employees in the exercise of their rights.
* Section 8(b)(1)(A) of the Act prohibits labor organizations or their agents from restraining or coercing employees in the exercise of their rights.

column1: * Unfair labor practices under section 8(a)(1) include verbal threats to adversely affect an employee's employment status or working conditions.

column2: * An employer's interrogation of its employees as to union sympathy and affiliation may also violate section 8(a)(1).
* The use or threatened use of violence by a union or one of its agents is similarly considered an unfair labor practice under section 8(b)(1)(A).

column1: * The NLRB has long maintained that an employer may make anti-union, but non-coercive, speeches to their employees on company time and on company property without allowing a union an equal opportunity to reply.

column2: * Last-minute speeches made by employers, however, have been distinguished from other pre-election speeches",0

column1: 539,"<summary>
• Banking plays a central role in the financial system by connecting borrowers to savers and allocating capital across the economy.

column2: • Banking is an inherently risky activity involving extending credit and taking on liabilities.
• Banking can generate tremendous societal and economic benefits, but banking panics and failures can create devastating losses.
• A regulatory system designed to foster the benefits of banking while limiting risks has developed over time.

column1: • Prudential regulation involves requirements besides capital ratios, such as liquidity requirements, asset concentration guidelines, and counterparty limits.

column2: • Capital is essential to absorbing losses, and as long as sufficient capital is in place, banks should not be subject to some of these additional regulatory restrictions.
• The different components of prudential regulation each play an important role in ensuring the safety and soundness of financial institutions.
• Whether the benefits of prudential regulation outweigh the potential costs of reduced credit availability and economic growth is an issue subject to much debate.

column1: • The Volcker Rule generally prohibits depository banks from engaging in proprietary trading or sponsoring a hedge fund or private equity fund.

column2: • Proponents argue that proprietary trading would add further risk to the inherently risky business of commercial banking.
• Some observers doubt the necessity of the Volcker Rule, asserting that proprietary trading at commercial banks did not play a role in the financial crisis.
• The effectiveness of the Volcker Rule in reducing bank risk is also disputed.

column1: • Consumer protection laws and regulations take a variety of approaches and address different areas of concern.

column2: • Disclosure requirements are intended to ensure consumers adequately understand the costs and other features and terms of financial products.
• Unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts and practices are prohibited.
• Fair lending laws prohibit discrimination in credit transactions based upon certain borrower characteristics.

column1: • The CFPB was established with the single mandate to implement and enforce federal consumer financial law while ensuring consumers can access financial products and services.

column2: • The CFPB has implemented rules mandated by the Dodd-Frank Act, but regulations it has promulgated under its general authorities are at the center of debate.
• Some observers assert lenders have been subject to unduly burdensome regulations and overzealous enforcement by the CFPB.
• Others believe the CFPB has struck an appropriate balance in its rulemaking between protecting consumers and ensuring that credit availability is not restricted.

column1: • Mortgage lending has long been subject to regulations intended to protect homeowners and to prevent risky loans.

column2: • The Dodd-Frank Act made a number of changes to the",0

column1: 540,"<summary>

• The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 (P.L. 110-173) makes changes to the nation's three major health programs, including Medicare, Medicaid, and the State Children's Health Insurance Program (SCHIP).

column2: • The Act suspends the Medicare physician payment cut scheduled to take effect and provides SCHIP funding through March 2009.

column1: • The Act extends the Medicare physician fee schedule for six months, providing a 0.5% increase in payments.

column2: • The conversion factor for the remaining six months of 2008 and afterwards will be computed as if the modification to the conversion factor for the first six months of 2008 had never applied.

column1: • The Act extends the Physician Quality Reporting System for physicians and other health care professionals under Medicare for FY2008 and FY2009.

column2: • The CMS Program Management Account is authorized to be appropriated $25 million for FY2008 and FY2009 to carry out the Physician Quality Reporting System.

column1: • The Act modifies the amounts available in the Physician Assistance and Quality Initiative (PAQI) Fund and the years in which the monies can be spent.

column2: • The net effect of the law is that no funds remain available in the PAQI Fund for the years 2008 through 2012, and $4.96 billion are available in 2013.

column1: • The Act extends cost reimbursement for brachytherapy services until July 1, 2008.

column2: • Therapeutic radiopharmaceuticals will be paid using this methodology for services provided on or after January 1, 2008, and before July 1, 2008.

column1: • The Act requires the Secretary to use constant volume weighting in the computation of the average sales price (ASP) for Medicare Part B drugs.

column2: • The provision applies with respect to payment for multiple source and single source drugs and biologicals furnished on or after April 1, 2008.

column1: • The Act establishes a new prospective payment system for long-term care hospitals (LTCHs) and modifies the LTCH-PPS rates.

column2: • The Secretary is required to conduct a study on the establishment of national long-term care hospital facility and patient criteria and submit a report to Congress within 18 months of enactment.",1

column1: 541,"<summary>
* House Rules and Committee Operations

column2: * Rule XI, clauses 1-2: Establishes rules for committee operations, including the adoption of written rules, meeting procedures, and quorum requirements.

column3: * Committees are required to adopt written rules, which must be published in the Congressional Record.
* Committees must hold regular meetings, with at least one meeting per month.
* A quorum is required for committee meetings, with a minimum of one-third of members present.

column2: * Rule XIII, clauses 2-3: Governs the reporting of measures and matters by committees.

column3: * Committees must report measures and matters to the House, with a majority of the committee present.
* Reports must include the names and numbers of members voting for and against, as well as the total number of votes cast.
* Reports may include supplemental, minority, or additional views from committee members.

column2: * Rule XIII, clauses 4-7: Regulates the consideration of measures and matters on the House floor.

column3: * Measures and matters must be available to members for at least three days before consideration.
* The House may not consider a measure or matter until it has been reported by the relevant committee.
* The House may waive the three-day rule by a majority vote.
* The House may consider a measure or matter reported by a committee, even if it has not been reported by the relevant committee.",0

column1: 542,"<summary>
* The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a 10-member organization that promotes regional dialogue and cooperation.

column2: * It was established in 1967 to foster economic growth, social progress, and cultural development in the region.
* It has a combined population of 580 million and a GDP of $1.5 trillion.

column1: * ASEAN's primary goals include promoting regional peace and stability, enhancing economic growth, and strengthening regional resilience.

column2: * It aims to create a single market and production base, increase competitiveness, and improve the quality of life for its citizens.

column1: * The organization has played a key role in promoting regional security and stability, particularly in the areas of counter-terrorism and non-proliferation.

column2: * ASEAN has also been active in promoting regional economic integration, including the creation of the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) and the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC).

column1: * ASEAN has established relationships with other regional organizations, including the European Union, the United States, and China.

column2: * It has also engaged in dialogue with other regional organizations, such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

column1: * The organization has faced challenges, including the need to balance the interests of its member states, address regional security concerns, and promote economic development.

column2: * ASEAN has also had to navigate the complexities of regional politics, including the rise of China and the role of the United States in the region.

column1: * ASEAN has a diverse membership, with countries at different stages of economic development and with different political systems.

column2: * The organization has had to balance the needs and interests of its member states, while also promoting regional cooperation and integration.

column1: * ASEAN has played a key role in promoting regional cooperation on issues such as disaster management, climate change, and pandemics.

column2: * It has also been active in promoting regional cultural exchange and cooperation, including through the ASEAN Cultural Fund.

column1: * The organization has a number of institutions, including the ASEAN Secretariat, the ASEAN Summit, and the ASEAN Ministerial Meeting.

column2: * ASEAN also has a number of sectoral bodies, including the ASEAN Economic Ministers' Meeting and the ASEAN Defence Ministers' Meeting.

column1: * ASEAN has a number of initiatives aimed at promoting regional economic integration, including the ASEAN Single Window and the ASEAN Trade Facilitation Agreement.

column2: * The organization is also working to promote regional connectivity, including through the development of transportation infrastructure and the creation of a single aviation market.
