543,"<summary>
* The ""state sponsors of terrorism list"" is mandated under Section 6(j) of the Export Administration Act of 1979.

column2: * The list is used to restrict trade benefits, foreign aid, and other benefits to countries that support international terrorism.
* Cuba has been on the list since 1982, along with four other countries: Iran, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria.

column1: * A country can be removed from the list if the President submits a report to Congress certifying that the country has not supported terrorism in the past six months and has provided assurances it will not do so in the future.

column2: * Congress can block the removal of a country from the list by passing legislation.
* The President has the authority to waive certain sanctions for national security or humanitarian reasons.

column1: * Cuba was added to the list in 1982 due to its support for terrorist groups in Latin America, including the M-19 guerrilla group in Colombia.

column2: * The State Department has reported that Cuba continues to support terrorist organizations and has not undertaken any counterterrorism efforts.

* Cuba has been accused of providing safe haven to members of several Foreign Terrorist Organizations, including the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and the National Liberation Army (ELN).

column1: * The State Department's annual reports on global terrorism have noted Cuba's continued support for terrorism, including its hosting of members of foreign terrorist organizations and U.S. fugitives from justice.

column2: * Cuba has ratified all 12 international counterterrorism conventions and has expressed sympathy and offered support to the United States in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks.
* Some argue that Cuba's retention on the list is a holdover from the Cold War and that domestic political considerations keep it on the list.

column1: * Those who support keeping Cuba on the list point to its history of supporting terrorist acts and armed insurgencies, as well as its continued hosting of members of foreign terrorist organizations and U.S. fugitives from justice.

column2: * Critics of retaining Cuba on the list argue that it is a holdover from the Cold War and that Cuba's presence on the list diverts U.S. attention from more serious terrorist threats.
* Some suggest that there should be a tiered approach to sanctions, with countries that are less active supporters of terrorism facing fewer sanctions.

column1: * The level of terrorist activity by countries on the state sponsors of terrorism list varies considerably, with Iran considered the most active and Sudan and Cuba considered less active.

column2: * Some suggest that there should be more flexibility in",0

column1: 544,"<summary>
• The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is a separate tax calculation that adds back certain deductions and exemptions to the regular tax base.

column2: • The AMT base is broader than the regular tax base, but excludes certain provisions like capital gains tax rates and the exclusion for tax-exempt bonds.
• The AMT has two brackets: 26% on the first $175,000 and 28% on amounts above that.

column1: • The AMT was originally designed to ensure that high-income individuals pay a minimum amount of tax, but it has grown to affect more middle-class taxpayers due to inflation.

column2: • In 1999, 823,000 returns paid the AMT, and by 2009, it was projected to affect over 9 million taxpayers.
• The AMT would have constituted a larger share of joint returns filed, since incomes are higher for these returns than for single returns.

column1: • The cost of correcting the AMT is significant, with indexing AMT exemptions estimated to cost $13.9 billion by 2008.

column2: • Eliminating the credit limit provision would cost about $1 billion currently, but would cost many billions of dollars by 2008 or 2009.
• Eliminating the credit limit provision and adding standard deductions would cost the U.S. Treasury $26 billion by 2009.

column1: • Tax cuts that reduce regular tax liabilities and do not also alter the AMT will interact with the AMT in two ways: increasing the number of taxpayers on the AMT and the number affected by the credit limit.

column2: • Tax provisions aimed at reducing taxes for joint returns may particularly interact with the AMT because married couples have a greater number of dependents.
• The interaction is also affected by how the tax change is distributed across income classes.

column1: • The marriage penalty arises because family income is combined and subject to progressive tax rates, causing some couples to lose standard deductions and be taxed at higher rates.

column2: • The marriage penalty relief provisions would not benefit taxpayers who are on the AMT, and the tax cuts in the marriage penalty legislation would likely increase the number of taxpayers on the AMT.
• The amount by which marriage penalties are reduced by the proposed legislation will decline over time because of the AMT.

column1: • There are various approaches to dealing with the AMT, including cutting taxes without altering the AMT, indexing AMT exemptions, or eliminating the AMT altogether.

column2: • The Congress has considered the most urgent issue of dealing with the lack of offset of the credits",0

column1: 545,"<summary>

• The Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittees are responsible for drafting bills to provide annual appropriations for the Department of Transportation (DOT), the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and six small related agencies.

column2: • The DOT is primarily a grant-making and regulatory organization, with programs organized by mode of transportation.
• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is an exception, with the largest portion of its budget dedicated to operating the U.S. air traffic control system.

column1: • Title II of the THUD appropriations bill funds HUD, which addresses housing problems faced by low-income households through programs such as rental assistance and block grants.

column2: • HUD's Federal Housing Administration (FHA) insures mortgages made by lenders to homebuyers with low down payments.
• HUD's programs are designed to serve low-income families, the elderly, and persons with disabilities.

column1: • Title III of the THUD appropriations bill funds a collection of agencies involved in transportation or housing and community development.

column2: • These agencies include the Access Board, the Federal Maritime Commission, and the National Transportation Safety Board.
• The Surface Transportation Board was made independent of DOT in 2015 legislation.

column1: • The THUD appropriations bill typically sets out general provisions applicable to the bill, including restrictions on funding and supplemental funding for disasters.

column2: • Most programs and activities in the THUD bill are funded through regular annual appropriations.
• Appropriations are drawn from the general fund of the Treasury.

column1: • The majority of DOT's budget is in the form of contract authority, which is a type of mandatory budget authority based on federal trust fund resources.

column2: • Contract authority controls spending from the Highway Trust Fund and the Airport and Airway Trust Fund.
• The amount of contract authority is typically set in DOT authorizing legislation.

column1: • Congressional appropriators are subject to limits on the amount of new nonemergency discretionary funding they can provide in a year.

column2: • One way to stay within these limits is to appropriate no more than the allocated amount of discretionary funding in the regular annual appropriations act.
• Another way is to find ways to offset a higher level of discretionary funding.

column1: • The cost of regular annual appropriations for the THUD bill is generally offset in two ways: rescissions and offsetting receipts and collections.

column2: • Rescissions are cancellations of unobligated or recaptured balances from previous years' funding.
• Offsetting receipts and collections are derived from fees collected by federal agencies, such as",0

column1: 546,"<summary>
* India and Iran have a long history of positive relations, with a ""strategic partnership"" established in 2003.

column2: * The partnership includes cooperation on energy, trade, and security issues, as well as cultural and historical ties.

column1: * The United States has expressed concerns about India's relations with Iran, particularly with regards to Iran's nuclear program.

column2: * The US has pressured India to align its policy with that of the US, including voting against Iran at the IAEA.

column1: * India has sought to balance its relations with Iran and the US, while also pursuing its own national interests.

column2: * India has voted with the US on some IAEA resolutions, but has also maintained its independence on other issues.

column1: * India and Iran have significant energy ties, including a proposed gas pipeline project.

column2: * The project has been met with opposition from the US, which views it as a violation of the Iran Sanctions Act.

column1: * India and Iran have also cooperated on defense and security issues, including joint naval exercises and defense sales.

column2: * However, the cooperation has been limited and has not evolved into a strategic alliance.

column1: * The US Congress has expressed concerns about India's relations with Iran, particularly with regards to the proposed civil nuclear cooperation agreement.

column2: * The agreement has been conditional on India's cooperation with US policy towards Iran, including securing India's participation in US efforts to prevent Iran from obtaining weapons of mass destruction.",1

column1: 547,"<summary>
• Milk Protein Concentrates (MPCs) are derived from raw milk and used in various food products, animal feed, and industrial products.

column2: • MPCs are imported into the US with limited or no trade restrictions, unlike other dairy products.
• The US produces very little casein or MPCs, and dairy economists suggest that federal dairy policies have encouraged the production of nonfat dry milk instead.
• MPC imports have been a concern since the late 1990s, with major suppliers being New Zealand, Australia, and the European Union.

column1: • The US dairy program supports prices of dairy products and pays farmers subsidies when milk prices decline below certain levels.

column2: • Unlimited market access could lead to large purchases by the federal government and/or lower farm prices that would drive up payments under the Milk Income Loss Contract (MILC) program.
• Dairy imports are modest relative to domestic production, with imports of MPCs and casein/caseinates hovering around 150,000 metric tons or less.
• The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) estimated import quantities during 2000-2004 at about 3% of milk production.

column1: • Legislation has been proposed to limit imports of MPCs, casein, and caseinates by introducing tariff rate quotas (TRQs).

column2: • The proposed TRQs would assess a duty of $1.56/kg ($0.708/lb) on imports exceeding 18,488 metric tons and $2.16/kg ($0.98/lb) on imports exceeding 55,477 metric tons.
• Enactment of the proposed legislation would likely require the US to enter into compensation negotiations with WTO member countries that are major suppliers of MPCs.
• The amount of compensation could be an estimated $500 million, which could be in the form of tariff reductions on other products or other benefits.

column1: • The dairy industry is divided on the issue of import restrictions, with milk producers generally supporting legislation to limit imports and dairy product processors and manufacturers opposing it.

column2: • The National Milk Producers Federation (NMPF) supports the proposed legislation, but cautions against taking import measures that could harm prospects for US dairy exports.
• The International Dairy Foods Association (IDFA) is opposed to more restrictions on dairy imports, arguing that it would increase production costs and raise prices for consumer products.
• The potential price impact of imposing TRQs depends on the level of farm prices relative to the implied level of support under the Dairy Product",0

column1: 548,"<summary>

* Serbia's political landscape has undergone significant changes since 2000, with a coalition of democratic parties defeating Slobodan Milosevic and the country transitioning towards Western democratic and free market standards.

column2: * The country has held largely free and fair elections, with the Serbian Progressive Party (SNS) winning the most recent parliamentary election in 2012.
* The government has made progress in fighting corruption, but the economy remains a significant challenge, with high unemployment and a large budget deficit.

column1: * Serbia's relations with its neighbors have improved, with the country playing a key role in regional cooperation and seeking to join the European Union.

column2: * The country has made progress in normalizing relations with Kosovo, with the signing of an agreement on principles governing the normalization of relations in 2013.
* However, the issue of Kosovo's independence remains a sensitive topic, with Serbia refusing to recognize it and seeking to maintain its influence in the region.

column1: * The United States has played a significant role in Serbia's transition, providing aid and support for democratic reforms and economic development.

column2: * The US has also been involved in efforts to resolve the Kosovo issue, recognizing Kosovo's independence in 2008 and supporting EU-led negotiations between Serbia and Kosovo.
* The US has also sought to strengthen its bilateral ties with Serbia, including through military cooperation and cultural exchanges.",0

column1: 549,"<summary>
* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term.

column2: * Florida v. Jardines involved the question of whether a trained narcotics-detection dog's sniff at the front door of a suspected marijuana grow house is a Fourth Amendment search.
* The Court held that the use of a drug-detection dog at the front door and on the porch of a home is a search within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment, and therefore requires probable cause.

column1: * Florida v. Harris related to whether an alert by a trained drug-detection dog is sufficient to establish probable cause for a search of a vehicle.

column2: * The Court unanimously reversed the judgment of the Florida Supreme Court, holding that the positive reaction of a reliable dog trained to detect drugs is sufficient to establish probable cause.

* The Court emphasized that a defendant must be afforded the opportunity to challenge a dog's reliability, but the prosecution had presented substantial evidence of the dog's proficiency at detecting drugs.

column1: * Missouri v. McNeely addressed whether the natural metabolization of alcohol in the bloodstream presents a per se exigency that justifies an exception to the Fourth Amendment's warrant requirement for nonconsensual blood testing in all drunk-driving cases.

column2: * The Court rejected a per se rule, holding that the existence of an ""destruction of evidence"" exception can only be determined on a case-by-case basis, taking into account all the relevant facts presented in a specific case.
* The Court emphasized that the general rule that a search can only be executed pursuant to a warrant is particularly compelling when the search involves an intrusion upon bodily integrity.",1

column1: 550,"<summary>
* The Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) is the federal government's lead entity for energy sector-specific responses to national energy security emergencies.

column2: * OE's mission is to support more economically competitive, environmentally responsible, secure, and resilient U.S. energy infrastructure.
* OE works with a variety of stakeholders, including private industry and federal, state, local, and tribal governments on a variety of initiatives to modernize the electric grid.

column1: * The FY2017 budget request for OE sought $262 million, a 27% increase over the FY2016 level, to fund three new programs: a Grid Institute, State Distribution-Level Reform, and State Energy Assurance.

column2: * The largest requested increases were for Energy Storage and Infrastructure Security programs.
* The Cybersecurity program would have been cut by nearly $17 million.

column1: * OE's programs are aligned with the Obama Administration's priorities, as documented in A Policy Framework for the 21st Century Grid: Enabling Our Secure Energy Future and the President's Climate Action Plan.

column2: * OE's goal for the future grid is to support economic growth and energy innovation through delivery of reliable, affordable, and clean electricity to consumers.

* OE aims to achieve three key national targets: a 10% reduction in the economic costs of power outages, a 33% decrease in the cost of reserve margins, and a 50% decrease in the net integration costs of distributed energy resources.

column1: * The Grid Modernization Multi-Year Program Plan outlines DOE's vision for a future electric grid that provides a critical platform for U.S. prosperity, competitiveness, and innovation.

column2: * The plan aims to achieve three major technical achievements: a transmission and distribution system operating reliably on a lean reserve margin, resilient distribution feeders with high percentages of low-carbon distributed energy resources, and an advanced modern grid planning and analytics platform.
* Multiple demonstrations will be conducted across various regions of the country to underpin these achievements.

column1: * The FY2017 request also sought to continue crosscutting programs that coordinate across the department and employ DOE's full ability to address national energy, environmental, and security challenges.

column2: * OE serves as the central hub of the Grid Modernization and Cybersecurity crosscutting programs.
* The FY2017 request sought to establish three new programs: Grid Institute, State Distribution-Level Reform, and State Energy Assurance.",0

column1: 551,"<summary>
* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) was enacted in 1986 to guide the creation of memorials in the District of Columbia.

column2: * The CWA established a process for authorizing commemorative works, including the requirement for congressional approval and the involvement of the National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission.
* The CWA also designated areas of the District of Columbia for memorial placement, including the Reserve, Area I, and Area II, each with its own set of criteria and approval processes.

column3: * The Reserve is a protected area where new commemorative works are prohibited, except for those authorized prior to 2003.
* Area I is reserved for works of preeminent historical and lasting significance to the United States, and requires congressional approval for placement.
* Area II is for works of lasting historical significance, and does not require congressional approval.

552,"<summary>
* The Senate Finance Committee approved the America's Healthy Future Act of 2009, which aims to reform the private health insurance market.

column2: * The bill would require individuals to maintain health insurance, with penalties for non-compliance.
* The bill would provide subsidies to help individuals and small businesses afford health insurance.

column1: * The bill would establish new federal standards for private health insurance plans, including guaranteed issue and renewal, and prohibition of pre-existing condition exclusions.

column2: * The bill would create a new health insurance exchange, where individuals and small businesses could purchase health insurance.
* The exchange would offer four tiers of coverage: bronze, silver, gold, and platinum, with varying levels of cost-sharing.
* The bill would allow states to establish their own exchanges, and would provide funding for states to implement the reforms.
* The bill would also establish a temporary reinsurance program to help stabilize the individual market during the transition period.

* The bill would require health insurance plans to provide an essential benefits package, which would include hospitalization, outpatient services, prescription drugs, and other essential health benefits.

553,"<summary>
* High risk health insurance pools are designed to provide health coverage to individuals who cannot obtain or afford health insurance in the private market due to preexisting health conditions.

column2: * 35 states have established high risk pools, which target individuals who have sought health coverage in the individual market but have been denied or offered unaffordable coverage.

* High risk pools generally cover people who have been denied coverage, received quotes that are higher than the premiums offered by the high risk pool, or received offers that exclude coverage of preexisting conditions.
* Many states use high risk pools to comply with the portability and guaranteed availability provisions of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA).

column1: * High risk pools tend to enroll a small percentage of the uninsured, with approximately 200,000 individuals enrolled in 34 high risk pools in 2008.

column2: * The Government Accountability Office (GAO) estimated that nearly 4 million additional persons were potentially eligible for enrollment.
* The limited enrollment reflects the narrow focus of high risk pools on individuals with preexisting health conditions who do not have access to public or group health insurance.
* High risk pools are designed to fill a niche in the health insurance system, providing a safety net for the nongroup market.

column1: * High risk pools are operated through state-established nonprofit organizations, with private insurance companies responsible for daily administrative duties.

column2: * Boards oversee the governance of high risk pools, consisting of representatives from insurance companies, consumer groups, health care providers, and state agencies.
* High risk pools operate at a loss, requiring funding from other sources such as assessments on insurers, general revenue, and federal grants.
* States have discretion regarding the establishment and operation of high risk pools, including covered benefits, eligibility requirements, and funding sources.

column1: * Federal grants have been provided to states to support the creation and implementation of high risk pools, with funding authorized and appropriated through various laws.

column2: * The Trade Act of 2002 authorized and appropriated $20 million in seed grants and $80 million in operational grants.
* The State High Risk Pool Funding Extension Act of 2006 reauthorized federal grants through FY2010 and changed the funding formula.
* The Deficit Reduction Act of 2005 provided appropriations for grants to states for FY2006.

column1: * The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a temporary high risk pool program prior to 2014.

column1: 554,"<summary>
* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) is a program that allows the US government to use commercial aircraft to support military operations during times of crisis.

column2: * The program was created in 1951 and is managed by the Department of Defense (DOD) and the Department of Transportation (DOT).

column1: * The CRAF has been activated twice, during Operations Desert Shield/Storm and Iraqi Freedom, and has provided significant airlift capacity to support military operations.

column2: * The program has also been used to support humanitarian and peacekeeping missions.

column1: * The CRAF is made up of three segments: international, national, and aeromedical evacuation, and is composed of commercial aircraft that are committed to the program by their owners.

column2: * The program provides a cost-effective way for the DOD to access additional airlift capacity during times of need, and has been shown to be effective in supporting military operations.",1

column1: 555,"<summary>

• The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is an agency in the U.S. Department of Commerce that serves as the executive branch's principal advisory office on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies.

column2: • It frequently works with other executive branch agencies to develop and present the Administration's position on key policy matters.
• It represents the executive branch in both domestic and international telecommunications and information policy activities.

column1: • The NTIA has several responsibilities, including overseeing the transfer of radio frequencies from the federal domain to the commercial domain, administering grant programs, and establishing requirements for a $135 million grant program to help states plan for participation in a new, nationwide public safety broadband network.

column2: • It also fulfills many responsibilities for different constituencies, including acting as a facilitator and mediator in negotiations among federal agencies regarding usage, priority access, causes of interference, and other radio spectrum questions.
• It works in consultation with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) on matters concerning spectrum access, technology, and policy.

column1: • The NTIA leads and participates in interagency efforts to develop Internet policy and plays a lead role in the DOC's Internet Policy Task Force.

column2: • It collaborates with the National Institute of Standards (NIST) on research projects and with other federal agencies, such as the FCC.

• It works with the Rural Utilities Service in coordinating loans and grants made through the Broadband Technology Opportunities Program (BTOP) and with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in overseeing grants made through the Public Safety Interoperable Communications (PSIC) grant program.

column1: • The NTIA has several offices, including the Office of Spectrum Management (OSM), the Office of Policy Analysis and Development (OPAD), the Office of International Affairs (OIA), and the Institute for Telecommunication Sciences (ITS).

column2: • The OSM formulates and establishes plans and policies that ensure the effective, efficient, and equitable use of the spectrum both nationally and internationally.
• The OPAD supports NTIA's role as principal adviser to the Executive Branch and the Secretary of Commerce on telecommunications and information policies.

column1: • The NTIA has a budget of $45.6 million for FY2012, an increase of 9.6% over the previous year, and has requested $46.9 million for FY2013.

column2: • The Administration has proposed increasing the amount of radio frequency spectrum available for mobile services, including clearing federal users from designated frequencies for transfer to the commercial sector through a competitive bidding system.

column1: 556,"<summary>
• The Energy Policy Act of 2005

column2: • Signed by President Bush on August 8, 2005
• First omnibus energy legislation enacted in over a decade

column1: • Electricity Provisions

column2: • Establishes federal jurisdiction over activities required to support reliability of the U.S. bulk power system
• Clarifies the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's (FERC) authority to establish and regulate an electric reliability organization (ERO)

column1: • Siting of Interstate Electric Transmission Facilities

column2: • Authorizes the Secretary of Energy to designate a geographic area as congested
• Allows FERC to issue construction permits for transmission facilities in congested areas

column1: • Advanced Transmission Technologies

column2: • Directs FERC to encourage deployment of advanced transmission technologies
• Establishes an incentive program for owners or operators of advanced power generation systems

column1: • Net Metering and Additional Standards

column2: • Requires states to consider implementing net metering standards
• Directs states to consider implementing a standard to minimize dependence on one fuel source

column1: • Cogeneration and Small Power Production Purchase and Sale Requirements

column2: • Repeals the mandatory purchase requirement under Section 210 of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 (PURPA)
• Allows FERC to exempt qualifying facilities from the mandatory purchase requirement

column1: • Public Utility Holding Company Act of 2005

column2: • Repeals the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA)
• Establishes new regulations for holding companies and their affiliates

column1: • Electricity Market Transparency

column2: • Directs FERC to facilitate price transparency in wholesale electric markets
• Requires FERC to establish rules for reporting information about wholesale electric energy and transmission service prices

557,"<summary>
* The Robinson-Patman Act was enacted in 1936 to promote competition among small businesses

column2: * It prohibits sellers from charging different prices to different buyers for goods of like grade and quality
* The act applies only to the sale of goods, not services, and only to sales within the United States
* It does not prohibit price differentials between goods sold for resale within the US and those sold for export

column1: * The act has been criticized for its potential to harm consumers and limit discounting

column2: * The Department of Justice has historically been opposed to the act, citing its adverse effects on the economy
* The Federal Trade Commission has inconsistently enforced the act over the years
* The act's benefits are debated, with some arguing it helps small businesses and promotes fair dealing

column1: * Defenses to Robinson-Patman violations include

column2: * Meeting competition defense: a seller can charge a lower price to meet a competitor's price

column3: * Primary line competition: meeting a competitor's price to sell to the same buyer
* Secondary line competition: meeting a competitor's price to enable a buyer to compete with another buyer

column2: * Cost justification defense: a seller can charge a lower price if it reflects a cost difference
* Nonprofit exemption: certain nonprofit institutions are exempt from the act's provisions

column1: * The nonprofit exemption has been interpreted by the courts

column2: * The exemption applies only to purchases made for the institution's own use
* The Supreme Court has clarified the exemption's scope in several cases
* Health maintenance organizations have been found to be eligible for the exemption

column1: * Damages for Robinson-Patman violations are not automatic

column2: * A plaintiff must show actual injury attributable to the violation
* The Supreme Court has rejected the ""automatic damages"" theory
* Treble damages are available under 15 U.S.C. § 15

column1: * There have been efforts to amend or repeal the Robinson-Patman Act

column2: * The 94th Congress considered proposals to amend or repeal the act in the 1970s
* The Antitrust Modernization Commission recommended repealing the act in 2007
* The act's future is uncertain in the current economic climate

558,"<summary>
* The Take Care Clause of the US Constitution imposes a duty on the President to ""take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed.""

column2: * This clause has been interpreted to mean that the President has a constitutional obligation to enforce the laws, but also has some discretion in how to do so.

column1: * The Supreme Court has consistently held that the President's obligation to execute the law is a personal responsibility that cannot be delegated to others.

column2: * This means that the President must oversee those who execute and enforce the law, and cannot simply ignore or disregard the law.

column1: * The Take Care Clause has also been interpreted to give the President some discretion in how to enforce the law, including the power to decide when and how to prosecute crimes.

column2: * This discretion is not unlimited, and the President must still act in accordance with the law and the Constitution.

column1: * The doctrine of prosecutorial discretion has a long history, dating back to English common law.

column2: * It allows prosecutors to decide whether or not to bring charges against someone, and is generally not subject to judicial review.

column1: * The executive branch has argued that it has exclusive authority to initiate and prosecute actions to enforce the laws, and that neither the judicial nor legislative branches can interfere with this authority.

column2: * However, courts have held that this authority is not unlimited, and that the executive branch must still act in accordance with the law and the Constitution.

column1: * The Administrative Procedure Act (APA) establishes a general presumption that all final agency decisions are subject to judicial review, but also provides an exception for agency actions that are ""committed to agency discretion by law.""

column2: * This means that agency decisions not to enforce the law are generally not subject to judicial review, unless Congress has provided specific guidelines or standards for the agency to follow.

column1: * Congress has the authority to curtail an agency's discretion by setting substantive priorities or providing meaningful standards for defining the limits of that discretion.

column2: * If Congress has provided such guidelines, courts may review agency decisions not to enforce the law to ensure that they are in accordance with the law and the Constitution.",1

column1: 559,"<summary>
* Poverty rates in the US have been declining since 2013, with a significant drop in 2014.

column2: * The poverty rate for children dropped from 21.3% in 2012 to 19.5% in 2013.
* The poverty rate for adults aged 18-64 remained unchanged from 2012 to 2013.
* The poverty rate for those aged 65 and older increased from 8.7% in 2012 to 9.5% in 2013.

column1: * Poverty rates vary significantly by race and ethnicity.

column2: * In 2013, the poverty rate for African Americans was 27.2%, for Hispanics it was 23.5%, and for non-Hispanic whites it was 9.6%.
* Poverty rates are also higher for those with lower levels of education and those who are unemployed or have a disability.
* Single-parent families with children are also more likely to be poor.

column1: * The Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM) is a new measure of poverty that takes into account a broader range of factors, including in-kind benefits and taxes.

column2: * The SPM is intended to provide a more accurate picture of poverty in the US.
* The SPM thresholds are based on the cost of a basket of goods and services, including food, clothing, shelter, and utilities.
* The SPM is adjusted for geographic differences in the cost of living.",0

column1: 560,"<summary>
* The WTO's Agreement on Agriculture (AoA) sets rules and limits on domestic agricultural support programs, with the goal of reducing trade distortions and promoting fair trade practices.

column2: * The AoA categorizes support programs into three boxes: green (minimally or non-trade distorting), blue (production-limiting), and amber (trade-distorting).
* The United States is subject to a spending limit of $19.1 billion in amber box outlays, and must notify the WTO of its domestic support programs and their classification.

column3: * The AoA's green box includes programs that are minimally or non-trade distorting, such as research, pest and disease control, and environmental programs.
* The blue box includes production-limiting programs, such as those that provide payments based on fixed areas and yields.
* The amber box includes trade-distorting programs, such as price support and income support programs.

column1: * The AoA also includes rules for classifying and counting trade-distorting support, including the use of a traffic light system to group programs by their potential to distort markets.

column3: * Green box programs are not subject to spending limits, while blue box programs are exempt from limits but contain safeguards to prevent production expansion.
* Amber box programs are subject to spending limits, and the United States must ensure that its total AMS does not exceed $19.1 billion.
* The AoA also includes a de minimis clause, which exempts small amounts of support from counting towards the AMS limit.

column1: * The United States must comply with AoA rules and limits, and must also consider the potential impact of its domestic support programs on international markets and trade.

column3: * The SCM rules govern adverse market effects resulting from domestic farm support programs, and the United States may be subject to challenge under WTO dispute settlement procedures if its programs are deemed to cause market distortion.
* The United States has never exceeded its AMS limit, but must continue to ensure compliance with AoA rules and limits.
* The AoA's structure is intended to encourage countries to design their domestic farm support programs to be green-box-compliant.",0

column1: 561,"<summary>

• The campus-based programs, including FSEOG, FWS, and Perkins Loans, are unique in that they provide aid to students through institutions, which are required to provide a partial match of federal funds.

column2: • The programs are allocated funds based on a formula that takes into account the institution's base guarantee and fair share of unmet need.
• The allocation formula has been criticized for favoring long-term participants over new participants and not adequately targeting low-income students.

column1: • The FSEOG program has been proposed for elimination or consolidation with other aid programs, with some arguing that it duplicates the Pell Grant program.

column2: • However, proponents of the program argue that it provides a unique source of aid that is targeted to students with exceptional need.
• The program's award rules could be amended to better target low-income students.

column1: • The FWS program has been criticized for its community service requirement, which some institutions find difficult to meet.

column2: • The program's employment opportunities could be more closely linked to students' career or education goals.
• The program's allocation formula could be revised to better target institutions that serve low-income students.",0

column1: 562,"<summary>
* Adult missing persons cases may not receive the same level of attention as child abductions, but policymakers are increasingly focusing on this issue.

column2: * The federal government has provided funding for programs to help locate missing adults, such as the Missing Alzheimer's Disease Patient Alert Program.

column1: * The Silver Alert system is a state-level program that helps locate missing adults, particularly those with cognitive impairments.

column2: * The system is similar to the AMBER Alert system, but is used for adults instead of children.

column1: * Eleven states have implemented Silver Alert systems, with varying criteria for activation.

column2: * The systems are often administered by state law enforcement agencies, with local agencies playing a key role in activation and dissemination of alerts.

column1: * The process for activating an alert typically begins with a missing persons report filed with local law enforcement.

column2: * The report is then reviewed to determine if the state's criteria for activation have been met, such as the person's status being unknown and their disappearance posing a credible threat to their health or safety.

column1: * Once an alert is activated, information about the missing person is disseminated to law enforcement agencies and the public through various media outlets.

column2: * This may include electronic highway signs, lottery terminals, and reverse 911 systems.

column1: * States may have different criteria for activating alerts, such as age or disability requirements.

column2: * Some states also have different procedures for activating alerts, such as requiring a local or regional alert before activating a statewide alert.

column1: * The duration of an alert can vary by state, with some states imposing time limits and others leaving it to the discretion of law enforcement agencies.

column2: * The effectiveness of Silver Alert systems in recovering missing adults is still being evaluated, but they have the potential to make a significant impact in this area.

column1: * Policymakers are considering ways to expand and improve Silver Alert systems, such as increasing funding and coordination between states.

column2: * The federal government may also play a role in supporting and standardizing Silver Alert systems across the country.",1

column1: 563,"<summary>
• The report describes and analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2017.

column2: • It compares the enacted FY2016 appropriations for DHS, the Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request, and the Trump Administration's requests for additional funding.
• It identifies additional informational resources, reports, and products on DHS appropriations that provide additional context for the discussion.

column1: • The report provides an overview of the DHS budget structure, including the Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) and the different categories of appropriations.

column2: • It explains the differences between budget authority, obligations, and outlays.

• It discusses the various titles of the DHS appropriations bill, including Departmental Management and Operations, Security, Enforcement, and Investigations, Protection, Preparedness, Response, and Recovery, and Research and Development, Training, and Services.
• It highlights the importance of understanding the DHS budget and appropriations process.

column1: • The report provides detailed tables and comparisons of FY2016 enacted and FY2017 requested and enacted appropriations for each DHS component.

column2: • It discusses the impact of the Budget Control Act on DHS appropriations.
• It highlights the importance of hiring and retention in DHS, and the need for the department to improve its hiring process.

column1: 564,"<summary>
* Water Infrastructure Security

column2: * The water infrastructure sector is vulnerable to various types of attacks, including physical disruption, bioterrorism/chemical contamination, and cyber attacks.
* The sector is highly linked with other infrastructure systems, making security of all of them an issue of concern.
* The federal government is responsible for only about 5% of the dams whose failure could result in loss of life or significant property damage.

column1: * Security Measures and Initiatives

column2: * The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has established a Water Security Division and a National Homeland Security Research Center to develop scientific foundations and tools to respond to attacks on water systems.

* The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has developed a National Infrastructure Protection Plan (NIPP) and a Critical Infrastructure Partnership Advisory Council (CIPAC) to coordinate federal infrastructure protection programs with similar activities of the private sector, and state, local, and tribal governments.
* DHS has also established an information-sharing network, called the Homeland Security Information Network (HSIN), to provide security information to water utilities.

column1: * Research and Development

column2: * Research is being conducted on real-time monitoring of water supplies and development of information technology to improve water security.
* The National Infrastructure Advisory Council is engaged in a regional resilience study focused on the Philadelphia region, examining interdependencies of water and other critical sectors.
* The Water Sector Coordinating Council has developed guidance on protecting potentially vulnerable drinking water and wastewater systems from targeted cyber attacks or accidental cyber events.

column1: * Funding and Coordination

column2: * There are no federal funds dedicated to physical security improvements for drinking water and wastewater utilities, and utilities generally must pay for improvements using the same revenue or funding sources also needed for other types of capital projects.
* Congress has provided appropriations to the Corps, the Bureau, and EPA for security-related programs and activities to protect water infrastructure since the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

* Coordination between EPA and DHS on water security issues is ongoing, with efforts to clarify their roles in providing security to water utilities and to develop a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to define the relationship of the two entities with regard to the protection and security of the nation.",1

column1: 565,"<summary>
* The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 (Perkins IV) reauthorizes and amends the Perkins Act.

column2: * It authorizes funding for vocational and technical education through FY2012.
* It retains the overall purpose and structure of the Perkins Act, with some changes to the state allotment formula and accountability requirements.

column1: * Perkins IV modifies the state allotment formula when there are ""additional funds"" above the FY2006 funding level.

column2: * At least two-thirds of the ""additional funds"" are allotted to states based on the underlying formula.
* Up to one-third of the ""additional funds"" are allotted to states with FY2006 grants that are less than the minimum grant amount.

column1: * The act continues to require states to distribute at least 85% of state grant funds to the local level.

column2: * States may reserve up to 10% of the funds distributed to the local level for eligible recipients in rural areas and areas with high percentages or high numbers of career and technical education students.
* States may reserve up to 5% of their grants for ""administration of the State plan.""

column1: * Perkins IV strengthens and changes accountability requirements, including separate core indicators of performance for secondary and postsecondary levels.

column2: * Eligible agencies and recipients must establish measures for each of the indicators and negotiate adjusted levels of performance.
* Sanctions for failing to meet adjusted levels of performance include withholding of funds and development of improvement plans.

column1: * The act requires states to submit a state plan to the Secretary, which must cover a six-year time period and include specific information, such as descriptions of career and technical programs of study and how funds will be used to develop or improve CTE courses.

column2: * The plan must also describe how the eligible agency will ensure that best practices among eligible recipients and tech-prep recipients are shared and how professional development will promote the integration of academic content standards and CTE curricula.",0

column1: 566,"<summary>
* The federal estate tax is a tax on the estate of a decedent, levied against and paid by the estate.

column2: * The gross estate includes the value of all property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, wherever situated, in which the decedent owned an interest on the date of death.
* The gross estate may also include certain interests in property which the decedent had transferred to another person at some time prior to the date of death.

column1: * The federal gift tax is a tax imposed on an annual basis on all gratuitous transfers of property made during life.

column2: * The taxable gift is determined by reducing the gross value of the gift by the available deductions and exclusions.
* The gift tax liability created on the basis of the donor's taxable gifts may be reduced by the available unified transfer tax credit.",1

column1: 567,"<summary>
• Border and Transportation Security (BTS) is a critical function in protecting the American people from terrorists and their instruments of destruction.

column2: • The federal government has put into place multiple programs and policies to achieve this goal, including the creation of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the USA PATRIOT ACT.

column1: • The U.S. government has employed a number of strategies and programs to make the nation's borders more secure, including pushing the border outwards, hardening the border, making the border more accessible for legitimate trade and travel, strengthening the border through more effective use of intelligence, and multiplying effectiveness through the engagement of other actors in the enforcement effort.

column2: • Examples of pushing the border outwards include pre-inspections, advanced passenger manifest requirements, and the Container Security Initiative (CSI) program.

column1: • The U.S. northern and southwest borders extend over 6,000 miles, with vast areas of both borders lacking direct surveillance by border patrol personnel.

column2: • Efforts are underway to enhance border technology, including the use of video cameras, ground sensors, radiation detectors, geographic information systems, and physical barriers to provide surveillance at the border.

column1: • Intelligence plays an essential role in the protection of U.S. national security, contributing to the protection of U.S. borders by seeking to prevent certain goods and individuals from crossing U.S. borders.

column2: • The Terrorist Screening Database (TSDB) is a key tool in the government's counterterrorism arsenal for border protection, and is shared broadly across the U.S. government.

column3: • New Zealand's cultural identity is shaped by its indigenous Māori people, as well as its history as a British settler society.
• The country's foreign policy reflects its commitment to multilateralism and its desire to promote peace and stability in the region.

column1: • The United States and New Zealand have a strong economic relationship, with the US being one of New Zealand's largest trading partners.

column1: 570,"<summary>
* The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods for Presidents to appoint officers: with Senate advice and consent, or unilaterally during a Senate recess.

column2: * The Recess Appointments Clause has been a source of tension between Presidents and Congresses.
* The clause has been interpreted to allow appointments during both inter- and intrasession recesses.

column1: * The President's recess appointments on January 4, 2012, raised legal questions about the scope of the Recess Appointments Clause.

column2: * The appointments were made during a three-day recess between pro forma sessions of the Senate.
* The Senate had previously used pro forma sessions to prevent recess appointments.

column1: * A reviewing court would first need to determine if a plaintiff has standing to challenge the appointments.

column2: * Standing requires an injury in fact, causation, and redressability.
* Private plaintiffs, individual Members of Congress, and the Senate as an institution may have standing.

column1: * The political question doctrine may prevent a court from reviewing certain aspects of the appointments.

column2: * The doctrine bars judicial review of questions committed to other branches or lacking judicially discoverable standards.
* The doctrine may apply to questions about the Senate's internal processes or the minimum duration of a recess.

column1: * A court may consider the merits of the appointments if a plaintiff has standing and the political question doctrine does not apply.

column2: * The court would need to determine if the appointments were made during a recess of sufficient duration.
* The court may consider the Senate's use of pro forma sessions and the historical practice of recess appointments.

column1: * The Senate's use of pro forma sessions raises questions about the meaning of a ""Recess"" under the Recess Appointments Clause.

column2: * A court may consider whether pro forma sessions are standard sessions of Congress.
* The court may look at the content of the sessions or the Senate's capacity to conduct business.

column1: * A court may determine that a minimum number of days is required for a recess to trigger the President's recess appointment power.

column2: * The court may consider the Adjournment Clause in making this determination.
* The court's decision would depend on its interpretation of the Recess Appointments Clause and historical practice.

column1: </summary>",0
571,"<summary>
* Federal immigration laws govern the exclusion and removal of non-U.S. nationals who do not meet specified criteria regarding their entry or presence in the United States.

column2: * The Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) provides procedural guarantees, including written notice, counsel, a hearing, and appeal, before an alien can be removed.

column1: * The Supreme Court has recognized the federal government's authority to expel or exclude aliens, and has held that an alien's admission into the United States is a privilege, not a right.

column2: * The Court has also established the ""entry fiction"" doctrine, which treats an alien seeking admission as though they had not entered the country, even if they are physically present.

column1: * The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act (IIRIRA) of 1996 replaced the exclusion/deportation framework with a new framework that turns on whether an alien has been lawfully admitted into the country.

column2: * IIRIRA also created the expedited removal process, which allows for the removal of certain arriving aliens without a hearing or further review.

column1: * The expedited removal process applies to aliens who lack valid entry documents or have attempted to procure admission through fraud or misrepresentation.

column2: * The process involves inspection by an immigration officer, who determines whether the alien is inadmissible and subject to expedited removal.

column1: * Aliens subject to expedited removal may be entitled to administrative review of their claim if they express a fear of persecution or torture, or claim to be a U.S. citizen, LPR, or asylee.

column2: * The review process involves a credible fear determination, which is a screening process to evaluate whether the alien could potentially qualify for asylum, withholding of removal, or protection under the Convention Against Torture.",1

column1: 572,"<summary>
* The legal framework for congressional redistricting involves both constitutional and federal statutory requirements, as well as case law interpretations of each.

column2: * The Elections Clause of the Constitution, Article I, Section 4, clause 1, provides that the times, places, and manner of holding congressional elections be prescribed in each state by the legislature thereof, but that Congress may at any time make or alter such laws.

column1: * The Supreme Court has interpreted the Constitution to require that each congressional district within a state contain approximately the same population, known as the ""equality standard"" or the principle of ""one person, one vote.""

column2: * The Court has also described the extent to which precise mathematical equality among districts is required, and has permitted state legislative districts a greater deviation from precise equality than congressional districts.",1

column1: 573,"<summary>
• Federal fire protection programs have been debated and reformed in response to severe fire seasons.

column2: • The National Fire Plan was proposed in 2000 to increase funding for fire protection on federal lands.
• The Healthy Forests Initiative was proposed in 2002 to expedite fuel reduction projects on priority areas.

column1: • Federal funding for wildfire management has increased significantly since 2000.

column2: • Total federal land fire management appropriations rose from $1.1 billion in 2000 to $4.46 billion in 2008.
• The Federal Land Assistance, Management, and Enhancement (FLAME) Act was enacted in 2009 to provide a separate fund for major wildfire suppression efforts.

column1: • The Forest Service (FS) and Department of the Interior (DOI) have different approaches to fire management.

column2: • The FS focuses on protecting human life, private property, and natural resources.
• The DOI focuses on protecting federal lands and resources.

column1: • Fuel reduction efforts are intended to reduce the threat of significant damages from wildfires.

column2: • Prescribed burning and thinning are used to reduce fuel loads on federal lands.
• However, fuel treatment acreage has not kept pace with the need, and funding has been inconsistent.

column1: • The Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003 aimed to expedite fuel reduction activities.

column2: • The act established an expedited process for environmental review and public involvement in fuel reduction activities.
• However, the use of categorical exclusions from NEPA was later ruled unlawful.

column1: • Wildfire management costs have risen significantly, with a growing share of discretionary appropriations spent on wildfire management.

column2: • The costs of wildfire suppression have exceeded agency appropriations annually for over a decade.
• The FLAME Act aimed to address this issue by providing a separate fund for major wildfire suppression efforts.

column1: • The federal role in fire protection of non-federal lands and structures is a topic of debate.

column2: • Some argue that state and local governments should take more responsibility for fire protection.
• Others argue that the federal government has a role in protecting private lands and structures.

column1: • Post-fire rehabilitation is another issue related to wildfire management.

column2: • The federal government provides funding for post-fire rehabilitation efforts.
• However, the effectiveness of these efforts is not well-documented.

column1: • Research and development are important components of wildfire management.

column2: • The Joint Fire Science Program is a collaborative effort between the FS and DOI to fund wildfire research.
• Research is needed to improve fire prediction, prevention, and suppression techniques.</summary>",1

column1: 574,"<summary>
• Mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees has been recommended by recent deficit reduction groups.

column2: • The Bipartisan Policy Center's Debt Reduction Task Force recommended mandatory coverage to increase the universality of the program and to shore up state and local pension systems.
• The National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform also recommended mandatory coverage to mitigate risks for plan sponsors and participants.

column1: • Mandatory coverage is projected to have a net positive effect on the Social Security Trust Funds on average over the 75-year projection period.

column2: • The Office of the Chief Actuary estimates that mandatory coverage would close 9% of the system's projected long-range funding shortfall and extend the projected trust fund exhaustion date to 2040.
• The Congressional Budget Office estimates that mandatory coverage would increase revenues by about $24 billion over 5 years and $96 billion over 10 years.

column1: • Opponents argue that mandatory coverage would not necessarily result in better benefit protections for workers because state and local governments could reduce some pension benefits currently available under non-covered pension plans.

column2: • Higher-wage workers, such as state and local government employees, receive lower replacement rates under Social Security compared to lower-wage workers.
• Mandatory coverage could result in better benefit protections through the provision of dependents' and survivors' benefits under Social Security.

column1: • The portability of state and local pension plans is usually limited to positions that fall within the same public pension system, whereas Social Security coverage is portable among most jobs.

column2: • Social Security beneficiaries can move from job to job, continue to build years of service and earnings, and all covered earnings are indexed for inflation as part of the benefit computation.
• Mandatory coverage would eventually eliminate the need for the windfall elimination provision (WEP) and the government pension offset (GPO).

column1: • States and localities would have to decide what pension benefits to offer new employees who would be covered by Social Security, and would have to administer two different systems until there were no more pensioners under the original pension system.

column2: • The impact on overall costs to employees and governments would depend on the type of pension benefit structure governments adopt in response to mandatory participation in Social Security.

column1: </summary>",0
575,"<summary>
* Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) provides federal assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to foreign competition.

column2: * The primary benefits for TAA-eligible workers are funding for training and reemployment services as well as income support while a worker is enrolled in training.
* Workers may also be eligible for other benefits, including a tax credit equal to a portion of qualified health insurance premiums.
* Workers age 50 and over may be eligible for Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance, a wage supplement program.

column1: * TAA is jointly administered by the federal government and the states.

column2: * The U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) makes group eligibility determinations, allots appropriated funds to cooperating state agencies, and oversees grantees.
* Individual benefits are provided through state workforce systems and state unemployment insurance systems.
* Workers may physically receive benefits and services through local American Job Centers (also known as One-Stop Career Centers).

column1: * To be eligible for TAA group certification, a group of workers from a firm (or a subdivision of a firm) must have become totally or partially separated from their employment or have been threatened with becoming totally or partially separated.

column2: * The petitioning workers must establish that foreign trade contributed importantly to their separation.
* The role of foreign trade can be established in one of several ways, including an increase in competitive imports or a shift in production to a foreign country.
* Adversely affected secondary workers may also be eligible for TAA certification.

column1: * TAA benefits for individual workers include training and reemployment services and income support for workers who have exhausted their UC benefits and are enrolled in training.

column2: * Workers may also receive case management services and reimbursements for qualified job search and relocation expenses.
* TAARA caps annual funding for training and reemployment services at $450 million per year.
* Training and reemployment services funds are granted to state workforce agencies via formula.

column1: * Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) is a weekly income support payment to certified workers who have exhausted their UC benefits and who are enrolled in training.

column2: * To be eligible for TRA, a worker must be enrolled in training within 26 weeks of separation from the worker's job or within 26 weeks of TAA certification, whichever is later.
* TRA is funded by the federal government and administered by the states through their unemployment insurance systems.
* TRA is an individual entitlement and not subject to an annual funding cap.

576,"<summary>

* The Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP) was established in 2004 to provide supplemental dental and vision benefits to federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and dependents.

column2: * FEDVIP offers four nationwide dental plans and three vision plans, with varying premiums and benefits.
* Eligible individuals can enroll in FEDVIP during the standard open season for FEHB plans, and can choose to enroll in one or both types of coverage.
* Premiums vary by plan, geographic location, and residency, and are paid 100% by the enrollee.

column1: * Key considerations for deciding whether to enroll in FEDVIP include:

column2: * Coverage of dental and vision services in FEHB plans, likelihood of using services, and placing premium dollars in an FSA.
* Weighing expected benefits against premiums, and considering the unknown risk that insurance protects against.",0

column1: 577,"<summary>

* The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA) provided $17.15 billion in supplemental FY2009 discretionary appropriations for biomedical research, public health, and other health-related programs within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

column2: * The funds were designated as emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2009 and were to remain available for obligation through the end of FY2010.

column1: * ARRA included new authorizing language to promote the widespread adoption of electronic health records and other health information technology (HIT), and established a federal interagency advisory panel to coordinate comparative effectiveness research.

column2: * The panel was required to submit an initial report describing current federal comparative effectiveness research activities and providing recommendations for future research.

column1: * The Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) received $2 billion for grants to health centers authorized under section 330 of the Public Health Service (PHS) Act.

column2: * $1.5 billion was for the construction and renovation of health centers and the acquisition of HIT systems, and $500 million was for operating grants to health centers to increase the number of underinsured and uninsured patients who receive health care services.

column1: * The National Institutes of Health (NIH) received $10.0 billion for biomedical research and extramural research facilities.

column2: * The funds were to be used to support research that would stimulate the economy, create or retain jobs, and have the potential for making scientific progress in two years.

column1: * The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) received $1.1 billion for comparative effectiveness research.

column2: * The funds were to be used to support research that compares the clinical outcomes, effectiveness, and appropriateness of preventive, diagnostic, and therapeutic items, services, and procedures.

column1: * The Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC) received $2 billion to fund activities and grant programs authorized under the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act.

column2: * The funds were to be used to promote the widespread adoption of HIT for the electronic sharing of clinical data among hospitals, physicians, and other health care providers.

column1: * The Prevention and Wellness Fund received $1 billion for three specified activities: immunization grants, reducing health care-associated infections, and evidence-based clinical and community prevention and wellness programs.

column2: * The funds were to be used to support activities that address chronic diseases, such as increasing physical activity, improving nutrition, and decreasing obesity rates.

column1: * The Indian Health Service (IHS) received $500 million",0
578,"<summary>

• The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (LMR) requires meat packers to report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, and other livestock to the US Department of Agriculture (USDA).

column2: • The law was enacted in 1999 and has been reauthorized several times, with the most recent reauthorization in 2015.
• The law aims to provide accurate and objective market information to buyers and sellers.
• The USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) collects and reports the data.

column1: • The LMR program covers a significant portion of the livestock industry, including 79% of total slaughtered cattle, 94% of hogs, and 46% of sheep.

column2: • The program also covers 94% of boxed beef production, 87% of wholesale pork, and 57% of lamb meat.
• Small plants and non-federally inspected plants account for the remaining percentage of slaughter and production.
• The AMS market news operates on an annual appropriation of about $34 million, with the LMR program accounting for about $5-6 million.

column1: • Packers are required to report prices and other information twice daily, with different reporting requirements for different species.

column2: • The reports include information on the type of purchase, premiums and discounts, and quality characteristics.
• The reports are confidential to protect the identity of packers and contracts.
• The AMS uses a ""3/70/20"" guideline to determine what data can be published.

column1: • The AMS publishes 62 daily reports and 47 weekly reports, covering cattle, swine, beef, pork, and lamb.

column2: • The reports are used by producers, packers, and other market participants to make informed marketing decisions.
• The reports are also used by the CME Group to settle live hog and cattle futures contracts.
• The reports are available on the AMS website.

column1: • The livestock industry has raised several issues with the LMR program, including concerns about confidentiality and the need for more timely and accurate data.

column2: • The industry has also proposed changes to the program, including the addition of new reporting categories and the expansion of reporting requirements to smaller plants.
• The USDA has conducted studies on the program and has made changes in response to industry concerns.
• The program is subject to periodic reauthorization by Congress.

column1: • The LMR program has been supported by the livestock industry, which views it as an important tool for promoting market transparency and fairness.
