639,"<summary>
• Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) and Oxidative Stress

column2: • PAD is a predictor of substantial coronary and cerebral vascular risk, and oxidative stress is involved in its development and progression.
• The study aimed to evaluate lipid peroxidation parameters and total antioxidant capacity in patients with PAD before and after surgery, and compare them with those receiving simvastatin therapy.
• The study found that PAD patients had enhanced oxidative stress, as demonstrated by elevated serum levels of malondialdehyde (MDA), and that simvastatin therapy reduced MDA concentrations.

column1: • Effects of Surgery and Simvastatin Therapy on Oxidative Stress

column2: • The study found that surgery did not decrease lipid peroxidation parameters, but simvastatin therapy reduced MDA concentrations.
• The total antioxidant capacity (FRAP) decreased after surgery, but was similar in patients on simvastatin therapy.
• Thiol group concentrations decreased 35 days after surgery, but increased 710 days after surgery.
• Ceruloplasmin activity was influenced by both simvastatin therapy and surgical treatment, but only 710 days postoperatively.

column1: • Implications of the Study

column2: • The study provides strong support for the efficacy of statin therapy in PAD.
• The results suggest that simvastatin may be implicated in antioxidant properties of ceruloplasmin.
• Further studies are needed to clarify the mechanisms involved in PAD and the relative importance of lipid-related and non-lipid-related effects of statins.
• The study's findings have implications for the treatment and management of PAD patients.",0

column1: 640,"<summary>
* The study investigated the effects of oral and repeated exposure to Fijk herbal mixture on rat biochemical and morphological parameters.

column2: * The study found that the oral administration of Fijk did not produce significant changes to average body weights of animals, but caused gradual decreases in rat body weights.
* The relative organ to body weight ratio showed no significant difference among the various treatment groups.

column1: * The study evaluated the lipid profile of rats exposed to Fijk and found that:

column2: * The oral exposure of rats to Fijk at the highest dosage caused significant elevation in rat plasma level of triglyceride.
* The daily administration of Fijk mixture depleted rat plasma level of HDL-C.
* The level of rat plasma LDL-C rose with increasing doses of Fijk herbal.

column1: * The study assessed the effects of Fijk on liver enzymes and found that:

column2: * The treatment of rats with Fijk herbal mixture at all doses significantly increased the levels of plasma ALT and AST relative to the control group.
* The rat plasma ALP level was lowered following oral exposure to Fijk herbal mixture, but the reduction was only significant in the group that received the highest dose of Fijk.
* The ratio of AST to ALT in plasma was less than one (< 1), which may indicate ensuing acute or chronic liver injury.

column1: * The study evaluated the effects of Fijk on oxidative stress and found that:

column2: * The oral and repeated exposure to Fijk mixture was capable of predisposing to oxidative stress, as evidenced by the increased level of rat plasma MDA.
* The depleted level of rat plasma GSH suggested the presence of oxidative stress caused by oral exposure to Fijk herbal mixture.
* The low level of GSH may be attributed to increased usage in order to scavenge free radical species or consumption as substrate by antioxidant enzymes.

column1: * The study found that the oral and repeated exposure to Fijk herbal mixture caused hepatic lesions, including:

column2: * Haemorrahage, ruptured vascular channels, hyperemia, and inflammation in the liver.
* The histopathological findings support the biochemical alterations caused by oral and repeated exposure to Fijk herbal mixture and are reminiscent of rat hepatic injury.
* The study revealed elevated atherogenic index caused by oral and repeated exposure to Fijk mixture in rats.",0

column1: 641,"<summary>
* Identifying carriers of autosomal recessive or X-linked disorders before pregnancy can benefit prospective parents

column2: * Couples can become aware of genetic risks to future offspring and reproductive options
* Carrier screening and carrier testing are two approaches to identification
* Carrier screening detects carrier status in persons without a priori increased risk
* Carrier testing detects carrier status in persons with a priori increased risk based on family history

column1: * Preconceptional carrier screening can strengthen reproductive autonomy and informed decision-making

column2: * Screening can be offered individually or as an organized program before or during pregnancy
* International studies have shown positive attitudes towards CF carrier screening
* CF carrier screening is recommended by various medical associations

column1: * Direct-to-consumer (DTC) genetic testing companies offer preconceptional carrier tests

column2: * Companies like Counsyl, DNA Direct, and Pathway Genomics offer tests for multiple disorders
* Tests are marketed directly to consumers without the involvement of healthcare professionals
* Concerns have been raised about the validity and utility of these tests

column1: * Ethical issues raised by DTC genetic testing include informed consent and medical supervision

column2: * Informed consent is crucial, but may be compromised by online information provision
* Medical supervision is necessary for adequate information provision and follow-up
* The absence of medical supervision may compromise patient health

column1: * The implementation of preconceptional carrier tests should ensure optimization of advantages and minimization of risks

column2: * Tests should be suitable for important health problems and have known predictive value
* Quality pre- and post-test information and counseling are necessary
* The testing process should lead to correct understanding of test results</summary>",0

column1: 642,"<summary>
* The study investigated the common indications for removal of internal fixation devices and highlighted potential issues.

column2: * The study included 83 patients who underwent implant removal, with 71 males and 12 females.
* The mean age of the patients was 38 years.

column1: * The reasons for removal of implants were categorized into five groups: pain/discomfort/prominent hardware, infected hardware, implant failure, elective (patient's insistence), and other reasons.

column2: * Pain/discomfort/prominent hardware was the most common reason for removal (39.75%).
* The implants most commonly responsible for pain/discomfort were patella tension band wiring, olecranon tension band wiring/plates, distal humeral plates, and femoral intramedullary nails.

column1: * Infected hardware was the second most common reason for removal (28.91%).

column2: * The implants most commonly removed due to infection were distal tibial/ankle plates and screws, proximal tibial plates, and olecranon plates.
* Infection subsided in 21 out of 24 patients after removal.

column1: * Implant failure was the third most common reason for removal (9.52%).

column2: * The implants most commonly removed due to failure were femoral intramedullary nails, distal tibial locked plates, humeral shaft dynamic compression plates, and cannulated cancellous screws in the femoral neck.
* Revision osteosynthesis was performed in all cases of implant failure.

column1: * Elective removal of implants was the fourth most common reason (20.48%).

column2: * The most commonly removed implants in this group were distal tibial/ankle plates, femoral intramedullary nails, olecranon wires and plates, and tibial intramedullary nails and patellar tension band wiring.
* Three patients developed persistent pain at the operated site, and two developed superficial wound infections.

column1: * The study found that the most frequently removed implants were distal tibial/ankle plates, femoral intramedullary nails, olecranon wires and plates, and tibial intramedullary nails and patellar tension band wiring.

column2: * All implants except one were made of stainless steel, and all were made by Indian manufacturers.
* The study highlights the need for concrete indication guidelines for implant removal and the importance of careful consideration of the risks and benefits of removal.

column1: * The study's limitations include a small sample size and short follow-up period.
643,"<summary>
• Glaucoma and its effects on retinal ganglion cells (RGCs)

column2: • Glaucoma is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by gradual loss of RGCs and optic nerve atrophy.
• High intraocular pressure (IOP) is a major risk factor for glaucoma, leading to RGC death and vision loss.
• Mller cells, a type of glial cell, play a role in RGC support and maintenance, but can also contribute to RGC death through gliosis and TNF- production.

column1: • Protective effects of -aminoadipic acid (AAA) on RGCs in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension (AOH)

column2: • AAA treatment attenuated RGC apoptosis and rescued the reduced number of RGCs in the AOH model.
• AAA inhibited Mller cell gliosis and downregulated TNF- production, promoting RGC survival.
• These findings suggest that AAA may be a potential therapeutic target for treating neurodegeneration in glaucoma.",1

column1: 644,"<summary>
* The LAEFTR-L procedure is a minimally invasive technique for resecting non-ampullary superficial duodenal neoplasms (SDNs).

column2: * It combines laparoscopic and endoscopic approaches to achieve full-thickness resection with ligation device.
* The procedure involves mobilizing the duodenum, identifying the target lesion, ligating the tumor with a ligation device, and resecting the lesion under the ligation band using a snare technique.

column1: * The LAEFTR-L procedure has several advantages over conventional endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) and surgical treatment.

column2: * It allows for complete resection without peritoneal exposure of tumor cells, reducing the risk of intraperitoneal tumor dissemination.
* It does not require proficient experience in endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) and has a shorter endoscopic resection time compared to conventional FTR procedures.

column1: * The study reported a mean operative time of 173 minutes, and complete resection was achieved in all 5 patients with a mean tumor size of 9 mm.

column2: * The procedure was performed without complications, and patients were discharged after a 1-week hospital stay.

column1: * The LAEFTR-L procedure may be a promising technique for the treatment of non-ampullary SDNs, but further prospective studies are needed to evaluate its efficacy and safety.

column2: * The procedure may be limited by tumor size, with lesions smaller than 15 mm in diameter being potential candidates, and tumor location, with lesions close to the ampulla of vater being technically difficult to access.",0

column1: 645,"<summary>
• Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of autosomal recessive conditions caused by defects in enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis.

column2: • 90-95% of CAH cases are caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD).
• CAH can be managed effectively with oral glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid administration.

column3: • This treatment compensates for adrenal steroid deficiencies and suppresses adrenal androgens.
• Typical medical treatment consists of hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone administration.

column1: • The pathophysiology of CAH due to 21-OHD is closely linked to the degree of enzyme deficiency.

column2: • A defect in cortisol biosynthesis leads to a compensatory increase in hypothalamic and pituitary secretion of CRH and ACTH.

column3: • This stimulates the adrenal cortex and results in the pathological correlate of hyperplastic adrenal glands.
• The consequence of 21-OHD is a state of hypocortisolism, hypoaldosteronism, and hyperandrogenism combined with catecholamine deficiency and several metabolic disturbances.

column1: • CAH is classified into classic and non-classic forms.

column2: • Classic CAH is subclassified as salt-losing or non-salt-losing (simple virilizing).

column3: • Non-classic CAH may be asymptomatic or may be associated with signs of androgen excess developing during childhood or at puberty.
• The classic forms are characterized by a congenital decrease of cortisol and aldosterone secretion and an increase in androgen biosynthesis.

column1: • The aim of medical treatment in 21-OHD is to suppress adrenal androgens sufficiently without impairing growth.

column2: • Glucocorticoids are given in doses sufficient to suppress excessive secretion of CRH and ACTH without total suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis.

column3: • Fludrocortisone is administered in cases of salt-losing manifestation and elevated plasma renin activity.
• The use of fludrocortisone in patients with non-salt-losing classic CAH allows management with lower doses of glucocorticoid and improves linear growth.

column1: • Adrenal masses are common in patients with CAH, particularly in those with untreated 21-OHD.

column2: • The development of adrenal adenoma or carcinoma in patients with CAH is rare, but the incidence of adrenal masses appears to be higher in CA",0

column1: 646,"<summary>
* The study examined the relationship between lifestyle behaviors and self-rated health (SRH) in a diverse population of adults from Miami-Dade County, Florida.

column2: * The study found that modifiable lifestyle behaviors, such as low fruits and vegetables intake and high fat intake, were associated with poor/fair SRH in both males and females.

column3: * Females who consumed 2 servings of fruits and vegetables per day were 2.1 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH compared to those who consumed 5 servings per day.
* Females who consumed mostly high fat foods were 1.5 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH compared to those who consumed primarily low fat foods.
* Males who consumed mostly high fat foods were 3.2 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH compared to those who consumed primarily low fat foods.

column1: * The study also found that physical activity was associated with SRH, but only in females.

column2: * Females who performed 13 times a month or never of physical activity were 1.6 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH compared to those who performed 5 days per week of physical activity.

column3: * The association between physical activity and SRH was not significant for males after adjusting for confounding variables.
* The study suggests that gender differences in physical activity levels and SRH may be due to biological and sociocultural environment inequalities between men and women.
* The study highlights the importance of promoting physical activity, particularly among females, to improve SRH.

column1: * The study has implications for designing and monitoring lifestyle interventions to prevent cardiovascular diseases, particularly in diverse populations.

column2: * The study suggests that interventions should target modifiable lifestyle behaviors, such as diet and physical activity, to improve SRH and reduce cardiovascular disease risk.

column3: * The study highlights the need to consider gender differences in designing interventions, particularly in terms of physical activity promotion.
* The study suggests that interventions should be tailored to the specific needs and cultural context of diverse populations.
* The study emphasizes the importance of promoting healthy lifestyle behaviors, particularly in minority populations, to reduce health disparities.",0

column1: 647,"<summary>
* The role of endoscopic injection of dextranomer/hyaluronic acid copolymer (DX/HA) has expanded as an alternative to open surgery for treating vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).

column2: * DX/HA has been FDA approved since 2001 for treating grade 2-4 VUR in children above one year of age, and its success rate has improved over time, with reported rates ranging from 55% to 89%.

column1: * The study compared two different positional instillation of contrast (PIC) cystography techniques to detect de novo contralateral VUR in patients with preoperative unilateral VUR and to predict successful surgical outcome.

column2: * The results showed that PIC cystography can detect occult VUR, but a negative intraoperative cystogram does not guarantee a successful outcome, and postoperative studies are still necessary to confirm the results.",1

column1: 648,"<summary>
* Fetal MRI is used to detect and characterize fetal anomalies, particularly central nervous system pathology.

column2: * The first reported use of fetal MRI dates back to 1989.
* Advances in MRI technology and knowledge of fetal pathology have increased its role in prenatal diagnosis.

column1: * Ventriculomegaly is a condition where the maximal diameter of the atrium of the lateral ventricles exceeds 10 mm.

column2: * The prevalence of ventriculomegaly ranges from 0.3-1.5% and can be classified as mild, moderate, or severe.
* Measurement of the lateral ventricle is subject to errors due to off-axis image plane, angled measurement, or improper choice of ventricular boundary.

column1: * Causes of ventriculomegaly include imbalance between cerebrospinal fluid production and absorption, abnormal cerebral development, and destructive disease processes.

column2: * Unilateral ventriculomegaly is more often seen in destructive processes, while developmental anomalies are characterized by bilateral broadening of the ventricles.
* The reported incidence of additional anomalies ranges from 70-85%, depending on the study population and severity of ventriculomegaly.

column1: * Fetal MRI is mainly performed on 1.5 Tesla scanners, and no adverse health effects have been demonstrated.

column2: * The HASTE sequence is commonly used, combining short acquisition times with good signal-to-noise ratio and spatial resolution.
* T1-weighted imaging is used to detect hemorrhages or calcifications, but has a lower signal-to-noise ratio and is more susceptible to fetal and maternal motion.

column1: * MRI has excellent contrast resolution, enabling differentiation between gray and white matter, and allows direct visualization of the cortical region and fossa posterior.

column2: * Knowledge of normal cerebral gyri and sulci development is essential for accurate diagnosis and counseling.
* The sylvian fissure and callosal sulcus are visible at 14-16 weeks, and the central sulcus is reliably seen at 24-25 weeks of gestation.

column1: * Fetal MRI is useful for detecting and characterizing additional cerebral anomalies, particularly in cases of moderate and severe ventriculomegaly.

column2: * The incidence of additional malformations detected on MRI varies greatly between studies, depending on the severity of ventriculomegaly and expertise of the sonographer.
* Interobserver agreement between experts using the same imaging modality can vary greatly, and subspecialty training of the interpreting radiologist is important.

649,<summary>
* Lung cancer is the third most common cancer diagnosed and the leading cause of cancer-related death in the US.

column2: * In 2012, 226,160 patients were diagnosed with lung cancer, and 160,340 died from the disease.

column1: * The study analyzed data from the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program and Medicare claims to investigate the impact of bone metastasis on mortality among older lung cancer patients.

column2: * The study included 126,123 patients aged 65 or older diagnosed with lung cancer between 1999 and 2005.

column1: * Bone metastasis was common, occurring in 19.8% of patients, and was associated with mortality.

column2: * The proportion of patients with bone metastasis was higher among those with distant stage disease (38%) compared to those with localized stage disease (5%).

column1: * Skeletal-related events (SREs) were common among patients with bone metastasis, occurring in 51% of patients.

column2: * The most common SRE was radiotherapy to bone (81% of patients with SRE), followed by fracture, spinal cord compression, and surgery to bone.

column1: * The study found that having a bone metastasis was associated with mortality among lung cancer patients, but there was no additional effect of SRE on mortality.

column2: * The association between bone metastasis and mortality was stronger among patients with localized stage disease compared to those with distant metastatic disease.

column1: * The study's strengths include the use of large population-based data and the focus on lung cancer in the elderly.

column2: * The study's limitations include the characteristics of the SEER-Medicare data, which may not be generalizable to patients under 65 or those with different insurance coverage.

column1: * The study's findings highlight the importance of considering bone metastasis in the management of lung cancer patients.

column2: * Further research is needed to validate the procedures used to identify bone metastasis and to explore the impact of treatment factors and comorbid conditions on mortality.",0

column1: 650,"<summary>
• The study compared the effect of different smear layer removal methods on the bond strength of self-adhesive cements using fiber posts.

column2: • The methods used were 5.25% sodium hypochlorite, 0.9% physiological saline, 17% EDTA, 37% orthophosphoric acid, and photodynamic diode laser.
• The results showed that the photodynamic diode laser and 37% orthophosphoric acid groups had higher bond strength values than the other groups.

column3: • The laser group showed post-cement failure, while the other groups showed mixed failures.
• The SEM analysis showed that the laser and orthophosphoric acid groups were more effective in removing the smear layer than the other groups.

column1: • The study concluded that the photodynamic diode laser is a valuable instrument for removing or modifying the smear layer in root dentin, and it can improve the bond strength of self-adhesive cements.

column2: • The results suggest that the laser can be used as an alternative to traditional irrigation systems for smear layer removal.

column1: • The study's findings have implications for the use of self-adhesive cements in post restoration, and highlight the importance of removing or modifying the smear layer to improve bonding effectiveness.

column2: • The study's results support the use of the photodynamic diode laser as a tool for improving the bond strength of self-adhesive cements in post restoration.

column1: 651,"<summary>
• The human gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that plays a crucial role in our overall health and well-being.

column2: • The gut microbiome is composed of trillions of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi.
• Research has shown that the gut microbiome is involved in various physiological processes, including digestion, immune system function, and production of certain vitamins.

column1: • The composition of the gut microbiome can vary greatly between individuals and is influenced by factors such as diet, lifestyle, and genetics.

column2: • Studies have shown that an imbalance of the gut microbiome, also known as dysbiosis, has been linked to various diseases, including obesity, inflammatory bowel disease, and metabolic disorders.
• The gut microbiome can be modulated through dietary interventions, such as the consumption of probiotics and prebiotics, which can help to promote a healthy balance of microorganisms.

column1: • The enterotype concept has been proposed as a way to classify individuals based on their gut microbiome composition.

column2: • Enterotypes are distinct clusters of microbiome compositions that are associated with specific physiological and clinical characteristics.
• Research has shown that enterotypes can be influenced by factors such as diet and lifestyle, and may be associated with certain diseases.

column1: • The gut microbiome plays a crucial role in the regulation of energy metabolism and weight management.

column2: • Studies have shown that the gut microbiome is involved in the extraction and storage of energy from food, and that alterations in the gut microbiome have been linked to obesity and metabolic disorders.
• The gut microbiome can also influence appetite and satiety hormones, which can impact food intake and weight management.

column1: • Further research is needed to fully understand the complex interactions between the gut microbiome and human health.

column2: • The development of new technologies and analytical tools has enabled researchers to study the gut microbiome in greater detail.
• A better understanding of the gut microbiome and its role in human health may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of diseases.",0

column1: 652,"<summary>
* Onychomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the nail, characterized by discoloration, thickening, and defect.

column2: * The most common agents of onychomycosis are dermatophytes, yeasts, and nondermatophytes, with Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes being the most common.
* Aging and reduced peripheral circulation are among the major risk factors for onychomycosis, and diabetes can weaken the immune function, favoring slow nail growth and susceptibility to infections.

* Tazarotene, a synthetic retinoid, has been shown to be effective in treating onychomycosis, with a rapid and progressive amelioration of clinical parameters, and a fungistatic activity against Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Trichophyton verrucosum, Candida albicans, and Candida glabrata.

column3: * The treatment with tazarotene was well-tolerated, with only mild erythema on the perionychia in two patients.
* The study suggests that tazarotene could be a promising therapeutic approach for onychomycosis, particularly in patients with treatment-resistant forms or evident enhanced nail thickening.

653,"<summary>
• Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) is an important treatment for patients with heart failure and left ventricular (LV) dyssynchrony, but 25-35% of patients do not respond to CRT.

column2: • The study aimed to investigate the acute haemodynamic response to endocardial LV pacing in patients who did not respond to CRT.

column1: • The study included 24 patients with heart failure and LV dyssynchrony who did not respond to CRT.

column2: • The patients underwent an acute haemodynamic study to assess the response to endocardial LV pacing.

column1: • The study found that 11 patients had a positive response to endocardial LV pacing, with an increase in LV dP/dtmax of ≥15%.

column2: • The best response was seen in the basal and mid-posterolateral segments.

column1: • The study also found that the longest Q-LV interval was associated with the best haemodynamic response in 12 out of 14 patients.

column2: • The average Q-LV interval was 155±26 ms, and the average QRS width was 133±22 ms.

column1: • Ten patients were considered candidates for LV endocardial pacing, and 5 of them underwent implantation of an LV endocardial lead.

column2: • All 5 patients improved clinically with a reduction of at least 1 class in the NYHA score after 6 months of follow-up.

column1: • The study suggests that endocardial LV pacing guided by acute haemodynamic studies may be a useful approach for patients who do not respond to CRT.

column2: • Further studies are needed to confirm the long-term benefits of this approach.

column1: • The study highlights the importance of optimizing the pacing site and timing to achieve the best haemodynamic response.

column2: • The study also suggests that the Q-LV interval may be a useful parameter to guide pacing optimization.</summary>",0

column1: 654,"<summary>
* Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) affects 1 in 500 to 1 in 1000 individuals, with no clinical symptoms until the third or fourth decade of life.

column2: * Only half of patients will progress to renal failure, with risk factors including hypertension, renal hemorrhage, multiple pregnancies, male gender, and PKD1 disease genotype.
* The disease may not be predictable in young patients, but careful monitoring can help identify complications.

* Complications associated with pregnant subjects with chronic renal failure undergoing dialysis include maternal hypertension, preeclampsia, anemia, infected renal and hepatic cysts, pyelonephritis, and rupture of cerebral artery aneurysm during labor with subarachnoid hemorrhage.

column1: * A 35-year-old primigravida with ADPKD was scheduled for emergency cesarean section (LSCS) at full term.

column2: * She was diagnosed with ADPKD in the seventh month of pregnancy and was hospitalized and hemodialyzed thrice a week for two months.
* Her clinical parameters were stable, with a heart rate of 102/min, systemic blood pressure of 120/74 mmHg, and central venous pressure (CVP) of 1-2 cm H2O.
* She underwent spinal anesthesia with 1 ml of 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine (5 mg) with 25 mcg fentanyl, and a 2.0 kg live male child was delivered with an Apgar score of 9 at 5 min.

column1: * Women with moderate or severe antenatal renal insufficiency often experience deterioration of their renal functions during pregnancy.

column2: * The pathophysiology of this is unknown, but one hypothesis is that increased glomerular perfusion causes further injury to the kidneys in patients with preexisting impairment of function.

* Another hypothesis is that preexisting renal disease may induce a cascade of platelet aggregation, microvascular fibrin thrombus formation, and endothelial dysfunction that leads to microvascular injury.
* Increased cardiac output and decreased intrarenal vascular resistance in pregnancy cause an 80% increase in renal blood flow and a 50% increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

656,"<summary>
* The study investigated the effects of nordihydroguaiaretic acid (NDGA) on mouse and drosophila lifespan.

column2: * NDGA extended the median lifespan of mice by 12% at a dose of 373mg/kg body weight/day.

column1: * The study found that NDGA consumption was associated with an increase in multiple tumor types and hemorrhagic diathesis in mice.

column2: * The drug also increased the lifespan of drosophila, suggesting its target(s) and mechanism(s) of action may be phylogenetically conserved.

column1: * The optimal dose of NDGA for extending lifespan in mice was 3.5g/kg diet, but higher and lower dosages were ineffective.

column2: * The NIH-ITP found that NDGA extended male mouse lifespan at 2.5g/kg diet, but the actual dose was uncertain due to lack of continuous food intake measurement.

column1: * The study found little evidence for acute liver or kidney toxicity as measured by serum chemistries, but others reported that high doses of NDGA stunted growth and induced inflammatory lesions in mice and rats.

column2: * In humans, NDGA has been associated with toxic hepatitis, cirrhosis, and fulminant liver failure.

column1: * The mechanisms of NDGA's longevity effects are unclear, but may involve inhibition of mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) or other pathways.

column2: * NDGA decreased the mass of liver tumors by 24% relative to those found in control mice, suggesting it decreased the rate of liver tumor growth.

column1: * The study's results suggest that while NDGA reduces tumor growth rates, it increases tumor formation, and its effects on lifespan may be sex-dependent.

column2: * The data are inconsistent with the extension of lifespan through inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation or reduction of oxidative stress.</summary>",0

column1: 657,"<summary>

* Genetic variation contributes to disease susceptibility and treatment response, and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have enabled the discovery of genetic variants associated with complex diseases.

column2: * GWAS have identified many pharmacogenetic markers, which can be used to personalize medicine.
* Personalized medicine aims to improve medical decision-making by identifying the optimal drug and dosage for individual patients.

column1: * Biomarkers are characteristics that can be measured in the body and are used to diagnose, predict, or monitor diseases.

column2: * Biomarkers can be classified into different types, including DNA biomarkers, DNA tumor biomarkers, and general biomarkers.
* Biomarkers can be used to predict treatment response, monitor disease progression, and identify patients at risk of adverse reactions.

column1: * The development of biomarkers involves several phases, including discovery, assay development, retrospective validation, prospective investigation, and health economics study.

column2: * Each phase has specific goals and requirements, and the process can be iterative.
* The development of biomarkers is a complex process that requires careful planning and execution.

column1: * Biomarkers can be used to personalize treatment and improve patient outcomes.

column2: * Examples of biomarkers in current use include DNA biomarkers for breast cancer prognosis and predictive biomarkers for treatment response in hepatitis C virus-1 infection.
* Biomarkers can also be used to identify patients at risk of adverse reactions and to monitor disease progression.

column1: * The validation of biomarkers is a critical step in their development.

column2: * Validation involves assessing the analytical and clinical validity of the biomarker.
* The validation process can be complex and requires careful planning and execution.

column1: * The use of biomarkers in clinical practice requires careful consideration of their limitations and potential biases.

column2: * Biomarkers should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and other diagnostic tools.
* The use of biomarkers should be guided by evidence-based guidelines and regulations.",0

column1: 658,"<summary>
• Myosin Va (MyoVa) is a processive molecular motor involved in intracellular cargo transport along the actin cytoskeleton.

column2: • It consists of a pair of N-terminal motor domains connected to lever arms, followed by a coiled-coil rod domain, ending in a globular C-terminal cargo-binding domain.
• The motor's directed movement is accomplished by a conformational change in the motor domain following ATP hydrolysis.
• The lever arms consist of six tandem-helix motifs, stabilized by calmodulin or calmodulin-like light chains.

column1: • The flexural stiffness of MyoVa constructs and subdomains was measured using tethered particle microscopy (TPM).

column2: • TPM was used to directly measure the flexural stiffness of individual MyoVa motors and their subdomains.
• The measurements suggest that the lever arm flexural stiffness is critical for MyoVa's processive movement and that calcium signaling can tune this stiffness.
• The distal rod domain and lever arm/rod junction were found to be highly compliant, allowing MyoVa to maneuver through actin-actin intersections and switch tracks on actin bundles.",0

column1: 659,"<summary>

* The study aimed to determine if clinical outcome after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) could be predicted by functional polymorphisms in different proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.

column2: * Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the AURKA, ERBB2, MDM2, CDH1, CDKN2A, and TP73 genes were genotyped in a consecutive cohort of 346 esophageal cancer patients.

column1: * The study found no significant associations between the tested polymorphisms and disease-free survival (DFS) in patients with EAC or ESCC in univariate analysis.

column2: * However, in multivariate analysis, patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous MDM2 (rs2279744) T/G genotype had significantly improved DFS compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype.

column1: * The study also found that patients with EAC harboring the homozygous CDH1 (rs5030625) GA/GA genotype had a significantly reduced survival as compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype.

column2: * The MDM2 protein is a nuclear phosphoprotein that binds and inhibits the tumor suppressor TP53 as part of an autoregulatory negative feedback loop.

column1: * The study suggests that the variant MDM2 genotypes (T/G and G/G) may be associated with improved survival in EAC patients, possibly due to interaction with TP53 status.

column2: * The CDH1 GA/GA genotype may be associated with reduced survival in EAC patients, possibly due to suppression of CDH1 gene expression and impairment of cell-cell adhesion.

column1: * The study concludes that the results could contribute to the identification of patients who are at high or low risk for the development of disease recurrences and may serve as hypothesis-generating for prospective studies that evaluate the prognostic significance of germ-line variants.

column2: * Further prospective studies are necessary to validate the associations found in this study and to study the prognostic significance of both germ-line variants.",0

column1: 660,"<summary>
• Oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, with a prevalence of over 90% in some studies.

column2: • OPC can appear as erythematous patches or white, scrapable lesions and is often one of the first clinical signs of HIV infection.

column1: • The study found that Candida albicans was the most frequent species isolated in 92% of OPC cases, followed by Candida tropicalis and Candida glabrata.

column2: • The distribution of oral lesions based on CD4+ count showed that 62% of oral lesions occurred at CD4+ count < 200 cells/mm.

column1: • The study highlights the importance of continued awareness of OPC as a major clinical sign in HIV population, especially in patients with CD4+ cell counts < 200 cells/mm.

column2: • The use of fluconazole is effective in treating OPC, but the emergence of resistant species is a concern.

column1: • The study's findings are consistent with previous studies, which have shown that OPC is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, and that Candida albicans is the most frequently isolated species.

column2: • The study's results emphasize the need for continued monitoring and management of OPC in HIV patients, particularly in resource-limited settings.",1

column1: 661,"<summary>
• Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with approximately 1.67 million new patients diagnosed annually worldwide.

column2: • It predominantly spreads via the lymphatic system to locoregional lymph nodes.
• The sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) are defined as the first draining nodes from a primary tumor.
• The status of these lymph nodes is important for staging of the disease and determining prognosis.

column1: • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) with the combined technique of radioisotope and blue dye is the standard method for determining axillary staging in early-stage breast cancer patients.

column2: • The combined technique is performed by injecting a radioactive tracer and blue dye interstitially.
• The tracers are then detected within the SLNs by the surgeon using a handheld scintillation counter (gamma probe) and/or visually.
• The gamma probe is first used to transcutaneously localize the SLNs and determine the optimal incision site.

column1: • The use of radioisotopes is subject to stringent regulations on training of staff and handling and disposal of radioactive material.

column2: • Many hospitals in the world do not have access to radioisotopes.
• Only approximately 60% of patients in the Western world and negligible numbers in the rest of the world have access to SLNB.
• This has led to the search for other techniques, not reliant on the use of radioisotopes.

column1: • A magnetic tracer and a handheld magnetometer were evaluated against the combined technique as a radiation-free alternative in two separate clinical trials.

column2: • The magnetic technique was found to be noninferior to the combined technique with identification rates of 94.4%-98.0%.
• There was a discordance in SLNs identified between the magnetic and combined techniques that ranged between 2.0% and 6.9%.
• This potentially leads to false-negative staging with the magnetic technique.

column1: • Three superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIO)-based licensed formulations with a broad range in particle size were used as magnetic tracers in this study.

column2: • Feraheme/Rienso, Sienna+, and Endorem/Feridex were the three tracers used.
• The hydrodynamic particle size of all tracers was determined by dynamic light scattering.
• The tracers were diluted to the same iron concentration of 11.2 mg Fe/mL to facilitate comparison of performance.

column1: • A previously developed and validated porcine model that closely resembles human lymphatic drainage was used to evaluate the performance",0

column1: 663,"<summary>

• The study analyzed data from two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials to test surrogate variables for neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and explore the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing.

column2: • The trials included 190 ulcers from 190 patients with type 1 or 2 diabetes, Wagner grade 3 or 4 DFUs, and a median age of over 60 years.
• The study used intralesional injections of recombinant human epidermal growth factor (rhEGF) as the treatment, with a maximum of 8 weeks of treatment.

column3: • The treatment was administered adjuvant to standard care, which included thorough debridement, moist dressing, pressure offloading, and antibiotics if necessary.
• Patients with chronic, uncontrolled illness, psychiatric or neurologic diseases, or neoplasia were excluded from the study.

column1: • The study generated several surrogate variables, including percent change in area, log healing rate, and ratio of log areas at the 2nd week and end of treatment (EOT).

column2: • The variables were calculated using the area in mm and time in days, and the results were compared to the 4-week area change proposed by other authors.

column3: • The study used the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve to evaluate the capacity and quality of discrimination among individuals.

column1: • The study found that granulation tissue development at the EOT was an early predictor of final healing, with a 72.9% certainty and positive/negative predictive values of 71.7/75.8%, respectively.

column2: • The proportion mediated by granulation variables was very high, suggesting that almost 100% of the effect of the treatment on complete healing may have been mediated by the formation of granulation tissue.

column3: • The study confirmed that granulation tissue development is a good surrogate marker for complete wound closure in advanced DFUs.

column1: • The study's results can be useful for clinical trial design, particularly during the exploratory phase of development of new products, and may have relevant implications for healthcare programs managing diabetic foot ulcers.

column2: • The surrogate markers reported in the study can easily be applied by clinicians because the measurement of the proportion of wound area covered by granulation tissue is part of routine clinical care.

664,"<summary>
* Laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) mesh repair is a standard treatment for inguinal hernia in adults, but it is associated with early postoperative pain and chronic pain.

column2: * Surgical trauma to the abdominal wall, mesh implantation, and mesh fixation in the groin region are possible causes of the pain.

column1: * The ideal mesh material is still debated, but mesh fixation with fibrin glue or self-fixating mesh with microhooks has advantages in reducing chronic groin pain.

column2: * Guidelines suggest that using a 10-mm trocar in the umbilical region or oblique abdominal wall predisposes patients to local nerve or vessel injury and port-site hernia.

column1: * Modified TAPP repairs by needlescopic surgery (NTAPP) and single-incision laparoscopic surgery (STAPP) have been shown to be superior in patient outcomes over conventional TAPP repairs.

column2: * NTAPP uses smaller trocars than standard 10-mm optical trocars and 5-mm working trocars, while STAPP uses a single umbilical port.

column1: * The study compared the perioperative extent of surgical trauma and its postoperative impact on the abdominal wall after NTAPP and STAPP repair.

column2: * The study included 85 patients with single-sided primary inguinal hernia who underwent NTAPP or STAPP repair between 2009 and 2012.

column1: * The results showed that NTAPP required significantly less operating time than STAPP repair, especially in cases of direct hernia.

column2: * The mean length of postoperative hospital stay was similar between the two groups.

column1: * Postoperative pain was less in the NTAPP group, and they had a shorter mean period of sick leave compared to the STAPP group.

column2: * However, there was no significant difference in hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction between the two groups.

column1: * The study concluded that NTAPP with smaller caliber trocars can further minimize surgical trauma to the abdominal wall tissue and requires less operating time than STAPP.

column2: * NTAPP has distinct advantages in the immediate postoperative phase, including reduced postoperative wound pain and shorter sick leave.",0

column1: 665,"<summary>
• Mouth breathing in children can lead to morphological adaptations in the stomatognathic system, affecting facial growth and dental occlusion.

column2: • These adaptations can result in maxillary hypoplasia, posterior mandibular demotion/rotation, and alterations in speech, chewing, and deglutition.
• The main causes of mouth breathing in childhood include hypertrophy of the pharyngeal and/or palatine tonsils, nasal mucosa and turbinate edema, nasal septal deviation, and extended suction habits.

column1: • Nasopharyngoscopy is considered the gold standard exam for assessing the nasopharynx, providing a dynamic and tridimensional view of the pharyngeal tonsils and their relation to other structures.

column2: • Cephalometry is a complementary exam that provides information about craniofacial growth and can be used to document and monitor morphofunctional modifications related to mouth breathing.
• However, cephalometry tends to underestimate the size of the pharyngeal tonsils compared to nasopharyngoscopy.

column1: • The study found a regular and positive correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in diagnosing hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils, but cephalometry was not as accurate as nasopharyngoscopy.

column2: • The sensitivity of cephalometry was 35%, and the negative predictive value was 72%, suggesting that a negative cephalometric exam may not provide a proper assessment of the nasopharynx.
• Nasopharyngoscopy is recommended for children with mouth-breathing symptoms and normal radiography to ensure accurate diagnosis and treatment.

column1: • The study highlights the importance of multidisciplinary intervention, including physicians, phonoaudiologists, odontologists, and physiotherapists, in the care of mouth-breathing patients.

column2: • Cephalometry can provide early identification of alterations present in mouth-breathing patients and inform professionals about facial growth, morphological alterations, and dental occlusion.
• Collaboration between multidisciplinary staff members is essential for effective diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of mouth breathing in childhood.

column1: • The study suggests that patients presenting with mouth-breathing symptoms and normal radiography should be referred for a complementary assessment with nasopharyngoscopy.

column2: • Nasopharyngeal assessment of children can be performed with nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry, which are associated with a regular and positive correlation.
• However,",0

column1: 666,"<summary>
• Breast cancer treatment and recurrence

column2: • Breast-conserving treatment is as effective as mastectomy in terms of overall survival, disease-free survival, and long-term disease-free survival.

• Inflammatory breast carcinoma is a rare and aggressive form of locally advanced breast carcinomas, requiring a differential diagnosis with locally advanced noninflammatory breast carcinomas and non-neoplastic diseases.
• The risk of second breast cancer is the same whether the patient had previously undergone a mastectomy or breast-conserving therapy.

column1: • Ipsilateral breast tumor relapse (IBTR)

column2: • IBTR can be classified as either true local recurrence (TR) or new primary tumor (NPT) based on pathologic features, location, and genetic sequencing.

• TR has a poor prognosis and may benefit from more aggressive adjuvant treatment, while NPT generally has a favorable prognosis and therapeutic decisions should be similar to those in patients with de novo breast carcinoma.
• Salvage mastectomy is the standard treatment for all types of IBTR, but there is no conclusive evidence of its superiority compared to conservative surgery.

column1: • Follow-up and prevention

column2: • The care of breast cancer survivors requires an understanding of relapse patterns, establishing appropriate follow-up visits and screening tests.
• Patients with NPT benefit from adjuvant tamoxifen, if indicated, which reduces contralateral and ipsilateral disease recurrence with minimal side effects.
• There is a need for better chemoprevention strategies, especially for patients with a higher risk of developing contralateral breast carcinoma due to genetic predisposition.",1

column1: 667,"<summary>
* Study Overview

column2: * The study investigated the effect of switching from ranibizumab to aflibercept in patients with neovascular age-related macular degeneration (AMD) who had persistent fluid despite previous treatment.
* The primary outcome measure was change in contrast sensitivity (CS) at 12 weeks.
* The study included 40 patients with treatment-resistant neovascular AMD who received aflibercept injections every 2 months.
* The study found a statistically significant improvement in CS and a reduction in central retinal thickness (CRT) at 12 weeks.

column1: * Visual Function and Quality of Life

column2: * The study used the Pelli-Robson chart to measure CS, which is a standardized and reproducible technique.
* CS measurement provides a more complete understanding of visual function and quality of life in patients with neovascular AMD.

* The study found that two-thirds of patients experienced an improvement in vision-related quality of life, as measured by the National Eye Institute 25-Item Visual Function Questionnaire (NEI VFQ-25).
* CS measurement may provide early information on visual impairment not identifiable on visual acuity (VA) assessment alone.

column1: * Comparison to Other Studies

column2: * The study's results are consistent with other studies that have shown improvements in anatomic parameters and stable or moderately improved VA outcomes in treatment-resistant neovascular AMD patients switched to aflibercept from another anti-VEGF agent.

* The study's findings support the argument that measurement of CS may provide a more complete understanding of the benefits of anti-VEGF treatment on vision-related functional performance in patients with neovascular AMD.
* The study's results are limited by its small sample size and short follow-up period.
* Further studies are needed to validate the results and explore the use of CS measurement in other retinal diseases.

column1: * Clinical Implications

column2: * The study's results suggest that switching to aflibercept may be a viable treatment strategy for patients with neovascular AMD who have persistent fluid despite previous treatment.
* The study's findings support the use of CS measurement as a valuable additional outcome endpoint in clinical studies of neovascular AMD.
* The study's results may inform treatment decisions and improve patient care.
* Further research is needed to explore the long-term outcomes of switching to aflibercept and to develop personalized treatment strategies for patients with neovascular AMD.",1

column1: 668,"<summary>
• Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, causing cognitive and physical impairments.

column2: • It is a common disease, affecting young adults, with a prevalence of 85-90% in relapsing-remitting form.
• The exact cause of MS is unknown, but genetic and environmental factors, including viruses, are involved in its pathogenesis.
• Researchers are investigating the role of interleukin-25 (IL-25) in MS, as it regulates immune responses and is involved in the development of T helper 2 (Th2) responses.

column1: • The study aimed to evaluate the association between the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene and MS in an Iranian population.

column2: • The study included 74 patients with relapsing-remitting MS and 75 healthy controls, and used PCR amplification and RFLP to analyze the polymorphism.
• The results showed that the frequency distribution of the genotypes was not statistically different between patients with MS and controls.
• The study found no association between the c424c/a polymorphism and MS.

column1: • The study's results are consistent with a previous study that found no association between the c424c/a polymorphism and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

column2: • The study suggests that IL-25 may play a role in the pathogenesis of MS, but the c424c/a polymorphism is not important in this process.
• Other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene may regulate its expression and be associated with MS.
• The study's limitations include the small sample size and lack of evaluation of serum levels of IL-25.</summary>",0

• Endometrial cancer has become the most common invasive malignancy of the female genital tract in developed countries.

column2: • The incidence of endometrial cancer is increasing due to changes in lifestyle, such as lack of exercise and high fat intake leading to obesity and high BMI.
• Obesity triggers hormonal imbalance and hyperactive proliferative pathways, contributing to the pathogenesis of endometrial carcinoma.

column1: • Early screening methods for cervical cancer have made major progress, and a similar approach is needed for endometrial carcinoma.

column2: • Endometrial complex hyperplasia with atypia and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) are considered precursors of type I endometrioid adenocarcinoma.
• Endometrial glandular dysplasia is the precursor of type II carcinoma.

column1: • The SAP-1 device is a direct endometrial sampler designed for minimal pain during sampling, meeting the requirements for endometrial samplers.

column2: • The device has a soft loop that can flex within the endometrial cavity, and the spindles can easily obtain adequate endometrial cells with minimal chance of injuring myometrium and bleeding.

column1: • The study aimed to investigate whether liquid-based SurePath preparation for endometrial cytology test (ECT) can maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium.

column2: • Histology is the gold standard for evaluating the accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, positive prediction value (PPV), and negative prediction value (NPV) of ECT.

column1: • The study included 1514 patients with endometrial carcinoma risk factors who underwent SAP-1 sampling, and 375 of these women also underwent D&C or hysteroscopy.

column1: 676,"<summary>
* Biological invasions have been noted for centuries, with examples such as the phylloxera and chestnut blight.

column2: * The phylloxera destroyed grapevines and devastated the wine industry in Europe in the 1860s.
* The chestnut blight entered North America in the early 20th century and virtually eliminated a dominant tree species.
* Charles Elton's book in 1958 did not inspire a broad research thrust on invasions or a widespread public and policy response.

column1: * In the mid-1980s, an international project engaged over 100 prominent scientists and triggered an explosion of research on invasions.

column2: * This research included studies on how non-native invaders eat native species, compete with them, or infect them.
* Two new lines of research have become prominent: impacts at the ecosystem level and the role of genetics and evolution.
* Research has shown that introduced species can change ecosystem processes and physical structure.

column1: * Impacts of introduced species are more varied and widespread than previously thought.

column2: * Introduced species can affect nutrient cycles, fire cycles, and hydrology.
* Molecular genetic research has revealed cases of hybridization and introgression with native species.
* This research has also shown that introduced populations often combine genes from multiple source populations.

column1: * Critics of invasion biology argue that the problems are overblown and that introduced species can increase native biodiversity.

column2: * They also argue that the antipathy towards introduced species is xenophobic and that it is a hopeless battle to slow the spread of invasions.
* However, many complete species extinctions have been caused by introduced species, especially on islands.
* The key criticisms from an ecological standpoint are which introduced species really cause harm and can we really do anything about it.

column1: * Modern invasion biology is very new, and the great majority of introduced species have not been studied in their introduced ranges.

column2: * It is not possible to say that they have no significant impact without further research.
* The lag effect suggests that it would be foolhardy to wait for an impact to be recognized before acting.
* Eradication or containment may be possible if action is taken early.

column1: * Attempts to identify which species would be likely to become invasive have had some success.

column2: * Risk assessment tools have been developed, especially for plants.
* These tools are not foolproof, but they have been valuable in preventing some planned introductions.
* They can also be used to identify recently introduced populations that should be priorit",0

column1: 680,"<summary>
• Nasopharyngeal bursitis

column2: • Originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut
• Believed to be a remnant of embryonic communication between the notochord and the roof of the pharynx
• Normally disappears during the second month of intrauterine fetal development

column1: • Types of nasopharyngeal bursitis

column2: • Cystic type: develops if the embryonic remnant becomes obstructed
• Crust type: forms if crusts adhere to the orifice without obstruction
• Crust type can shed periodically, causing an offensive smell and unpleasant taste

column1: • Symptoms

column2: • Space-occupying lesion: nasal obstruction, eustachian tube obstruction, dysphagia, cranial nerve paralysis
• Rhinitis: choanal discharge, halitosis, pharyngitis, laryngitis, bronchitis, gastritis
• Pulsating headache and occipital pain felt at the external occipital tuberculum

column1: • Incidence and demographics

column2: • Approximately 4% incidence in adults
• Peak incidence between 15 and 30 years
• Caucasian predominance, no gender predilection

column1: • Diagnosis and treatment

column2: • Endoscopic examination of the nasopharynx and computed tomography scan/MRI
• Surgical technique: combined endonasal and transoral approach with electrocauterization
• Complete recovery with no recurrence of symptoms at more than one year postoperatively

column1: • Histopathology

column2: • Cystic type: epithelial cyst lined with columnar epithelium
• Crust type: reactive lymphoid mucosa with necrotic tissue
• Adjacent tissues may show reactive lymphoid mucosa with cicatricial streaks

column1: • Importance of awareness

column2: • Crust type may produce no symptoms other than retching and irritative expectoration of crusts
• Awareness of the crust type would pick up many missed cases and increase appropriate referrals
• Proper endoscopic nasopharyngeal examination with CT and MRI remains the best method of clinical assessment

column1: 684,"<summary>
* Toxoplasmosis is caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, which can infect humans as an intermediate host.

column2: * The primary host is a cat.
* Humans can become infected through contact with cat feces or contaminated food and water.
* Most people with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic.

column1: * Congenital toxoplasmosis can occur when a pregnant woman is infected, and the parasite enters the fetal circulation through the placenta.

column2: * This can cause a range of clinical manifestations, including chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, mental retardation, seizures, and intracerebral calcifications.
* Seizures are a common presenting symptom in patients with congenital toxoplasmosis.
* Many patients with congenital toxoplasmosis take anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) constantly.

column1: * The patient in this case report is a 34-year-old woman with congenital toxoplasmosis and medically intractable mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.

column2: * She had hydrocephalus and underwent ventriculoperitoneal shunting at 1 month old.
* She also had decreased visual acuity in both eyes and a history of seizures.
* Her seizures were characterized by psychic aura, right eyeball deviation, and head version.

column1: * The patient's seizures were not controlled with AEDs, and she underwent video-EEG monitoring and neuroimaging studies.

column2: * These studies revealed multifocal encephalomalacic change, left hippocampal sclerosis, and multifocal parenchymal calcification.
* The patient underwent epilepsy surgery with left anteromesial temporal resection, including the calcified lesion.
* The surgery was successful in controlling her seizures.

column1: * The case report highlights the association between congenital toxoplasmosis and mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.

column2: * The pathogenesis of hippocampal sclerosis in this case is unclear, but may be related to the calcified nodule or inflammatory reaction.
* The case report emphasizes the importance of comprehensive evaluation and surgical treatment for patients with congenital toxoplasmosis and medically intractable epilepsy.
* The report also highlights the need for careful prenatal and neonatal monitoring for congenital toxoplasmosis in Korea.

• Chondroblastoma is a rare bone tumor that accounts for less than 1% of all primary bone tumors.

column2: • It typically affects the epiphyseal regions of tubular bones, especially the ends of the tibia, femur, and humerus.
• It can also occur in the head and neck region, particularly in the temporal bone or temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

column1: • Chondroblastoma in the temporal bone can cause various symptoms, including:

column2: • Occlusal abnormalities, trismus, clicking of the TMJ, hearing impairments, dizziness, and otorrhea.

column1: • Malignant changes in chondroblastoma have been observed after irradiation, so radiation therapy should not be considered.

column2: • Instead, complete surgical removal is recommended for curative treatment.

column1: • The diagnosis of chondroblastoma can be difficult, especially in the temporal bone, due to its unusual histological features.

column2: • Incomplete resection carries a high risk of recurrence.

column1: • A 41-year-old male patient was misdiagnosed with otitis media and TMJ disorder, and underwent several unsuccessful treatments for 5 years.

column2: • He was eventually referred to the department with chronic hearing impairments and progressive trismus.

column1: • Imaging analysis and histopathologic examination revealed a giant cell tumor in the temporal bone, which was later diagnosed as chondroblastoma.

column2: • The tumor had progressively enlarged and destroyed the middle cranial fossa in the temporal lobe.

* The study examined fireworks-related eye injuries during the Diwali festival in a tertiary eye care hospital in North India over 5 consecutive years.

* The study highlights the importance of public awareness and strong legislation to regulate the manufacture, sale, and use of consumer fireworks to reduce the preventable cause of ocular morbidity.

691,"<summary>
* Subclinical hypothyroidism (SCH) is a common disorder characterized by elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with normal free thyroxine (FT4) levels.
* SCH is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality, particularly in individuals with higher TSH levels.
* The prevalence of SCH varies according to population, age, sex, race, region, and method of TSH measurement.
* SCH can lead to vascular problems, including increased vascular stiffness and endothelial dysfunction.
* The treatment of SCH is controversial, and the benefits and risks of replacement therapy remain unclear.
* Some studies suggest that T4 replacement therapy can improve cardiovascular function, reduce serum lipid levels, and improve symptoms in patients with SCH.
* However, other studies have not consistently shown beneficial effects of T4 treatment on cardiovascular outcomes.
* The TRUST study, a large randomized controlled trial, is currently underway to assess the effects of T4 replacement therapy on clinical outcomes in older adults with SCH.",0
692,"<summary>
* The study investigated patients with Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) who had submitted stool specimens for CD toxin testing.

column2: * The study aimed to compare patient characteristics, diarrhea duration, antibiotics usage, and severity among patients with toxin-positive stool, toxin-negative stool but toxin-positive isolates, and toxin-negative stool and isolates.
* The study found that patients with toxin-negative stool specimens had shorter diarrhea duration and milder symptoms compared to those with toxin-positive stool specimens.

column3: * The study suggested that patients with toxin-negative stool specimens but toxin-positive isolates may have milder symptoms due to low toxin concentration or other intestinal factors.
* The study found no significant differences in clinical characteristics, antibiotics usage, and inflammation among the three groups.

column1: * The study highlighted the limitations of enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for toxin detection, which has low sensitivity compared to polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

column3: * EIA directly measures toxin proteins in stool, making it a more accurate reflection of disease status, but it has a high positive predictive value.
* PCR detects the presence of bacteria with toxin genes, but may include carriers with diarrhea due to other causes.

column1: * The study suggested that patients with gdh-positive and toxin-negative stool specimens may not require CDAD treatment, but still require care to prevent hospital infection.

column3: * The study recommended nucleic acid amplification tests to detect toxigenic C. difficile in stool for CDAD diagnosis, but noted that toxin production is not evaluated.
* Further large-scale analysis is required to determine whether patient groupings reflect bacterial genetic characteristics.",0

column1: 693,"<summary>

* The DREAM trial was a large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial designed to determine whether ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay the development of type 2 diabetes in people with impaired fasting glucose (IFG) or impaired glucose tolerance (IGT).

column2: * The trial included 5,269 participants with IFG, IGT, or both, who were randomized to either ramipril and/or rosiglitazone and followed for a median of 3 years.
* The primary outcome variable was change in β-cell function over the course of follow-up, assessed using two measures: the insulinogenic index (IGI) and proinsulin (PI) concentration.
* Rosiglitazone significantly increased IGI/IR and reduced PI/C by 86% and 42%, respectively, indicating improved β-cell function.

column3: * These findings were consistent across glucose tolerance subgroups (IIFG, IIGT, and IFG+IGT), although the effect was more modest in the IIFG subgroup.
* Rosiglitazone's effect on diabetes prevention persisted after adjustment for baseline β-cell function.

column1: * Ramipril did not significantly affect β-cell function compared to placebo, suggesting that its glucose-lowering effects may operate through other metabolic mechanisms.

column2: * The study's major strengths include its large sample size, randomized, double-blind design, and completeness of follow-up.

* The study's major limitation is the lack of detailed measures of β-cell function, such as those obtained from the hyperglycemic clamp technique or the frequently sampled intravenous glucose tolerance test.

694,"<summary>
* Microbial communities exhibit complex interactions and emergent properties that cannot be predicted from the characteristics of individual strains.

column2: * The authors studied the interactions between pairs of E. coli auxotrophs, which are strains that lack the ability to synthesize a particular metabolite.

* They found that certain pairs of auxotrophs can complement each other's growth in minimal media by cross-feeding essential metabolites, a phenomenon they term ""synthetic mutualism in trans"" (SMIT).

* The authors developed a quantitative and predictive theoretical model that reveals the extent to which complex metabolic interactions emerge from the relatively simple topology of the biochemical reaction network.

column3: * The model is based on flux balance analysis (FBA) and takes into account the stoichiometric constraints of the metabolic network.
* The model predicts the growth of co-cultures and the efficiency of cooperation between strains, which is defined as the ratio of the benefit to the cost of metabolite exchange.

column2: * The authors found that the predicted efficiency of cooperation is correlated with the measured growth of co-cultures, and that strains tend to show the most growth when predicted to require only small quantities of metabolites that are cheap for their partner to produce.

column3: * The results provide new insights into the evolution of cooperation in microbial communities and have implications for the design of synthetic biological systems.
* The study demonstrates the power of combining experimental and theoretical approaches to understand complex biological systems.",0

column1: • The family pedigree suggested an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern of the disease.

column2: • The exon 8 sequencing of the CYLD gene revealed the heterozygous mutation c.1628_1629delct.

column1: • Genetic counseling was offered to the patient's first-grade relatives, providing information about the main characteristics of BSS and the 50% probability of descendants developing the syndrome.

column2: • The authors describe a new case of BSS due to the rare heterozygous CYLD gene mutation c.1628_1629delct in three women of the same family.",0

* Biological scaffold materials have been used for soft tissue repair applications, including hernia repair, breast reconstruction, and staple-line reinforcement.

column2: * These materials are particularly useful in clean-contaminated or contaminated settings due to their rapid revascularization and clearance of bacteria.

column1: * Permanent, synthetic polymer mesh materials are not typically used in these settings due to the risk of infection.

column2: * Biological scaffolds are also used as an alternative to fascial closure when there is excessive tension on the wound or tissue loss.

column1: * Dexon and Vicryl are two absorbable polymer scaffolds that have been used in the past, but they have limitations, including rapid loss of mechanical strength and resorption.

column2: * Dexon is fully resorbed in 2-3 months, while Vicryl is fully resorbed in 2-3 months as well.

column1: * Newer absorbable scaffold designs have been developed, including Gore Bio-A, Tigr Matrix, and Phasix Mesh.

column2: * These materials have longer-lasting polymers that degrade more slowly, making them more suitable for hernia repair applications.

column1: * Phasix Mesh is a fully resorbable polymer monofilament that is knitted into a flat sheet configuration.

column2: * It has been evaluated in a porcine model, where it demonstrated suitable mechanical properties, resorption profile, and histological characteristics.

column1: * The study found that Phasix Mesh had a suture retention strength of 59.16 N and a tear resistance strength of 30.33 N, which are suitable for hernia repair applications.

column2: * The mesh also demonstrated a maximum compressive load of 486.97 N and a tensile strength of 140.70 N/cm.

column1: * The study also evaluated the in vivo performance of Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug in a porcine model, where they demonstrated similar burst strengths and relative stiffness at 6, 12, 26, and 52 weeks.

column2: * The molecular weight of both materials decreased significantly over time, with Phasix Mesh decreasing from 300,397 Da to 44,434 Da at 52 weeks.

column1: * The study concluded that Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug are suitable for hernia repair applications due to their mechanical properties, resorption profile, and histological characteristics.

column2: * Further studies are needed to fully understand the long-term capabilities of these materials.",0

column2: * Double osteotomy was found to be beneficial for patients, resulting in a greater increase in MCA1.
* Placing a columellar strut was also found to be beneficial, resulting in a greater increase in MCA1 and MCA2.
* The study concluded that even in cases with mild septal deviation, performing septoplasty may increase patient nose patency.

column1: * The study's findings are consistent with previous studies, which have shown that nasal surgery can result in changes to nasal geometry and airflow.

column2: * The study highlights the importance of careful consideration in the region of the second constriction during surgery.

column1: 700,"<summary>
• Cardiovascular disease is a leading cause of mortality in many economically developed nations, accounting for about 30% of all deaths.

column2: • The incidence of cardiovascular disease is still increasing.
• Ongoing research aims to investigate and prevent the early development of cardiovascular risk factors.
• The beneficial effects of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) have been proved in several observational and experimental studies.

column1: • n-3 PUFAs have been shown to have anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, and antiarrhythmic effects.

column2: • Low-grade chronic inflammation is recognized as a prominent process in the development of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease.
• The induction of inflammation may provide a link between hyperlipidemia and atherogenesis.
• Atherosclerosis is considered a systemic disease featured by low-grade arterial inflammatory lesions.

column1: • n-3 PUFAs may play a significant role in modulating the inflammatory response.

column2: • Unsaturated fatty acids are referred to as PUFAs when two or more double bonds are present.
• There are two PUFA families, omega-3 (n-3) and omega-6 (n-6) fatty acids.
• The human body can produce almost all fatty acids, except linoleic acid and α-linolenic acid.

column1: • The beneficial effects of n-3 PUFAs have been confirmed in randomized controlled trials.

column2: • Several intervention studies have shown that an increased intake of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) lowers the risk of coronary heart disease.
• The GISSI-Prevenzione trial demonstrated a significant protective effect with doses much lower than those previously considered necessary.
• The JELIS trial showed a moderate decrease in both all-cause mortality and admissions to hospital for cardiovascular disease.

column1: • The incorporation of EPA and DHA into the cell membrane influences its organization, fluidity, and permeability.

column2: • Both EPA and DHA modulate K+, Na+, and Ca2+ channel activities in myocardial cells.
• The effects are concentration-dependent and appear to be mediated by the action of EPA and DHA on membrane fluidity.
• Animal studies support the increasing evidence that DHA rather than EPA is preferentially incorporated into the myocardial cell membrane.

column1: • n-3 PUFAs may interfere with cardiovascular disease through other physiological effects.
701,"<summary>
• Our understanding of H. pylori-induced inflammation leading to cancer is built on the work of three pioneering pathologists: Rudolf Virchow, Pelayo Correa, and Robin Warren.

column2: • Virchow is considered the father of modern pathology and proposed that cancer arises from initially normal cells in response to chronic irritation or inflammation.

• Correa developed a model for gastric cancer development, proposing that it results from a stepwise process beginning with chronic atrophic gastritis and progressing to intestinal metaplasia and cancer over 30-50 years.

column1: • Correa initially thought that environmental factors, such as diet, were responsible for promoting the progression from gastritis to cancer.

column2: • However, he later focused on the role of H. pylori in gastric cancer, and his model has stood the test of time.
• Warren and Marshall discovered H. pylori and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, and were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2005.

column1: • Initial investigations into the association between H. pylori and gastric cancer provided weak evidence for a link.

column2: • However, subsequent studies, including three large cohorts with nested case-controls, found that H. pylori infection was significantly associated with gastric cancer.
• The World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancer declared H. pylori a definite carcinogen in 1994.

column1: • H. pylori eradication can reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer.

column2: • Studies have shown that eradication decreases the risk of gastric cancer development by approximately 40% in primary prevention and 54% in tertiary prevention.
• The benefit of H. pylori eradication is most evident in subjects living in areas with high gastric cancer prevalence.

column1: • There is a concern about the ecologic consequences of using multiple antibiotics to prevent H. pylori-related disease.

column2: • However, recent results of vaccination against H. pylori with an oral urease B construct suggest that a non-antibiotic strategy may be possible.
• Further investigation of this vaccine should be a priority to avoid widespread antibiotic administration and the consequent problems of microbiome perturbation and antibiotic resistance.

column1: • H. pylori is less common in patients with esophageal adenocarcinoma than in matched controls.

column2: • The absence of H. pylori may promote more severe esophageal mucosal damage, Barrett's metaplasia, and the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
