* Preeclampsia (PE) is a leading cause of maternal and neonatal mortality and morbidity, complicating 25% of all pregnancies.

column2: * PE is classically diagnosed by the presence of proteinuria in women with gestational hypertension.
* However, several studies have shown that proteinuria is not a significant predictor of adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes.
* The incidence of PE increased in China after the introduction of the two-child policy.

column1: * Hypoalbuminemia may serve as an indicator of the severity of PE.

column2: * Hypoalbuminemia occurs due to systemic small vessel spasm, increased secretion of angiotensin, and damaged and increased permeability of vascular endothelial cells.
* This leads to a large number of proteins and liquid leaking into tissue clearance and a loss of a large number of plasma proteins.
* Hypoalbuminemia may accelerate the appearance of intravascular lesions.

column1: * The study aimed to evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE according to the different value of albumin (25 g/L and <25 g/L).

column2: * The study included 299 women with PE, divided into two groups: mild hypoproteinemia (MHP) and severe hypoproteinemia (SHP).
* The results showed that SHP was a significant risk factor for cesarean section, poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes.
* SHP was associated with increased risk of severe hypertension, abnormal liver or renal function, ascites, and abruptio placenta.

column1: * The study found that SHP was associated with a higher risk of adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes than MHP.

column2: * SHP was associated with a higher risk of cesarean section, severe hypertension, and abnormal liver or renal function.
* SHP was also associated with a higher risk of preterm delivery, low birth weight, and fetal growth restriction.
* The study suggests that SHP may be a useful indicator of the severity of PE and may help identify women at high risk of adverse outcomes.",0

* The results showed that there was no significant difference in the incidence of ONFH between the WB and NWB groups, suggesting that weight bearing does not contribute to the development of ONFH.

* The study's findings have implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of ONFH and the development of prevention strategies, but may not be applicable to the study of femoral head collapse.

column1: 712,"<summary>
* UTI is a common problem in infants and young children, with a frequency, symptoms, and causative organisms that vary by sex, age, and gender.

column2: * The frequency of UTI ranges from 4-25% in very low birth weight infants to 0.1-1% in term infants.
* UTI in neonates can lead to urosepsis or neonatal sepsis, making it a critical issue.

column1: * The most common causative organisms of UTI in neonates are gram-negative bacilli, with E. coli being the most prevalent.

column2: * Other enterobacteriaceae causing UTI in neonates include Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Citrobacter, Proteus, Providencia, Morganella, Serratia, and Salmonella.
* Gram-positive bacteria like Staphylococcus and Enterococcus are less commonly retrieved from neonates with UTI.

column1: * The study aimed to determine the frequency of UTI causative organisms in neonates admitted to the neonatal division of Bahrami Children's Hospital over an 8-year period.

column2: * The study included 73 cases, with a mean age of 14.14 days, mean birth weight of 3055.85 grams, and mean admission weight of 3180.55 grams.
* Boys constituted 69.9% of the study population, with a boys-to-girls ratio of 2.32.

column1: * E. coli was the most prevalent organism, with a relative frequency of 64.4%, followed by Enterobacter with a relative frequency of 19.2%.

column2: * E. coli was found to be mostly resistant to ampicillin (93.6%), cefixime (85.7%), and cephalexin (77.3%).
* The most sensitivity of E. coli was toward cefotaxime (63.6%), norfloxacin (100%), and ciprofloxacin (100%).

column1: * Enterobacter susceptibility pattern showed high resistance to amikacin (100%) and ampicillin (92.8%), and high sensitivity to ceftazidime (100%) and norfloxacin (100%).

column2: * Klebsiella and S. epidermidis were found to be completely (100%) resistant to ampicillin.
* The study highlights the need for continuous assessment of uropathogen epidemiology in the neonatal period.

713,"<summary>
• Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of autosomal recessive disorders that cause a deficiency in an adrenal enzyme, leading to altered cortisol and aldosterone secretion.

column2: • The most frequent form of CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD), which accounts for 95% of all affected patients.
• CAH can cause a range of symptoms, including virilization, hypertension, and cognitive impairment.

column3: • The study found that 42.3% of patients with CAH had MRI abnormalities, including white matter hyperintensities and temporal lobe atrophy.
• The abnormalities were more common in patients with poorly controlled CAH and those who had experienced adrenal crises in the neonatal period.

column1: • The study found that hormonal imbalance during brain development and corticosteroid treatment may contribute to the development of brain MRI abnormalities in CAH patients.

column2: • The abnormalities may be related to the effects of excess glucocorticoids on the brain, including changes in myelination and neuronal maturation.
• The study suggests that CAH patients may be at risk for cognitive impairment and other neurological problems.

column3: • Further studies are needed to define the relationships between brain involvement and different CAH phenotypes and treatment regimens.

column1: • The study highlights the importance of monitoring CAH patients for brain MRI abnormalities and cognitive impairment.

column2: • Early detection and treatment of these abnormalities may help to prevent long-term neurological problems.
• The study also suggests that CAH patients may benefit from cognitive and psychological assessments to identify any potential problems early on.

column3: • This may help to improve outcomes for CAH patients and reduce the risk of long-term neurological complications.

column1: • The study provides new insights into the effects of CAH on the brain and highlights the need for further research in this area.

column2: • The study's findings may have implications for the management and treatment of CAH patients.
• The study's results may also be relevant to other conditions that involve hormonal imbalance and corticosteroid treatment.

column3: • Further research is needed to fully understand the effects of CAH on the brain and to develop effective strategies for preventing and treating brain MRI abnormalities and cognitive impairment in CAH patients.",0

column1: 714,"<summary>
• The human genome draft sequence promises significant biomedical advances, but biologists must navigate vast genomic data to uncover hidden knowledge.

column2: • The genomic landscape appears featureless, but surveying and signposting can guide experiments and address specific hypotheses about gene function.
• Different biological communities speak in dialects, and adopting universal vocabularies is essential for understanding gene function.

column1: • There are two common ways of annotating genes: integrating information from diverse sources and predicting evolutionary relationships.

column2: • Websites like LocusLink, GeneCards, and Ensembl integrate sequence information, molecular and cellular function, and disease relevance.
• Annotation is essential, but currently restricted to characterized genes.

column1: • Homology-based annotation relies on predicted evolutionary relationships, defining genes that arose from a common ancestor as homologs.

column2: • Homologs have similar tertiary structures and functions, making it possible to infer function from homologous genes.
• However, homology assignment is approximate and may not indicate exact function.

column1: • Domain architectures are crucial for understanding protein evolution and function.

column2: • Domains are homologous portions of sequences that have survived evolutionary tests and represent the finite vocabulary of protein evolution.
• Resources like Pfam, SMART, and InterPro detect domains using numerical representations of multiple sequence alignments.

column1: • Proteome annotation by domain content implies that a gene product's function is a synthesis of its component parts.

column2: • This approach provides approximate predictions of molecular function, but not cellular or organismal role.
• Automatic annotation is necessary for newly sequenced genomes, which are in a high state of flux.

column1: • Comparative proteomics relates gene content to the evolution of eukaryotic organisms.

column2: • Domain family sizes may not directly relate to their contribution to cellular and organismal function.
• Future proteome comparisons should focus on understanding the biology underlying domain family sizes.

column1: • The Gene Ontology project aims to create a common vocabulary for describing gene function.

column2: • Orthology prediction and partitioning of domain families into subfamilies with distinct functions will guide genome navigation.
• Sophisticated web forums will integrate functional data, but integrating information from large datasets will be a major challenge.",0

column1: 715,"<summary>
* Heart rate monitors have been widely used in sports and sports science for 25 years, with recent developments focusing on real-time monitoring.

column2: * The study compared four commercially available systems: Polar Team Pro, Acentas Team Monitoring System, Suunto Pro Team Pack, and Activio Sport System.
* All systems allow direct and real-time monitoring of multiple individuals at the same time.
* Data are transmitted wirelessly to a receiver connected to a laptop with relevant software.

column1: * The study evaluated the systems' operating distance, validity against a commercially available ECG, and installation and use of software and hardware.

column2: * A total of 12 active people participated in the study, with 10 men conducting an online field test during a real football match.
* The study used a quality rating system with three main categories: measurement, software, and hardware.
* The rating system was weighted in favor of measurement, with subcategories rated subjectively by the authors.

column1: * The study found that Acentas and Polar led the field in terms of hardware, with high-quality receivers and storage capacity.

column2: * Activio offered a harmonious concept and the highest ranking in software evaluation.
* Acentas had the highest operating distance, with a range of 349m.
* The study found that all systems had their strengths and weaknesses, and no single system could be recommended.

column1: * The study's results should be used for further system improvements, and prospectively, online monitoring for swimmers could be a great challenge.

column2: * Some of the tested systems have been updated and upgraded with new functions.
* The study's investigators were responsible for the study design, data collection, and data analysis.
* The authors declare no financial conflict of interests with any of the companies named in the paper.

716,"<summary>
* Stem cell definition and characteristics

column2: * Stem cells have the ability to make identical copies of themselves (self-renewal)
* Stem cells can proliferate extensively and self-renew in vitro
* Stem cells can be isolated and tracked using cell surface proteins unique to stem cells

column1: * Stem cells in the lung

column2: * Populations of stem cells have been identified throughout the lung by their role in response to injury
* Stem cells in the lung exhibit self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency
* The earliest stages of lung malignancies may be related to a deregulation of this stem cell-based repair mechanism

column1: * Proximal airways

column2: * Tracheal basal cells are pluripotent and express keratin-5 (K5) and keratin-14 (K14)
* K5 and K14 cells are capable of the functional aspects of stem cell niches
* Squamous cell carcinoma may arise from K5 stem cells

column1: * Middle airways

column2: * Clara cells can proliferate into phenotypically diverse progeny
* Clara cells are facultative progenitor cells, capable of but not limited to behavior indicative of a stem cell
* Small cell lung carcinomas may arise from mid-airway stem cell subpopulations

column1: * Distal airways

column2: * There is no consensus on the cell surface marker phenotype of representative lung stem cells
* CCSP cells in the bronchoalveolar duct junction (BADJ) are pluripotent and can differentiate into diverse populations of cells
* Carcinomas of the distal airway may arise from stem cells from the BADJ region

column1: * Cancer stem cell hypothesis

column2: * Relatively rare, multipotent cells gain unlimited proliferative potential and drive tumor growth
* The multipotent nature of these cells leads to heterogeneity within the tumor
* Stem cells express high levels of anti-apoptotic and drug-resistant proteins

column1: * Targeted therapies

column2: * Targeting lung cancer stem cells or the pathways that confer stem cell-like properties may lead to major therapeutic advances
* Measurement of the lung cancer stem cell fraction in a tumor could prove a useful modality for differentiating between transient tumor debulking effects of chemotherapy and longer lasting therapies
* CD133 cells isolated from lung cancer specimens exhibit stem-like properties and may be a target for therapy

column1: * Controversies and future directions

column2: * It remains difficult to discriminate between potential or facultative and",0

• The study examined the role of urethral plate character in the success of TIP repair for primary anterior penile hypospadias in 100 children.

column2: • The study found that patients with urethral plate width < 8 mm had a statistically significant higher fistula rate and failed 8 fr calibration compared to patients with urethral plate width > 8 mm.
• The study also found that patients with flat urethral plate had a higher fistula rate and failed 8 fr calibration, although not statistically significant.

• The study concluded that TIP urethroplasty has good cosmetic and functional results, and urethral plate augmentation with buccal mucosal graft may be recommended for patients with narrow and inelastic urethral plate.

719,"<summary>
* Trichomonas vaginalis infection is a common and curable STI that affects 173 million people annually, with adverse reproductive health outcomes.

column2: * It is associated with pelvic inflammatory disease, low infant birth weight, and premature delivery.
* It increases the transmission and acquisition of other STIs, including HIV infection.

column1: * The frequency of trichomonal infection is not monitored in most countries, and control programs do not exist.

column2: * Peruvian STI guidelines do not include trichomonas diagnostic testing, and syndromic management is the current standard for clinical care.
* Long-standing, asymptomatic infections may lead to continued community-level transmission.

column1: * This study aimed to understand the epidemiology of trichomonal infection in women in low-income neighborhoods in Peru.

column2: * The study enrolled 308 women from 20 communities and found a high prevalence of trichomonal infection.
* The prevalence was higher among older women, those with less education, and those with multiple sex partners.

column1: * The study found no association between vaginal symptoms and trichomonal infection.

column2: * Syndromic management of trichomonal infection may result in over and under treatment.
* The asymptomatic nature of trichomonal infection contributes to its spread in the population.

column1: * The study's findings are important for disease control programs, as socially marginalized women are often under-represented in health care and may maintain endemic trichomonal infections.

column2: * The study's results support the need for improved disease control activities to reduce adverse reproductive health outcomes.
* Further studies are needed to determine if screening and treatment of trichomoniasis will improve reproductive health and birth outcomes.

column1: * The study had some limitations, including a small sample size and potential selection bias.

column2: * The results may not be generalizable to other female populations.
* The study's findings highlight the need for prioritizing the screening and treatment of sex partners of infected women to prevent reinfection and reduce infection prevalence.",0

* Rufinamide is a novel anticonvulsant drug with promising potential for treating Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS)

column3: * It has a broad-spectrum of anticonvulsant effectiveness in animals, including the maximal electroshock model and the subcutaneous pentylenetetrazol model
* It has a good safety profile and is well tolerated with minimal expected side effects, such as somnolence and vomiting
* It appears to be effective in reducing total seizures and tonic-atonic seizures in patients with LGS

column1: * Rufinamide's role in the treatment of LGS needs to be further defined, including its place in the treatment algorithm and its relationship to prior drugs with reported effectiveness

column3: * A larger number of patients must be treated with this medication to establish its role in the treatment armamentarium
* The study populations are notoriously difficult to treat, with multiple anticonvulsant medications and seizures of several different types
* Patient and caretaker satisfaction data need to be obtained to fully understand the benefits of rufinamide
* Further research is needed to determine the optimal dosage and titration schedule for rufinamide in patients with LGS",0

column1: 722,"<summary>
• The scientific activity of researchers is manifested through published papers, which are validated and legitimized by their peers.

column2: • These papers serve as indicators of the degree to which their scientific knowledge in their area of research has been developed.

column1: • The formal means of releasing scientific publications include national and international scientific journals indexed into databases representing various areas of knowledge.

column2: • Examples of major international databases include Medline/PubMed, Web of Science, Embase, and Current Contents.

column1: • In Brazil, the main databases are LILACS (Latin American and Caribbean Health Sciences) and SciELO (Scientific Electronic Library Online).

column2: • SciELO is a database allowing free access to full texts of Brazilian, Latin American, and Caribbean scientific literature.

column1: • Medline/PubMed is the most often searched database, offering free access and containing over 5,100 titles.

column2: • It allows researchers to retrieve information using a controlled vocabulary known as Medical Subject Headings (MeSH).

column1: • The recovery of articles and citations can be complicated by the different ways authors' names and institutions are entered.

column2: • This can make it difficult for researchers to find desired articles and for institutional evaluations to be made.

column1: • The journals selected for publication reflect the level of productivity of a research group and, consequently, the institution to which they belong.

column2: • The impact factor (IF) of a journal is calculated from the number of citations of the articles published by the journal over a two-year period.

column1: • The evaluation of scientific production from a university is complex and involves different areas of knowledge, each with its own peculiarities.

column2: • Analysis of smaller units, like university departments, disciplines, or services, can be made more easily.

723,"<summary>
• Rubella Infection and Vaccination

column2: • Rubella infection during early pregnancy has a 90% chance of passing the virus to the fetus, leading to Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS).
• Vaccination of susceptible individuals, especially women of reproductive age, can prevent the disease and its complications.
• The primary purpose of rubella vaccination is to prevent congenital infection and CRS, which affects an estimated 110,000 infants each year in developing countries.
• Rubella is a global disease, and vaccination has decreased its spread among children.

column1: • Immunity and Vaccination Efficacy

column2: • The most commonly used vaccine globally is derived from the RA27/3 virus strain, which induces seroconversion in 95% of vaccinated persons.
• Seroepidemiological studies have been conducted globally to evaluate the situation of protective antibodies and the need for vaccination against rubella virus.
• In Iran, studies have shown a significant increase in immunity against rubella after vaccination, with a rise in seropositivity from 79.6% to 99.3%.
• The effectiveness of the RA27/3 vaccine has been demonstrated by the elimination of rubella and CRS from the Western Hemisphere and several European countries.

column1: • Iranian National Vaccination Program

column2: • In 2003, Iran added rubella and mumps vaccines to its national vaccination plan, and almost all individuals aged 5-25 were vaccinated.
• The national immunity program was commenced in December 2003, with a target of vaccinating 33,579,082 people, and 98% of the target population were vaccinated.
• The program resulted in a decrease in the appearance of measles and rubella to less than one case per million.
• The study's findings are in line with reliable sources and extensive country studies that have compared immunity rates before and after vaccination.

column1: • Comparison with Other Studies

column2: • The study's results are consistent with those reported from Mashhad, Shahre-Kord, and Hamadan cities in Iran.
• The level of immunity before and after vaccination has been reported to be 70.38% and 98.5%, respectively, in Mashhad.
• In Shahre-Kord, the level of immunity increased from 86% to 96% after vaccination.
• In Hamadan, the level of anti-rubella antibody increased from 83.5% to 98.4% after vaccination.

724,<summary>
• Quantum dots (QDs) are used for non-amplified whole-mount fluorescent in situ detection of endogenous mRNAs in Xenopus embryos.

column2: • QDs have ideal optical properties for use in biology, including strong fluorescent signal emission, narrow and tunable emission spectra, and resistance to photobleaching.
• QDs can be used to detect multiple transcripts simultaneously, allowing for the creation of three-dimensional maps of expression at high resolution.
• The use of QDs eliminates the need for enzymatic amplification, which can limit the resolution of traditional in situ hybridization methods.
• QDs can be used in conjunction with proteinase K treatment to enable deep tissue staining and specific deep tissue staining in whole-mount immunostaining experiments.

column1: • The QD in situ protocol is capable of detecting endogenous mRNAs in Xenopus embryos with high resolution and strong signal intensities.

column2: • The protocol uses biotin-, FITC-, and digoxigenin-labeled RNA probes and QD-streptavidin and QD-anti-FITC conjugates.
• The use of QDs allows for the detection of mRNAs in deep tissues and provides a high signal-to-noise ratio.
• The protocol can be used to detect multiple transcripts simultaneously, including endodermin, xbra, and myod.

column1: • The QD in situ protocol has several advantages over traditional in situ hybridization methods.

column2: • The protocol eliminates the need for enzymatic amplification, which can limit the resolution of traditional methods.
• The use of QDs provides strong fluorescent signal emission and narrow and tunable emission spectra.
• The protocol allows for the detection of mRNAs in deep tissues and provides a high signal-to-noise ratio.
• The protocol can be used to create three-dimensional maps of expression at high resolution.

column1: • The QD in situ protocol has been used to detect several mRNAs in Xenopus embryos, including ltbp1, amylase, edd, xbra, and myod.

column2: • The protocol has been used to detect mRNAs in the head region, branchial arches, and somites of Xenopus embryos.
• The protocol has been used to detect mRNAs in the gut, pancreas, and muscle somites of Xenopus embryos.
• The protocol has been used to detect mRNAs in the cytoplasm and near the plasma membrane of Xenopus embryos.

column1: • The QD in situ protocol",0
725,"<summary>
* The study developed and validated two Cox proportional hazards models for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) patients, stratified by tumor extension (Localized PDAC and Extended PDAC).

column2: * The models were trained on a large dataset of 18,352 pathologically confirmed PDAC cases from the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database.
* The models included 13 categorical variables, including demographic, clinical, and treatment-related factors.

column1: * The models were validated using c-indices, calibration plots, and cross-validation, and showed good discrimination and calibration.

column2: * The c-indices for the Localized PDAC and Extended PDAC models were 0.702 and 0.712, respectively.
* The models were also tested for generalizability and transportability to different geographic areas.

column1: * A web-based tool (estimator) was developed to estimate survival probability, conditional survival probability, and their standard errors for PDAC patients using the models.

column2: * The estimator uses personalized demographic and clinical data, as well as information on medical treatment, as input data.
* The estimator provides a more accurate and personalized assessment of survival probability compared to clinicians' personal experience.",0

column1: 726,"<summary>
• Study population and methods

column2: • 278 CLI patients underwent PTA between 2003 and 2009 at Kansai Rosai Hospital in Japan
• Patients were evaluated for limb ischemia by angiography and diagnosed with CLI according to TASC II guidelines

column1: • Preoperative variables and outcomes

column2: • Preoperative variables included sex, age, ADLs, Fontaine stage, infection, diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, smoking, and serum albumin level
• Outcomes included limb salvage and survival, with major amputation and mortality as endpoints

column1: • Diabetes and glycemic control

column2: • Diabetes was associated with major amputation, but not mortality
• A1c level was independently associated with major amputation, with higher levels (≥6.8%) conferring greater risk

column1: • Prognostic factors for limb salvage

column2: • Diabetes with A1c ≥6.8%, infection, and hemodialysis were independently associated with major amputation
• The accumulation of these prognostic factors increased the amputation risk, with those having all three factors having a poor prognosis

column1: • Prognostic factors for survival

column2: • Age, impaired ADLs, hemodialysis, and serum albumin level were associated with mortality
• Diabetes and A1c level were not associated with mortality

column1: • Comparison with nondiabetic patients

column2: • Diabetic patients with A1c ≥6.8% had a higher risk of major amputation compared to nondiabetic patients
• Diabetic patients with A1c <6.8% did not have a significantly higher risk of major amputation compared to nondiabetic patients

column1: • Peripheral arterial factors

column2: • Preoperative peripheral arterial factors (Fontaine stage, ankle-brachial index, and runoff below the ankle) were not associated with limb salvage
• Postoperative peripheral blood flow was associated with limb salvage

column1: • Nutritional status

column2: • Serum albumin level was used as a nutritional marker and was associated with mortality
• Malnutrition was confirmed to be associated with mortality using other nutrition-related markers

column1: • Limitations and future directions

column2: • The study was limited to CLI patients undergoing PTA and did not include patients undergoing bypass surgery or nonrevascularized patients
• Further prospective studies are needed to determine whether interventions on glycemic control improve prognosis

column1: • Conclusion

column2: • Prognostic indicators differ between survival and limb salvage in CLI patients undergoing PTA",0

column1: 727,"<summary>
• Human cystic echinococcosis (CE) is a parasitic zoonosis caused by Echinococcus granulosus, which can lead to fluid-filled cysts in the liver, lungs, and other viscera.

column2: • CE is common in areas where there is close contact between intermediate and definitive hosts, usually sheep and dogs.
• Humans acquire the infection by ingesting E. granulosus eggs in contaminated dog feces.
• Diagnosis is typically made through radiology and serology.

column1: • The study aimed to identify specific antigens for the serologic diagnosis of CE and monitor post-operative patients using Western blotting.

column2: • The study included 50 CE patients, 40 non-CE patients, and 20 healthy controls.
• Serum samples were collected before and after treatment, and Western blotting was used to analyze IgG reactivity against hydatid cyst fluid antigen.
• The results showed multiple immunoreactive bands ranging from 18-239 kDa.

column1: • The major immunoreactive bands were 24, 39, 46, 52, 57, 60-61, and 63 kDa, which were specific for hydatid disease.

column2: • The 39 kDa band reactivity decreased significantly in post-operative samples, while the 24 kDa band persisted in two patients who had a relapse.
• The antigenic fractions of 52, 46, 39, and 24 kDa in combination may serve as useful diagnostic markers.
• The Western blotting technique appears to be a useful method for diagnosing hydatidosis and post-surgical monitoring.

column1: • The study's results are in agreement with previous studies, which have reported similar immunoreactive bands in CE patients.

column2: • The variability in results may be due to differences in antigen sources, purification protocols, and experimental conditions.
• The Western blotting technique can detect specific antibodies against hydatid antigens, which can be used for post-surgical monitoring.
• Further studies are required to analyze the behavior of these antibodies after medical treatment.

column1: • The study's findings suggest that Western blotting can be a useful tool for diagnosing and monitoring CE patients.

column2: • The technique can detect specific antibodies against hydatid antigens, which can help identify patients who require further treatment.
• The study's results can contribute to the development of more effective diagnostic tools for CE.
• Further research is needed to validate the use of Western blot",0

column1: 728,"<summary>
• The study examined the relationship between obesity indices and lipid metabolism parameters in 66 obese non-diabetic patients.

column2: • The patients were divided into three groups based on their obesity level: class I (BMI 30-34.9 kg/m), class II (BMI 35-39.9 kg/m), and class III (BMI ≥40 kg/m).
• The study found that patients with class III obesity had lower mean serum levels of total cholesterol and LDL-C compared to patients with class I obesity.

column1: • The study found significant correlations between obesity indices and lipid metabolism parameters.

column2: • Negative correlations were found between BMI, WC, WHR, and HDL-C, and positive correlations were found between WC, WHR, and TG/HDL-C.
• The VAI index demonstrated the strongest correlation with TG and HDL-C levels and with lipid indices TC/HDL-C, LDL-C/HDL-C, and TG/HDL-C.

column1: • The study suggests that obesity, especially abdominal obesity, is significantly associated with dyslipidemia, which manifests itself mainly with reductions in HDL-C.

column2: • The VAI index may be the most valuable obesity index in obese patients with dyslipidemias.
• The study's findings support the importance of considering obesity indices in the assessment of cardiovascular risk in obese patients.

column1: • The study's results are consistent with previous studies that have found a relationship between obesity and lipid disturbances.

column2: • The study's findings are also consistent with previous studies that have found a negative correlation between BMI and HDL-C levels.
• The study's results suggest that the relationship between BMI and LDL-C levels is complex and depends on numerous factors such as age or sex.

column1: • The study's strengths include its focus on obese patients grouped according to obesity level, especially among the morbidly obese (BMI ≥40 kg/m).

column2: • The study's use of multiple obesity indices, including VAI, WHTR, and BAI, provides a more comprehensive understanding of the relationship between obesity and lipid metabolism.
• The study's findings have implications for the assessment and management of cardiovascular risk in obese patients.",0

column1: 729,"<summary>

• Internet addiction is a growing concern worldwide, with studies suggesting that it can be a subset of behavioral addiction, characterized by salience, mood modification, tolerance, withdrawal, conflict, and relapse.

column2: • The prevalence of internet addiction varies across studies, with some reporting 6% among the general population and 14% among college students.

• The study found that internet addiction is more common among males, and addicts tend to use the internet for social networking, academic purposes, chatting, emailing, gaming, and downloading media files and pornography.
• The study used the Internet Addiction Test (IAT) and the Duke Health Profile to assess internet addiction and its impact on mental and physical health.

column3: • The IAT is a 20-item 5-point Likert scale that measures the severity of self-reported compulsive use of the internet.
• The Duke Health Profile is a 17-item generic questionnaire that measures adult self-reported functional health status.

column1: • The study found that internet addicts have poor mental, physical, and social health scores, and are more likely to experience anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression.

column2: • The study suggests that internet addiction may be a distinct disorder or a behavioral problem secondary to another disorder, and that further research is needed to understand its effects on human behavior and to develop interventions.

column3: • The study recommends setting boundaries and detecting early warning signs of underlying psychopathology.
• The study highlights the need for further research to understand the association between internet usage and its effects on human behavior.</summary>",0

column1: 730,"<summary>
• Measurement setup

column2: • The frequency response of the resonators was measured using a downmixing method.
• The device was electrostatically actuated, and the driving voltage was applied to a side-gate parallel to the resonator.
• The drive signal was set to half the actuation frequency to reduce parasitic signals.

column1: • Actuation and biasing

column2: • A bias voltage was used to down-mix the resistance change of the gauges.
• The bias voltage was set to 1.5 V at a measurement frequency of 500 kHz.
• All measurements were performed in a vacuum chamber at a pressure of 10 mbar and at room temperature.

column1: • Allan deviation measurement

column2: • The Allan deviation was measured in open-loop configuration.
• The frequency stability was extracted from the response of the resonator actuated at resonance frequency with a fixed driving frequency.
• The phase of the measured signal was monitored and transformed into frequency fluctuations using the phase response of the resonator.

column1: • Correlation measurement

column2: • Correlation measurements were performed by simultaneously measuring the response of the resonator at different frequencies within the resonator's bandwidth.
• The measurement setup was based on the one described in supplementary section 3, but with doubled signals.
• Particular care was taken to choose drive signal amplitudes to keep the resonator in the linear regime.

column1: • Data processing

column2: • The phase traces were converted to frequency traces corresponding to different integration times.
• The complete phase response of the resonator was used rather than the linear approximation.
• Harmonics appearing at the frequency of the electricity supply were filtered out of data during post-processing.

column1: • Allan deviation calculation

column2: • The Allan deviation for a given integration time was calculated using equation (2).
• The Allan deviation for higher integration times was obtained by averaging initial samples in groups of n samples.
• The process was repeated multiple times until the number of samples was too low to provide a statistically significant result.

column1: • Correlation calculation

column2: • The correlation coefficient of the filtered frequency traces was defined by equation (4).
• The correlation for a given τ only depends on frequency variations with characteristic time close to τ.
• The Allan deviation transfer function was used as the band-pass filter.

column1: • Experimental conditions

column2: • Thermomechanical noise was measured using the same setup, with the drive electrode disconnected.
• Measurements were taken with a lock-in amplifier, which also generated the drive and bias signals.

731,<summary>
• The study examines the use of aspirin for cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention in the US population.

column2: • The study found that less than a third of patients eligible for primary prevention reported being recommended by their doctor to take aspirin.
• Among high-risk patients, fewer than half received a recommendation for aspirin, and among low-risk patients, over a quarter received a recommendation.

column1: • The study also found that demographic and access-to-care variables, such as education level, insurance status, and having a regular source of care, were predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin.

column2: • The study suggests that decisions for treatment recommendations seem to be being made on criteria other than objectively calculated future CHD risk.

column1: • The study highlights the need for improved clinical decision support and interventions to ensure that patients receive appropriate preventive care.

column2: • The study's findings have implications for quality of care and patient outcomes, particularly for high-risk patients who are not receiving the recommendation and low-risk patients who are exposed to adverse risks with unnecessary use of aspirin.

column1: • The study's limitations include reliance on self-reported data, limited generalizability to younger populations, and lack of information on use of warfarin or other anticoagulant/antiplatelet therapy.

column2: • The study's results suggest that further research is needed to understand physician prescribing practices and patient usage of aspirin, particularly in the context of other antiplatelet and anticoagulant use.",0

column1: 732,"<summary>
* Mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (mROS) play a crucial role in cellular signaling pathways, including those regulating tumorgenesis, immune responses, and cellular adaptation to stresses.

column2: * mROS generation is required for the propagation of numerous cellular signaling pathways.
* The exact oxidative events required for the effects of ROS on these pathways are unknown and likely involve multiple oxidative targets.

column1: * Mitochondrial metabolism and ROS production promote signaling through pathways required for differentiation of mammalian stem cell populations in vivo.

column2: * Increased mitochondrial and oxidant content correlates with stem cell differentiation, while low mitochondrial mass and oxidant content correlates with stem cell maintenance.
* mROS act as pro-differentiation signals and are key upstream regulators of stem cell fate decisions.

column1: * The regulation of epidermal homeostasis involves the interplay between mitochondrial metabolism and ROS production.

column2: * Mitochondrial calcium uptake promotes the mitochondrial metabolism and ROS production required for epidermal differentiation.
* Uncoupling protein 2 (UCP2) may play a role in regulating differentiation-dependent metabolism.

column1: * The mechanisms by which mitochondrial metabolism promotes cellular differentiation remain poorly understood, but may involve the nutrient-dependent regulation of chromatin.

column2: * Acetyl-CoA, a key fuel for oxidative metabolism, is also a substrate used by histone acetyltransferases to acetylate histones and other cellular proteins.
* Global increases in histone acetylation are associated with differentiation of embryonic stem cells, 3T3-L1 preadipocytes, and keratinocytes.",1

column1: 733,"<summary>
* Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a single-stranded RNA virus that is difficult to detect in serum due to low viral levels.

column2: * Diagnosis is typically made using branched chain DNA signal amplification assay and reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
* HCV detection in liver tissue is important for routine diagnostic purposes.

column1: * The study aimed to establish a reliable histochemical technique for detecting HCV-RNA in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) liver tissues.

column2: * The technique used a locked nucleic acid (LNA) probe and biotin-free tyramide amplification system (CSAIi).
* The LNA probe was targeted at the HCV-5 untranslated region (HCV-5UTR), a highly conserved portion of the HCV genome.

column1: * Humanized liver specimens from HCV-infected chimeric mice were used as positive controls.

column2: * The mice were maintained by M. Kohara, Department of Microbiology and Cell Biology, Tokyo Metropolitan Institute of Medical Science, Tokyo.
* A total of 13 humanized liver specimens were used, including non-infected, genotype 1a-infected, genotype 1b-infected, and genotype 2a-infected specimens.

column1: * Needle biopsy liver specimens from patients with chronic hepatitis C were also examined.

column2: * A total of 11 specimens were used, including specimens from patients with hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, fatty liver, and autoimmune hepatitis.
* The activity of inflammation and the degree of fibrosis were evaluated according to the New Inuyama classification (1996).

column1: * The LNA-based in situ hybridization (ISH) technique was used to detect HCV-RNA in FFPE sections.

column2: * The technique involved hybridization with the LNA probe, followed by signal amplification using CSAIi.
* The reaction products were visualized using diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride and hydrogen peroxide.

column1: * The specificity of the ISH technique was verified by treating consecutive sections with DNase and RNase.

column2: * The technique was able to detect HCV-RNA in the cytoplasm of almost all chimeric human hepatocytes.
* The positive signals remained after DNase treatment but were completely abolished after RNase treatment.

column1: * The study showed that LNA-based ISH can be used to detect HCV-RNA in FFPE liver biopsy specimens.

column2: * The technique is relatively simple",0

column1: 734,"<summary>
* The amphibian metamorphosis assay (AMA) is a standardized test used to detect potential endocrine disruptors, particularly those that affect the thyroid system.

column2: * The AMA uses larval African clawed frogs (Xenopus laevis) and measures endpoints such as mortality, developmental stage, hind limb length, snout-vent length, and wet body weight, as well as thyroid gland histology.
* The thyroid gland histology is a sensitive and reliable endpoint for detecting antithyroidal activity, but less useful for weak agonistic effects.

* The AMA has undergone extensive validation and has been adopted by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as a guideline for testing of chemicals.

column1: * The AMA is based on the functions of the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid (HPT) axis, which is conserved between vertebrates, and the thyroid hormone balance is influenced by various processes such as sulfation, deiodination, and glucuronidation.

column2: * The AMA has been used to test various chemicals, including thyroid-disrupting substances, and has shown that some chemicals can alter the timing of metamorphosis, while others have no effect.

* The AMA is a useful tool for detecting potential endocrine disruptors, but further research is needed to determine whether exposure to chemicals at environmentally relevant concentrations can affect frog metamorphosis.",0

column1: 735,"<summary>
• Cesarean sections (CS) are necessary for life-saving and preventing maternal or perinatal complications, but the rate of CS without medical indication is increasing worldwide.

column2: • The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a CS rate of 10-15%.
• The actual rate of CS in many countries is higher than the recommended range.
• The rate of CS in Iran has increased six-fold over the past three decades.

column1: • The debate on the best practices for minimizing postnatal morbidity continues, with conflicting views on the impact of mode of delivery on postpartum quality of life (QOL).

column2: • Postpartum mothers experience physical health conditions that affect their QOL, future health, and their children's health.
• Socio-economic deficiencies and medical problems are risk factors for decreased QOL and depressive symptoms in women during the postnatal period.
• Mode of delivery and childbirth experience may have a long-term effect on self-rated health.

column1: • The study aimed to explore the impact of delivery mode on women's postpartum physical and mental health-related QOL.

column2: • A prospective study was conducted on 365 pregnant women who admitted for prenatal care in health centers in Kashan, Iran.
• The women were divided into two groups: vaginal delivery (VD) and CS (elective or emergency).
• The study used a generic HRQOL instrument, the Iranian version of the Short Form-36 Health Survey (SF-36), to measure QOL.

column1: • The results showed that physical HRQOL at 2 and 4 months after delivery was better in women with VD.

column2: • There were significant differences in physical functioning and role physical parameters in time 1 and physical functioning in time 2 assessments.
• Mental HRQOL at 4 months after delivery and improvement on mental HRQOL from time 1 to time 2 assessments was better in the VD group.
• Differences were significant in social functioning and emotional well-being.

column1: • The study's findings are consistent with several previous studies, but differ from some studies that found no significant differences in HRQOL between VD and CS groups.

column2: • The study's limitations include the use of a general instrument and not considering the type of CS (elective or emergency).
• Future studies should include both general and specific questionnaires in assessing postpartum QOL among women with VD, elective CS, and emergency CS.
• Other studies are needed to recognize social and cultural factors related to physical",0

column1: 736,"<summary>
• Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs

column2: • Proposed by Abraham Maslow in 1943 and 1954
• Human needs are portrayed in a pyramid shape, with physiological needs at the bottom
• Safety needs emerge after physiological needs are relatively satisfied

column1: • Physiological Needs

column2: • Physical requirements for individual and animal survival (e.g., food, sex)
• Safety needs are more fundamental than physiological needs
• Example: deer cannot eat when chased by wolves

column1: • Safety Needs

column2: • Personal security, financial security, and health and well-being
• Can block physiological needs (e.g., Miller's avoidance and approach experiments)
• Negativity bias: organisms are more sensitive to threatening information
• Ito's findings: brain amplifies threats and initiates behavioral responses

column1: • Emotions and Appraisal Theory

column2: • Emotions result from people's interpretations and explanations of their circumstances
• Primary appraisal: fast-acting, automatic process related to fear
• Secondary appraisal: slower, more deliberate process related to anger
• Lazarus's process model: perceptual stimuli, associative processing, and reasoning

column1: • Neural Basis of Safety Needs

column2: • Amygdala: neural basis for fear and stress-elicited fear and anxiety
• Thalamus-amygdala circuit: fast-acting system for threat detection
• NE/LC system: directs behaviors to cope with dangerous environments
• Locus coeruleus (LC) sends projections to amygdala

column1: • Mental Disorders and Safety Needs

column2: • Fear and anger are due to things happening in an unexpected way
• Phobia patients: unable to successfully accomplish emotional flow (fear-anger-happiness-sadness-calm)
• Depression: related to primary appraisal, worrying about safety instead of physiological satisfaction
• Anxiety, phobia, depression, and PTSD are related to safety needs

column1: • Emotional Flow and Rainbow

column2: • Fear-anger-happiness-sadness-calm constitutes our emotions in everyday life
• Emotional flow: first safety check, then hedonic need, and finally calmness or worry
• Fear and anger are two sides of one sword, acting in different directions
• Emotional rainbow: fear-anger-happiness-sadness-missing",0

column1: 737,"<summary>
* The study investigates the involvement of epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs) in various physiological functions, including blood pressure regulation, nociception, and anti-inflammatory activity.

column2: * The researchers synthesized and evaluated a series of EET analogues with improved stability and potency, including tetrazole and thioxo-1,2,4-oxadiazol derivatives.

* The most promising analogue, urea 19, showed potent vasorelaxant activity and inhibition of soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH), making it a potential therapeutic agent for cardiovascular and inflammatory diseases.

738,"<summary>
• The Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) model aims to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care to patients.

column2: • It was developed by the American Academy of Family Physicians, American Academy of Pediatrics, American College of Physicians, and American Osteopathic Association.

column1: • The PCMH model is an extension of the Chronic Care Model, which was developed to address the increasing rate of patients with chronic conditions in the US.

column2: • It has proven to reduce patients' healthcare costs and improve patient care quality.

column1: • The PCMH model strives to increase access to services, practice efficiency, and provider and patient satisfaction.

column2: • It requires a team-based care approach, where practice staff and providers take time to analyze patients' needs as a whole.

column1: • The National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) recognizes PCMH practices, but does not provide instructions for implementation.

column2: • Practices must create their own written policies that adhere to PCMH principles and fit their specific practice structure.

column1: • The transition to a PCMH requires significant changes in office culture, including training for nurses and front office staff.

column2: • It also requires the use of electronic medical records (EMRs) to facilitate care coordination and population management.

column1: • The PCMH model faces challenges, including physician buy-in, reimbursement, and resource constraints, particularly for small practices.

column2: • Despite these challenges, PCMH demonstrations have shown improved patient outcomes and reduced healthcare costs.",1

column1: 739,"<summary>
• Incremental improvements in CPR survival rates occurred as more people were trained and defibrillators became portable and widely available.

column2: • In the early 21st century, the survival rate of cardiac arrest outside of hospitals remained around 78%.
• About one-quarter of patients regained pulses after CPR, and about one-third of those patients survived hospitalization.

column1: • Mild hypothermia therapy has been proposed to protect the brain after cardiac arrest.

column2: • It has been shown to increase survival rates and improve neurological function in animal experiments.
• It reduces metabolic rate and the expression of pro-apoptosis proteins.

column1: • The effectiveness of hypothermia has been proven in clinical trials.

column2: • The 2010 American Heart Association guidelines recommended cooling comatose patients with out-of-hospital ventricular fibrillation cardiac arrest to 32-34°C for 12 or 24 hours.
• However, recent studies have shown that mild hypothermia may not improve patient prognosis.

column1: • A meta-analysis was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of mild hypothermia in patients with cardiac arrest.

column2: • The analysis included six studies with a total of 531 adult patients who suffered from cardiac arrest and were successfully resuscitated.
• The studies compared the therapeutic effect of hypothermia versus normothermia.

column1: • The results showed that mild hypothermia does not improve survival rate and neurological function at hospital discharge.

column2: • However, it does improve survival rate and neurological function after 6 months.
• The pooled results showed that mild hypothermia does improve the prognosis of patients with cardiac arrest.

column1: • The possible mechanisms of mild hypothermia include reducing cerebral oxygen consumption and energy metabolism, reducing reactive oxygen species generation, and preserving the integrity of the blood-brain barrier.

column2: • The study also found that mild hypothermia does not influence the incidence of adverse events such as rearrest, renal failure, and pulmonary edema.

column1: • The study has some limitations, including the small number of trials and study size, as well as clinical and methodological heterogeneity.

column2: • Further research is needed to analyze the impact of different cooling measures or different hypothermia duration on survival rate and neurological function.

column1: • In conclusion, the meta-analysis demonstrated that mild hypothermia does not improve survival rate and neurological function at hospital discharge, but it does improve prognosis of patients with cardiac arrest.

column2: • Mild hypothermia therapy is safe and can be recommended for patients with cardiac arrest.",0

column1: 740,"<summary>
* Varicocele is a condition characterized by persistent enlargement and elongation of the pampiniform plexus, venous convolution, and sinus formation with transient or permanent backflow.

column2: * It is a common cause of male infertility, accounting for approximately 40% of marital infertility.

column1: * The etiopathogenesis of varicocele remains unclear, but it is believed to be related to blood turbulence in the vicinity of the opening of the testicular vein, leading to retrograde flow of renal metabolites and adrenal hormones to the testis.

column2: * This can result in testicular hyperemia and compromised testicular oxygen concentration.

column1: * Varicocele can be diagnosed through a meticulous andrologic examination involving inspection and palpation of the genital organs while standing up, and grading is usually based on the Dubin-Amelar 1 to 3 scale.

column2: * Ultrasound examination, including Doppler, is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size of both testes.

column1: * Laparoscopic repair is a recommended treatment for varicocele, involving division of the testicular vein only, and has been shown to be effective in increasing testicular volume and improving semen parameters.

column2: * The evaluation of surgical outcome should include ultrasound evidence of varicocele subsidence and increase of testicular volume on the affected side, as well as semen analysis and hormonal tests.

column1: * The study found that laparoscopic varicocele repair resulted in significant increase in hypotrophic testicular volume in 83.8% of subjects, and normal sperm count, motility, and morphology were observed in 85.2% of patients.

column2: * The study also found that normal FSH, LH, and T levels were observed in young men operated on in adolescence, and that late diagnosis and treatment frequently result in spermatogenesis disturbances and abnormal concentrations of sex hormones.

column1: * The authors conclude that laparoscopic varicocele repair should be recommended as the treatment of choice for varicocele, especially in boys and adolescents, and that early surgical repair can improve fertility potential.

column2: * The authors also emphasize the importance of postoperative follow-up, including semen analysis and hormonal tests, to evaluate the efficacy of surgical varicocele repair.",0

column1: 741,"<summary>
• Radical retropubic prostatectomy is the surgical treatment of choice for patients with localized prostate cancer, but it can result in erectile dysfunction due to injury of cavernosal nerves.

column2: • The cavernosal nerves are mainly concentrated laterally to the prostate and are referred to as neurovascular bundles.
• Nerve-sparing radical retropubic prostatectomy has led to improvements in potency rates, but the exact anatomy of periprostatic nerve fibers is still not well understood.

column1: • The study aimed to describe periprostatic nerve distribution and construct a 3-dimensional model of nerve distribution using male adult cadavers.

column2: • The prostate, seminal vesicle, bladder, and rectum were removed en bloc, and whole-mount histologic sections were prepared and stained with anti-S-100 antibody neural stain.
• The stained sections were divided into four arbitrary sectors, and nerve fibers were counted and measured in each sector.

column1: • The results showed that the number of nerve fibers was distributed evenly around the prostatic capsule, with fewer fibers in the ventral part.

column2: • The average distance from the prostatic capsule to nerve fibers was similar in all parts, and there was no significant difference in nerve fiber thickness according to level.
• The 3-dimensional model revealed an almost even distribution and similar thickness of periprostatic nerve fibers on dorsal and lateral parts.

column1: • The study's findings challenge the traditional concept of the neurovascular bundle and suggest that modified nerve-sparing techniques may be feasible for saving periprostatic nerves.

column2: • The results support the idea that incising the periprostatic fascia more anteriorly may be effective in preserving nerve fibers.
• However, an excessive high up incision on the ventral part of the prostate may not be effective due to the fewer number of nerve fibers in this area.

column1: • The study's results have implications for improving potency rates after radical prostatectomy and may guide surgeons in developing new techniques for nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy.

column2: • The study's findings may also help to explain the unpredictable response to erection recovery and the lack of correlation between surgeon perception of the quality of neurovascular sparing and functional results after radical prostatectomy.
• Further studies are needed to confirm the study's findings and to develop new techniques for nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy.",0

column1: 742,"<summary>
* Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by joint damage and systemic inflammation.

column2: * Serum amyloid A (SAA) is an acute-phase protein that increases in response to inflammation and is associated with RA.
* SAA is also involved in cholesterol metabolism and may contribute to cardiovascular disease.

column1: * The study aimed to assess SAA levels in RA patients with different disease activity and its relationship with inflammatory, metabolic, and cardiovascular parameters.

column2: * The study included 140 RA patients with varying levels of disease activity, and SAA levels were measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).

* The results showed that SAA levels were significantly higher in patients with high disease activity and correlated with inflammatory markers such as C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

column1: * SAA levels were also associated with cardiovascular risk factors, including high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and triglycerides.

column2: * Patients with atherosclerotic plaques had significantly higher SAA levels, indicating an increased risk of cardiovascular disease.
* SAA levels were also higher in patients with increased cystatin C levels, a marker of chronic kidney disease.

column1: * The study found that SAA levels were higher in men than in women, and that women treated with biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) had lower SAA levels.

column2: * The use of glucocorticoids was associated with higher SAA levels, which may be due to their anti-inflammatory effects.
* The study suggests that SAA may be a useful biomarker for monitoring disease activity and cardiovascular risk in RA patients.

column1: * The study's limitations include the use of different biological DMARDs and the lack of detailed information on treatment regimens.

column2: * Further studies are needed to confirm the relationship between SAA and cardiovascular risk in RA patients.
* The study's findings suggest that SAA may be a useful tool for identifying RA patients at high risk of cardiovascular disease and for monitoring the effectiveness of treatment.</summary>",0

column1: 743,"<summary>
* Glucocorticoids have anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects, but they can also promote inflammation and Th2-type immunity.

column2: * Glucocorticoids play a coadjuvant role in promoting inflammation.
* They can increase eosinophil production and promote Th2-type immunity.
* They have a differential effect on Th1 and Th2 cytokine production.

column1: * Perforin deficiency is associated with a selective defect in granulopoiesis.

column2: * Perforin-deficient mice have lower bone marrow cellularity and eosinophil and neutrophil counts.
* The defect is not due to differences in body weight or age.
* The defect is specific to granulocytes and does not affect lymphocyte or total leukocyte counts.

column1: * Dexamethasone increases eosinophil and neutrophil production in wild-type mice but not in perforin-deficient mice.

column2: * Dexamethasone injection increases bone marrow eosinophil and neutrophil counts in wild-type mice.
* The effect of dexamethasone is abolished by RU486 pretreatment.
* The thymus of perforin-deficient mice responds to dexamethasone injection.

column1: * Lymphocytes from naive wild-type mice can reconstitute the granulopoietic response to dexamethasone in perforin-deficient mice.

column2: * The reconstitution is specific to granulocytes and does not affect lymphocyte or total leukocyte counts.
* Depletion of CD4+ or CD8+ cells abolishes the reconstitution of the eosinopoietic response.
* Depletion of CD4+ cells does not prevent reconstitution of the neutropoietic response.

column1: * The perforin-deficient mice have a lower response to GM-CSF.

column2: * The mice have fewer GM-CSF-responsive progenitors in the bone marrow.
* The defect is not due to a chronic inflammatory disease.
* The defect can be corrected by transfer of wild-type lymphocytes.

column1: * The study suggests that perforin is required for normal granulopoiesis and response to glucocorticoids.

column2: * The study raises the issue of how perforin contributes to regulation of granulocyte lineages in vivo.
* The study has implications for understanding the role of glucocorticoids in immune responses and trauma.
* The study suggests that perforin deficiency may affect the outcome of sepsis.

column1: * The study has limitations,",0
744,"<summary>
* The A1chieve study assessed the safety and effectiveness of insulin analogues in people with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in routine clinical care.

column2: * The study found that insulin analogues improved glycaemic control and quality of life, with a low number of hypoglycaemic events and favourable weight change.

column1: * The study included 66,726 patients with T2DM, with the majority (73.9%) starting on or switching to biphasic insulin aspart.

column2: * The study found that hypoglycaemic events reduced significantly in the insulin user group, and quality of life improved in all groups.

column1: * The study reported improved glycaemic control and quality of life following 24 weeks of treatment with any of the insulin analogues, with no severe adverse drug reactions (SADRs) or major hypoglycaemic events.

column2: * The study suggests that insulin analogues can be considered effective and safe for treating T2DM in Mumbai, India.",1

column1: 745,"<summary>
* Many cell types have been evaluated for cardiac regeneration, including embryonic stem cells, mesenchymal stem cells, skeletal myoblasts, and bone marrow-derived progenitor cells.

column2: * Each cell type has its own advantages and limitations, such as pluripotency, ease of expansion, and potential for teratoma formation.

column1: * Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) have been generated from adult somatic cells and have shown promise for cardiac regeneration.

column2: * iPSCs can be differentiated into functional cardiovascular lineages and have been used to restore myocardial structure and function in animal models.

column1: * Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) can be easily expanded and have been used in clinical trials, but their propensity to differentiate into non-cardiac tissues limits their use.

column2: * MSCs have been shown to improve ventricular function in some clinical trials, but more research is needed to optimize their use.

column1: * The route and timing of stem cell delivery are critical factors in cardiac regeneration.

column2: * Intramyocardial delivery appears to be superior to intravenous delivery, and the use of adenosine to enhance homing and retention is being explored.

column1: * Stem cell homing and retention can be improved through the use of growth factors and chemokines, such as SDF-1 and VEGF.

column2: * Genetic modification of stem cells to overexpress these factors has shown promise in improving engraftment and survival.

column1: * The use of cell-based gene therapy to promote cardiac regeneration is being explored, including the use of Akt-1 and IGF-1 to promote survival and proliferation.

column2: * These approaches have shown promise in animal models, but more research is needed to translate them to human clinical trials.",1

column1: 746,"<summary>
• Polyhalite is a mineral that commonly occurs in sedimentary evaporite successions and rarely in volcanic successions.

column2: • It was first described from the salt mine Bad Ischl-Perneck in Austria.
• Its chemical formula is K2Ca2Mg(SO4)4·2H2O.
• It is associated with halite, anhydrite, glauberite, carnallite, kieserite, langbeinite, vanthoffite, chlorides, and sulphides.

column1: • Polyhalite can be synthesized under laboratory conditions by a reaction of gypsum with appropriate solutions.

column2: • The crystal structure was first determined in samples from Altaussee in Austria.
• Substitution of divalent cations by other elements like Zn, Cu, Ni significantly changes dehydration reactions.
• Dehydration reactions occur at temperatures between 255°C and 343°C.

column1: • Polyhalite forms early-diagenetically by brine-back reactions of K-Mg-SO4 brine with earlier formed gypsum, anhydrite, or glauberite.

column2: • It can form in marginal marine shallow water sedimentary environments.
• Polyhalite is stable between room temperature and 255-343°C.
• It contains potassium in stoichiometric amounts, making it interesting for absolute age dating.

column1: • The Hallstatt salt mine is part of the Hallstatt nappe north of the Echern valley.

column2: • The salt body is around 600m wide and 1350m above sea level.
• The mining started in Celtic times, as indicated by a bronze-age staircase found in the mine.
• The sedimentary succession of the lower juvavic unit is nearly complete.

column1: • The Hallstatt mine is part of the upper juvavic nappe.

column2: • The rocksalt and the Jurassic cover are found within the area of the upper juvavic nappe.
• Maximum temperatures for the central sectors of the NCA are estimated between 160 and 180°C.
• Vitrinite reflectance studies were used to estimate the maximum temperatures.

column1: • Polyhalite rocks occur in tectonic lenses within the protocataclasite to protomylonite matrix.

column2: • Thin section analysis reveals many different fabric types.
• Monomineralic polyhalite mylonites show large grain size variations.
• Polyhalite rocks show various effects of recrystallization, respectively annealing.

747,"<summary>
* Oxidative stress and propofol

column2: * Oxidative stress is an imbalance between free radical production and antioxidant defense
* Propofol, a widely used anesthetic, has antioxidant properties similar to vitamin E
* The effects of propofol on lipid profile, cardiovascular markers, and antioxidant indices in rodents have not been fully studied

column1: * Methodology

column2: * Twenty-one male albino rats were divided into three groups and treated with propofol at different doses
* Blood and tissue samples were collected and analyzed for various biochemical indices and lipid profiles
* Antioxidant parameters were assayed using various methods

column1: * Lipid profile and cardiovascular markers

column2: * Propofol increased serum total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL-cholesterol levels
* Propofol decreased serum HDL-cholesterol levels
* The increased cholesterol level may be linked to increased alpha-hydroxyl methyl glutaryl CoA reductase activity

column1: * Antioxidant status

column2: * Propofol increased hepatic glutathione levels and glutathione-dependent enzyme activities
* Propofol did not affect renal and hepatic superoxide dismutase and catalase activities
* The increased glutathione levels and enzyme activities may result in increased detoxifying and antioxidant capability of the liver

column1: * Conclusion

column2: * Propofol promotes antioxidant status but has a detrimental effect on lipid profile
* The use of propofol in patients with cardiovascular or lipid disorders should be carefully reviewed
* Further studies are needed to fully understand the effects of propofol on oxidative stress and cardiovascular health",1
