column1: 749,"<summary>
* The study aimed to evaluate the apical extrusion of debris after using Protaper Universal rotary files (RFS) and different finishing files for removing residual root canal fillings.

column2: * The finishing files used were Protaper Next (PTN), WaveOne (WO), and Self-Adjusting File (SAF).

column1: * The null hypothesis was that the three different supplementary files used would exhibit no significant differences in the amount of debris extruded.

column2: * The study used 80 samples, divided into four groups, with the control group using only RFS and the other three groups using RFS followed by PTN, WO, or SAF.

column1: * The RFS were used to remove the bulk of the root canal fillings, and the finishing files were used to remove the residual fillings.

column2: * The debris extruded was collected and weighed, and the results were compared between the groups.

column1: * The results showed that all retreatment protocols caused apical debris extrusion, with WO resulting in the most extrusion, followed by PTN and SAF.

column2: * SAF was associated with the least extrusion of debris among the three experimental groups.

column1: * The study concluded that using supplementary files after RFS is important to refine the apical preparation and remove residual root fillings.

column2: * The SAF file system was found to be effective in reducing debris extrusion due to its design and continuous irrigation.

column1: * The study's results were in accordance with earlier studies, but it was the first to report on apical extrusion of debris using PTN, WO, or SAF.

column2: * The study's findings can be useful in improving endodontic retreatment protocols.

column1: * The limitations of the study included the use of an in vitro model and the need for further studies to confirm the results in clinical settings.

column2: * The study's results should be considered in the development of new endodontic instruments and techniques.",0

column1: 750,"<summary>
• The Anterior and Middle Superior Alveolar (AMSA) nerve block technique:

column2: • Was proposed by Friedman and Hochman in 1998 as a single-injection method to anesthetize multiple maxillary teeth without causing facial numbness.
• Involves injecting anesthetic solution into the palatal process of the maxilla to diffuse through nutrient channels and anesthetize the anterior and middle superior alveolar nerves.
• Has been reported to have varying success rates in different studies, with some achieving high rates of pulpal anesthesia and others showing lower success rates.

column1: • The study's methodology:

column2: • Involved 30 patients who received an AMSA nerve block on one side of the maxilla using a conventional syringe.
• Used a pulp tester to measure anesthetic success, with a criterion of two consecutive no-response readings at the maximum output.
• Recorded anesthetic induction times, duration of pulpal anesthesia, and any complications or adverse reactions.

column1: • The study's results:

column2: • Showed anesthetic success rates ranging from 16.7% to 66.6% for the five experimental teeth.
• Found that the duration of pulpal anesthesia declined over the 60-minute testing period.
• Did not achieve anesthesia of the lips and facial muscles of expression.

column1: • Comparison to other techniques:

column2: • The AMSA nerve block has been compared to the infraorbital nerve block (IONB), which has been shown to have better success rates of pulpal anesthesia but causes facial numbness.
• The AMSA nerve block has the advantage of not causing facial numbness and anesthetizing palatine tissue.
• The technique may be useful in restorative dentistry and periodontal surgery due to its excellent hemostatic control in palatal soft tissues.

column1: • Limitations and conclusions:

column2: • The study's results may not be applicable to children or the elderly due to the young population studied.
• The technique's unpredictable anesthetic success and variable anesthesia duration make it disadvantageous for clinical application as the first choice.
• Further studies are needed to fully understand the efficacy and limitations of the AMSA nerve block technique.",1

column1: 751,"<summary>
* Malaria in India and Jammu and Kashmir

column2: * Malaria is a significant public health problem in India, with 76% of cases in the South-East Asian region occurring in India.
* In Jammu and Kashmir, the state falls in the low endemic zone, but the Jammu division has a higher incidence of malaria than the Kashmir division.
* The study aimed to assess the knowledge, attitude, and practice (KAP) of malaria among inhabitants of RS Pura block in Jammu district.
* The study found that the KAP of malaria among the respondents were reasonably good.

column1: * Study Findings

column2: * The majority of respondents had heard of malaria and associated it with mosquito bites.
* Respondents had good knowledge about malaria symptoms, prevention, and treatment, but knowledge about its fatality was lower.
* The main source of information about malaria was mass media (TV/newspaper) followed by friends/neighbors.
* The study found a positive attitude towards malaria prevention and treatment, with a high percentage of respondents considering malaria a serious health problem.",0

column1: 752,"<summary>
• Recent advances in molecular biology and microscopy have enhanced our understanding of genome folding.

column2: • The dynamic folding of chromatin is fundamental in regulating gene expression and DNA replication.
• The genome is folded in a hierarchical manner into chromosome territories, genomic compartments, and topologically associating domains (TADs).
• TADs are units of chromosomes that exhibit higher frequency of physical contacts between genes and their cognate regulatory regions.

column1: • TAD boundaries are associated with the enrichment of CTCF, cohesin, DNase I hypersensitivity, and certain histone marks.

column2: • The boundaries serve as barriers to long- and short-range interactions between DNA sequences.
• A strong TAD boundary limits interactions between the two adjacent TAD domains, whereas a weak TAD boundary allows a higher frequency of inter-TAD interactions.
• The effects of enzymes that modify or remodel chromatin on TAD boundaries are largely unknown.

column1: • The major ATPase subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex, BRG1, is required for proper nucleosome occupancy and positioning at target regions.

column2: • BRG1 contributes to TAD boundary strength and regulates the expression of genes related to extracellular matrix and lipid synthesis.
• BRG1 knockdown resulted in the differential expression of many long non-coding RNAs, which are thought to be involved in genome organization.
• BRG1 binding primarily occurs at genic regions, including super-enhancers.

column1: • The strength of TAD boundaries is significantly reduced in BRG1 knockdown human mammary epithelial MCF-10A cells.

column2: • BRG1 loss may disrupt chromatin accessibility and preclude the binding of transcription factors and/or chromatin modifiers at TAD boundaries.
• The orderly positioning and occupancy of nucleosomes at TAD boundaries may be achieved by enriched CTCF binding.
• BRG1 plays a role at TAD boundaries by regulating nucleosome occupancy and possibly CTCF localization.

column1: • The directionality of CTCF binding is very strongly associated with the formation of TADs.

column2: • The relationship between BRG1 binding and CTCF binding site orientation remains to be determined.
• Topoisomerase II beta (TOP2B) binding overlaps with almost half of CTCF/cohesin binding sites.
• TOP2B may facilitate supercoiling at CTCF sites in a transcription-dependent manner.

column1: • BRG1 is required for the recruitment of topoisomerase I",0
753,"<summary>
* Statistical modeling is used to investigate count data using variables, and Poisson distribution is used if the mean and variance are the same.

column2: * If the variance is larger than the mean, negative binomial distribution is preferred.

column1: * Poisson regression is a subset of generalized linear models (GLM) used for count variables such as number of blood donations or failed courses.

column2: * It is often used in medicine and health to investigate relationships between phenomena.

column1: * Count variables may have an inflation of zeros, which can be modeled using Poisson zero-inflated or negative binomial zero-inflated distributions.

column2: * This is often the case in educational data, such as number of failed courses or semesters.

column1: * Previous research has applied statistical modeling to count data using negative binomial or Poisson regressions, with zero-inflated models.

column2: * Examples include modeling hospitalization periods, student health situations, and number of cigarettes smoked.

column1: * The current study aims to apply statistical modeling to educational count data, specifically the number of failed courses and semesters in university students.

column2: * The study uses Poisson and negative binomial regressions with zero-inflated models to investigate the relationship between demographic and educational factors and academic performance.

column1: * The study finds that university average and quota system have an inverse relationship with the number of failed semesters.

column2: * The increase in university average and choosing a free quota system can reduce the number of failed semesters.

column1: * The study also finds that the number of failed courses has a positive relationship with the number of failed semesters.

column2: * The increase in the number of failed courses results in an increase in the number of failed semesters.

column1: * The results of the study are consistent with previous research, which has shown that university average and quota system are important factors in academic performance.

column2: * The study contributes to the literature by applying zero-inflated Poisson and negative binomial regressions to educational count data.

column1: * The study has implications for educational policy and practice, suggesting that increasing university average and providing free quota systems can improve academic performance.

column2: * The study also highlights the importance of considering demographic and educational factors in modeling academic performance.

754,"<summary>
• The study investigates the role of electrostatic interactions in enzyme catalysis using E. coli dihydrofolate reductase (ecDHFR) as a model system.

column2: • The enzyme's active site microenvironment is probed using thiocyanate (SCN) probes at two specific locations, T46C-CN and L54C-CN.

column1: • The SCN probes are used to monitor the changes in the local microenvironments over the five major catalytic species of ecDHFR.

column2: • The probes are incorporated into the enzyme through site-specific mutagenesis and labeling with SCN.

column1: • The enzyme's activity is evaluated by its ability to catalyze the NADPH-dependent reduction of dihydrofolate (DHF) and the enzyme turnover rates at pH 7.0 and 25°C.

column2: • The catalytic efficiencies of the T46C-CN and L54C-CN variants are comparable to that of wild-type ecDHFR.

column1: • The study uses a combination of experimental and theoretical approaches, including FTIR spectroscopy, NMR spectroscopy, and molecular dynamics simulations.

column2: • The simulations are used to calculate the vibrational frequency of the SCN probes and to analyze the contributions of individual residues and ligands to the electric field at the midpoint of the CN bond.

column1: • The results provide insights into the interplay between electrostatic and conformational changes along the catalytic cycle of ecDHFR.

column2: • The study demonstrates the power of using SCN probes to experimentally monitor the changes in the local microenvironments in enzyme active sites.",0

column1: 755,"<summary>
* Resovist is not suitable as an intravascular tracer for MPI due to its rapid decay in blood

column2: * The MPI signal of Resovist declines rapidly, with a half-life of around 5 minutes, and is undetectable after 30 minutes
* This is in contrast to its use in MRI, where it has a longer half-life and can be used as a contrast agent
* The rapid decay of the MPI signal is due to the clearance of Resovist particles by the reticuloendothelial system

column1: * There are differences in the blood half-life of Resovist between the two distributors, Bayer Pharma AG and Irom Pharmaceutical Co Ltd

column2: * The MPI signal of Resovist from Irom Pharmaceutical Co Ltd decays faster than that from Bayer Pharma AG
* The reason for this difference is unclear, but may be due to differences in the formulation or manufacturing process
* Further studies are needed to fully understand the differences between the two distributors and to develop a dedicated MPI tracer with a longer half-life </summary>",0

column1: 756,"<summary>
• The study examines the host-pathogen interaction between Leishmania donovani and liver macrophages in vivo.

column2: • The researchers used a tractable experimental model of Leishmania infection in mice to study the early response of liver macrophages to infection.
• They used a combination of intravital two-photon imaging, flow cytometry, and transcriptomic analysis to study the behavior of infected and uninfected macrophages.

column1: • The study found that uninfected macrophages in the liver also undergo significant biological and gene transcriptional changes in response to the presence of Leishmania amastigotes.

column2: • These changes are associated with the activation of macrophages and the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
• The activation of uninfected macrophages is likely mediated by soluble mediators or signals operating in trans.

column1: • The researchers identified a gene network centered around retinoid X receptor alpha (RXRA) that is associated with the survival of Leishmania amastigotes within the liver.

column2: • This network includes genes involved in lipid metabolism and small-molecule biochemistry.
• The RXRA network is aberrantly maintained in infected macrophages, suggesting that it may play a role in parasite survival.

column1: • The study used pharmacological manipulation of RXR activity to perturb the gene network and examine its effect on parasite survival.

column2: • Treatment with an RXR antagonist (HX531) or agonist (LG268) reduced parasite burden in the liver and spleen.
• The mechanism by which the RXRA network controls parasite survival is currently unknown, but may involve the regulation of lipid metabolism or the sensing of Leishmania-derived lipids.

column1: • The study demonstrates the power of using cells exposed to inflammation as a means to discover pathogen-regulated gene pathways.

column2: • The approach can reveal important host response pathways that would be invisible in studies of macrophage-pathogen interactions in vitro.
• The study provides proof of concept for the use of this approach to identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of leishmaniasis.

column1: • The study highlights the importance of considering the complexity of the in vivo microenvironment when studying host-pathogen interactions.

column2: • The in vivo environment can influence the behavior of infected and uninfected macrophages in ways that are not recapitulated in vitro.
• The study demonstrates the need for caution when interpreting gene expression data from in vitro studies.

column1: • The study provides new insights into the biology of Leishmania",0
757,"<summary>
• The control of appetite is complex and involves both physiological and environmental inputs

column2: • Early theoretical approaches focused on signals from glucose metabolism, amino acids, and adipose tissue
• These approaches led to the glucostatic, aminostatic, and lipostatic hypotheses

column1: • More recent models emphasize inputs from adipose tissue and the gastrointestinal (GI) tract

column2: • These models include signals from hormones such as leptin, ghrelin, and insulin
• These signals contribute to the regulation of appetite and body weight

column1: • The major task facing models of human appetite regulation is to account for the ongoing drive to eat and episodic satiety signaling

column2: • This drive is influenced by body composition and energy expenditure (EE)
• EE is a key factor in appetite regulation, with resting metabolic rate (RMR) being a major component

column1: • Exercise has a dual effect on appetite control, stimulating hunger but also increasing post-prandial satiety signaling

column2: • The effect of exercise on appetite is influenced by the intensity and duration of exercise
• Exercise can lead to a partial compensatory response in food intake, but this is highly variable between individuals

column1: • Fat-free mass (FFM) is a key determinant of appetite, with a strong correlation between FFM and daily energy intake

column2: • RMR is also strongly correlated with FFM and daily energy intake
• FFM and RMR reflect the body's physiological demand for energy, which drives food intake

column1: • The proposed formulation for appetite control includes a tonic drive for food arising from FFM and RMR

column2: • This drive is under tonic inhibition from leptin, which reflects energy storage in the body
• Episodic signals from the GI tract in response to food consumption also play a role in appetite regulation

column1: • The recognition of the importance of FFM and RMR in appetite regulation has implications for the management of obesity

column2: • Body composition, rather than body weight, should be used in research and management of obesity
• The formulation can help to promote research into the relative strength of biological and environmental variables contributing to energy intake and body weight changes",0

column1: 758,"<summary>
• The study evaluated the effect of surface treatments on the shear bond strength of denture teeth to heat-polymerized and autopolymerized denture base resins.

column2: • The study found that surface treatments significantly improved the bond strength of denture teeth to denture base resins.
• The bond strength of denture teeth to heat-polymerized resin was higher than to autopolymerized resin.

column1: • The study used three surface treatments: untreated, treated with monomer, and treated with airborne particle abrasion.

column2: • The results showed that all three treatments improved the bond strength, but there was no significant difference between the monomer and airborne particle abrasion treatments.

column1: • The failure mode of the specimens was predominantly mixed (adhesive and cohesive) for heat-polymerized resin and adhesive for autopolymerized resin.

column2: • The study suggested that the use of mechanical retention, such as airborne particle abrasion, can improve the bond strength between acrylic resin teeth and denture base resins.

column1: • The study's results are consistent with previous studies that found that heat-polymerized acrylic resins show the highest bonding values compared to autopolymerized or light-polymerized acrylic resins.

column2: • However, the study's results contradict some previous studies that found that airborne particle abrasion or grinding decreases the bond strength of the treated teeth to denture bases.

column1: • The study's limitations include the lack of consideration of mechanical fatigue, thermal cycling, and chewing simulation.

column2: • The study's results should be interpreted with caution and further research is needed to fully understand the effects of surface treatments on the bond strength of denture teeth to denture base resins.",0

* The use of 80% Ar + 20% CO2 as a shielding gas
* Pulsed welding currents

* Globular transfer being less hazardous

column1: 760,"<summary>
• Polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) are energy and carbon storage compounds produced by various microorganisms.

column2: • PHAs are synthesized by many bacteria and archaea when carbon is available but other essential nutrients are not.
• They are divided into two groups: short-chain-length (SCL) PHAs and medium-chain-length (MCL) PHAs.

column1: • The study aimed to determine whether bacteria from freshwater reservoirs in glacier forefield areas have the potential to synthesize PHAs.

column2: • Samples were collected from five shallow freshwater reservoirs and one stream in the foreland of Ecology Glacier, King George Island, Antarctica.
• A total of 50 bacterial isolates were characterized by sequencing of 16S rRNA gene.

column1: • The most frequently recovered group of isolates was members of the Pseudomonas genus, followed by Janthinobacterium genus.

column2: • The presence of bacteria possessing specific forms of PHA synthase genes was analyzed in relation to environmental background.
• Canonical correspondence analysis showed correlation between the presence of bacteria possessing particular PHA synthase gene and environmental conditions.

column1: • The study suggests that PHA metabolism in Antarctic strains could be an adaptation mechanism to withstand harsh conditions in polar regions.

column2: • The high number of isolates possessing genes responsible for PHAs synthesis suggests that Antarctic bacteria evolved or obtained this metabolic ability to endure extreme conditions.
• Microbial mats created in Antarctic ponds could be a potential source of PHA-producing bacteria.

column1: • The comparative analysis of DNA sequences of 16S rDNA and PHA synthase genes suggested that some strains possess PHA synthesis genes that might have not been obtained by gradual evolution.

column2: • The genes responsible for SCL-PHA synthesis differ so much from those responsible for MCL-PHA synthesis that their presence in closely related bacteria is most likely not the result of gradual evolution.
• The study highlights the potential of Antarctic microorganisms as a source of novel enzymes and bioproducts.</summary>",0

column1: 761,"<summary>
* The study aims to estimate the frequency of successful establishment of native perennial warm-season grasses in southern Arizona using 31 years of historical rainfall event data.

column2: * The study uses a land surface model to simulate soil moisture and evaluate the germination and establishment of grasses under different rainfall scenarios.
* The model is calibrated using data from the Santa Rita Experimental Range and flux tower measurements.

column1: * The results show that the average germination date for the 2-day scenario was around July 20, and for the 3-day scenario, it was around August 1.

column2: * The study found that in most years, there was little difference in germination date and success among the gages and scenarios, but in a few years, there were substantive differences.

* The study concludes that the frequency of successful establishment of native perennial warm-season grasses in southern Arizona is around 64% (20 out of 31 years) for the 2-day scenario and 71% (22 out of 31 years) for the 3-day scenario.",0

column1: 762,"<summary>
* Major depression (MD) is a leading cause of disability and is projected to become the second leading cause of burden of disease by 2020.

column2: * Up to 40% of patients with MD do not respond to initial antidepressant therapy, and treatment-resistant depression (TRD) evades a universally accepted definition.

column1: * Neuromodulation therapies (NTs) are increasingly being used to treat TRD, including seizure therapies, noninvasive therapies, neurosurgical approaches, and new approaches on the horizon.

column2: * Examples of NTs include electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), vagus nerve stimulation (VNS), deep brain stimulation (DBS), and transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS).

column1: * ECT is effective in TRD, but has significant neurocognitive side effects, while rTMS and VNS have fewer side effects and are also effective.

column2: * rTMS has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of MD and TRD, and VNS has been approved for the treatment of TRD.

column1: * DBS is a reversible invasive technique that involves stereotactical implantation of electrodes into specific brain regions, and has been shown to be effective in TRD.

column2: * Other NTs, such as magnetic seizure therapy (MST), epidural cortical stimulation (ECS), and optogenetic stimulation (OS), are also being explored for the treatment of TRD.

column1: * More research is needed to establish the efficacy, safety, and cost-effectiveness of NTs, as well as to identify predictors of response and non-response to these therapies.

column2: * Collaborative, multisite, and/or multicountry studies with larger samples and standardized protocols are needed to address these research gaps.

column1: * The optimal parameters of NTs are not yet defined, and more research is needed to determine the best approaches for individual patients.

column2: * Adaptive designs and collaborative networks may be useful in optimizing NTs for TRD.

column1: * There is a need for more naturalistic studies and comparative research between NTs and antidepressant drugs to inform treatment decisions.

column2: * The development of tools to measure refractoriness of depression and strict eligibility criteria are also needed to improve the conduct of NT trials.",1

column1: 763,"<summary>
* The study explores the use of small RNA molecules, called sarnas, to activate specific genes involved in stem cell regulation and reprogramming.

column2: * Sarnas are designed to target antisense transcripts that regulate gene expression, and can be used to upregulate specific genes without altering the genome.

column1: * The researchers designed sarnas to target the klf4 and c-myc genes, which are important for stem cell maintenance and pluripotency.

column2: * They used a bioinformatic approach to identify potential antisense transcripts and design sarnas that could bind and degrade these transcripts, leading to gene activation.

column1: * The sarnas were tested in human mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) and were found to upregulate klf4 and c-myc expression in a time- and dose-dependent manner.

column2: * The upregulation was specific to the targeted genes and did not activate the interferon response, a common problem with RNA-based therapies.

column1: * The researchers also examined the global gene expression profile of MSCs treated with sarnas and compared it to cells transduced with lentiviral vectors expressing klf4 and c-myc.

column2: * They found that the sarnas and lentiviral vectors had similar effects on gene expression, but with some differences in the specific genes regulated.

column1: * The study demonstrates the potential of sarnas as a tool for studying stem cell biology and as a safe method for manipulating stem cell gene expression.

column2: * The approach could be used to activate specific genes involved in stem cell maintenance and pluripotency, and could have applications in regenerative medicine and tissue engineering.

column1: * The researchers also found that the sarnas induced changes in cell morphology and gene expression that were consistent with the activation of stem cell-related genes.

column2: * The study provides new insights into the mechanisms of gene regulation and the potential of sarnas as a therapeutic approach.",1

column1: 764,"<summary>
• Chronic kidney diseases lead to end-stage kidney failure, characterized by changes in kidney structure and fibrosis, regardless of the underlying cause.

column2: • Urinary tract obstruction causes tubular atrophy or dilation, cell death, interstitial leukocyte infiltration, and increased interstitial matrix deposition.
• Taurine has been shown to have beneficial effects on renal fibrosis in various kidney diseases, including cisplatin-induced injuries, diabetic nephropathy, and age-related renal changes.
• The study investigated the effects of taxol and taurine on tubulointerstitial fibrosis in a rat model of unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO).

column3: • Taxol and taurine were found to attenuate tubulointerstitial fibrosis and preserve normal renal histology in the UUO rat model.
• Taxol was more protective than taurine in preventing renal tissue damage.
• The mechanisms of taxol and taurine's protective effects may involve modulation of microRNA-192 pathobiology, transforming growth factor- signaling, and antioxidant properties.
• The study suggests that taxol and taurine may be effective in preventing structural renal damage in the direct obstruction model in rats.

765,"<summary>
* Autophagy plays a critical role in host defense responses by promoting the elimination of pathogens and the induction of acquired immunity.

column2: * Autophagy is involved in the clearance of old/damaged organelles, long-lived proteins, insoluble protein aggregates, and lipid droplets, regulating cellular homeostasis, cell death/survival, and lipid metabolism.
* Autophagy is also involved in antigen presentation to antigen-specific T cells, which is essential for the induction of acquired immunity.
* The loss of ATG16L1, an essential component of the autophagic machinery, results in the production of inflammatory cytokines in response to endotoxin.

column3: * This is due to the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the activation of caspase-1, leading to the production of IL-1.
* The source of ROS has not yet been identified, but mitochondria are a possible source.

column1: * TLR signaling induces the maturation of phagosomes after exposure to bacteria and promotes MHC class II antigen presentation.

column2: * NOD1 and NOD2, intracellular sensors that recognize bacterial polypeptides, are involved in the formation of bacteria autophagosomes and the regulation of antimicrobial responses.

column3: * NOD1 and NOD2 associate with ATG16L1 and recruit it to the bacterial entry sites after bacterial infection.
* The most common NOD2 mutation associated with Crohn's disease fails to induce the movement of ATG16L1 and the formation of autophagosomes.

766,"<summary>
* Betel quid chewing has been a popular habit in India and Southeast Asia for centuries, but it has become a significant public health problem in recent years.

column2: * The habit was considered innocuous until the introduction of tobacco by European settlers, which led to a significant increase in oral cancer cases.
* The causal association between betel quid chewing and oral cancer was established in the 20th century.

column1: * Betel nut, a key ingredient in betel quid, was initially thought to be safe, but later studies revealed its role in oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF), a precancerous condition.

column2: * OSMF was rare in the 1980s, but its incidence increased among young Indians due to the rise of gutkha chewing.
* The frequency of oral cancer has also increased among young adults as a result of OSMF.

column1: * The industrial manufacturing and marketing of gutkha and pan masala have contributed to the increasing incidence of OSMF and oral cancers.

column2: * These products are widely available and aggressively marketed, leading to widespread addiction.
* The lack of statutory warnings and low cost of these products have also contributed to their popularity.

column1: * Oral cancer is a major cause of cancer-related deaths in Indian men, with an incidence rate of 12.5/100,000.

column2: * The disease is uncommon in the West, but it is a significant public health problem in India.
* Large funds have been spent on education, laws, and healthcare infrastructure to reduce the use of betel nut and tobacco products.

column1: * The study analyzed 63 cases of oral cancer patients, with a mean age of 61.20 years for males and 59.92 years for females.

column2: * The patients had a history of betel quid, gutkha, and pan masala chewing, with a mean duration of 18.56 years for males and 20 years for females.
* The patients also had a history of tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption.

column1: * The study found a direct relation between oral cancer and the duration of betel quid, gutkha, and pan masala chewing.

column2: * Betel nut contains alkaloids that are responsible for its biological actions in humans.
* The alkaloids are cholinergic agonists that affect the nervous system via acetylcholine.

column1: * Betel nut is the fourth most common addictive substance after tobacco, alcohol, and caffeine.

column2: * It is possibly the second most consumed carcin",0

column1: 767,"<summary>
* Patient Blood Management (PBM) is crucial in cardiac surgery due to the high risk of bleeding and transfusion-related complications.

column2: * PBM strategies should focus on reducing transfusions, as allogeneic red blood cell (RBC) transfusions are associated with increased morbidity and mortality.
* The decision to transfuse should be based on the patient's risk of developing complications of inadequate oxygenation, rather than a single hemoglobin (Hb) trigger.

column3: * The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) recommends that RBC transfusions should be based on the patient's risk of developing complications of inadequate oxygenation.
* The lowest acceptable Hb level in patients with coexisting cardiovascular diseases is approximately 6.0 g/dL (3.7 mmol/L).

column1: * The use of antiplatelet agents, such as aspirin and clopidogrel, in patients undergoing cardiac surgery increases the risk of bleeding and transfusion requirements.

column2: * The timing of surgery in patients exposed to these drugs is critical, and international guidelines recommend discontinuing aspirin 2-10 days and clopidogrel at least 5 days before elective cardiac surgery.

column1: * A restrictive RBC transfusion policy has been shown to be equally effective and possibly superior to a more liberal transfusion strategy in cardiac surgery patients.

column2: * The age of the RBC at the time of transfusion may impact the clinical outcome, with older RBCs potentially having a reduced ability to transport oxygen to tissues.
* Institutions should establish their own patient blood management strategy to conserve blood products and maximize outcome.",0

column1: 768,"<summary>
* Neurogenesis occurs in mammals, including humans, throughout life, particularly in the hippocampus, dentate gyrus, subventricular zone, and olfactory epithelium.

column2: * This process involves the proliferation, differentiation, and migration of neural stem cells into neurons.
* The olfactory epithelium is a unique tissue that can regenerate completely without loss of function.

column1: * The olfactory epithelium contains two types of basal cells: horizontal basal cells (HBCs) and globose basal cells (GBCs).

column2: * GBCs are small, round, and morphologically non-descript, and they proliferate at a high rate in the normal olfactory epithelium.
* GBCs are thought to be the stem cells of the olfactory epithelium.

column1: * The study used albino Wistar rats to isolate and characterize GBCs from the olfactory epithelium.

column2: * The rats were anesthetized, and the olfactory mucosa was surgically excised and dissociated into individual cells.
* The cells were then sorted using fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) and a specific antibody (GBC-III) to isolate 99% pure GBCs.

column1: * The isolated GBCs were cultured in a specialized medium and formed neurospheres, which are clusters of cells that resemble the neural stem cell niche.

column2: * The neurospheres were found to express various neural progenitor markers, including NCAM, Nestin, Sox-2, CD29, CD54, and CD73.
* The GBCs were also found to be electrophysiologically quiescent, meaning they do not have the ability to generate action potentials.

column1: * The study's results suggest that GBCs are a promising source of neural progenitor cells for therapeutic applications.

column2: * The olfactory epithelium is an accessible and renewable source of autologous stem cells.
* Further research is needed to fully understand the biology of GBCs and their potential for treating nervous system disorders.

column1: * Future studies should focus on isolating GBCs using magnetic assisted cell sorting (MACS) and performing electrophysiological studies to understand the functional properties of GBCs.

column2: * Animal studies using GBCs to repair spinal cord injuries and other nervous system disorders should be conducted.
* The ultimate goal is to translate the knowledge gained from this research into human clinical trials.</summary>",0

column1: 769,"<summary>
* The central nervous system (CNS) was previously considered a site of immune privilege, but recent evidence suggests that it is more constitutively active than previously thought.

column2: * Microglia, derived from yolk sac erythromyeloid progenitors, play a pivotal role in innate immunity within the CNS.
* They facilitate immune surveillance of brain interstitial fluid through the glymphatic system.

column1: * Microglia are multifunctional cells that participate in immune surveillance, phagocytosis, and synaptic pruning.

column2: * They recognize apoptotic cells and eliminate unwanted neurons, contributing to proper brain tissue remodeling.
* Microglia also play a role in angiogenesis and synapse formation.

column1: * Cortical spreading depression (CSD) is a wave of rapid depolarization of neurons and astrocytes, accompanied by changes in cerebral blood flow.

column2: * CSD can be elicited by chemical stimulation, pinprick stimulation, and electrical stimulation of the intact cerebral cortex.
* It is characterized by a rapid increase in extracellular potassium and a decline in sodium and calcium.

column1: * Microglia are involved in CSD, expressing voltage-sensitive ion channels and sensing electrical activity.

column2: * CSD elevates extracellular pH, which may be detected by microglial transient receptor potential cation channel subfamily V, member 1 (TRPV1).
* Microglia exhibit increased NMDA-dependent inward rectifying potassium conductance after CSD.

column1: * CSD can initiate inflammatory activation of microglia, leading to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and pro-inflammatory cytokines.

column2: * Microglial activation can be inhibited by insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) treatment and environmental enrichment.
* IGF-1 antagonizes TNF and promotes M2-polarization of microglia.

column1: * Multiple CSD inductions lead to microglial activation, characterized by morphological changes and increased expression of cathepsin D.

column2: * Activated microglia may contribute to synaptic repair and neuroprotection.
* The mechanisms by which microglia induce CSD remain unknown.

column1: * The glymphatic system enables communication between the brain parenchyma and the peripheral lymphatic system.

column2: * The recently discovered lymphatic system makes possible immunological communication between the brain and the periphery.
* This may be relevant to CSD pathophysiology, particularly in familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM).

770,"<summary>
* Transposable elements (TEs) were once considered ""junk DNA"" but are now recognized as important contributors to genetic innovation and evolution.

column2: * TEs can be domesticated and become functional genes, encoding proteins with various functions such as integrases, transposases, and envelopes.
* Many TE-derived genes are specific to mammals, but others are found in other vertebrate sublineages, and their functions are still unknown.
* Domestication of TEs can occur through the elimination of sequences essential for transposition, and their expression can be controlled to prevent deleterious consequences.
* TE-derived genes can be identified through genome comparisons and functional gene analyses.

column1: * The gin genes, a pair of ancient vertebrate domesticated genes, have no known function but are derived from gin transposons that gained their transposase from LTR retrotransposons.

column2: * Gin1 is found in mammals, birds, and reptiles, while gin2 is found in tetrapods, bony fish, and sharks, and possibly in urochordates.
* The presence of both genes over long periods of evolution suggests important, conserved functions in vertebrates.
* The loss of gin2 in monotremes and placental mammals may indicate that its function is no longer essential or is fulfilled by gin1.

column1: * The gin genes may have been generated from two independent events of molecular domestication, and their functions may be related to DNA or RNA binding.

column2: * Gin2 is particularly expressed in brain and gonads in fish, and its expression pattern during zebrafish embryogenesis suggests a role during gastrulation.
* Functional analysis in fish is needed to determine the role of gin2.
* The study of TE-derived genes like gin supports the importance of molecular domestication as a driver of genetic innovation during evolution.",0

column1: 771,"<summary>
• Progressive diseases affect 45 million people worldwide, expected to reach 76 million by 2030, with high societal costs and loss of life expectancy and quality of life.

column2: • These diseases are characterized by the aggregation of misfolded proteins, which amplify and propagate from cell to cell.
• The aggregation of misfolded proteins leads to a self-sustaining, exponential vicious circle of disease.

column1: • Misfolded proteins can cause both loss of function and gain of pathologic function, leading to cell death and disease.

column2: • This is due to the ability of misfolded proteins to permeabilize membranes, perturb membrane dynamics, and recruit molecular chaperones and other partner proteins.
• The aggregation of misfolded proteins can also lead to the formation of novel signaling platforms with undesirable properties.

column1: • The spread and transmission of disease via misfolded protein aggregates is a widespread phenomenon in neurodegenerative diseases.

column2: • This is supported by the observation of distinctive patterns of pathological changes over time throughout the brain.
• The transmission of misfolded protein aggregates has been demonstrated in various diseases, including Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Huntington's.

column1: • Fibrillar assemblies of misfolded proteins are the most toxic and have the highest seeding capacity.

column2: • The toxicity of fibrillar assemblies is due to their ability to bind to and permeabilize cell membranes, leading to cell death.
• The binding of fibrillar assemblies to cells also leads to the recruitment of soluble cytosolic counterparts, amplifying the aggregation process.

column1: • The existence of distinct strains of misfolded proteins, such as α-synuclein and tau, has been demonstrated.

column2: • These strains have different biochemical properties, seeding capacities, and toxicities.
• The existence of distinct strains may account for the different phenotypic traits observed in various diseases.

column1: • Targeting early enough protein assemblies involved in disease formation and propagation may represent a novel and effective preventive therapeutic avenue.

column2: • Small molecules, such as polyphenols, have been shown to interfere with protein aggregation and stimulate proteostasis.
• Strategies aimed at protecting and/or stimulating neuronal cells, such as the use of neurotrophic factors, are also being explored.

column1: • Innovative strategies aimed at interfering specifically with protein assemblies propagation and seeding capacities are being developed.

column2: • This includes the design of binders that change the surface properties of protein assemblies, making them unable to bind to cells or elongate.
• The identification of interaction interfaces",0

column1: • The study also found that AA males were at higher risk for developing HCC than AA females, but achieving an SVR reduced the risk of HCC in both genders.

column2: • However, the study also found that cirrhosis at the first visit was not predictive of HCC development, and that individual patients could not be reliably predicted to develop HCC based on serum assays or fibrosis assays.

• Stroke is a major public health burden

column2: • It is the second leading cause of death globally, accounting for 5.7 million deaths annually
• It is a multifactorial disease with genetic influences playing a significant role in its pathogenesis

column1: • Beta-adrenergic receptors (βAR) are a type of G-protein coupled receptor

column2: • They have a seven-transmembrane domain structure and are receptors for neurohormones epinephrine and norepinephrine

column1: • The β2AR gene has been associated with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases

column2: • Two non-synonymous SNPs, Arg16Gly and Gln27Glu, have been identified in the β2AR gene

column1: • A meta-analysis was conducted to investigate the association between β2AR polymorphisms and ischemic stroke

column2: • Three studies were included in the meta-analysis, involving 1,642 cases and 1,673 controls

column1: • The results of the meta-analysis showed a significant association between the Gln27Glu polymorphism and ischemic stroke

column2: • The association was observed under both recessive and dominant models of inheritance

column1: • The study suggests that the Gln27Glu polymorphism may be an independent risk factor for ischemic stroke

column2: • However, the study has some limitations, including the lack of haplotype analysis and gene-environment interaction studies

column1: • Further studies are needed to validate the findings and establish the underlying molecular mechanisms

column1: 777,"<summary>
* Isolation of pure cell populations is crucial in clinical and basic research.

column2: * The diagnostic test for HIV infection relies on the separation of human lymphocytes from whole blood.
* Isolation of rare cells has become an active area of research, particularly in stem cell biology.

column1: * Miniaturized cell separation devices offer advantages over conventional techniques, including small sample volumes, portability, low cost, improved sterility, and potential for integration with analytical techniques.

column2: * These devices can be classified into two categories: techniques based on size and density, and techniques based on affinity (chemical, electrical, or magnetic).

column1: * Size-based separation techniques do not require cell-specific markers or proteins, making them useful for isolating stem cells and other rare cells.

column2: * Examples of size-based techniques include the use of microfluidic devices with obstacles or channels of varying sizes to separate cells based on their size and deformability.

column1: * Affinity-based separation techniques rely on the interaction between cells and specific markers or proteins.

column2: * Examples of affinity-based techniques include fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS), magnetic-activated cell sorting (MACS), and adhesion-based cell separation.

column1: * FACS systems use a laser beam and photodetectors to sort cells based on their fluorescence and light scattering properties.

column2: * Microfluidic FACS systems offer advantages over conventional systems, including low cost, high throughput, and integration with downstream analysis systems.

column1: * Magnetic separation techniques use magnetic beads or particles to capture target cells, which can then be separated from non-target cells using a magnetic field.

column2: * Microscale magnetic separation systems offer advantages over conventional systems, including small sample volumes and potential for integration with downstream analysis systems.

column1: * Electrophoretic separation techniques use electric fields to separate cells based on their dielectric properties.

column2: * Examples of electrophoretic techniques include dielectrophoresis (DEP) retention, DEP migration, and DEP-field flow fractionation (DEP-FFF).",0

780,"<summary>
* The healthcare industry faces challenges in addressing its current issues, including the ""iron triangle"" of access, cost, and quality of care.

column2: * The industry is experiencing significant stress due to competition for limited funding.
* Research institutions are struggling to fund research, leading to a decrease in grants and discoveries.
* The NIH lost 22% of its capacity to fund research from 2003 to 2015.

column1: * The power of technology and innovation can enable step changes in performance while reducing costs.

column2: * Moore's Law in semiconductors demonstrates the exponential power of technology.
* The Eroom's Law in pharma industry shows a negative exponential growth, highlighting the challenges in the industry.
* The ""valley of death"" exists between academic research and commercialization of new products.

column1: * Successful innovation in healthcare requires navigating a long and challenging journey.

column2: * The journey involves translating research into practice, which requires new skills and resources.
* Investigators need to focus on creating technologies with a better chance of surviving the commercialization journey.
* Financial investors are not impressed with technical results and expect a clear commercialization pathway.

column1: * Healthcare Commercialization Programs (HCPs) can help address the challenges.

column2: * HCPs aim to strike a balance between advancing projects into commercialization and building the skills of team members.
* Examples of HCPs include the I-Corps program and the Coulter Foundation C3i program.
* HCPs provide educational opportunities to help investigators understand and address commercialization challenges.

column1: * The I-Corps program has been adapted for healthcare innovations.

column2: * The program involves getting team members out of the lab to talk to stakeholders and customers.
* The program uses a flipped-classroom structure with off-line assignments and weekly interactive sessions.
* The program runs for at least 8-10 weeks to allow for sufficient interviews and potential pivots.

column1: * HCPs differ from I-Corps in several ways.

column2: * HCPs require a different team composition, including clinical, technical, and business environments.
* HCPs need executive faculty with healthcare industry expertise.
* HCPs cover specific challenges facing healthcare innovations, such as buying dynamics and reimbursement complexities.
* HCPs require a different style, with faculty developing strong rapport with team members.

column1: * The context in which an HCP is used can help address funding challenges.

column2: * HCPs can be conducted as an integral part of an ecosystem or program.

* Anal incontinence (AI) is a common and bothersome condition that affects women's quality of life.

column2: * It is associated with hygienic problems, limitations in daily life, sexual dysfunction, and reduced self-esteem.
* The prevalence of AI varies widely in previous studies, ranging from 2.2% to 28.4%.
* This study aimed to assess the prevalence and risk factors of AI in an unselected female population across parity groups in the second trimester of pregnancy.
* The study found that the overall prevalence of AI was 8.4%, with 7.8% of nulliparous women and 9.8% of parous women reporting AI.
* Previous obstetric anal sphincter injury (OASI) was the strongest risk factor for AI among parous women.

column3: * The risk of AI was threefold among women with previous OASI compared to women without.
* The prevalence of AI increased with increasing number of vaginal deliveries.

column2: * Low educational level and comorbidity were significant risk factors for AI among nulliparous women.

column3: * Dermatological disease was also associated with AI in both nulliparous and parous women.

column2: * The study's findings support the notion that the process of vaginal delivery may be more damaging to anal continence mechanisms than pregnancy per se.

column3: * The study's results can inform the development of strategies to prevent AI, particularly among parous women with a history of OASI.

column1: 784,"<summary>
* Chronic pain and depression are common health problems in primary care patients, and diagnosing them can be challenging.

column2: * Pain is associated with significant limitations in daily activities, physical activities, and poor self-rated health.
* Depression is often comorbid with pain, and healthcare providers tend to underestimate the intensity of pain symptoms.

* The Dolotest tool has been developed to provide a shared understanding of the patient's situation, integrating measurement of pain intensity with assessment of its impact on mood and other aspects of health-related quality of life.

column1: * The study aimed to determine the usefulness of Dolotest as a screening tool for depression in primary care patients.

column2: * The study included 715 patients, and the results showed that Dolotest is a useful tool for screening for depression, with a sensitivity of 78% and specificity of 95%.
* The study found that patients meeting criteria for depression had higher pain scores and reduced health-related quality of life than patients not meeting criteria for depression.
* The Dolotest domain ""low spirits"" was found to be associated with depression, and a cut-off value of 65 was optimal for detecting patients meeting criteria for depression.

column1: * The study's findings are clinically important, as they highlight the need for healthcare providers to be aware of pain symptoms in patients with depression and depressive symptoms in patients with pain.

column2: * The study's results support the use of targeted screening for the co-occurrence of pain and depression, and the importance of treating both conditions when they co-exist.
* The Dolotest tool can facilitate awareness and communication about depression and pain, leading to improved health-related quality of life and reduced healthcare costs.
* The study's findings are representative of the Danish population, and the results can be generalized to other primary care settings.

column1: * The study's limitations include the lack of control over the scoring of the Dolotest and MDI, and the fact that depression diagnoses were not provided through interview or further examination.

column2: * However, the study's results suggest that Dolotest is a useful tool for screening for depression in primary care patients, and can be used to identify patients who require individualized treatment for both pain and depression.
* The study's findings support the importance of integrating pain and depression management in primary care, and highlight the need for further research in this area.
* The Dolotest tool has the potential to improve patient outcomes and reduce healthcare costs, and its use should be considered in primary care settings.",0

column1: 786,"<summary>
• The healthcare system faces challenges in transferring knowledge from research to practice, resulting in a gap between what physicians do and what they should do.

column2: • This gap leads to ineffective care, with over 40% of patients not receiving care based on best evidence and 20% receiving harmful care.
• Evidence-based medicine (EBM) aims to bridge this gap by directing clinical services towards effective, efficient, and error-free care.

column1: • EBM integrates available evidence with clinical experience and patient values to solve clinical problems.

column2: • It helps physicians make informed decisions based on the best evidence, ensuring equitable distribution of resources and removal of ineffective treatments.

column1: • The main challenge is transferring knowledge to physicians to make informed decisions in a timely manner.

column2: • This requires an integrated system to manage dispersed data and ensure the use of evidence in clinical decision-making.

column1: • A national evidence-based healthcare system is necessary to ensure the best evidence is generated, stored, used, shared, and monitored.

column2: • This system would promote clinical effectiveness, patient safety, and improvement of health outcomes.

column1: • The system consists of three subsystems: national clinical knowledge management, national evidence-based practice, and integrated national network of clinical effectiveness.

column2: • These subsystems work together to provide the best evidence for decision-making, facilitate evidence-based practice, and promote clinical effectiveness.

column1: • The national clinical knowledge management system provides the best evidence through analysis, synthesis, and localization of fragmented data.

column2: • It ensures monitoring and control of new data, producing knowledge products that are used to inform clinical decisions.

column1: • The national evidence-based practice system promotes the use of clinical policies and knowledge products produced at the national level.

column2: • It facilitates evidence-based decision-making, classifies care providers and service centers, and provides educational services on evidence-based practice.

column1: • The integrated national network of clinical effectiveness facilitates evidence-based practice, promotes service quality, and ensures the best evidence is used in clinical decision-making.

column2: • It requires active participation from the Ministry of Health and Medical Education and other involved organizations in health policy-making.

column1: • Implementing evidence-based practice requires a system with micro and macro strategies to enable, facilitate, and guarantee production and application of clinical knowledge.

column2: • The government should adopt policies and interventions to change behavior at individual and organizational levels, requiring cooperation from various stakeholders.

787,"<summary>
• Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) is a negative single-stranded RNA virus that causes respiratory tract infections in infants, seniors, and immunocompromised individuals.

column2: • HMPV has a genome of approximately 13 kb, with a gene composition similar to Human Respiratory Syncytial Virus (HRSV), but lacking two nonstructural genes.

column1: • Synonymous codon usage bias in HMPV genomes is influenced by nucleotide composition, with a high abundance of A/U nucleotides.

column2: • The preferred codons in HMPV are ended with A/U, and the nucleotide composition is the main force affecting codon usage bias.
• The effective number of codons (ENC) values among HMPV genomes show a range from 45.127 to 48.28, indicating a conserved genomic composition.
• The correlation analysis suggests that mutation pressure is the main factor influencing synonymous codon usage bias in HMPV.

column1: • The study reveals that HMPV shows a complementary trend with human cells in terms of codon usage, which may benefit virus replication and persistence in the human host environment.

column2: • The difference in codon usage bias among different phylogenetic types of HMPV may influence its virulence.
• The study provides insights into the molecular evolution and pathogenicity of HMPV.
• The findings can help in understanding the cell-host interaction and viral evolution of HMPV.",0

column1: 788,"<summary>
* The suite of protein tasks, protsweep, domainsweep, and 2dsweep, perform analysis from sequence similarity to small domains and structural elements.

column2: * The tasks include similarity searches against protein sequence databases and specialized motif collections, prediction of secondary structural elements, and domain functional assignation.

column1: * The strategy for assigning functional roles is based on the joint use of both global and local sequence similarities.

column2: * The user can upload query sequences in fasta format, and the tasks can be run with a single click.

column1: * The results are provided as HTML for visual inspection or can be downloaded as XML for storage in private databases.

column2: * In case of error, a log-file is displayed with more human-readable error messages.

column1: * The tasks use standard protein databases like UniProt, RefSeq, and Ensembl, which are automatically updated whenever new versions become available.

column2: * The databases and programs used in the pipelines are described in Table 1.

column1: * Protsweep classifies proteins into categories like identical, homolog, similar, weakly similar, and putative proteins based on the results of the blast cascade.

column1: 790,"<summary>
* The study investigates the relationship between personal and neighborhood environmental characteristics and active transport among inhabitants of Dutch deprived neighborhoods.

column2: * The study focuses on a low-SES population, cycling behavior, and ethnic composition.

column1: * The study used a cross-sectional design and recruited 740 adults from 20 deprived neighborhoods in the Netherlands.

column2: * The participants were predominantly Dutch, with a mean age of 43 years, and 43% were migrants.

column1: * The study found that younger participants were more active in terms of walking and cycling than older participants.

column2: * Migrants walked more than the Dutch, while the Dutch cycled more than migrants.

column1: * The study found that perceived speed of traffic was the only neighborhood environmental characteristic associated with walking for transport.

column2: * When the average speed of traffic was perceived as low, people reported more walking for active transport.

column1: * Interactions between ethnicity and neighborhood walkability showed that migrants were more responsive to neighborhood walkability than the Dutch respondents.

column2: * Speed of traffic and aesthetics were found to be more strongly associated with active transport among migrants than among native Dutch.

column1: * The study found that personal characteristics were stronger associates of active transport than neighborhood characteristics.

column2: * This finding is supported by multiple other studies.

column1: * The study's results may be used to design experimental research to test causality of the findings.

column2: * This may lead to evidence for effective intervention development for subgroups most in need of interventions to increase active transport.

column1: * The study has some limitations, including a low response rate and self-reported measures of active transport.

column2: * The study's results may not be generalizable to other populations or countries.

column1: * The study's findings have implications for policy and intervention development in deprived neighborhoods.

column2: * Insight into the associations between neighborhood characteristics and patterns of physical activity can inform the contents and implementation of policies and interventions.",0

column1: 791,"<summary>
* Optic neuritis related to MS is an acute optic neuropathy that occurs in young people, especially women.

column2: * It is characterized by a decline in visual acuity, pain that increases with eye movements, and changes in the visual field.
* The incidence of optic neuritis is 1-5 per 100,000 annually, and it occurs more often unilaterally in young people, predominantly in women.
* The main aim of the study was to determine the onset of optic neuritis as the first MS clinical presentation.

column1: * The study was a clinical, retrospective study conducted at the Eye Clinic and the Neurological Clinic, Sarajevo University Clinical Centre.

column2: * The study included 89 patients with verified MS diagnosis, and 10 patients had a clinical picture of optic neuritis as a first clinical sign of disease.
* The patients were analyzed using clinical, radiological, and laboratory tests, including MRI of the brain and spinal cord, and optic coherent tomography (OCT).
* The study found that optic neuritis is one of the first clinical manifestations of MS, compared to other motor, sensory, and sensory events.

column1: * The study analyzed ophthalmological parameters, including visual acuity, visual field, and thickness of the peripapillary rim nerve fibers.

column2: * The study found that the most frequent disturbances in the computerized visual field were centrocecal and paracentral scotoma and diffuse sensitivity.
* The study also found that the thickness of the nerve fibers in the whole circumference was reduced, most often in the upper quadrant.
* The study found that pulse corticosteroid therapy improved visual acuity in all patients with optic neuritis.

column1: * The study found that the disease appeared most often in patients aged 18-30 years, and the ratio of the incidence of occurrence of MS ranged from 1.9:1 to 3.6:1 in favor of women.

column2: * The study confirmed that cigarette smoking is a risk factor in the development of MS and optic neuritis.
* The study found that centrocecal scotoma in the visual field and sensitivity depression were present in 50% and 30% of the subjects, respectively.
* The study found that disturbances in the central areas of the visual field were verified in other studies as well.

column1: * The study found that pulse corticosteroid therapy improved visual acuity in all patients with optic neuritis, and that corticosteroids administered intravenously by the",0

column1: * The study highlights the need for health education interventions to prevent diabetes in the rural ethnic community.

column2: * The language barrier is a major obstacle to educating minority groups, and culturally tailored health education strategies are necessary.

column1: 793,"<summary>
• Individuals with serious mental illness (SMI) have higher rates of morbidity and mortality compared to the general population, with diabetes affecting approximately 25% of individuals with SMI.

column2: • This increased rate of diabetes is associated with lower utilization of preventive care and use of newer antipsychotic medications.
• The Affordable Care Act (ACA) promotes preventive and population-based care, including health home programs designed to reduce barriers to care for those with chronic conditions.

column1: • A behavioral health home (BHH) was established to provide services to individuals with SMI, focusing on population-based care to identify abnormal hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels and provide individualized interventions.

column2: • The BHH was embedded in the Division of Community Psychiatry at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, serving 2000 individuals annually.
• Patients were referred to the BHH based on their need for assistance, with a minimum of 2 BHH services per month, including care coordination, comprehensive transitional care, and health promotion.

column1: • Preliminary results of the BHH showed that 54 patients did not have their HbA1c levels drawn within 6 months, and 33 patients had a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes, with 4 newly diagnosed as a result of the population-based health management initiative.

column2: • Of the 33 patients with type 2 diabetes, 4 achieved their target goal, 7 had improvements in HbA1c but remained above their target goal, and 4 had elevated HbA1c levels.
• The BHH services identified gaps in care, such as laboratory monitoring or missed diagnoses, and allowed for the delivery of preventative and individualized proactive care.

column1: • The use of BHH services may be particularly useful in understanding the unique characteristics of a specific population, allowing for earlier recognition of common medical disorders and promoting proactive preventative care.

column2: • A center for disease control and prevention diabetes prevention program group has been started within the mental health clinic, and closer monitoring of clinician practice is being done.

• Future research is needed to examine the utility of BHH services, including investigating both a clinical and a control sample, and examining patient satisfaction with BHH and population-based health management services.

column1: • Limitations of the study include the fact that not all patients received equal amounts of population-based health management services, and the lack of a comparison group, which limited the ability to conduct meaningful statistical tests.

column2: • Future research should address these limitations to provide a more",0

column1: 794,"<summary>

• The article discusses Valerie Oppenheimer's theory on the role of men's socioeconomic position in demographic change, particularly in the declining rates of marriage and the increasing trend of postponing or forgoing marriage.

column2: • Oppenheimer's theory focuses on men's economic position, arguing that men's uncertainty and instability in the labor market lead to delays in marriage.
• The theory is different from other perspectives that emphasize women's economic independence or cultural changes.

column1: • The article reviews previous research on Oppenheimer's theory, including studies in the US and Europe.

column2: • American research generally supports the view that poor economic prospects for men are associated with a delay in marriage.
• European studies also provide evidence for the theory, although the effects may vary across countries.

• The study also explores differences across societal contexts, including traditional and egalitarian societies.

column1: • The data and methods used in the study are described.

column2: • The ECHP provides a large and representative sample of men from 13 European countries.
• The analysis uses discrete-time event-history analysis and logistic regression models.

column1: • The study's findings are not presented in this summary.

column1: • The article concludes by highlighting the importance of understanding the role of men's socioeconomic position in demographic change.

column1: 795,"<summary>
* Osteoporosis in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS)

* Long-term GC treatment and vitamin D deficiency

* Dose-dependent effect on bone loss
* Increased risk of osteoporotic fractures

* Supplementation recommended to achieve optimal levels

column1: * Exercise and physical activity

* Whole-body vibration as a potential new approach

* Pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions

* Teriparatide as an anabolic agent
* Sclerostin antibody as a potential new therapeutic approach

column1: * Future directions

• The study evaluated the frequency of symptoms in patients with vivax malaria before and after treatment with chloroquine and primaquine.

column2: • The most common symptoms reported before treatment were fever, chills, sweating, and weakness, as well as pain symptoms such as headache, arthralgia, and lower back pain.

• The treatment led to a significant reduction in the prevalence of fever, arthralgia, back pain, and retroocular pain, but also caused an increase in gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
• The frequency of choluria (dark urine) increased significantly after primaquine was started, which may be related to hemolytic anemia caused by primaquine in patients with G6PD deficiency.

797,"<summary>

* The life span of humans has increased, and the proportion of elderly people in the population has also increased, leading to a higher incidence of age-related diseases such as lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and erectile dysfunction (ED).

column2: * LUTS and ED often occur concurrently in elderly men, and their coexistence affects quality of life (QOL).

column1: * Several community-based studies have shown a strong correlation between sexual dysfunction, increasing age, and the severity of LUTS.

column2: * The pathophysiological mechanism of the correlation between LUTS and ED is not fully understood, but hypotheses include overactivation of the autonomic nervous system and endothelial dysfunction.

column1: * The primary treatment regimen for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is to administer alpha-blockers, which improve urinary flow rate and voiding symptoms.

column2: * Concomitant administration of alpha-blockers and anticholinergics may improve LUTS more effectively in patients with LUTS/BPH.

column1: * This study examined the effects on erectile function of a combination of the alpha-blocker tamsulosin and the antimuscarinic agent solifenacin in patients with LUTS/BPH and ED.

column2: * The study found that concomitant treatment with alpha-blockers and antimuscarinics improved LUTS, but did not significantly improve sexual function.

column1: * The study also found that improvement in storage symptoms was associated with improved sexual function in patients treated with tamsulosin alone, but not in those treated with tamsulosin and solifenacin.

column2: * The use of anticholinergic agents in patients with LUTS/BPH is selective, and their effects on sexual function are not well understood.",0

column1: 798,"<summary>
* Mir-200c is a microRNA that plays a crucial role in maintaining the epithelial phenotype in cancer cells.

column2: * It does this by targeting and repressing the transcription factor ZEB1, which is involved in epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT).

column1: * Mir-200c also regulates cell migration and invasion by targeting genes involved in these processes.

column2: * This is independent of E-cadherin expression, which is a hallmark of epithelial cells.

column1: * Restoration of mir-200c in cancer cells increases their sensitivity to microtubule-targeting agents such as paclitaxel.

column2: * This is due to mir-200c's ability to repress the expression of TUBB3, a protein involved in resistance to these agents.

column1: * Mir-200c also affects cell adhesion, with increased mir-200c leading to decreased adhesion to certain substrates.

column2: * This could be relevant to ovarian cancer, where cancer cells adhere to sites in the peritoneal cavity.

column1: * The double-negative feedback loop between mir-200c and ZEB1 is not always intact in cancer cells.

column2: * This can be exploited to identify the distinct roles of mir-200c and ZEB1 in different cell types.

column1: * Mir-200c's effects on cell proliferation are complex and may involve both direct and indirect mechanisms.

column2: * Further study is needed to fully understand the relationship between mir-200c and cell proliferation.",1

column1: 799,"<summary>
* The transobturator approach to treat female stress urinary incontinence was first described by Delorme in 2001.

column2: * The approach was designed to prevent complications associated with the retropubic midurethral sling (MUS) placement.

column1: * A similar transobturator passage utilizing an inside-out approach was later described by De Leval in 2003.

column2: * The inside-out approach aimed to further reduce the potential injury to the urethra and bladder.

column1: * A recent meta-analysis found similar cure rates between the three most commonly used surgical approaches for treating stress urinary incontinence.

column2: * The approaches included the retropubic, outside-in transobturator, and inside-out transobturator MUS procedures.

column1: * Multiple studies have discussed the anatomical trajectories of both obturator approaches and confirmed their anatomical safety from a neurovascular perspective.

column2: * The studies used various methods, including cadaveric dissections and imaging techniques.

column1: * The aim of this cadaveric study was to compare the specific relationship between the tape and the urethra in both the inside-out and outside-in approaches.

column2: * The study used CT-scan image analysis to visualize the tape's trajectory in relation to the urethra.

column1: * The study found that the inside-out approach angulated around the urethra in a more acute fashion than the outside-in approach.

column2: * The outside-in approach seemed to follow a more horizontal, flatter trajectory.

column1: * The study's findings have clinical implications for surgeons performing MUS procedures.

column2: * Surgeons must pay attention to the 2nd half of the helical pass and take care to avoid complications, such as button-holing and vaginal wall injury.

column1: * The study's results may be useful for future research using 3D ultrasonography or MRI to visualize mesh-tape trajectories in vivo.

column2: * These imaging techniques may allow for correlation of findings to nuances in clinical outcomes and a better understanding of the mesh-tissue interaction.",1

column1: 805,"<summary>

column1: • The Minister is also considering the need for a more graduated system of intervention, with a range of powers available to the regulator, rather than just a few severe sanctions.

806,"<summary>
* Kirsty Williams' views on managing risks in the higher education sector

column2: * She believes that the 2015 Act has not struck the right balance in regulating institutions, with stronger institutions being over-regulated and riskier private providers being under-regulated.
* She thinks that the Act has created a system where the level of regulation is not proportionate to the level of risk posed by an institution.

column1: * The Minister's approach to risk management in the new PCET Bill

column2: * She wants to create a system of outcome agreements that will allow for a more proportionate approach to regulation, with institutions being regulated based on their level of risk.
* She believes that this approach will allow for a more effective use of resources and a more targeted approach to addressing risks in the sector.

column1: * The role of HEFCW in managing risks

column2: * HEFCW has a range of powers to intervene in institutions, but these powers are not always used effectively.
* The Minister wants to ensure that HEFCW has the right powers and resources to manage risks effectively and to support institutions in improving their performance.

column1: * The importance of institutional autonomy

column2: * The Minister believes that institutional autonomy is important, but it must be balanced with the need to manage risks and ensure that institutions are accountable for their performance.
* She wants to create a system that allows institutions to have the freedom to innovate and take risks, while also ensuring that they are held accountable for their actions.",1
