• The buttons should include channel up and down, volume up and down, and power on/off.

column1: • The team considered the use of speech recognition technology.

column2: • Younger people are more open to speech recognition, but older people are less interested.
• Implementing speech recognition may be too complex and expensive.

column1: • The team discussed the problem of lost remotes.

column2: • A whistle or clap function could be added to help locate the remote.
• This feature would be a unique selling point and cater to all age groups.

column1: • The team decided to exclude teletext functionality.

column2: • Teletext is becoming outdated due to the rise of the internet.
• The remote control should focus on TV functionality only.

column1: • The team discussed the number of buttons on the remote.

column2: • Ten number buttons (0-9) and a mechanism to allow multiple digits to be entered are needed.
• This would enable users to enter channel numbers easily.

column1: • The team considered additional features, such as an LCD menu.

column2: • An LCD menu could provide access to additional functions, such as audio settings.
• However, this may add complexity and expense to the remote control.

column1: </summary>",1
813,"<summary>
• Project Requirements

column2: • The project is to design a remote control for a TV only, with a focus on simplicity and user-friendliness.
• The remote control should have a limited number of buttons, with a focus on the most commonly used functions.
• The project has a short timeline and a limited budget.

column1: • Design Decisions

column2: • The remote control will have a ""clap back"" feature to help users locate it when it's lost.
• The remote control will have a simple design with a limited number of buttons, including numbers 0-9 and a mechanism to allow for multiple digits to be entered.
• The remote control will not have a teletext button, as teletext is becoming outdated.

column1: • Functionality

column2: • The remote control will have basic functions such as channel changing, volume control, and power on/off.
• The remote control may have a menu system, such as an LCD menu, to access additional functions.
• The remote control will need to have a tuning function, as not all TVs have automatic tuning.",1

column1: 814,"<summary>
* Functional Requirements

column2: * The remote control should be able to send messages to the TV, switch it on and off, and change channels.
* It should have a simple and user-friendly design.
* The user should be able to easily identify the remote control.

column1: * Target Group

column2: * The target group is people of all ages, from kids to adults.
* The remote control should be easy to use for people with little to no technical experience.
* The design should be accessible to people with disabilities.

column1: * Technical Specifications

column2: * The remote control should have a power source, such as batteries or a charger.
* It should have a smart chip that can perform various functions.
* The chip should be able to communicate with the TV and other devices.

column1: * Design Considerations

column2: * The remote control should have a large on-off button and large buttons in general.
* It should have a finding device, such as a homing device or a tracker.
* The design should include the company's color and logo.

column1: * Speech Recognition

column2: * The remote control should have speech recognition capabilities.
* The speech recognition should be able to recognize commands such as ""channel 5"" or ""volume up"".
* The speech recognition should be able to locate the remote control if it is lost.

column1: * Additional Features

column2: * The remote control should have a menu button that pops up with a menu on the TV.
* The menu should include options such as audio and video settings, language, and subtitles.
* The remote control should have up, down, and side-to-side buttons for navigating the menu.",1

column1: 815,"<summary>
• Project Overview

column2: • The meeting is about designing a modern and high-class remote control for a TV.
• The goal is to determine the user requirements and technical functions of the remote.
• The project manager leads the discussion and takes notes.

column1: • User Interface

column2: • The user interface expert presents their research on the functions of a remote control.
• They discuss the importance of simplicity and ease of use.
• They show examples of complex and simple remote controls.

column1: • Marketing Research

column2: • The marketing expert presents their research on user preferences.
• They found that users want a modern and high-tech design.
• They also want a simple and easy-to-use remote control.

column1: • Technical Requirements

column2: • The industrial designer discusses the technical requirements of the remote control.
• They mention the need for a power source, smart chip, and infrared bulb.
• They also discuss the possibility of using a rechargeable battery.

column1: • New Project Requirements

column2: • The project manager announces new project requirements.
• The remote control will only be for a TV, not for other devices.
• The company's color and logo will be included on the remote.

column1: • Target Group

column2: • The team discusses the target group for the remote control.
• They decide that the target group is people of all ages, from kids to adults.
• They want the remote control to be easy to use for people with little technical experience.

column1: • Functions

column2: • The team discusses the functions of the remote control.
• They decide to include basic functions such as on/off, volume, mute, and channel up/down.
• They also consider including speech recognition and a finding device.

column1: • Budget and Design

column2: • The team discusses the budget and design of the remote control.
• They want to keep the design simple and modern.
• They need to consider the cost of including additional features such as speech recognition and a finding device.

816,"<summary>
• Introduction and Icebreaker

column2: • The meeting starts with an introduction and an icebreaker activity where each team member introduces themselves and draws their favorite animal on a smart board.
• The team members are: Danny Wolfs (Project Manager), Juergen Toffs (User Interface Designer), Tim (Marketing Expert), and Janus (Industrial Designer).
• The icebreaker activity is meant to help the team get to know each other and have some fun before diving into the project.

column1: • Project Overview

column2: • The project aim is to create a new remote control that is original, trendy, and user-friendly.
• The project has three stages: functional design, conceptual design, and detailed design.
• The team will work individually and in meetings to complete each stage.

column1: • Project Requirements

column2: • The remote control must be sold for 25 Euros, and the production cost must not exceed 20.5 Euros.
• The team needs to sell 2 million remotes to make a profit of 50 million Euros.
• The remote control should be able to be used internationally.

column1: • Brainstorming Session

column2: • The team discusses what features they think are important for the remote control, such as being intuitive, small, and multi-purpose.
• They also discuss the possibility of using new technology, such as radio waves or Bluetooth, instead of infrared.
• The team agrees that the remote control should be innovative and technically advanced.

column1: • Next Steps

column2: • The team will work individually on their tasks and provide feedback via email.
• They will discuss their progress and ideas at the next meeting.
• The team will create a plan and come to a consensus on what they want to achieve with the remote control.

column1: • Conclusion

column2: • The meeting ends with a summary of the discussion and tasks assigned to each team member.
• The team will reconvene in 30 minutes to continue working on the project.
• The Project Manager reminds the team to be careful and wishes them success.",1

column1: 817,"<summary>
• The meeting discusses the format for storing and sharing data for speech recognition and prosody analysis.

column2: • The goal is to find a format that is easy to use, flexible, and compatible with existing tools.
• The format should be able to handle different types of data, including speech recognition output, prosody features, and annotations.

column1: • The current format being used is based on an XML-like structure with tags and attributes.

column2: • The format is easy to parse and can be easily translated to and from other formats.
• However, it may not be flexible enough to handle all the types of data that need to be stored.

column1: • The ATLAS format from NIST is also being considered as an alternative.

column2: • It uses a graph-based representation, which is more flexible than the current format.
• However, it may require more infrastructure and tools to support.

column1: • The pros and cons of each format are being weighed, including ease of use, flexibility, and compatibility.

column2: • The decision will depend on the specific needs of the project and the tools that will be used.
• The format should be able to handle large amounts of data and be easy to translate to and from other formats.

column1: • The format should be able to handle different types of annotations, including speech recognition output, prosody features, and manual annotations.

column2: • The format should be able to handle data from multiple speakers and channels.
• The format should be able to handle data from different time scales, including frame-level and utterance-level data.

column1: • The format should be easy to use and intuitive, with clear documentation and examples.

column2: • The format should be flexible and able to handle new types of data as they are added.
• The format should be compatible with existing tools and infrastructure.

column1: • The decision on the format will depend on the specific needs of the project and the tools that will be used.

column2: • The format should be able to handle large amounts of data and be easy to translate to and from other formats.
• The format should be easy to use and intuitive, with clear documentation and examples.

column1: • The meeting concludes with a plan to investigate the ATLAS format further and to consider the pros and cons of each format.

column2: • The goal is to make a decision on the format soon and to begin implementing it.
• The format should be able to handle all the types of data that need to be stored and should be easy to use and flexible.",0

column1: 819,"<summary>
* The Welsh Government is discussing the early childhood education and care provision in Wales.

column2: * The Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan, is leading the discussion.
* The focus is on supporting both children and parents, with the goal of providing a high-quality early childhood education and care system.

column3: * This includes supporting parents in finding stable, well-paid jobs.
* The system should also provide jobs in the childcare sector.

column1: * The group is discussing the differences in care provision across Wales.

column2: * The Deputy Minister acknowledges that there are variations in provision, but notes that quality is good across the country.

column3: * The Flying Start programme is targeted at areas of high need, and is universally available in those areas.
* The childcare offer is demand-led, with funding following demand from parents.

column1: * The committee is concerned about the lack of consistency in provision across Wales.

column2: * The Deputy Minister agrees that this is a challenge, but notes that the government is working to address it.

column3: * The government is piloting a project in Flintshire to test the impact of consistent funding rates for education and childcare.
* The government is also encouraging the development of foundation phase provision in non-maintained settings.

column1: * The committee asks about the impact of cuts to the education improvement grant on the foundation phase.

column2: * The Deputy Minister says that she hasn't seen any evidence of a drop in standards, but acknowledges that funding is a challenge.

column3: * The government is planning to extend the childcare offer to parents in education and training.
* The government is also working to improve the Welsh language skills of the childcare workforce.

column1: * The committee asks about the evaluation of the childcare offer.

column2: * The Deputy Minister says that the first year's evaluation showed limited impact, but expects the second year's evaluation to show more progress.

column3: * The government is planning a big push to promote the childcare offer this autumn.
* The take-up of the offer is increasing each month, with almost 16,000 children accessing it by the end of July.

column1: * The committee asks about funding for the childcare offer.

column2: * The Deputy Minister says that the government is committed to providing the necessary funding, and that local authorities will not have to find extra money from their own budgets.

column3: * The government expects to spend around £50-55 million on the childcare offer this financial year.
* The government is reviewing the programme and will report back early next year on how to bring",0

column1: 820,"<summary>
• The Welsh Government's approach to childcare and early years education

column2: • The government is working to simplify the system and make it more accessible to families, with a focus on supporting both children and parents.
• The childcare offer is being expanded to include more families, including those in education and training, and those ""on the cusp"" of returning to work.

column1: • The government is committed to providing funding to support the childcare offer, with an expected spend of £50-55 million in the current financial year.

column2: • Local authorities will receive full funding to deliver the offer, and will not have to find extra money from their own budgets.

column1: • The government is taking into account various factors in developing the childcare offer, including the need to encourage people back into work, cost, and the definition of ""on the cusp"" of returning to work.

column2: • The government is also considering the needs of specific groups, such as those in full-time education and training, and those undertaking short training programs or preparing for work.",0

column1: 821,"<summary>
• The Welsh Government is working to simplify the early childhood education and care system, which is currently complex and has grown from different routes.

column2: • They are conducting pilot projects in eight local authorities to look at ways of simplifying the system and improving accessibility and take-up.

column1: • The Deputy Minister, Julie Morgan, emphasized the importance of supporting both children and parents, as working parents are more likely to have stable jobs and be able to provide for their children.

column2: • The childcare system is a big employer and provides jobs, which is also an important consideration.

column1: • The Welsh Government is committed to extending the childcare offer to parents in education and training, and those ""on the cusp"" of returning to work.

column2: • This decision was influenced by the committee's recommendations and the First Minister's manifesto commitment to include education and training in the childcare offer.

column1: • The evaluation of the childcare offer is ongoing, with a second evaluation due in November 2020, which is expected to provide more meaningful results.

column2: • The first evaluation showed that 94% of respondents were already using formal childcare before the offer was introduced.

column1: • The Welsh Government is working to improve the availability of Welsh language skills in the early years workforce, with a programme to develop workplace Welsh language skills and attract more bilingual staff.

column2: • They are also incorporating Welsh language skills into early years training to ensure that staff are equipped to transmit the language to children.",1

column1: 822,"<summary>
• Meeting Overview

column2: • The meeting was held to discuss early childhood education and care in Wales.
• The Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan, attended the meeting.
• The meeting covered topics such as the childcare offer, early years workforce, and bilingualism.

column1: • Childcare Offer

column2: • The childcare offer is a key priority for the Welsh Government.
• The offer is currently available to working parents, but there are plans to extend it to parents in education and training.
• The government is committed to making available the total funding needed to deliver the offer.

column1: • Early Years Workforce

column2: • The Welsh Government is developing a more integrated approach to the early years sector.
• The government is working to upskill the existing workforce and attract new staff with Welsh language skills.
• The National Centre for Learning Welsh is providing education programs to support the development of Welsh language skills in the workforce.

column1: • Bilingualism

column2: • The government is committed to promoting bilingualism in the early years sector.
• The childcare offer is available in Welsh or bilingual settings, and the government is working to increase the number of Welsh-medium childcare places.
• The government is also providing support for staff to develop their Welsh language skills.

column1: • Evaluation and Funding

column2: • The government is evaluating the childcare offer and will publish a second evaluation in November.
• The evaluation will provide more information on the impact of the offer, including its effect on parents' ability to work.
• The government is committed to providing the necessary funding to support the offer, including funding for local authorities.",1

column1: 833,"Here is the summary:
<summary>
* Huw Morris's thoughts on the ""no deal"" scenario

column2: * He mentioned that the higher education Brexit working group has been meeting since September 2016
* They have been looking at the impact of Brexit on higher education and further education
* The group has been visiting individual institutions to discuss their preparedness for a ""no deal"" scenario
* They believe that funding for much of the activity is secured until December 2020

column1: * Kirsty Williams's thoughts on student recruitment

column2: * She mentioned that the Welsh Government has been working with Universities Wales to access resources under the European transition fund
* They are looking to boost international marketing of the HE sector
* The Global Wales programme aims to increase the ability of universities to market themselves internationally
* The programme is targeting specific markets, including the United States and Vietnam

column1: * Concerns about the drop in EU student applications

column2: * The drop is attributed to the change in tuition fee arrangements
* Wales is the only country in the UK to have seen a significant drop in EU student applications
* The change in tuition fee arrangements has removed an incentive for EU students to come to Wales
* The Welsh Government is working with universities to increase their ability to market themselves internationally

column1: * The impact of Brexit on further education

column2: * Eluned Morgan mentioned that the FE sector is more locally anchored and has fewer EU students
* The sector is more concerned about the impact of Brexit on apprenticeships and ESF funding
* The Welsh Government is working with FE colleges to prepare for the impact of Brexit
* They are also looking at ways to mitigate the impact of Brexit on the sector

column1: * The sustainability of higher education

column2: * Kirsty Williams mentioned that the sector is in a managed deficit
* The Welsh Government is committed to implementing the Diamond review proposals
* The implementation of Diamond will provide a more sustainable funding settlement for the sector
* The Government is also discussing how to implement the Reid review recommendations

column1: * The importance of multi-year funding settlements

column2: * Eluned Morgan mentioned that the multi-annual nature of European funding programmes has been useful for institutions
* The Welsh Government is considering introducing multi-year funding settlements for HE and FE
* This would provide more security and comfort for the sectors
* It would allow institutions to plan and have strategic aims

842,"<summary>
* The discussion revolves around the data collection process for a project involving a conversational system.

column2: * The system will ask users to choose tasks they would like to perform in Heidelberg.
* The tasks will be presented in a hierarchical fashion, with users selecting a category and then a specific task.
* The goal is to gather data on how users phrase their requests and plan their activities.

column1: * The team is considering whether to use a simple response system or a more complex planning system.

column2: * A simple response system would ask users to choose a task and then respond with a single answer.
* A more complex planning system would ask users to plan multiple tasks and organize them.
* The team is leaning towards starting with the simple response system.

column1: * The team is also discussing how to present the tasks to the users.

column2: * They are considering using categories and offering only one member of each category.
* This would allow users to choose between different tasks, but not between similar tasks (e.g. zoo and castle).
* The goal is to gather data on different constructions and phrasings.
* The team wants to limit the choices to make the task more manageable for users.

column1: * The team is planning to review the data after collecting it from 10 subjects.

column2: * They will listen to the audio recordings and identify interesting points.
* They will also consider transcribing the data, but it may not be necessary.
* The review will help them decide whether to move to a more complex planning system.

column1: * The team is discussing the logistics of the data collection process.

column2: * They need to schedule users and ensure that the system is working properly.
* They are also considering buying additional storage space for the audio recordings.
* The team is working together to solve technical problems.

column2: * They are planning to review the data in two weeks.
* They will use the review to decide whether to make changes to the system.
* The team is flexible and willing to adapt to any issues that arise.

column1: * The team is considering the limitations of the system.

column2: * They are aware that users may not always follow the instructions.
* They are also aware that the system may not be able to handle complex requests.
* The team is working to minimize these limitations.
* They are also considering ways to make the system more user-friendly.

856,"<summary>
• The PDG for looked-after children lacks visibility compared to the PDG for free-school-meal pupils.

column2: • Only 15% of primary schools and 23% of secondary schools are aware that PDG is targeted at looked-after children.
• The MORI/WISERD survey highlights the lack of awareness among schools about PDG for looked-after children.

column1: • The role of schools and regional consortia in PDG for looked-after children is unclear.

column2: • The decision to regionalize PDG for looked-after children was made in 2015 to drive greater impact.
• Looked-after PDG is held at a regional level, and co-ordinators are responsible for deploying the resource.

column1: • The resource can be used in various ways, including individual allocation to schools or capacity building for the whole system.

column2: • An example of effective use is in Carmarthenshire, where training teachers on attachment disorder has improved attainment for looked-after children.

column1: • The Cabinet Secretary has asked officials to scrutinize how the resource has been used and will ask detailed questions about accountability.

column2: • A letter was sent to the system outlining expectations and advising of the need for accountability.",0

column1: 857,"<summary>
* The PDG (Pupil Deprivation Grant) is a funding program in Wales aimed at supporting disadvantaged pupils.

column2: * The grant is allocated to schools based on the number of pupils eligible for free school meals, looked-after children, and those from minority ethnic backgrounds.

column1: * The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, was questioned by the Children, Young People and Education Committee about the effectiveness of the PDG.

column2: * She acknowledged that the grant has been successful in narrowing the attainment gap between disadvantaged pupils and their peers.

column1: * However, the committee raised concerns about the targeting of the grant, with some schools using it to support pupils who are not eligible.

column2: * Kirsty Williams acknowledged that there may be some flexibility in how the grant is used, but emphasized the importance of targeting it at those who need it most.

column1: * The committee also discussed the use of PDG to support looked-after children, with only 15% of primary schools and 23% of secondary schools aware that the grant is available for this purpose.

column2: * Kirsty Williams acknowledged that there is less awareness about the availability of PDG for looked-after children and that the grant is held at a regional level.

column1: * The Cabinet Secretary emphasized the importance of evaluating the effectiveness of the PDG and making adjustments as needed.

column2: * She also highlighted the need for a more sophisticated approach to measuring school performance, moving away from the current level 2 plus measure.

column1: * The committee also discussed the role of regional consortia in supporting schools in using the PDG effectively.

column2: * Kirsty Williams emphasized the importance of collaboration between schools and regional consortia to ensure that the grant is used to maximum effect.

column1: * The Cabinet Secretary acknowledged that there may be challenges in evaluating the effectiveness of the PDG, particularly in terms of its impact on individual pupils.

column2: * She emphasized the need for ongoing evaluation and monitoring to ensure that the grant is making a positive difference for disadvantaged pupils.",0

column2: • The Cabinet Secretary cited examples of schools using PDG to improve attendance, such as a walking bus initiative

column1: • The committee discussed the use of PDG to support looked-after children

column1: 861,"Here is the summary of the meeting:
<summary>
* The meeting started with a discussion about a previous meeting and some jokes about laughing.

column2: * Grad A and Grad E had a brief exchange about who was known for something.
* The conversation then turned to the topic of the meeting.

column1: * Grad B gave an update on the EDU project.

column2: * He mentioned that Fey's time with them is almost over and they have collected 30 subjects and transcribed 10 dialogues.
* They plan to make the next round of data collection more complicated.

column1: * Grad D presented his work on the PRM (Probabilistic Relational Model) for the travel planner.

column2: * He explained that the PRM is a way to model the relationships between different classes and attributes.
* He showed a diagram of the PRM and explained how it could be used to make decisions about travel plans.

column1: * The group discussed the PRM and its potential applications.

column2: * They talked about the need to find an interpreter for the PRM and the possibility of using it to plan travel for groups of people.
* They also discussed the idea of using the PRM to model uncertainty and make decisions based on probabilities.

column1: * Grad C (Andy) introduced himself and explained that he is visiting from the International University.

column2: * He is working on a project to develop a smart FAQ system that can understand context and provide relevant answers.
* He wants to use a probabilistic approach to model the uncertainty of the search results.

column1: * Grad C explained that his system would use a combination of keywords and context to retrieve relevant documents.

column2: * He wants to use a peer-to-peer approach to allow users to share knowledge and expertise.
* He also wants to integrate existing domain information and ontologies to make the system more effective.

column1: * The group discussed the similarities between Grad C's project and their own work on the travel planner.

column2: * They talked about the importance of understanding context and the need for a shared interpretation of keywords and concepts.
* They also discussed the potential for reusing existing domain information and ontologies.

column1: * The meeting ended with a discussion of the potential for collaboration and knowledge sharing between the different projects.

column2: * Grad C expressed interest in learning more about the group's work and potentially collaborating in the future.
* The group agreed to follow up and discuss potential collaborations further.",1

864,"<summary>
• Dr. Frank Atherton, Chief Medical Officer for Wales, discussed the ""Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales"" draft strategy with the Children, Young People and Education Committee.

column2: • The strategy aims to address childhood obesity and promote healthy weight in Wales.

column1: • The committee asked about investment in the strategy, and Dr. Atherton mentioned that £8-10 million per year may be needed, but the exact figure depends on the final strategy.

column2: • The sugar levy revenue could be used to fund the strategy, but Dr. Atherton prefers not to hypothecate the funding.

column1: • The committee discussed the importance of targets and evaluation metrics for the strategy.

column2: • Dr. Atherton is open to considering targets, but wants to ensure they are deliverable and challenging.

column1: • Dr. Atherton emphasized the need for a whole-system approach, involving multiple government departments and stakeholders.

column2: • He wants to see local leadership and ownership of the strategy, with directors of public health and chief executives playing key roles.

column1: • The committee asked about data collection and measurement of childhood obesity.

column2: • Dr. Atherton mentioned that the child measurement programme provides data, but there may be gaps in the data, and expanding the programme could be considered.

column1: • The strategy may involve legislating on issues like price promotions and energy drinks, but the timing is uncertain.

column2: • Dr. Atherton wants to explore the use of the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways near schools.

column1: • The committee discussed the importance of community sport infrastructure and accessible facilities in new schools.

column2: • Dr. Atherton supports building health into public infrastructure and using health impact assessments to inform policy decisions.

column1: • Dr. Atherton mentioned the healthy and sustainable preschool scheme, but acknowledged that staffing ratios in schools may impact the foundation phase.

column2: • He agreed to consider the committee's points about local leadership and accountability in the strategy development board.

column1: </summary>",0

column1: 869,"<summary>
• Meeting Overview

column2: • The meeting was held to discuss the ""Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales"" draft strategy.
• The Chief Medical Officer for Wales, Dr. Frank Atherton, and Nathan Cook from the Welsh Government attended the meeting.
• The committee discussed the strategy's approach to tackling childhood obesity.

column1: • Leadership and Targets

column2: • Dr. Atherton emphasized the need for a whole-system approach to tackle obesity.
• He suggested that the strategy should focus on prevention and early intervention.
• The committee discussed the possibility of setting targets for reducing childhood obesity.

column1: • Resource Allocation

column2: • Dr. Atherton mentioned that £8-10 million per year would be needed to implement the strategy.
• The committee discussed the use of revenue from the sugar levy to fund obesity prevention initiatives.
• Dr. Atherton emphasized the need to make the most of existing resources.

column1: • Partnership Working

column2: • Dr. Atherton stressed the importance of partnership working across different sectors.
• He suggested that a national implementation board should be established to oversee the strategy.
• The board would need to be accountable to Ministers.

column1: • Data Collection

column2: • Dr. Atherton mentioned that the child measurement programme provides data on childhood obesity.
• The committee discussed the possibility of introducing a second measurement point in Wales.
• Dr. Atherton emphasized the need for better data to inform policy decisions.

column1: • Healthy Environments

column2: • Dr. Atherton suggested that the planning system could be used to restrict hot food takeaways near schools.
• He emphasized the importance of building health into the environment.
• The committee discussed the need for community sport infrastructure.

column1: • Education Settings

column2: • Dr. Atherton emphasized the importance of healthy habits acquired early in life.
• The committee discussed the healthy and sustainable preschool scheme.
• Dr. Atherton suggested that the strategy development board should consider the foundation phase.

column1: • Local Leadership

column2: • Dr. Atherton emphasized the importance of local leadership in implementing the strategy.
• The committee discussed the need for accountability at the local level.
• Dr. Atherton suggested that the strategy development board should consider the connection between the strategy and the new curriculum.

column1: • Next Steps

column2: • The committee will continue to scrutinize the draft strategy.
• Dr. Atherton will take the committee's points back to the strategy development board.
• The final strategy will be published in the autumn.",1

875,"<summary>
• Meeting discussion about PhD student E's experiment on mean log magnitude spectral subtraction

column2: • The experiment aims to reduce word error rate in speech recognition systems
• The approach uses a filter to subtract the mean of the speech signal over a certain time window

column1: • Professor C suggests considering the filter as a high-pass filter and designing it to remove low-frequency components

column2: • This approach could be used in conjunction with other techniques, such as caching utterances to improve response time

column1: • PhD student B presents his experiment on Wiener filtering

column2: • The experiment uses a single-stage Wiener filter and achieves a 30% improvement over the baseline
• Adding a second stage of Wiener filtering with smoothing in the frequency domain improves the result to 56.46%

column1: • The discussion touches on the importance of the Voice Activity Detection (VAD) system in estimating noise

column2: • Using the VAD output from the close-talking microphone (channel zero) improves the noise estimation

column1: • The group discusses the rules for the upcoming evaluation, including the use of a common set of files with pre-defined boundaries

column2: • The boundaries will be provided by the organizers, and participants will be allowed to use them to improve their systems",0

column1: 876,"<summary>
* The meeting discusses the results of a wizard test data test, where a subject had to read aloud and complete tasks with a system that sometimes broke down.

column2: * The test revealed that the reading needs to be shorter, and the introduction needs to be improved.

column1: * The group discusses the role of a wizard in the system, and how to refine the tasks to avoid rephrasing.

column2: * The professor suggests hiring the wizard, Fey, and paying her for her work, and also involving linguists in the project to get their input on the task design.

* The group also discusses a pedagogical belief net created by Grad A, which groups concepts into categories such as Trajector-Landmark and Source-Path-Goal, and how to use it to make decisions in the system.
* The professor suggests simplifying the belief net by making each node narrower and more specific, and using summary nodes to reduce the complexity of the input to the final decision node.

column1: </summary>",0

column1: 885,"<summary>

column1: • Technical Specifications

column2: • The remote control will use infrared technology and will need to be adapted to the existing TV receiver protocol.
• The team discussed the possibility of integrating video and TV functions into one remote control.

column1: • Design Concepts

column2: • The design should be trendy and appealing to younger users, with a focus on ease of use and intuitive functionality.
• The team considered taking inspiration from mobile phone designs, with larger keys and a more compact layout.

column1: • Key Features

column2: • The remote control should have a prominent on/off button, channel selection, and volume control.
• The team discussed the possibility of including teletext and other features, but noted that these are not as commonly used as they once were.

column1: • Next Steps

column2: • The team will continue to refine their designs and consider the technical specifications and market research.
• The project manager will share the team's findings with the account manager and provide further guidance on the project.",1

column1: 899,"<summary>

• The professor mentions that the baseline has been changed to 22% better than the old one

column1: • The professor talks about the TRAPS recognition system

column2: • It's a different approach to speech recognition that uses temporal patterns
• The system is still in the experimental stage and the professor is trying to understand how it works
• The professor mentions that the system is sensitive to the frequency bands used
• The professor is exploring ways to improve the system, including using neighboring frequency bands

column1: • The professor discusses the issue of masking in speech recognition

column2: • Masking is when a noise in one frequency band affects the recognition of a signal in another frequency band
• The professor mentions that the human brain can discard information from neighboring frequency bands if it's the same
• The professor is trying to understand how to apply this to the TRAPS system
• The professor mentions that the system is not yet ready for evaluation

column1: • The professor talks about the team's progress and plans

column2: • Sunil is on vacation in India and may be getting married

column1: 917,"Here is the summary of the meeting in 10 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
* Project Overview

column2: * The meeting discussed the conceptual design of a remote control for a TV system called Real Reaction.
* The project aims to create a user-friendly and innovative remote control.
* The team consists of a Project Manager, Industrial Designer, Marketing, and User Interface experts.
* The meeting covered various aspects of the remote control's design and functionality.

column1: * Industrial Designer's Presentation

column2: * The Industrial Designer presented two concepts for the remote control's shape: single-curved and double-curved.
* The team discussed the pros and cons of each design, including the cost and feasibility of production.
* The Industrial Designer also presented options for the remote control's material, including plastic and rubber.
* The team preferred rubber as the material for its soft and luxurious feel.

column1: * Battery and Kinetic Energy

column2: * The team discussed the options for powering the remote control, including batteries and kinetic energy.
* They considered the advantages and disadvantages of each option, including cost, convenience, and environmental impact.
* The team decided to combine both options, using a battery with kinetic energy as a backup.
* This solution would provide a reliable and sustainable power source for the remote control.

column1: * Touch-Screen and LCD Display

column2: * The team discussed the possibility of using a touch-screen and LCD display for the remote control.
* They considered the benefits of a touch-screen, including ease of use and customization options.
* The team also discussed the importance of keeping the menu structure simple and intuitive.
* They decided to use a touch-screen with a simple and customizable menu structure.

column1: * Marketing Research

column2: * The Marketing expert presented research on consumer preferences for remote control design and functionality.
* The research showed that younger users prefer bright colors and soft materials, while older users prefer more traditional designs.
* The team decided to target the younger demographic and incorporate their preferences into the design.
* The Marketing expert also suggested adding games and other features to the remote control to appeal to younger users.

column1: * User Interface Design

column2: * The User Interface expert presented a mock-up of the remote control's interface.
* The design featured a large touch-screen display with clear and visible buttons.
* The team discussed the importance of keeping the interface simple and intuitive.
* They also considered the need for customization options and a menu structure that is easy to navigate.

column1: 922,"<summary>
* The meeting was held to discuss the Welsh Baccalaureate qualification.

column3: * The skills challenge element of the qualification helps prepare students for further study and the world of work.
* The qualification is broad and balanced, and recognizes the importance of knowledge and skills in core subjects.

column1: * The committee discussed the variability in the delivery of the Welsh Baccalaureate.

column2: * Some schools deliver the qualification well, while others do not.

column3: * This inconsistency can affect the value that learners attach to the qualification.

column1: 923,"<summary>
• The Bill aims to prohibit physical punishment of children in Wales.

column2: • It removes the defense of reasonable punishment, making it an offense to physically punish a child.
• The Bill is part of a wider package of support for children and parents.

column1: • The Bill's implementation will require awareness campaigns and education on positive parenting methods.

column2: • The 'Parenting. Give it time' campaign will be updated to include information on positive discipline methods for children up to 18 years old.

column1: • Support services for families and parents are essential to the Bill's success.

column2: • A mapping exercise will be conducted to identify gaps in support services and opportunities for improvement.

column1: • Early intervention strategies are crucial, and there is a need for a more coordinated approach.

column2: • Investing in support services in the early years is essential to prevent problems later on.

column1: • The 'Incredible Years' program in Gwynedd is a successful example of a positive parenting program.

column2: • Expanding this program across Wales could be a valuable part of an early intervention strategy.

column1: • The Bill's effectiveness will depend on the availability of support services and education for parents.

column2: • Monitoring and evaluation will be necessary to assess the Bill's impact and identify areas for improvement.

column1: • Social services and CAFCASS may need to adapt to an increase in reporting of physical punishment cases.

column2: • However, the evidence suggests that the number of cases will not be overwhelming.

column1: • The Bill is a simple but important step towards promoting positive parenting and protecting children's rights.

column2: • It is part of a broader effort to create a society that values and respects children.",0

column1: 934,"Here is the summary of the meeting in 8 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>
• Meeting Overview

column2: • The meeting discussed the design and features of a new TV remote control.
• The team members present were from marketing, industrial design, and user interface.
• The goal was to decide on the final design and features of the remote control.

column1: • Energy Source

column2: • The team decided on a basic battery as the energy source.
• This decision was based on cost and simplicity.
• The battery will be a standard, non-rechargeable type.

column1: • Case Design

column2: • The team chose a rubber case for the remote control.
• The rubber case will be double curved to fit comfortably in the user's hand.
• The rubber material will also provide a soft, grippy surface.

column1: • Buttons and Interface

column2: • The team decided on a simple button layout with a limited number of buttons.
• The buttons will include power, channel up and down, volume up and down, and a numerical keypad.
• The interface will not include a display or speech recognition.

column1: • Look and Feel

column2: • The team discussed the importance of the remote control's look and feel.
• The rubber case will provide a unique and comfortable feel.
• The team will consider adding some color accents to the design.

column1: • Technological Innovation

column2: • The team discussed the need for technological innovation in the remote control.
• Bluetooth connectivity was considered, but deemed unnecessary for a TV remote control.
• The kinetic provision of energy was suggested as a unique feature.

column1: • Marketing Strategy

column2: • The team discussed the importance of marketing the remote control's unique features.
• The kinetic provision of energy will be a key selling point.
• The team will emphasize the comfort and durability of the rubber case.

column1: • Final Decisions

column2: • The team finalized the design and features of the remote control.
• The remote control will have a rubber case, basic battery, and simple button layout.
• The team is confident in their design and is ready to move forward with production.

column1: 940,"<summary>
• The meeting discusses the reopening of schools in Wales during the COVID-19 pandemic

column2: • The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams, outlines the principles for reopening schools, including the safety and well-being of children and staff, and the need for clear communication with parents and staff
• The principles will apply to both schools and further education colleges, but not to universities, which are independent institutions

column1: • The Minister discusses the current situation in schools, including the number of schools open, the number of children attending, and the number of staff involved

column2: • The majority of children attending schools are children of key workers, with a small number of vulnerable children also attending
• The Minister acknowledges the challenges of supporting vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs during the pandemic

column1: • The Minister discusses the importance of testing and contact tracing in the next phase of the pandemic response

column2: • The Welsh Government is working across departments to support vulnerable children and families, including those with additional learning needs

• The Minister acknowledges the potential for the attainment gap to widen during the pandemic and is considering ways to address this, including the use of digital resources and support for parents and carers",0

column1: 941,"<summary>
• Kirsty Williams AM explains the five principles for reopening schools:

column2: • The safety and well-being of children and staff must be considered.
• Decisions will be made in the context of the wider Welsh Government response to the pandemic.
• Clear communication and evidence-based decision-making are crucial.
• The needs of vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs must be prioritized.
• The operational challenges of reopening schools must be addressed.

column1: • The Minister emphasizes that schools will not reopen until it is safe to do so, and that a phased return is likely.

column2: • The principles will apply to both schools and further education colleges, but not to universities.

column1: • The Minister reports that 518 school hubs are open, with 4,200 children attending, and 5.6% of teaching staff working in these hubs.

column2: • 85% of the children attending are children of key workers, and 600 are vulnerable children.

column1: • The Minister acknowledges the challenge of supporting vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs during the pandemic.

column2: • She emphasizes the importance of testing, tracing, and quarantining in the next phase of the response.

column1: • The Minister announces an additional £1.25 million for school counselling services to support children's mental health.

column2: • The funding will be used to increase and ramp up services to support children and families, including remote counselling and therapy.

column1: • The Minister recognizes the risk of inequality due to varying access to digital resources and is working to ensure equal access to learning.

column2: • Officials are working with local authorities to ensure all children have access to hardware and connectivity for digital learning.",0

column1: 942,"<summary>
• The meeting discussed the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on education in Wales.

column2: • The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams, emphasized the importance of protecting public health and well-being.
• The committee discussed the principles for reopening schools, including safety, communication, and confidence.

column1: • The Minister discussed the current situation in schools, including the number of schools open, children attending, and staff involved.

column2: • She mentioned that 85% of children attending schools are children of key workers, and 15% are vulnerable children.
• The committee expressed concerns about the low number of vulnerable children attending schools.

column1: • The Minister discussed the importance of testing in the next phase of the pandemic response.

column2: • She mentioned that testing, tracing, and quarantining will be critical in relaxing restrictions.
• The committee asked about the impact of testing on vulnerable children and those with special educational needs.

column1: • The Minister discussed the support for children with additional learning needs, including specialist provision and remote support.

column2: • She mentioned that local authorities are working to ensure that children with additional learning needs have access to support.

column1: 946,"<summary>
• The meeting discussed the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on education in Wales.

column2: • The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams, emphasized the importance of protecting public health and well-being.

column1: • The principles for reopening schools were outlined, including the need for a safe environment, communication with parents and staff, and consideration of vulnerable children and key workers.

column2: • The principles apply to both schools and further education colleges, but not to universities, which are independent institutions.

column1: • The current situation in schools was discussed, including the number of schools open, children attending, and staff involved.

column2: • The Minister reported that 85% of children attending schools are children of key workers, and 15% are vulnerable children.

column1: • The importance of testing was emphasized, particularly in relation to the next phase of responding to the pandemic.

column2: • The Minister stated that testing, tracing, and quarantining will be critical to the next phase of the Government's response.

column1: • The impact on particular groups of children was discussed, including vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs.

column2: • The Minister acknowledged the challenges of supporting these children and young people during the pandemic.

column1: 947,"<summary>
* Free School Meals

column2: * The Welsh Government is working to ensure that children who receive free school meals will continue to receive support during the pandemic.
* This includes providing meals for children of key workers and vulnerable children.
* Local authorities and schools are being asked to develop plans to deliver this support.

column1: * School Closures

column2: * Schools in Wales will close for statutory education provision from Monday, but will remain open for children of key workers and vulnerable children.
* Headteachers will be expected to come into school to plan and prepare for the new purpose of schools.
* The Welsh Government is working with local authorities to identify vulnerable children, including those on the at-risk register and young carers.

column1: * Exams

column2: * All exams in Wales have been cancelled due to the pandemic.
* Year 11 and 13 students will be given a grade based on their coursework and teacher evaluation.
* The Welsh Government is working with Qualifications Wales to develop a modulated arrangement for awarding grades.

column1: * Childcare

column2: * Childcare settings will remain open unless public health advice changes.
* The Welsh Government will continue to pay for childcare delivered under the childcare offer, even if children are not attending.
* Settings will be able to apply for support packages from the Welsh Government.

column1: * Communication

column2: * The Welsh Government is working to communicate with parents, schools, and childcare settings about the changes and support available.
* Letters will be sent to schools and settings today to clarify expectations.
* The Welsh Government is using all platforms to communicate with the public and provide updates.",1

column1: 948,"<summary>

964,"<summary>
• Discussion on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill

column2: • The Bill aims to remove the defence of reasonable punishment, making it illegal for parents to physically punish their children
• The witnesses from the Association of Directors of Social Services, the Association of Directors of Education in Wales, and the Welsh Local Government Association support the Bill
• They believe it will bring clarity and consistency to the law, and promote a cultural shift in how children are cared for in Wales

column1: • Implementation of the Bill

column2: • The witnesses emphasized the importance of awareness-raising and education for parents, professionals, and the public
• They suggested that the Bill's implementation should be accompanied by a major awareness-raising campaign and support for parents
• The witnesses also highlighted the need for resources and investment in preventative services and early intervention

column1: • Impact on social services

column2: • The witnesses acknowledged that the Bill may lead to an increase in referrals to social services, but emphasized that this would be a short-term effect
• They stated that social services would not be involved in long-term intervention in families' lives, but would focus on supporting families and providing early intervention
• The witnesses also noted that the Bill would not lead to the criminalization of parents, but rather would promote a culture of positive parenting

column1: • Threshold for social services intervention

column2: • The witnesses stated that the threshold for social services intervention would not change significantly as a result of the Bill
• They emphasized that social services would continue to focus on supporting families and providing early intervention, rather than intervening in families' lives unnecessarily

column1: • Practical response to referrals

column2: • The witnesses stated that each referral would be assessed on a case-by-case basis, and that social services would work with the police and other agencies to respond to referrals
• They emphasized that the response would be proportionate to the level of risk and harm involved

column1: • Assessment processes

column2: • The witnesses acknowledged that assessment processes within social services can be flawed, but emphasized that they are carried out by qualified professionals
• They stated that assessments are often carried out jointly with other agencies, such as the police and health professionals
• The witnesses also emphasized that support services would be offered to families, even if social services do not take action in a particular case",0

column1: 965,"<summary>

* The witnesses from the Association of Directors of Social Services, the Association of Directors of Education in Wales, and the Welsh Local Government Association expressed support for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.

column2: * They believe the Bill will bring clarity and consistency to the law, and will help to shift the cultural norm around physical punishment of children.

column1: * The witnesses acknowledged that the Bill may lead to an increase in referrals to social services, but emphasized that this would be a short-term issue and that the number of referrals would eventually decrease as the cultural norm changes.

column2: * They also emphasized the importance of providing support to parents and families, and ensuring that resources are available to help them manage their children's behavior in a positive way.",1

column1: 966,"<summary>

column2: * The meeting was a discussion about a new remote control design project.

column1: * Prototype Presentation

* The prototypes were well-received by the team.

column1: * Evaluation Criteria

column1: * Finance Discussion

column1: * Project Process Evaluation

column1: * Final Report and Next Steps

column1: 976,"Here is the summary of the text in 7 bullet points with 2 levels of indentation:
<summary>

column2: • The team discussed the design of a remote control, focusing on its shape, functionality, and user experience.

• The project manager emphasized the importance of simplicity and ease of use.

column1: • Market Research

column2: • The marketing team conducted research on user preferences and found that 75% of users dislike the look and feel of their current remote controls.
• Users want a remote control that is modern, cool, and easy to use.
• The research also showed that users are willing to pay more for a remote control with advanced features, such as speech recognition.
• The team discussed the importance of considering the target audience and their needs.

column1: • Technical Design

column2: • The industrial designer discussed the technical aspects of the remote control, including the energy source, user interface, and infrared lamp.
• The team considered the use of rechargeable batteries and a solar-powered option.
• The designer emphasized the importance of simplicity and ease of use in the design.
• The team discussed the possibility of using a scrolling wheel or a touchpad instead of buttons.

column1: • User Interface

column2: • The user interface designer discussed the importance of a user-centered design approach.
• The team considered the use of a rectangular shape with a scrolling wheel or a circular shape with buttons around the thumb.
• The designer emphasized the importance of minimizing the number of buttons and making the remote control easy to use.
• The team discussed the possibility of creating a two-in-one remote control with a smaller device that fits into a larger one.

column1: • Design Options

column2: • The team discussed various design options, including a ball-shaped remote, a rectangular shape with a scrolling wheel, and a circular shape with buttons around the thumb.
• The team considered the pros and cons of each option, including the ease of use, aesthetics, and functionality.
• The team also discussed the importance of considering the target audience and their needs.
• The designer emphasized the importance of simplicity and ease of use in the design.

column1: • Functionality

column1: 993,"<summary>
• The discussion revolves around schools causing concern, with questions from Huw Irranca-Davies.

column2: • The Minister, Kirsty Williams, explains that the school categorisation system is primarily a triage system to identify schools that need support.
• The system has evolved over time, and the Minister expects it to continue to evolve to align with the curriculum reform and self-evaluation.

column1: • The Minister acknowledges that the system is not perfect, and some schools are not identified early enough, which is a concern.

column2: • The Chief Inspector of Estyn has stated that schools are not being identified early enough, and urgent action is needed.

column1: • The Minister explains that the categorisation system is not solely driven by data, but also includes professional judgments from challenge advisers.

column2: • The system is not a fixed point and will continue to evolve to complement the reform journey.

column1: • The Minister highlights that primary schools are improving, but there is a particular challenge with secondary schools.

column2: • A new multi-agency approach is being piloted to support schools that are causing concern, involving local authorities, regional consortia, Estyn, and Welsh Government.

column1: • The approach focuses on identifying the fundamentals that need to be addressed in a school, the school's capacity to address them, and the extra support needed.

column2: • The goal is to achieve sustainable improvement in the long term, rather than just quick fixes.

column1: • The Minister acknowledges that local authorities have been reluctant to step in earlier, and there may be a deficit in their ability to do so.

column2: • The Welsh Government is working with local authorities to share best practice and provide training to address this issue.

column1: • Suzy Davies asks why local authorities have been reluctant to step in earlier, and whether they feel equipped to do so.

column2: • The Minister responds that each local authority will have its own explanation, but the collective effort is needed to address the issue.

column1: • Sian Gwenllian asks if it's time to move away from the categorisation system entirely, given the more sophisticated approach being developed.

column2: • The Minister is open to evolving the system further, but wants to see the OECD's feedback before making any decisions.

column1: • Huw Irranca-Davies expresses concern about the high percentage of secondary schools (11%) judged as unsatisfactory and needing urgent improvement.

column2: • The Minister acknowledges that this is unacceptable and is introducing a new pilot to address these schools, which will involve a more comprehensive approach to support.",0

column1: 994,"<summary>

column1: 995,"<summary>

column1: 996,"<summary>

• The Welsh Government is working to improve school standards through a new approach to school improvement, which includes a national evaluation and improvement resource and a multi-agency approach to supporting schools.

column2: • This approach focuses on self-evaluation and involves working with schools, local authorities, and Estyn to identify areas for improvement and provide targeted support.

column1: • The categorisation system, which identifies schools as green, yellow, amber, or red based on their performance, is evolving and may be replaced by a more sophisticated approach in the future.

column2: • The system has been criticized for not identifying schools that need support early enough, and the Welsh Government is working to address this issue through the new approach.

column1: • The Welsh Government is also working to address the issue of schools that are persistently causing concern, with 11% of secondary schools inspected in the last two academic years judged as unsatisfactory and needing urgent improvement.

column2: • A new pilot program is being introduced to provide targeted support to these schools and help them improve.

column1: • The Welsh Government is committed to continuing to evolve and improve its approach to school improvement, including working with local authorities and Estyn to share best practice and provide support to schools.

column2: • This includes providing training and development opportunities for cabinet members and scrutiny leads to help them hold their education portfolio holders to account.",1

column1: 1009,"<summary>

column2: * The girls engage in various activities, including a trust fall and a Ouija board session, which leads to a series of strange events.
* Meanwhile, at the Omega Chi house, Evan and Calvin are stuck together during the storm, leading to some unexpected bonding moments.
* At the KT house, Cappie meets a mysterious girl named Destiny, who turns out to be Patty, a girl he knew from camp who has been obsessed with him for years.

column3: * Patty has undergone a transformation and is now a beautiful and confident woman.
* Cappie is initially drawn to her, but Rusty tries to warn him about her obsessive behavior.
* Patty's true intentions are revealed, and Cappie is left feeling uneasy.
* The episode ends with Patty leaving, and Cappie reflecting on the encounter.</summary>",0

column1: 1010,"<summary>
* George is searching for Izzie and finally finds her in the cafeteria, where she is waiting for Callie to arrive for their fight.

column2: * However, Callie doesn't want to fight and instead wants to talk to Izzie.

column1: * Izzie and Alex are discussing their plan for the fight, with Alex giving Izzie advice on how to protect herself.

column2: * Meanwhile, Cristina and Meredith are watching from the sidelines, making comments about the situation.

column1: * Callie arrives at the cafeteria, but instead of fighting, she wants to talk to Izzie.

column2: * The scene ends with Callie leaving, and Izzie realizing that the whole situation was unnecessary.

column1: * Derek is planning a weekend getaway with Meredith and is asking Mark for advice on whether to go to Napa or Sonoma.

column2: * Mark is more concerned about Meredith's inexperience as an intern and the problems she may cause.

column1: * Callie is operating on Ruthie, who has a broken ankle and a bleeding duodenal ulcer.

column2: * The surgery is complicated, and George is assisting, but Ruthie's condition is critical.

column1: * Lexie is assisting Derek in Adam's surgery, but she is struggling to find the source of a bleed.

column2: * Cristina steps in to help her, and together they are able to cauterize the vein and stop the bleeding.

column1: </summary>",0
1011,"<summary>
• The episode revolves around Ty's struggles with poachers and his decision to take matters into his own hands.

column2: • Ty finds two dead bears, both killed with crossbows, and discovers that the poachers are targeting bears for their gallbladders.
• He tries to get help from Scott and Fish and Wildlife, but they are slow to act, leading Ty to take matters into his own hands.

column1: • Meanwhile, Jade is forced to work at Heartland Ranch and learns to care for the horses, despite her initial reluctance.

column2: • She makes mistakes, such as leaving a stall door open, but eventually helps to solve the mystery of a missing horse.
• Jade begins to bond with the horses and learns to overcome her fears, with the help of Georgie and Amy.",0

column1: 1012,"<summary>
* The episode starts with Ted telling his children the story of how he met their mother, but this story is about how he didn't end up with their mother.

column2: * The story begins with Ted wearing a yellow shirt that he hadn't worn in years, which sparks a conversation with his friends about second chances.
* Ted decides to call up an old girlfriend, Natalie, who he had dumped on her birthday via answering machine.

column1: * Ted's friends, including Robin, Marshall, Lily, and Barney, discuss their own relationships and dating experiences.

column2: * Robin is offered a promotion at work, but only if she says a certain word on live TV.
* Barney tries to convince Robin to take the offer, but she initially refuses.

column1: * Ted calls Natalie and they agree to meet up, but things don't go well when he reveals that he's not ready for a commitment.

column2: * Natalie reveals that she had a surprise party planned for her birthday when Ted broke up with her, making him feel guilty.
* Ted tries to make it up to her, but ultimately decides to break up with her again.

column1: * Ted's friends try to help him come up with a way to break up with Natalie, but nothing seems to work.

column2: * Lily suggests telling Natalie the truth, but Ted is hesitant.
* Marshall and Barney offer their own breakup lines, but they're not helpful.

column1: * Ted finally breaks up with Natalie on her birthday, and she reacts angrily.

column2: * Natalie reveals that she's been hurt by Ted's actions and feels like she can't trust him.
* Ted tries to explain himself, but it only makes things worse.

column1: * Meanwhile, Robin is forced to do a live news report from a horse stable, where she falls and gets covered in horse manure.

column2: * The incident becomes a laughingstock, and even Ted can't help but laugh.
* Robin is embarrassed, but realizes that her job is important to her.

column1: * The episode ends with Ted reflecting on the experience and realizing that sometimes, no matter how hard you try, things just don't work out.

column2: * He tells his children that the story is a cautionary tale about the dangers of dating.
* The episode ends with Ted's children laughing at their father's misfortune.",0

column1: 1014,"<summary>
• The scene opens in the cafeteria, where Sheldon is drawing a hypothetical containment field for a Frisbee-sized wormhole on a napkin.

column2: • He explains to Raj and Howard that it's a portal to a parallel universe.

column1: • Howard and Raj notice that Sheldon disappears every day at 2:45 PM and decide to investigate.

column2: • They discover that Sheldon's schedule is empty during that time and decide to follow him.

column1: • Meanwhile, Leonard is worried about Penny's new friend from school, Cole, who has an English accent.

column2: • He tries to warn Cole about Penny's ""scary"" boyfriend, but Cole is not intimidated.

column1: • Howard and Raj follow Sheldon to a room in the basement, where they find a mysterious door with a sign that says ""Authorized Personnel Only"".

column2: • They try to pick the lock, but it's booby-trapped.

column1: • Inside the room, Sheldon is seen playing with a beanbag, counting up to 43, and then getting frustrated when he loses count.

column2: • He is revealed to be recharging his energy by doing something he enjoys, away from the others.

column1: • Howard and Raj are caught by Sheldon, who is angry that they followed him and demands to know why they don't trust him.

column2: • He refuses to explain what he's doing in the room, saying they don't deserve to know.

column1: • The episode ends with Sheldon playing keepie-uppie with the beanbag, trying to reach 43 again.

column2: • The significance of the number 43 remains a mystery.",0

column1: 1015,"<summary>
• The episode starts with Sheldon hosting the final episode of ""Fun with Flags"" with Amy.

column2: • He announces that he can no longer balance his career, internet show, and girlfriend.
• He shows a montage of highlights from previous episodes.

column1: • Meanwhile, Leonard, Howard, and Raj are cleaning out a deceased professor's office.

column2: • They find a letter from the professor's mother, to be opened upon his first great discovery.

column1: • Penny is at a conference, where she meets her boss Dan and Bernadette.

column2: • Bernadette is her usual harsh self, but Penny tries to help her see that she comes across as mean.

column1: • Back at the apartment, Sheldon shows more highlights from ""Fun with Flags"".

column2: • He has a special guest, LeVar Burton, who is not thrilled to be there.

column1: • Howard and Raj try to decipher the meaning of the professor's notebooks.

column2: • They eventually discover that it's just a food diary, and the professor was trying to live forever by restricting calories.

column1: • Bernadette tries to make amends with Dan and Penny.

column2: • She learns that everyone is intimidated by her and that she's been taking advantage of the company's coffee and private bathroom.

column1: • Leonard and Howard reflect on the meaning of life and accomplishment.

column2: • They make a pact to celebrate each other's successes and toast Professor Abbott.

column1: • Sheldon decides to revive ""Fun with Flags"" after receiving a comment from a fan.

column2: • He goes to LeVar Burton's house to ask him to be on the next episode, but LeVar is not interested.

column1: </summary>",0

1017,"<summary>
* Veronica Mars investigates the case of a missing monkey, Twenty-Five, from a Hearst College lab.

column2: * The monkey is a genetically altered capuchin monkey used for research on cholesterol breakdown.

column1: * Veronica attends a PHAT (People for Humane Animal Treatment) meeting, where she meets Bronson, the chapter president.

column2: * She pretends to be interested in joining the group to gather information about the missing monkey.

column1: * Veronica's father, Keith, is investigating the death of Dean O'Dell, which is suspected to be a murder.

column2: * He discovers that the dean's suicide note was typed on a computer, which makes him suspicious.

column1: * Veronica talks to Piz, a radio DJ, and asks him to book Ed Argent, a conservative rocker, on his show.

column2: * She wants to use Argent to get close to the PHAT group, who are suspected of stealing the monkey.

column1: * Veronica and her friends, Mac and Parker, pose as sorority girls to get a picture with Ed Argent wearing a ""Meat is Murder"" sweatshirt.

column2: * The picture is published in the Hearst Free Press, and Veronica is contacted by Sam, a PHAT member, who invites her to a meeting.

column1: * Veronica and Mac attend the PHAT meeting, where they are initiated into the group.

column2: * They are now one step closer to finding the missing monkey and uncovering the truth behind the PHAT group's activities.",1
